HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Leading in the Homestretch, Clinton's Campaign Grows More Confident

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROMULUS, Mich., Oct. 17

 BODY:
Late Friday night, Gov. Bill Clinton climbed onto his chartered campaign plane to find his staff and a dozen reporters crowded into an aisle, watching a tape of a mock debate that had been televised on "Saturday Night Live."
Relaxed and energized after a day of campaigning in Virginia and Louisiana, Mr. Clinton laughed along with his traveling entourage as comedians Dana Carvey and Phil Hartman ridiculed the three candidates for President. He laughed especially hard at a sequence that portrayed him as a bead-wearing hippy defending himself against accusations that he evaded the draft. 
 Today, he played the tape again for his daughter, Chelsea, as they traveled to Michigan for debate preparations.
Mr. Clinton has seldom displayed a particularly well-honed sense of humor about himself. But as each day brings new signs that he is pulling away in the stretch leading up to the Nov. 3 general election, the tone of both the campaign and the candidate has changed.
 
Republicans Beset
 Within the last few weeks, the Democrats have watched in near astonishment as the Republicans have stumbled their way through the fall campaign, beset by adverse circumstance and misguided political direction.
And while President Bush was slow to recognize that a Rose Garden strategy would only backfire in a year when voters were unhappy with Washington, the Clinton campaign has tried to exploit -- often inadvertently -- the disadvantages of the President's incumbency.
Some of these disadvantages are cosmetic but telegenically important. When Mr. Bush campaigns, he is curtained off in many ways by the strict security that accompanies every incumbent President. Mr. Clinton -- merely a nominee for security purposes -- has been known to shake hands for an hour after his speeches end, and the result is a stream of attractive photographs and footage of the Governor grasping at outstretched hands and kissing babies.
This was never more clear than on Thursday night during the candidates' second debate. The same question that stumped Mr. Bush so thoroughly provided Mr. Clinton with what turned out to be his best opportunity of the evening.
"I have seen what's happened in this last four years," Mr. Clinton said when he was asked to explain how the economic downturn had affected him personally. "In my state, when people lose their jobs, there's a good chance I'll know them by their names. When a factory closes, I know the people who ran it. When the businesses go bankrupt, I know them."
 
Not Rehearsed, Aides Say
 Mr. Clinton's aides said he did not rehearse this answer but that it provided him the natural opportunity to showcase the personal manner of governing he has learned after 12 years at the helm of a small state. And the format -- which allowed direct contact with questioners in almost a round-table setting -- had been a favorite of Mr. Clinton's since the bleak New Hampshire primary campaign.
But there are signs everywhere of the campaign's new confidence. Its communications director, George Stephanopoulos, and its pollster, Stan Greenberg, were so happy with Mr. Clinton's performance after the first Presidential debate that they gave each other an exuberant high five in the middle of the press center, a bit of visual spin control, perhaps.
On the stump, Hillary Clinton has emerged once again as a spokeswoman for her husband, resuming a role that she had been forced to abandon when she became a target for critics who said the Clintons intended to conduct a co-Presidency.
And everywhere he goes, other Democratic politicians -- including recently critical ones like Rep. Charles E. Rangel of New York -- are climbing on his bandwagon with such alacrity that the whole thing threatens to tip over.
 
Polls Show Lead
 If Mr. Clinton is now sitting on his lead, polls that have been conducted for his campaign and for news organizations give him ample reason to believe that is a safe strategy.
The Democrats have decided that Mr. Clinton would not attack Mr. Bush outright, opting for restraint in an attempt to make Mr. Bush look frantic. After the President fiercely attacked Mr. Clinton in New Jersey on Friday, Mr. Clinton's only response was to call it "sad."
But talk of a landslide victory is "way premature," Mr. Clinton told reporters today. "This election is a long way from over. Seventeen days is a lifetime in public life."
His campaign schedule has begun to resemble an elaborate return on investment for the politicians who helped him out early on.
 
Fulfilling Political Promises
 His trip through southern Louisiana on Friday fulfilled a promise to black Democrats that he would help voter registration efforts and to Representative William Jefferson of Louisiana. Next week, he helps out several Western governors by taking his campaign on a hectic, two-day fly-around.
And occasionally he rubs the point. Today, he received the endorsement of a group of attorneys general and of Sarah Brady, the handgun-control advocate who is married to the former Reagan press secretary James S. Brady, who was wounded during a Presidential assassination attempt in 1981.
Mrs. Brady, who described herself as a "lifelong Republican" today, endorsed Mr. Clinton and described Mr. Bush's decision to object to anti-crime bills that included a waiting period for handgun purchases as "cowardly."
Frequently, the Democrats attempt to suppress their rising glee to remind anyone who asks that the race is not yet over. In conversations with reporters aboard the Governor's campaign plane, James Carville, the leading Clinton strategist, was hard-pressed to explain his reason for saying that he expected the race to tighten in its final weeks. Asked what the President should be doing, he demurred. "I don't see how," he responded, letting his response trail off.

HEADLINE: California City Endures A Series of Misfortunes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LINDSAY, Calif., Oct. 17

 BODY:
It's been a tough decade so far for this Central California farm town: the area's third-largest employer closed in spring, and two years ago half the workers lost their jobs when a freeze wiped out the orange crop.
But now residents in this town of 8,600 residents are facing another economic disaster that could bankrupt the city government. Last month the city's largest employer, Lindsay Olive Growers, closed, taking with it 350 jobs -- a setback that officials said could push the unemployment rate to 35 percent.
As Ron Cain, a car salesman, put it: 
 "It may be as big a disaster as the freeze. It could turn this town into a ghost town."
 
Environmental Woes, Too
 The 311-member cooperative, once the world's largest olive processor, had lost more than $18 million in the past three years. After months of unsuccessful negotiations to sell, it closed its plant Sept. 18. A rival company, Bell-Carter Foods, bought the Lindsay label and its inventory but will process olives at its own plant in another county.
But the job loss is not the only problem legacy of Lindsay Olives. The cooperative, in decades of processing, also left behind 200 acres of sewage treatment ponds tainted by salty discharge.
State water regulators had ordered the city and the cooperative to clean up the ponds, and city officials fear they will be stuck with the bill now that Lindsay Olives has closed. The overall cost could be $30 million for a city with a yearly budget of about $1 million.
The state's water board is scheduled to meet Oct. 23 to discuss the cleanup orders in light of the city's hardship.
"It's sudden and pretty devastating," said Mayor John Maynard. "There's some tough, tough times coming. Those cleanup costs are astronomical, and our candid answer is: We don't have the money. We'd bankrupt ourselves."
In addition, the city lost a $2.6 million lawsuit filed by farmers whose underground irrigation water was tainted by the salty ponds. The city also will need to replace $900,000 that Lindsay Olives paid each year to help maintain the ponds and reduce the smell.
 
Seeking Outside Help
 This farming town, 150 miles north of Los Angeles, has appealed to state and federal agencies for help.
"We've been left holding the bag, and if the state pushes it, we'll go bankrupt," said the assistant city manager, Scot Townsend. "Then all of this would fall on the county and ultimately back on the state."
The fiscal problems arrived just as Lindsay was gearing up for its first lucrative orange harvest since a freeze ruined most of the fruit crop just before Christmas 1990. And the closure of the olive plant came after the loss of 140 jobs when United Cable, a telephone cable manufacturer and the third-largest employer in Lindsay, shut down last spring.
But some residents predict the city will find a way to survive.
"That freeze taught us a couple of things," the Mayor said. "There's a lot of generous people out there, and this community has a lot more vitality than we even suspected."
Jessie Oakley, a flower shop owner and 52-year resident of Lindsay, said: "I do think these people will be O.K. The guys will find jobs. Some of them already have gone to Visalia or found work in the orange groves."
But she added: "I imagine we'll all be affected to a degree. I'm sure people won't be spending as freely."

HEADLINE: Dinkins's Tactic: Start Spreading the News

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's strategy for his re-election campaign next year became clearer last week when he appointed a political consultant to his cabinet and gave him a mandate to improve his public-relations efforts.
At the same time, Mr. Dinkins announced that Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch Jr., the political adviser who masterminded the Mayor's victory in 1989, will go directly to head the Dinkins re-election campaign after he finishes his stint as deputy director of Gov. Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign in New York. Mr. Lynch was on a leave of absence from his city post. 
 On Thursday, Mr. Dinkins created a new post for a Deputy Mayor with a mandate to oversee public relations efforts, and appointed Randy Daniels, a former television reporter, media adviser and press secretary, to fill it.
In announcing the appointment, Mr. Dinkins made an unusually blunt admission that he thinks his administration's most important initiatives get little attention in the press. Although he did not blame reporters and editors, he said he wanted Mr. Daniels to find new ways to promote those programs, which range from new neighborhood health clinics to special schools that function as community centers.
 
Ties to Stein
 "I wonder how many people know some of the things we've done," Mr. Dinkins said.
Besides helping the Mayor publicize little-known programs, mayoral aides say, Mr. Daniels's media savvy can also help him get re-elected.
As a bonus, Mr. Daniels, a Harlem resident, used to work for Mr. Dinkins's main Democratic rival, Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President. He is close to several politically crucial friends of Mr. Stein's in the black community, notably the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, who attended the appointment news conference and praised Mr. Daniels.
Mr. Daniels acknowledged the political nature of much of what he will do. "I consider myself a front-line soldier in the effort to give the Mayor a second term," he said.
 
Cutting Public Appearances
 But the 41-year-old Chicago native maintained he would also help shape the city's policies as a member of the Mayor's cabinet. "I am not known for sitting back looking at difficulty and allowing it to go on without saying something," he said.
Mr. Daniels will take over many of Mr. Lynch's duties, overseeing the community affairs and constituent offices. But he will also coordinate the Mayor's press, speech writing and scheduling staffs.
Mayoral aides said Mr. Dinkins wanted Mr. Daniels to pare the number of public appearances on his schedule and to focus on events that highlight his accomplishments and publicize his programs. He has been vexed by an overloaded schedule with many ceremonial appearances of dubious political worth, they said.
Mr. Dinkins articulated for the first time last week a frustration that he often dances around in his daily sparring matches with the press: the feeling that accomplishments that he thinks are important either do not get covered by news organizations or are covered but quickly forgotten.
"I believe many people are not aware or are not sufficiently aware of what we do," he said.
 
Frustration of Inaccuracies
 On a host of issues, from his relationship with the police to his priorities in cutting the budget, Mr. Dinkins often seems perplexed that the public does not seem to understand the reasonableness of his position. He said few people, for instance, know that his administration has balanced three budgets on time during a recession, or that the city has cut overtime costs by nearly $100 million. He often bristles at the suggestion that he has protected the Police Department from budget cuts at the expense of other agencies like the school system. Without safe streets, he says, children would never make it to school.
"I'm not sure everybody has understood these things as we've hammered away at them again and again and again," Mr. Dinkins said. "If people understand why some things exist, I think they are more inclined to accept it and feel there will be a brighter tomorrow."
Mr. Dinkins also expressed frustration that what he considers inaccurate reports of his actions sometimes take on a life of their own.
"To this very day people accuse me of holding back the police in Crown Heights," he said. "It's just untrue. It didn't happen. So when you ask me do people know, well, if you've got somebody misrepresenting our position sufficiently often a lot of people will believe that is what happened."
 
On Grass-Roots Level
 For his part, Mr. Daniels said his job was not to supplant the Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, who remains a cabinet member and the Mayor's chief liaison with reporters.
Mr. Daniels said his main mission will be to find creative ways to promote Mr. Dinkins's accomplishments on the grass-roots level, at meetings, speeches, and other forums. Part of his job will be educating interest groups and ordinary citizens who are affected by certain mayoral initiatives. But another part will be pure publicity, promoting Mr. Dinkins's good works.
"There are a lot of things that are covered and are even covered favorably but people still don't know about them," Mr. Daniels said.

HEADLINE: Ward H. Dennis, 54, for 15 Years General Studies Dean at Columbia

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Dr. Ward H. Dennis, Columbia University's senior dean and the head of its School of General Studies, died on Friday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 54 years old and lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.
He died of complications from a brain tumor, his family said. 
 Dr. Dennis, who started working at Columbia as a lecturer in 1961, was the general studies dean for the last 15 years. He was the longest serving of the university's current deans. His school has nearly 3,000 students.
Under his administration, the school created programs for premedical students, for economically and educationally disadvantaged students, and for junior faculty development, as well as a program in computer technology for nondegree students and a master's degree in liberal studies.
Dr. Dennis was named associate dean of general studies in 1969, and in 1977 became permanent dean, at the age of 38.
He was a former director of Columbia's Institute for Latin American and Iberian Studies, chairman of its Foreign Languages and Literatures Committee and Committee on University Services, and acting vice president of arts and sciences in 1989.
An expert on Spanish and Portugese literature, Dr. Dennis wrote a book, articles and reviews on the subject and was on the editorial board of Revista Hispanic Moderna, a journal.
Born in Boston, he grew up there and in Newport, R.I., and Madrid. His father was a business executive stationed for a time in Spain.
After graduating from Middlebury College in 1960, Dr. Dennis earned a master's degree in Spanish literature in 1961 and a doctorate in 1965, both at Columbia.
From 1965-67 he served in the Army as a training officer in language. In 1974, under a Fulbright-Hays grant, he was a consultant to the Catholic Universities in Quito and Guayaquil, Ecuador.
Dr. Dennis's first marriage ended in divorce.
He is survived by his wife, the former Sandra Howe; his mother, Amarie Whitters Dennis of White Plains; two sons, Ward of Manhattan and John of Niantic, Conn., and a daughter, Heather Dennis of Madison, N.J.

HEADLINE: Charges of Political Favoritism Mark Charged Battle Over a West Point Hotel

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON with ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y.

 BODY:
For generations, the quaint Thayer Hotel on the grounds of the United States Military Academy here has provided a respite for cadets' families and West Point visitors.
But for the last four years the famous hotel, which remains open although rundown and, some say, dangerous, has been the center of a quiet but furious battle that has sometimes made the Academy's lessons on warfare seem tame. The fight, over which of two competing bidders will win the right to "privatize" the hotel now owned by the Government, has dragged in major Wall Street and construction industry players. And it has brought assertions by one group of contestants that a member of the other group, a top political aide to President Bush, has used his influence and has benefitted from favoritism by military officials. 
 The controversy raises as many questions as it answers about what once seemed the simple idea of turning Government property over to private industry to increase efficency, and about the business activities of Frederic V. Malek, an official in a series of Republican administrations who is currently the general manager of the Bush-Quayle campaign.
 
'Limited Passive Partner'
 Mr. Malek, a West Point graduate, says he is nothing more than a "limited passive partner" in one group of bidders managed by Douglass Bennett, a Washington lawyer and another West Point graduate. "I have never talked to anyone in the Army or in the Government or anyone with influence over the Army and the Government about this project," Mr. Malek said.
But the leader of the other group, John A. Dodson, a Harvard and West Point trained engineer who served in the Army in Vietnam and Iran, says he and his partners have become convinced that Mr. Malek "is using his position of authority to further his own personal interest, which is not right."
Mr. Dodson said he believes Mr. Malek personally intervened to help his group and to hurt Mr. Dodson's group. The winning bidder would take over the hotel, refurbish it, and operate it as a private business. Mr. Dodson said the Army has changed the rules of the contest each time his group appeared to be on the verge of winning. "He was," Mr. Dodson said, "the preselected winner of this contract."
Senior Army officers involved in the project deny there has been any political influence. "I never had any pressure from above to provide favoritism or to look more favorably on one offer than another," said Jack K. Norris, who was the Army colonel in charge of the Thayer contract process until he retired this summer.
But two inquiries, a formal one by an Army Review Board in 1990 and an informal one by a Congressional panel this summer, bolstered to some extent the assertions by the Dodson group. And accounts by people involved in the process support some of Mr. Dodson's assertions.
The controversy had been simmering for two years when it expanded sharply in 1990 after the Army conditionally awarded the contract to start a $50 million renewal of the Thayer to the group that included Mr. Malek. Mr. Dodson's group and a third bidder, Treadway Inns Corporation, were disqualified. Mr. Dodson's group appealed and won a decision from the Army Review Board.
The Army panel concluded that "corrective action is necessary" because the bidders "were not treated equally" in the first bidding process, but it did not find any fault on the part of the group that includes Mr. Malek.
After the Review Board decision, the Army reopened the bidding process. Treadway dropped out.
The reopened procedure, however, has been marked by a series of roadblocks that have frustrated virtually everyone concerned.
 
Inquiry by House Panel
 This summer, after Mr. Dodson complained about what he called continuing unfairness, a panel of the House Armed Services Committee conducted an informal inquiry on his allegations that the unfair treatment is continuing.
The ranking members of the Armed Services Committee's Morale, Welfare & Recreation Panel then wrote to Army Secretary Michael P. W. Stone on Sept. 14. Their letter said they were "concerned" that "commitments have been made" on the Thayer project that could impinge on the panel's ability to monitor military spending.
The letter indicated that the Committee would be watching the actions of the Army, which has yet to decide which of the two competitors it favors.
Mr. Dodson, who has assembled a development team that includes a seasoned hotel operator, a nationally known architecture firm, HOK Architects, and a major contractor, Tishman Construction Corp., said he believes Mr. Malek, whose group is also backed by major construction and hotel companies, has been actively involved in his team's efforts to win the contract.
The Dodson group had obtained a commitment from the First Boston Corp., the New York investment banking house, that it would arrange financing if the Dodson group won the contract. At a key moment in the bidding process this spring, First Boston suddenly resigned and placed the Dodson group in jeopardy of disqualification because it lacked financing.
 
Exploring Investor's Role
 Mr. Dodson and other members of his team said they were told that Mr. Malek telephoned John Hennessy, the president of First Boston and the finance chairman for Bush-Quayle '92 in New York State, to request that First Boston renege on its commitment to the Dodson group.
Through a spokesman, Barry Koling, Mr. Hennessy said Mr. Malek never asked First Boston to withdraw and that Mr. Hennessy did not participate in the decision to withdraw the financing. Mr. Koling said First Boston decided to withdraw for reasons "having to do with the economics of the project." Mr. Malek said he never spoke about the Thayer project with Mr. Hennessy.
But Mr. Dodson and others on his team said that was not what they were told. Owen N. Rabourn, a convention center consultant and a former vice president of the GTE Corp. who is a partner in Mr. Dodson's group, said the timing of First Boston decision's to withdraw appeared suspicious. He said the explanation the Dodson team was given was that Mr. Hennessy was acting at the request of Mr. Malek.
Mr. Rabourn said the news of First Boston's withdrawl was delivered to the Dodson team by Jerome H. Mandel, a Westchester-based construction finance consultant, who had introduced the Dodson group to First Boston. Mr. Rabourn quoted Mr. Mandel as saying that, "a friend of his at First Boston, a vice president, told him Malek called Hennessy and told him not to finance us." Mr. Mandel declined to discuss the incident.
 
Concern Over Malek Role
 Others who were involved in the project also said Mr. Malek, who was at one time president of the hotels division of the Marriott Corporation, appeared to be actively involved in the West Point project.
Michael Crall, a hotel construction consultant who reviewed the bidders for West Point, said that in early 1990 Mr. Malek and Mr. Bennett made a formal proposal before a West Point panel considering bidders.
In the end, Mr. Crall said, he favored the group that included Mr. Malek because of Mr. Malek's experience with Marriott hotels.
Mr. Crall said in an interview that the West Point panel members were concerned that Mr. Malek might have permitted his name to be used by the group only because of his political connections and that they quizzed him about that. "My recollection was, quote, he would be an 'active participant' and he would have a real active role," Mr. Crall said.
 
Political Insider
 Mr. Malek said he recalled addressing a group at West Point about the Thayer project but did not recall what he said.
Mr. Malek has worked in the Nixon, Ford and Bush Administrations and compiled a record as a well-connected political insider who favors Washington-style hardball. He was criticized by the Senate Watergate committee for authoring a "responsiveness" plan to dole out Federal grants in a way that would help Mr. Nixon's re-election in 1972.
President Bush made him deputy chairman of the Republican National Committee in 1988 but he resigned from that post when news accounts showed he had compiled a list of Jews working in the Bureau of Labor Statistics for Mr. Nixon in 1971. Mr. Nixon had suggested to Mr. Malek that Jewish employees in that agency had been trying to embarrass him by reporting negative statistics.
In recent years, before he appeared once again at the helm of Mr. Bush's current campaign committee, Mr. Malek has been working in several major corporate posts and at a Washington, D.C., investment banking firm, Carlyle Group. While there, he persuaded Frank C. Carlucci, the former Secretary of Defense, to join Carlyle.
 
Claims of Unfair Advantage
 Mr. Dodson said the odds against his group remain unfair. He said his group labored through the night, for example, to meet a July 1992 deadline set by the Army for both sides' "best and final offers." Just after he submitted his final proposal, the Army advised him that it had postponed the deadline. Mr. Dodson said the deadline extension gave the other group an unfair advantage.
Colonel Norris, the Army contract officer, said both sides had failed to submit complete new offers.
Mr. Dodson said his bid was complete until the Army changed the rules once again after he submitted it. That change, he said, was a "ruse" to justify the extension.
On another occasion, contract officers said a new analysis of projected revenues showed the Dodson group would lose money in its 10th year operating the hotel. Mr. Dodson said that criticism was based on a faulty mathematical assumption.
 
Increasing Frustration
 Lieut. Col. Marilla Cushman, a spokeswoman for the Army, said that officials are paying special attention to the review because of Mr. Dodson's repeated complaints of unfairness and that a final decision is not expected before March 1993.
Some who have studied the hotel that holds the memories of generations of Army families say the delay will continue a dramatic path toward deterioration at The Thayer.
Mr. Crall, the West Point consultant on the project, said he grew frustrated as he saw the privitization project stretch into years. He has not been involved since the Army decision to reopen the bidding in 1990. But Mr. Crall said he has been in touch with senior Army officials because conditions at the Thayer, which was completed in 1925, are dangerous because of lack of maintenance.
"What is incredible," Mr. Crall said, "is this unconscionable delay by the Army. Nobody back there is willing to make a decision becasue they are afraid of the consequences of the decision they are going to make. So that what is happening is that people are going into that hotel everyday and they are at risk."

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
Bush's Support With Builders Reveals Cracks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: COMMACK, L.I.

 BODY:
It takes all kinds of people to build a house. It takes all kinds to elect a President.
Starting at the foundation is John Sudano, a concrete worker here, who smooths the freshly poured cement for the new Hamlet luxury houses. Mr. Sudano says: "I'm one of the few lucky ones. I'm working." Half the 60,000 unionized construction workers on Long Island are jobless. This is one of a handful of new complexes being built in a suburban region of 3 million people. Mr. Sudano did not vote in 1988, but will this time, he says. Because of the economy, he won't vote for President George Bush. "That's definite. Ross Perot is for me." 
 Russell Andreasi is the foreman who supervises the concrete workers for the new Hamlet luxury houses. Until the late 1980's, his company, Spartan Concrete, kept on 70 men during the summer; last summer they had 15. Mr. Andreasi is a Republican, which is typical here. Registered Republicans outnumber Democrats 3 to 2. He voted for Mr. Bush in '88. "Definitely not this time," he says. He will decide between Mr. Perot and Gov. Bill Clinton.
Ed Esposito drives the truck that mixes the concrete for the new Hamlet luxury houses. He's been driving 24 years. Until last year he worked six days a week; now it's three days. "I voted for Bush in '88. Not this time." He'll pick either "Perot for his business experience or Clinton for his health plan."
Stanley Midura runs the crane that digs the trenches that hold the water pipes for the new Hamlet luxury houses. He's lost three months of work in 1992. This is the first time in a few years he's had a job on a new home site. Mainly he's done road repair. Through the 80's he voted for Presidents Reagan and Bush. "I'm voting for Clinton. Bush is on TV talking about change, but why didn't he do it in office? He probably could have done more."
George Harris drives the coffee truck that feeds the workers breakfast every morning at 8:15 at the new Hamlet luxury houses. He visits several construction sites and industrial parks. His business is down by 30 percent in three years. Mr. Harris voted for President Bush in '88. "This time I don't think so. To tell the truth, I like Perot."
Ron Bloomfield directs the office that makes the sales of the new Hamlet luxury houses. He says he has 38 of 52 houses in contract. The project is selling, he says, because it is aimed at a rare group not hurt by the economy: "people looking for a country club style of living." These are second homes for many. The Hamlet will include an 18-hole golf course and a clubhouse with two restaurants. Houses sell for $369,000 to $445,000. Even so, prices are $100,000 to $200,000 lower than planned because of the economy, he says. This is more good news for the rich who often prosper in bad times -- lots of desperation selling. They can find good deals. Mr. Bloomfield voted for Presidents Reagan and Bush, but says it's time for change. "The main problem is confidence. I'm leaning toward Clinton."
Howard Kane is the publicist who promotes the good life at the new Hamlet luxury houses. "I'm a Republican, but won't vote Republican this time. I'm voting for Clinton because of the economy and abortion."
Elliot Monter is president of the Holiday Organization, which owns the land and does the building and makes the profit from the new Hamlet luxury houses. Since 1950, Holiday has built 6,000 houses on Long Island and 3,000 apartments. It's never been so bad, he says. "We just came off 18 months of not starting anything. That never happened before." He has not built a second phase of $170,000 houses in a Holbrook development because the economy has so hurt the middle class. "I'm a Republican, voted for Reagan and Bush." This year? "Absolutely not. Bush hasn't a clue what's going on." All the President's talk about Mr. Clinton and the draft does not interest him one iota. "A smoke screen. People want their jobs back."
Edwin Schwenk directs the Long Island Builders Institute that represents the developers of projects like the new Hamlet luxury houses. Last year Nassau County had its lowest level of new housing starts since World War II; Suffolk had its worst year in a decade. Mr. Schwenk is a former Republican chairman of Suffolk. "I too voted for Reagan and Bush. This time I'll have an easier time voting for Clinton or Perot."
John M. Kennedy manages the building trades council that represents the unions that provide the workers for the new Hamlet luxury houses. "I started as a union electrician in '52. I've never, never seen it this bad." He's a Democrat. "I never voted for Reagan, never voted for Bush. You can't blame this mess on me!"

HEADLINE: Update;
Congregation in Rockaways To Keep Synagogue Open

 BODY:
For several years now, Derech Emunoh, an 87-year-old synagogue on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, has seemed on the verge of extinction as its congregation has shrunk to about 40 members.
So bleak were the prospects for the seaside synagogue that recently the president, Robert Wein, said the congregation would consider shutting down for good. But last week he reported that after discussing the matter, the congregants had decided to try to continue. 
 The once-elegant but now battered temple stands in virtual isolation on a vast, largely empty urban renewal tract in the Arverne area. Thousands of deteriorated buildings were demolished there in the late 1960's, but little new housing has been built because of economic and other obstacles.
Moreover, while the Arverne area was once predominantly Jewish, most Jews left years ago, succeeded largely by poorer black residents. Of the 40 remaining members of the Orthodox Derech Emunoh congregation, fewer than half attend sabbath services at the 600-seat synagogue, which in recent years has been open from April to October only. One reason is that vandals and thieves have ruined the heating system at Derech Emunoh (pronounced DER-ekh eh-MOON-a), at Rockaway Beach Boulevard and Beach 67th Street.
Nonetheless, Mr. Wein said the congregation would continue to operate from April to October. "Maybe a miracle will occur by the end of the century and the area will be developed," he said, raising the possibility that new housing would finally be built on the Arverne renewal tract and would bring an influx of Orthodox Jews to the area.

HEADLINE: The Real Problem With Women and M.B.A.'s

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding "For Women, Fewer M.B.A.'s" (Sept. 27), I searched in vain for mention and discussion of a main deterrent in a woman's quest for this degree: college counselors. 
 As a single working mother, I advocated that both my daughters earn graduate-level degrees. Getting them through the obstacle course of college preparation and acceptance was formidable enough, but imagine my dismay when the eldest first came home from a state university bearing the imperial advice of her college counselor that she seek her degree in home economics rather than business because "it would be easier." She transferred to another university and earned her B.S. in business, but counselors there told her an M.B.A. would be "irrelevant" in her chosen field -- the hospitality industry. She joined the executive training program of a large hotel chain and we are still arguing the wisdom of an M.B.A.
My other daughter, an engineering student, received cursory attention at best from her upper-division college counselors. She was told she "didn't look like an engineer" and was repeatedly asked if she was "serious." Three weeks ago, beginning her fifth year, she called and said in amazement that "I found a counselor who finally takes me seriously." Then the bomb. She called last week and said her new insightful counselor advised her that she didn't "need a master's. He says because I am a woman, the time would be wasted."
My daughters and I don't need luncheons from graduate schools or brochures with more pictures of women in them to entice them to an M.B.A. My daughters grew up believing they would pursue graduate studies. Until the faculty members training young women shed their outdated opinions or totter into retirement, graduate schools are battling a significant impediment they apparently don't know exists.
 
JUDIE TAGGART
Tampa, Fla., Sept. 27

HEADLINE: Well, About That Energy Prophet . . .

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We in the Tennessee Valley found that S. David Freeman's guessing ("An Energy Prophet Who Guessed Right," Sept. 27) was not as good as ratepayers in the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, for which he now works, might hope. 
 Mr. Freeman was chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority for nearly four years. During that time, our residential electric rates doubled and industrial rates went up by 133 percent. In 1981, President Reagan replaced Mr. Freeman as chairman, although he served on the T.V.A. board until 1984.
In contrast, Marvin Runyon, named T.V.A. chairman in 1988, vowed to put the authority on a businesslike basis. Nonessential programs were terminated and other economies were effected. Electric rates have remained stable for the past six years.
Mr. Freeman's prophecies -- based on the continued availability of cheap natural gas, increased conservation and exploiting renewable energy sources -- should be viewed with skepticism.
 
FRANK R. BRUCE
Oak Ridge, Tenn., Oct. 5
 
Frank R. Bruce is a retired associate director of the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 604 words

HEADLINE: Q: The Economy. A: Incomplete.

 BODY:
The economy in this Presidential campaign is Topic A, B and C. Unemployment, stagnant wages and spiraling health care costs torment voters everywhere. Yet the candidates, in their two debates so far, have responded mainly with snippets.
It's not that they don't have economic plans. Indeed, each has a booklet outlining his answers to economic malaise. But even these documents are complex, incomplete and, in places, internally inconsistent. Tomorrow's third debate gives the candidates a last chance, face to face, to challenge and explain. 
 President Bush responds anemically to unemployment with untargeted cuts in capital gains taxes and small subsidies for first-time home-buyers. His plan to eliminate the deficit isn't much better. And he'd make matters worse by promising an across-the-board tax cut plus hundreds of billions in unspecified spending cuts.
Mr. Bush's long-term strategy is better. He'd spend $2 billion a year training dislocated workers. But his program would leave most employed low-skilled workers to wallow in dead-end jobs. He'd spend more on early-childhood education but not enough to bring every disadvantaged child into the program.
Mr. Bush's health care proposal is typically incomplete. He'd subsidize the purchase of insurance, but not by enough to make it universally affordable. He wisely proposes managed competition -- a system of regulated competition among large insurers -- but shrinks from the tax code changes that would make reform work.
Gov. Bill Clinton hasn't told voters how he'd do what most needs to be done right now -- re-start the economy. But his program for long-term growth is sound, even exciting.
He starts with two shrewd decisions. He aims to cut the deficit, but only in half during four years. That would give him the leeway to raise public investment for infrastructure, education, research and training by $50 billion a year. He would require large companies to upgrade the skills of workers. And he would provide loans to college-bound students, to be repaid from future earnings, while providing apprenticeship programs for those who don't go to college.
However constructive that would be, Mr. Clinton's program contains gaping inconsistencies. His revenue estimates are exaggerated. He doesn't take on runaway entitlement spending and would take only a nick out of defense. He, too, proposes managed competition for health care, but in the next breath calls for price controls. He accepts the free-trade treaty Mr. Bush negotiated with Mexico but then adds conditions that threaten the deal.
Finally, the biggest doubt is whether Mr. Clinton is prepared to take on Democratic leaders beholden to the politics of old. Public investment targeted on worthwhile projects could invigorate the economy -- or turn into traditional pork-barrel waste.
Ross Perot's plan for eliminating the deficit is bold and honest. But eliminating the deficit is not the right place to start. In fact, if deficits were cut at the expense of productive investment, the plan would do more harm than good.
The candidates offer voters starkly different economic prescriptions. Mr. Bush says cut taxes, spending and regulations. Then sit back and watch the private sector cure all ills. Mr. Clinton agrees that the private sector bears major responsibility for training workers and investing in equipment. But he identifies a decisive role for Government investment. And Mr. Perot levels with voters about the sacrifice needed to get the deficit under control.
These are differences worth exploring; tomorrow night's debate may well be the last chance.

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: How to Understand Bush's Attacks on Clinton;
Race and the Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In last Sunday's debate, the candidates addressed the "racial division which continues to tear apart our great cities." None of the candidates made the necessary linkages between our deindustrializing economy and massive unemployment, homelessness, unfair housing, high school dropouts, high infant mortality and the nexus between race and class. 
 Ross Perot commented, in his folksy style, "we ought to love one another because united teams win and divided teams lose." He fails to recognize love can't rectify the institutionalized racism plaguing African-Americans and other minorities.
Gov. Bill Clinton responded by stating, "If the American people cannot be brought together, we can't turn this country around." What does Mr. Clinton mean by brought together: wage gaps, educational resources, homicide rates? Or brought together on Nov. 3 to elect him as President?
President Bush addressed this issue in comments on family values. He insisted "the decline in urban America stems from the decline in the American family . . . I believe that discipline and respect for the law -- all of these things should be taught to children." According to President Bush, the urban unrest and racial disparities are the result of poor family values.
 
LEE D. BAKER
Cambridge, Mass., Oct. 12, 1992
 
The writer is a fellow at the W.E.B. Du Bois Institute for Afro-American Research, Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Bush's Gamble

BYLINE: By William Safire; William Safire is a columnist for The New York Times and author of "The First Dissident: The Book of Job in Today's Politics," published by Random House.

 BODY:
I was a Bush-watcher long before I thought it would ever be useful and may be able to pinpoint the time he was seized by his inordinate fear of running without solid support from the far right.
In the 1970 midterm elections, President Nixon sent his most sagacious political aide, Bryce N. Harlow, and two of his speech writers, Pat Buchanan and me, to help Vice President Spiro Agnew barnstorm the country to help Republican candidates defeat liberal Democrats. 
 We smote them hip and thigh with social themes, and awesome alliteration had its day in the oratorical arena. (Pat came up with "pusillanimous pussyfooters"; mine was "nattering nabobs of negativism.") On the campaign plane one day, Bryce came back to the writing section to say: "Scrub Texas from the schedule. Our senatorial candidate, George Bush, thinks he can do better without the red meat you fellows have been throwing in the cage."
That did not trouble Agnew or us; the Texas Democrat, Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr., was not the sort of flaming liberal we had been dispatched to dispatch. "On to Tennessee," said Harlow, the last courtly White House courtier. In that border state, Agnew's ability to rally the far right helped a moderate Republican upset the longtime liberal Senator from that state -- Albert Gore Sr., father of the present candidate for Vice President. Small world: George Bush, who scorned the Agnew red meat, went on to lose the Senate race to Bentsen and never again forgot his need to lock up the culturally resentful right.
The Bush persona has undergone four major shifts in the time I've known him. In the 1970's, after Nixon found a couple of assignments for the defeated Bush, we would take our families to the home of Charles Bartlett, the columnist, and his wife, Martha, an antiques dealer. We sat in the basement, the kids on floor mats, watching the reels of new movies projected on the wall. Five or six couples were regulars, including the Henry Cattos (he's now director of the United States Information Agency) and the John Robsons (he's Deputy Treasury Secretary), some socialites, a former C.I.A. station chief. In conversations over Saratoga water between reels, Barbara Bush was the savviest pol; George was easygoing, wryly funny and open.
Then, in the years as Ronald Reagan's vice president, Bush tightened up perceptibly. "He became guarded," said a member of that set toward the end of that stage. "You notice that defensive look in his eyes? He doesn't want to reveal anything that could be taken as disloyal to Reagan, not to his closest friends. George is keeping his eye on one ball -- inheriting that mantle."
He hardened in other ways; Bill Casey, the C.I.A. chief, a hawk who found a policy ally in Cap Weinberger and an adversary in George Shultz, confided in 1983: "George is with us more often than you think. He plays his cards close to the vest, but he's not the wimp we thought he was."
He shed that guarded persona and the last vestiges of wimpishness at the 1988 convention, asserting his individuality in Peggy Noonan's repeated phrase, "I am that man." (After Bush's "kinder, gentler" promise in 1988, Nancy Reagan is said to have turned to a convention boxmate and tartly asked "kinder than who?" She knew when the cord was being cut, despite her grammatical lapse.) The self-assured Bush served the nation well through the Persian Gulf crisis; nobody can ever take his hundred hours of greatness away from him, nor should conservative waverers forget the historic heights to which he can rise in times of international crisis.
Then Bush the winner was replaced by Bush the loser. For the first half of 1992, he seemed dispirited; many thought he was ill. As his approval rating eroded and the economy failed to respond to the Federal Reserve's dramatic rate cut of December, the President seemed to slide into melancholia. Although, in his State of the Union address, he challenged Congress to meet a spring deadline for action on his proposals, his domestic "line in the sand" disappeared into the sand; the President seemed to lose interest.
"I think I will be re-elected," he said with confidence at the end of last year. "I predicate that, of course, on that I think the economy is going to be doing much better." Well, it hasn't -- not even a little better -- surprising him, befuddling his economists and making pundits like me look less than prescient. As the economy remained dippy into the summer, failing to respond to the stimulus of a huge deficit and the lowest interest rates in a generation, Presidential spirits drooped further. He became listless, almost morose, and it did not help that Sam Skinner, his choice to replace the embarrassing martinet, John Sununu, as chief of staff, found it impossible to get a handle on the job.
At a reception in the Canadian Embassy, Bush struck me as a man unhappy in his work. I tried to cheer him up with a prediction that he would take Texas, then in jeopardy because of the first Perot diversion. "Do you mean that, or are you just saying it?" the President responded. His need for reassurance was uncharacteristic; when I replied that a three-way race would enliven life because, after all, punditry is my job, he shook his head sadly and muttered, "We're talking about my job."
An administration's energy flows from the top; as the Bush spirits sank, a sense of doom permeated the White House. A midlevel aide stopped me on the street outside the Executive Office Building to ask: "You got any software for resumes? Make a fortune with it around here."
July was the low point. The personal turnaround leading to Bush's fourth stage came around the time of the Democratic convention, as Governor Clinton "redefined himself" and surged in the polls. Psychohistorians will focus on Bush's visit to James Baker's ranch in Wyoming, when the two old friends and two of their sons took a deep breath of the wholesome air and together pulled up the Presidential socks. The quartet flew into Jackson and had a long corn-on-the-cob lunch with Senator Alan Simpson, the Republican whip, who at Baker's behest had written down a presentation to make to the President -- not merely a compilation of complaints from frightened Republican officeholders but a sympathetic personal exhortation to get his head centered again.
One aide pinpoints the first week of July as the period of self-rejuvenation. "The June unemployment figures came in, a dismaying jump from 7.5 to 7.8. The President was in the car, on the way to a caucus of House Republicans, and he had a few angry things to say about his economic advisers: 'They briefed me for an hour last week -- and nobody told me it would be this bad.' That was when he realized that Barbara Bush had been right, he really was in trouble, and the economy wasn't going to turn around in time."
Bush looked "one-term Presidency" in the face and snapped out of his lethargy. Concurrent with the Democratic post-convention poll bounce came George Bush's personal bounce back: within two weeks, he was impressing his fretful managers in meetings with what Fred Malek, one of the managers layered over by the Baker movable feast, likes to call "his steely resolve." That's the President in his current stage -- showing more of a desperate than a steely resolve.
The truism about this year's run-up to election is "the electorate is exceptionally volatile." Poll numbers swing wildly; approvals soar and sink. But it is small wonder that the voters are volatile: the campaigners, especially the President, have been destabilizing, and Ross Perot's second squeezing of protest further jerked some of the electorate around. Contributing to the public's uncertainty have been George Bush's personal ups and downs, complicated by his peculiar gamble of shifting radically into a "campaign mode"; his quadrennial metamorphosis from compromising Jekyll to partisan Hyde. He is not the candidate of change; he is the candidate who changes.
AMBIGUITY IS NOT MY THING; I am of two minds about even using the word "ambivalent." Yet here am I, a lifelong Republican, a card-carrying conservative, a right-wing pundit with foursquare opinions on anything you can name -- with two weeks and two days to go before a national election -- and not yet sure about which hole in the card to punch for President.
Other libertarian Republicans are in the same boat. Should we do the unthinkable -- "turn tail and run with the antelopes," as loyalty-first Richard Nixon used to say? Or should we cast "a clothespin vote," so named for those who must put a wooden clothespin on their noses before grimly voting for the party, not the candidate?
As I interpret the polls, one Republican in five -- about 8 percent of the total vote -- is thinking seriously of voting for Clinton. He is not pulling us over the way Reagan attracted Democrats: A "Reagan Democrat" was a voter who identified with most Democratic candidates, saw Republicans as big-shot richies, but was pulled away from voting habits and instincts by the personal and cultural appeal of Ronald Reagan. There are few "Clinton Republicans," attracted by the hyperarticulate pitch or umpteen-point program of the winking, wonking Bill Clinton and his masked army of Little Rock liberals. On the contrary, conservatives who cast a grudging vote for Clinton will be "Bushed Republicans": conservative women turned off in droves by the party platform's unequivocal anti-abortion stand; hawkish males tired of a spent Administration; hard hats with hard feelings about comparatively hard times; young suburbanites put off by the tooting of an uncertain domestic trumpet, and right-wingers of all feathers troubled by a candidate who presents himself as Mr. Nice Guy clanking about in far-right armor.
But polls, while fairly good at detecting the wide pendulum swings of public opinion (Bush way ahead in January, Clinton way ahead in July and the gap narrowing as we approach November), are less able to measure "cognitive dissonance" -- the sort of jangling that goes on in the minds of people in my present pickle who are forced to hold contradictory thoughts. Hence this frankly subjective essay; if I can figure out what's bothering me about the Bush Presidency, perhaps I can show what might motivate large numbers of uncomfortable righties to stick or to switch.
George Bush's central problem on the right is this: Republicans assume that in his heart Bush is a moderate, a centrist -- words that fall gently on the ears of independent voters, but which to even the reasonable right mean "weaseling pragmatist devoid of principle." At the same time, in his efforts to win over a far-right base that has never been his own, George Bush drops his g's, approves (but claims not to have read) the uncompromising platform demanded by evangelical activists, and -- at the crucial kickoff of the campaign -- sent out exclusionary signals under the rubric of "family values" that infuriated the main body of the party.
Result: the righteous right thinks of him as a vehicle to be used while the reasonable right thinks of him as a traitor to his kind. That accounts for the crack, "His support may be narrow, but it runs shallow"; it explains the lack of a hardy band of "Bush people" to energize local campaigns even during hard times, and for the paucity of right-wing punditry to defend him in his hour of underdoggery. Nobody ever says, "Let Bush be Bush," because nobody can be sure what that would be.
Who are the near-right conservatives considering defection? These are Republicans who shy away from what is left of the Rockefeller wing, but cannot identify with the delegates who dominated the Houston convention. We keep muttering that with the glue of anti-Communism dissolved, the party is groping for new cohesion. Less often observed is the likelihood that its core is afflicted with "pluralistic ignorance": because the far right makes the noise and the moderate fringe gets the adulation in the news media, Republicans in the rightist middle do not realize they outnumber those to their left or right.
A segment of that majority is what I'm in -- libertarian (hands off at home) and interventionist (hands on abroad). We're having a hard time this fall because this campaign centers on a decision about George Bush. Not about Dan Quayle, who many of us think is getting a derisive rap from a horde of wise guys who replace argument with ridicule. Nor is our voting decision primarily about Bill Clinton, who talks too fast and fuzzes his positions but is shrewd and gritty enough to present himself as wholly unlike past Democratic losers.
George Bush -- a man with wide mood swings and an inclination to gamble on assuming a dual political personality -- is the underlying issue for my lonely crowd. We know that the Bush who campaigns is not the Bush who governs.
His economic mind-set -- not unduly to interfere with the free-market system -- is our own, even in a dreary period of breath-catching after the long 80's surge. But his campaign theme is Henny Youngman's: "How's your wife? Compared to what?" Central to the White House strategy is to contrast the Bush ship of state, even with all its slow-growth barnacles and prewar Persian Gulf albatrosses, to the untested Clinton-Gore ferry, which would enter the Federal ferry-slip dragging behind it all the philosophical garbage from the liberal harbor.
That is the way the Bush candidacy is being flogged as the campaign enters the home stretch: not so much for what the President has done, but for all the terrible things he is not. Mainstream righties cannot deny that such negativism stirs our viscera: the specter of Ricki Seidman, the Clinton aide who was the character assassin of Judges Bork and Thomas, possibly gaining the power to besmear from a White House office reminds us of the dangers that lurk. We thrill to the fear that Hillary Clinton, now softly coiffed and sweetly embracing the Cookie Monster, once in the White House might impose Federal standards in local day-care centers and otherwise turn the East Wing into the Left Wing.
But we cannot let that rising of our gorge distract us from the essential comparison of George Bush's term to what we had a right to expect. If we are convinced that the first Bush term was largely a flop, and that the next four years would be riddled with that same lack of domestic discipline -- then even loyal Republicans will bail out, on the theory that a failed second term might cripple the party's prospects for a generation. If we are to sink with centrism, goes that line of reasoning, better let the Democrats bear responsibility.
I'm prepared to stipulate that the last four years were -- in the word that Bush's own pollsters find that their sample keeps using most -- "disappointing." A contrarian few of us think that in his foreign policy -- from the Baltics to China to the Persian Gulf -- Bush was woefully behind history's power curve. Many more of us think that here at home the President was inattentive, causing the deficit to swell despite the tax increase. But if Scarlett O'Hara had it right -- if "tomorrow is another day" -- then can we expect a better four years ahead if Bush is returned to office?
The first answer, drilled into living rooms from our worst convention since the short-lived triumph of Barry Goldwater in 1964, was no. For us, the Houston Republican convention of 1992 was even more off-putting than the San Francisco Democratic convention of 1984 -- the one that celebrated liberal pressure groups and led to the Reagan landslide. Pat Buchanan, the protest candidate resoundingly defeated by Bush in all the primaries, declared "religious war" and seemed to deliver our party's message: no untrue believers need apply. Instead of asserting a congenial diversity, we touted a lockstep unity, during which the party displayed the basest of its base.
James Baker cannot pretend all that took place before he rode to the rescue. He knew that a convention was in the works that could make or break the campaign. After a month of destructive delay -- including a lazy vacation taken well after the reconstructive surgery on his friend George's sagging spirit -- he and his team of aides quietly assumed de facto command in the week before the convention. He had time on the bridge to steer away from the iceberg. But Baker signed on to the ill-considered plan to overcome the unpopularity of the President in a slow-growth economy by turning away from the usual Republican "national" campaign. Instead, he went along with George Bush's tendency, derived from his 1970 defeat, to gamble all on locking up a far-right "base" before assembling a coalition of other interests.
That's why "family values," a phrase that raised no hackles in the 1976 platform, dominated the convention. Every speaker was constrained to sign off with "God bless you," as if to respond to a weeklong fit of national sneezing. When Minnie Minoso of the Chicago White Sox began a time at bat by drawing a cross on home plate, catcher Yogi Berra is said to have observed: "God should be allowed to just watch the game." (I just checked that legend with Yogi; pity he never said it.) Bush made his first major postconvention speech to evangelicals in Dallas, pointing out that Democrats had left "G-O-D" out of their platform. That sanctimony went down badly across the country, surprising Bush and Baker.
How did the disaster of Houston happen? "The convention got out of hand," one of its many anguished planners tells me. "We had in mind stressing the good family values, positive stuff that nobody can complain about. But we gave Buchanan prime time at the start -- what a mistake -- and he let loose with all the vicious stuff. Then, when our innocuous family values came on, it was tainted -- we seemed to be endorsing Pat's gay-bashing and the platform's 100 percent anti-abortion plank. Then on ladies' night, Marilyn Quayle, without meaning to, only reinforced the mean-spirited Buchanan message."
Another planner agrees: "We got the blame for being in control, but that's all wrong -- we should get the blame for letting it get out of control."
Thus, at the closely watched start of this campaign, any Republican hoping, in Bill Bennett's apt phrase, "not for four more years but for four different years," was quickly let down. James Baker, Richard Darman and Robert Zoellick, who drafted the President's nearly hourlong acceptance harangue, rejected Bush's original notion of a visionary speech keyed to future plans, drafted by Ray Price, master of rhetorical uplift. They produced instead a shapeless, "fighting" partisan speech, assuming that the first priority was to give the troops a Trumanesque pep talk, and festooned it with a tax-checkoff gimmick that drew deserved derision. Although it had been oversold beforehand as "the speech of his life," the stem-winder wound only the stems in the hall.
Former speech writers may pay too much attention to rhetoric, but oratory can draw responses that illuminate the character of candidates and parties. To me, the most indelible moment of the 1992 Republican convention was when George Bush felt it necessary to admit "it was a mistake" to break his read-my-lips, no-new-tax pledge. The delegate audience reacted with a roar, as if this apology were the latest form of red meat; for a long moment, it seized control from the speaker, its fierce applause at once a chastisement, a warning and an expression of satisfaction that the convention had forced the nominee to submit to its will. Not since Goldwaterites reviled the elitist Nelson Rockefeller, daring to speak for "the mainstream" in 1964, had such a tidal wave of delegate triumph washed up over the speaker's stand.
The President of the United States stood there and dutifully took the abusive applause from delegates not representative of the party's majority of voters. He then promised tax reductions, which seemed to abandon the hope of ever reducing the debilitating deficit. The undertone: No change. "Four more years" meant only that: four more years.
Longtime Republican stalwarts were afflicted with the double-vision thing: two George Bushes were in conflict. We could detect that problem in a second revelatory moment in his acceptance address. Here was a man brought up to be a gentleman, never to stoop to boasting of personal courage, especially at the expense of another. True to that breeding, when he came to a slashing line that was uncomfortable for him -- "I bit the bullet, he bit his nails" -- Bush fluffed it, stumbling over the line and throwing it away. His coach, Roger Ailes, tore what is left of his hair.
By choosing scrappiness over vision, the campaign overseer Baker transmitted an unneeded exclamation point to the harsh message that had overtaken and ruined the convention. Many Republicans watching at home, and the G.O.P. leader I stood next to for a while on the convention floor, were troubled by the way our party's candidate was right-winging it. Uneasiness shifted over to undecidedness. The central Bush problem became stark: the near-right resented his phony pitch to the far-right, and the far-right, despite their stroking by the convention management, felt a kind of bemused contempt for their temporary captive.
Moreover, the political plan called for the redefinition of George Bush as the Democrat Harry Truman. Today's Truman image is that of a peppery underdog, a plain, unvarnished man of the people against the "special interests" and the "do-nothing Congress"; that image (not the "mess in Washington" Truman) was what Bush tried to emulate.
The opposition to Congress fits; the underdog in the polls fits; but nothing else fits. George Bush is patrician, not folksy, and he clanks falsely when he puts on Joe Sixpack nonairs. The "kinder, gentler" rhetoric of his first acceptance, especially in its contrast to the ideological confrontation of the Reagan years, is the man I think he thinks himself to be, most of the time. The Truman identification was ludicrous; not until recently, as Bill Clinton began acting like Tom Dewey, trying to run out the clock, did it gain any validity.
Give Baker credit for cutting losses: recognition of that bad reaction led to a fast change in the Bush strategy. The word "family" was replaced by "traditional," and the central theme switched to "trust," in the hope that personal character and not the economy or abortion could be made the issue. The word went out to Vice President Quayle and the campaign surrogates: dissociate yourself from gay-bashing, Hillary-zapping and from the abortion plank of the platform -- all of which was bothering the near-right Republicans who have someplace else to go. (Socking the trial lawyers was still O.K., because that group is almost as widely despised as the news media.)
But even as "trust" became central, the theme of "change" could not be abandoned to Bill Clinton: the Baker team, better able than Bush to conceptualize and integrate a mind-set into a program, hurriedly put together "An Agenda for American Renewal" to suggest that profound economic change could come without a change of administrations. The anti-tax theme was dressed up in an integrated economic proposal, into which a respectable free-market philosophy was larded, enabling Bush to appear to be, like Paul Tsongas, "a man with a plan."
The message was reduced to this: The Democrat will raise your taxes (true enough), and I'll lower them (patently false). Thematic simplicity is a blessed thing to the writers of television spots, but a slice of the traditional Republican vote thinks it is plain silly to predicate the campaign on tax relief. We think the President is overcompensating for his guilt in breaking his read-my-lips pledge; he seems to be trying to expiate last term's sin by promising to give back the money in the next term.
"He's said he'll do anything to get elected," Clinton has charged repeatedly, which is not quite accurate. The Bush statement that has caused him the most trouble in this campaign, allowing Democrats to exploit the Jekyll-Hyde divide, was made to David Frost late last December: "I'm certainly going into this as a dog-eat-dog fight, and I will do what I have to do to be re-elected."
A Bush family friend I trust insists there was nothing sinister about that; the context was he would determinedly hit the campaign trail and would give as good as he got, not that he would become a political Jack the Ripper. But his assertion is easy for Democrats to exploit now because the charge -- "He said he'll do anything to get elected" -- fits the mode-changing, Jekyll-Hyde Bush.
At heart, and in governing, he's Jekyll: honorable, decent, noblesse oblige, kinder-gentler, offering a hand out to Congress. Come campaign time, however, George Bush turns into Hyde: after the 1984 Ferraro debate, reveling in the kicking of a small donkey (or however he put it); in 1988, Willie Horton, the A.C.L.U., the exploitation of the Pledge of Allegiance. In 1992, the Hyde turned out to be "family values" -- which he knew would be taken as a not-so-subtle dig at philandering, draft-dodging, homosexual moral equivalence, "Willary Horton" and abortion on demand. His governance is too soft and his campaigning too hard.
HIS POLITICAL wilding causes Republicans to ask: What is the campaign about? To achieve a plurality, it has to be about more than staying In, or about keeping the liberals Out.
The 1992 campaign is about George Bush, both of him, in all four stages. It's about his gamble with the support of the near-right detachables by his embrace of the hard-right irreconcilables. It's about Bush's own record and its consequences; only that can determine our judgment about whether he will stick to new promises.
For many conservatives, spending, not taxing, is his Achilles' heel. The far right professes to be upset at the breaking of his old tax pledge -- witness the roar at the convention when he confessed his error -- but economic policy is not their hottest button. Yes, supply-side intellectuals are sore at him for getting ambushed at Budget Gulch; having been let down before, these Kempians suspect that Bush's belated embrace of their policy will be abandoned again by the Baker-Brady-Darman trio at the next budget negotiation. But most conservatives are more concerned with reducing the rate of spending substantially than in reducing income taxes by 1 percent.
"I will fight to reduce spending," insists candidate Bush, but not since the Kennedy years has domestic spending risen so fast. He can accurately argue that Federal spending, as a percentage of the rising domestic product, has held steady, but there stands the deficit's growth from $153 billion to $365 billion on his watch. Bush blames Congress; but as the Republican Governor of California, Pete Wilson, showed recently, a runaway opposition legislature can be stopped.
The most local-smart, national-dumb part of Bush's "fight to reduce spending" was the way he dispensed Federal largesse to swing states. Nine billion dollars in pork went out the window in one campaign week. Michigan is vital for electoral victory; they make M-1 tanks in Michigan. "We already have more of those tanks than we'll ever need," a senior Republican member of the Senate Armed Services Committee told me. "That's pork-barrel politics at its worst." But what you gain on the local swings you lose on the national roundabouts. Because the national news media focus on local pork, no Presidential candidate can credibly denounce Big Spenders while merrily buying local votes with the taxpayers' money. In his budget, issued early this summer, Jekyll-Bush thriftily proposed to eliminate the "export enhancement" subsidy, saving $3 billion over five years; that sensible austerity move cut out the grain boondoggle that had been used in 1989 to finance Saddam Hussein's war machine. But in the fall, Farm Belt votes came before spending cuts, and Hyde-Bush announced "a broadside of Export Enhancement Program initiatives" because he again found the subsidy "vital."
Right-wingers who remember the ravages of 70's inflation have not been driven to "undecided" by the slow growth of the economy. Few are drawn into last year's issue, Iran-contra, though most of us assume Reagan's Vice President was "in the loop," and fewer still are moved to the switching point by next year's scandal, the obstruction of justice in the investigation into Bush's 1989 buildup of Saddam Hussein that we call "Iraqgate." What alienates Republican mainstreamers in 1992 is George Bush's too-occasional sense of purpose at home and abroad, which is giving conservatism a bad record, and his gamble that we will put habit before conscience as he surrenders to the antilibertarian beliefs of what he mistakenly considers our party's core, which is giving Republicanism a bad name.
What would bring us home in November? As this article appears, voters will be sifting through the gaffes and gambits, the planned thrusts and canned ripostes -- as well as character traits revealed in the crucible of the great Debatathon. Republicans like me, with one foot off the reservation, will be ruminating about these questions:
 Would continued divided government -- a Republican President, a Democratic Congress -- be better than an all-Democratic juggernaut in stopping the centralization of power in Washington? It probably would; Bush's finest domestic hours have been his vetoes. No high drama ahead; no "hundred days"; but better a future gridlock than a speed-up of tax-and-spend. Against the spending that Democrats now like to euphemize as "investment," Bush -- for all his compromises -- could at least be expected to drag a foot.$
