HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES;
For Baseball, the Worst of Times May Come After the Best of Seven

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
October heroics have a way of wiping from memory even the most rancorous disputes that can tarnish a baseball season. But this year more than most, public and private battles over such issues as Japanese ownership, the powers of the commissioner, National League realignment and escalating economic problems have detracted from developments on the field.
Baseball reached the showcase part of its calendar with the start of the World Series on Saturday night in Atlanta. But once the Braves and the Toronto Blue Jays conclude the Series in the next week, the business side of baseball's dual personality will again take the forefront, coloring the public image of the game and perhaps altering significantly the way it is administered. 
 Among the major issues baseball officials will confront are these:
*Economic problems: According to the club owners, this is the No. 1 concern. The escalation of payrolls has produced a $1 million average player salary that owners say has contributed heavily to financial distress. Television revenue under the current hefty contract -- $401 million will be paid in 1993 -- is expected to decline precipitously when that pact expires after next season. Attendance was down 1.6 percent over all in 1992, and 18 of the 28 teams suffered attendance losses. And a recent Gallup Poll showed baseball continues to lag behind football -- by almost two to one -- as America's favorite sport to watch.
*Labor problems: The potential volatility of the labor situation could lead to a lockout by the owners next spring, and possibly the cancellation of some, or all, of the 1993 season.
*Organizational and image problems: In the wake of the forced, and messy, resignation of Commissioner Fay Vincent last month, baseball is expected to restructure its central office; a commissionership with reduced powers is likely. Squabbling and lawsuits have become almost routine and have tarnished the sport's reputation.
For the immediate future, the baseball fan can wonder whether next season will start on time, or at all. Fans may also see a change in how, and how often, baseball is presented on television. And changing economics are likely to affect the makeup of their favorite teams. For example, the Oakland A's post-season roster included 13 free agents, some of whom will not be re-signed, and some of whom will depart. So the core of the team that won the American League West title four of the last five years is likely to splinter and relocate elsewhere.
 
A Bottom Line In Middle of Field
 According to almost every owner or other management official, finances head the list of problems.
"Clearly, the economic problems are the major problems facing this industry," said Bud Selig, owner of the Milwaukee Brewers and the man in charge of the major leagues since Vincent's resignation. "We've come to a moment where, I believe, there's a significant problem on the expense side. I think in the past we've all taken for granted that revenues would just keep on increasing. I don't know that any reasonable person can say that anymore."
A recently completed accounting report based on information provided by the clubs showed operating revenues rose from $1.33 billion in 1990 to $1.54 billion in 1991. Industrywide operating profits, however, dropped from $143 million to $87 million.
This year, major league officials said, citing information gathered from all of the clubs, the industry essentially will break even, even though revenues again increased, perhaps to $1.64 billion. Officials project a loss for 1993 and, one said, "a disaster" for 1994, the first year of a national television package yet to be negotiated.
The culprit for the deteriorating economy, owners cry in unison, is player salaries.
"We need a new player-compensation system that reflects the economy we live in," Selig said in a telephone interview. "That's where all our energies have to be directed, how we can get a new player-compensation system."
Donald Fehr, head of the Major League Baseball Players Association, has always been skeptical of the owners' financial reports. Not only did he reject the latest dire predictions, which he said he has heard before, but he also questioned the singling out of player salaries.
"When people cry doom and gloom," Fehr said, "it suggests to me their motives aren't to talk about the state of baseball but to set the stage for some new bargaining venture, with the networks or the players or whomever.
"I have been here for 15 years. I have never heard anybody with the sole exception of Peter Ueberroth, when he wanted to look good, say that things were good. What astonishes me is the pervasive notion that the natural and only recourse to solve the problem is to ask for subsidies from the employees. They have to get past that."
Based on the owners' own figures, major league player costs in 1991 amounted to $730 million, or 47 percent of the owners' revenue.
Player salaries, however they are approached, will be the key element in the next round of negotiations between the union and the clubs. The existing labor contract expires after the 1993 season, but either side can reopen it by Dec. 11.
Richard Ravitch, the clubs' chief labor executive, met with groups of owners in Los Angeles and New York in recent weeks discussing the pluses and minuses of reopening. Ravitch initially said he needed the support of three-fourths of the clubs to take that fateful step, but as a result of the meetings that standard was changed to a majority.
The prevailing belief has been that the owners would opt to reopen, but some owners have said recently that too many will be opposed to that move and it won't happen, thus preserving the 1993 season. In fact, there has even been talk that one or more owners might go to court to try to block an effort to reopen the contract.
These owners have learned that tactic from the Tribune Company, the owner of the Chicago Cubs, which in July gained a preliminary injunction in United States District Court in Chicago blocking Vincent's order realigning the National League. Vincent resigned before his appeal of the injunction could be heard, and the owners' executive council, with Selig as chairman, then rescinded the original realignment order.
Owners opposed to reopening the labor agreement do not favor a lockout next spring, which is generally believed to be Part 2 of the labor strategy. Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox, one of the most outspoken and influential owners, has said the owners will shut down the game for a year if necessary. One of the major reasons for Vincent's ouster was the perception by Reinsdorf and others that Vincent was too accommodating to the players union. Now, hard-line owners are insisting that a tough negotiating stance is essential.
 
It Could Be Time To Try On a Cap
 Whether the next negotiations occur sooner or later, the clubs most likely will try to persuade the players to accept a revenue-participation plan with some sort of overall cap on team salaries, such as the National Basketball Association has. The result would be that salary costs would be fixed and not subject to a meteoric rise through salary arbitration.
"But," Fehr said, "the salary cap is premised on the notion that a built-in margin over and above player costs ought to be preset in any or all economic circumstances, whether they manage poorly or not."
If the percentage of the clubs' total revenue is high enough -- the N.B.A. uses 53 percent of nearly 100 percent of its revenue in formulating the salary cap -- the players might at least consider the idea. On the other hand, the players, seeing the clubs freely awarding contracts like the one the Chicago Cubs gave Ryne Sandberg for $7.1 million a year, see no compelling reason to change the system.
Furthermore, the players will ask why the wealthier, large-market clubs can't share their revenue with the poorer, small-market clubs. In other words, why shouldn't the clubs help themselves before they ask the players to bail them out?
Steve Greenberg, the deputy commissioner, who formerly represented players in contract negotiations, noted the projected industry losses and said: "Revenue sharing at that point isn't revenue sharing. You're talking about loss sharing."
The teams in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, among others, would fight any effort to play Robin Hood with their riches. If somehow the poorer clubs could get a revenue-sharing plan through, some or all of those richer clubs could simply go to court and block it the way the Cubs blocked realignment.
The owners who sit on the executive council aren't likely to take any action that would offend a substantial number of their fellow owners. It's entirely possible that no future commissioner would either. Vincent did, and he wound up vacationing in Jamaica instead of attending playoff games.
The owners' ouster of Vincent left them with an even poorer image with baseball fans than they had before, Fehr said.
"It will take some time for baseball to recover from the soap opera that played around Fay's getting canned," Fehr said. "It wasn't so much that the commissioner should or shouldn't be fired or be asked to resign, but the way it was done is quite something else. I don't think I've talked to anyone in the past month who didn't say, 'Do those guys know what they're doing?' People who deal with baseball have to wonder if their dealings are going to be tossed around publicly like that."
A committee of owners has been working on the structure of the major leagues' hierarchy and appears headed toward turning the commissioner into a chief executive officer responsible to a board of directors made up of the 28 owners. The commissioner's best-interests-of-baseball powers likely will be diluted because they will be defined for the first time.
Other problems the owners will have to grapple with include television revenue and attendance.
Baseball will receive $401 million, or $15.4 million a club, in television revenue in 1993. No one knows what the owners will get in the upcoming negotiations for a new national television package, but Greenberg said, "There's absolutely no scenario under which our national television revenues don't drop significantly. Some would say precipitously. If it's a $2 million decrease per club, it's not the end of the world. If it's closer to $5 million, which some people are predicting, it's more disastrous."
As for attendance, some attribute the slight decrease to some unusually bad weather in 1992, the absence of division races and the collapse of some teams that had been expected to be contenders.
If the Mets and the Dodgers had played up to expectations and matched their attendance figures of 1991, the major leagues would have drawn nearly half a million more fans in 1992 than 1991 instead of drawing nearly a million fewer.
Greenberg noted that attendance in 1992 was still more than it was two years ago. "In this economy, that's darn good," he said. "But what is troubling is some of the trends we've seen. In a normal year, with relatively flat attendance, you'd expect to see about half the clubs up and half down. But this year, you saw 18 clubs down over last year and only eight that were up. Thirteen clubs were down more than 100,000. That's a trend we have to reverse."
Some baseball personnel people see another trend they'd like to reverse: the dilution of talent. Adding two teams to the National League spreads the available talent even more thinly across 28 clubs. Some officials candidly acknowledge that owners voted to expand only to create a new source of revenue ($95 million from each of the two new franchises).
While baseball officials and owners ponder all of these problems, they can ignore for the moment, but perhaps not forever, the threat of Congressional intrusion into their antitrust exemption.
A Congressional subcomittee was to have held hearings last month but canceled them in light of plans by the Senate Judiciary Committee to conduct hearings early next year. The owners' ouster of Vincent was among the developments that caught the attention of some members of Congress.

LENGTH: 1595 words

HEADLINE: TV Tunes In to New York, Hollywood Style

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Forget those decadent "Dallas" and "Dynasty" and "Falcon Crest" rich people of the 1970's and 1980's on television. Forget the never-never world of "Love Boat" and "Fantasy Island" and "Charlie's Angels." What's hot now, at least in television, are the gritty streets and the grittier characters of New York City.
Never before have so many television series been set in New York in a single season -- but with a twist. Most of these shows with New York settings are actually filmed on Los Angeles studio lots because New York (which really means Manhattan to TV executives) is considered simply too expensive.
 
'Stories Can Be Richer'
 Angela Lansbury, the star and executive producer of the venerable "Murder, She Wrote" on CBS, about a mystery writer in Maine who is now teaching part time at a school similar to New York University, said: "The New York locale just allows us to introduce a far wider ethnic diversity than Maine. We can use more black actors, more Latinos, more Asians. The stories can be richer. But we just can't afford to shoot in New York. Mayor Dinkins probably hates us!" 
 New Yorkers have always served as sources of laughter, and even lightning rods, on television. There were Ralph Kramden and Ed Norton, Archie and Edith Bunker. There were cop shows like "Naked City," "NYPD," "The Defenders" and "Kojak." New Yorkers were generally depicted as blue-collar guys (and gals) with Noo Yawwk accents. (There were exceptions, of course, including the enormously popular "The Cosby Show," which took place in Brooklyn Heights.)
But now, the numerous New York shows are strikingly different. They inevitably take place on the East Side and the West Side of Manhattan, not Brooklyn or Queens as in the old days. And the major characters are not Archie Bunker types married to long-suffering women, but Italian and Jewish neurotics involved with gorgeous WASPs from the Midwest. They usually have a melting pot of black and Hispanic friends.
Precisely why so many shows are set in New York is unclear. Grant Tinker, the former chairman of NBC, said each city has its moment on television -- it was Miami and Boston a few years ago -- and now New York is the favored setting. But Bill Haber, a television agent at Creative Artists Agency, and one of the most prominent in Hollywood, said the nation's economic downturn and apparent darker mood are central to the plethora of New York shows.
"In the 1980's the escape we all wanted was pleasant -- 'Love Boat,' 'Fantasy Island,' " Mr. Haber said. "Now it's a time of reality. People want to see some semblance of truth. The comedies now are meaner, edgier. The shows are grittier. New York is a microcosm. It's a canvas upon which everyone is drawing the reality of the 90's."
Paul Reiser, a comedian who grew up in Stuyvesant Town, is one of the creators and stars of "Mad About You," an NBC show about newlyweds setting up an apartment on 12th Street and Fifth Avenue. "A lot of writers come from New York and tend to write what they know," he said. "To set this show in Istanbul -- or, for that matter, Los Angeles -- makes no sense, even though I live in L.A. New York just has a faster, funnier edge."
 
'It's Nuts Out There'
 He added: "It's realistic to start a scene in New York with a guy walking into his apartment, cursing and saying 'Unbelievable! You wouldn't believe what happened to me! A lady dropped dead on the bus. The doorman spit on my shoes.' Whatever. Here in L.A. it's like, 'You're not going to believe what my agent said to me today.' Who cares?"
Jerry Seinfeld, who was born in Brooklyn and attended Queens College, and whose comedy "Seinfeld" is one of the most popular on television, said: "The older shows set in New York, 'That Girl,' 'The Odd Couple,' weren't scary. Now the city is quite scary. It's crazy. It's nuts out there. And most of the time that's the take of these TV shows. New York characters are generally a certain type. You spend a lot of time walking around, going to movies and ordering Chinese food up."
The shows using New York locales -- and New York characters -- include a range of comedies and dramas that generally underline the toughness of living in the city.
These shows include "Love and War," on CBS, about a woman (Susan Dey) who buys a crummy bar after losing her fancy restaurant, and her relationship with a chip-on-the-shoulder newspaper columnist, played by Jay Thomas, who can't find the right mate. ("One relationship lasted slightly longer than Hanukkah," he says). There is also "Mad About You," on NBC, starring Mr. Reiser and Helen Hunt as Manhattan newlyweds, and "Civil Wars," the drama on ABC about Manhattan divorce lawyers, played by Mariel Hemingway, who portrays a well-bred Minnesotan now living in the big town, and Peter Onorati as her solid, down-to-earth partner.
 
More in the Works
 There is also NBC's "Seinfeld," about a comedian and his neighbors on the Upper West Side; "Law & Order," the Emmy Award-winning series on NBC about lawyers and the police, filmed entirely on location in New York; "Here and Now," on NBC starring Malcolm-Jamal Warner as a New York graduate student in psychology struggling to balance college life with work at a Manhattan youth center, taped before an audience at the Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens; "Room for Two," the ABC show with Linda Lavin as a merry widow who lives in New York near her daughter, a television producer, and "Brooklyn Bridge," the sentimental comedy on CBS about Brooklyn in the 1950's. There's also HBO's series, "Dream On," about a newly divorced Manhattan book editor, played by Brian Benben, coping with the city and a variety of relationships.
Next year, the list of programs set in New York is scheduled to grow. There will be an hourlong police show, still untitled, created by Steven Bochco, one of TV's most successful writer-producers, as well as a series about the TriBeCa area of Manhattan produced by TriStar Television for the Fox Network by Robert DeNiro's company, TriBeCa Productions.
Trade union problems and costs are often cited as reasons for not making more television shows in New York. A rare exception is NBC's acclaimed "Law & Order."
Dick Wolf, creator and one of the executive producers of the show, said that New York's unions, including the Teamsters, which in the past had tangled with production companies, were "enormously helpful" but that costs escalated in the city. "Everything just takes longer," he said.
 
Anything Can Happen
 "If you have to make a move in the middle of the day in Manhattan, it takes much longer than moving from Encino to Sherman Oaks," he said. "Everything costs more. The soda costs more. The food and coffee is more. The gasoline is more."
But Mr. Wolf said that creating the texture of the show without filming it in New York would be virtually impossible. "You can't replace the acting pool -- it's more classically trained, more theater oriented than Los Angeles," he said. "But it's not only the acting. It's the reality of the place. Our bible for the show is the front page of The New York Post. Anything that happens on the planet, short of Somalia, happens in New York. You never have a believability problem in New York. You can say there are pygmy serial killers and they're operating in New York and it would be believable."
Nina Streich, acting director of Mayor David N. Dinkins's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, said unions were reaching out to production companies. But she said one of the problems of producing situation comedies in New York, before audiences, was the city had fewer stages than Los Angeles to tape shows.
"There's also the proximity to network and company executives in Los Angeles," said Ms. Streich, who added that the Dinkins administration was actively seeking more New York-filmed television programs, if not more situation comedies. Several full-length feature films are now in production or have just completed work in New York.
 
'Only in New York'
 Several shows set in New York but filmed in Los Angeles, like the critically praised "Civil Wars," a courtroom drama about divorce lawyers, are planning to use the city increasingly in their plots.
The Queens-born creator of "Civil Wars," William M. Finkelstein, said one of the lawyers, played by Alan Rosenberg, will meet a woman on the M104 Broadway bus, forget to get her phone number and place an ad in The Village Voice. She responds and they eat dinner in a Chinese restaurant on Mott Street. "This could only happen in New York," said Mr. Finkelstein, who added that the class and social demarcations of the city will also be highlighted in other episodes.
Two of the central characters are Debi Mazar, who plays a brassy secretary from Queens, and her new husband, David Marciano, who plays an artistic bicycle messenger and poet whose family is very wealthy.
"He lives on Avenue B on the Lower East Side and wants to stay there," said Mr. Finkelstein. "She wants to move to Long Island. To him, moving to Long Island is artistic death. To her, living on the Lower East Side is crazy, the last thing in the world she wants. They opt for a co-op on Central Park West -- remember, he's got family money. It's sufficiently middle-class for her, and sufficiently artistic for him."
Of New York, Mr. Finkelstein said: "It's just a great place for stories. You're at a pay phone and you hear a guy breaking up with his wife. You're constantly surrounded by din. If you listen, you gain access to what you ultimately make dramas about."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Stalled world trade talks could move ahead "in a matter of days," trade ministers said after a meeting in Ontario. They provided no details but said they thought a compromise in the dispute over farm subsidies would come when U.S. Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan and his European counterpart, Ray MacSharry, meet this week. [Page D1.]
The joke making the rounds among Chinese intellectuals is this: "Under the leadership of the Communist Party, we're advancing from socialism to capitalism." Yet Deng Xiaoping, the 88-year-old senior leader, has no intention of creating the kind of democratic capitalist society that exists in the West. [A1.]
 

The Economy
Growing networks of unregulated insurers, often based in the Caribbean, have sold hundreds of millions of dollars of insurance, from automobile to health to liability policies, investigators and regulators say. Their victims have ranged from poor immigrants to local governments to giant corporations. [A1.]
Bush's political team bears much responsibility for the nation's economic problems, not the economic team the President has said he will dismiss, economists say. Economic Memo. [D1.]
 
Companies
Apple has a new hybrid computer system combining attributes of portable and desktop machines that the company hopes will be a breakthrough in the marketplace. [D1.]
The maker of the flawed mirror on the Hubble Space Telescope may be liable for damages, according to the Government. The company is owned by G.M.'s Hughes Aircraft unit, but was owned by Perkin-Elmer when it made the mirror. [A1.]
For large manufacturers, the U.S. seems like an unsafe haven from European recessions and currency woes. Companies like Ford and I.B.M., which depend heavily on Europe, have begun reporting pinched profits and crimped sales. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
Magazine circulation and advertising are strong, and there has been a sharp drop-off in sudden announcements of magazine deaths. Publishers are optimistic. [D1.]
News magazine programs are making a case to advertisers that they should be considered on at least equal footing with shows aimed at younger audiences. Bill Carter: Television. [D6.]
The William Morris Agency has acquired Triad Artists, whose clients include Bruce Willis, Daniel Day-Lewis, Danny Glover, Whitney Houston, Patrick Swayze and Ray Charles. [C11.]
Madonna's spicy $50 opus, "Sex," complete with a compact disk, arrives in stores on Wednesday. [D6.]
The manner in which personal computers are advertised has changed radically in recent years. [D6.]
The Perry Ellis Group will ask consumers to donate used pairs of jeans to help clothe the homeless. For those who find altruism less than its own reward, the donated pants can be exchanged for free T-shirts. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

On Wall Street, I.B.M. isn't just a company -- it's a religion with at least two rival theologies. One holds that the company is trapped in a cycle of inevitable decline, the other that I.B.M. is going through a wrenching transition but retains enormous strengths and the ability to come back. Steve Lohr: Market Place. [D1.]
In the tax-exempt bond market, traders and investors face political uncertainty beyond the outcome of the Presidential election. At the state and local level, numerous spending and taxing initiatives could affect the credit outlook for state and local governments. Jonathan Fuerbringer: Credit Markets. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Trade Talk Progress Expected

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Ontario, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, met here today with her counterparts from the European Community, Canada and Japan, then said she expected a breakthrough in stalled world trade talks "in a matter of days."
She and the other ministers offered no specific details to back up their optimism or information on how they might overcome the firm statements by France that it would offer no further compromises to break the stalemate. 
 The broad talks aimed at liberalizing world trade, now in their sixth year, have been stalled by a disagreement between the United States and the European Community over farm subsidies, which Washington is trying to curtail sharply.
 
Political Forces
 President Bush, trailing in the opinion polls in his bid for re-election, has been hoping for a global trade agreement that he could point to as evidence of how his Administration is effective overseas and stimulates economic growth.
Asked whether there had been talk of the Nov. 3 election at the meeting this weekend, Canada's Trade Minister, Michael Wilson, said with a grin: "What happens on Nov. 3?"
The strongest opposition to a deal has come from France, where farmers are a potent political force and a general election is scheduled within six months. At last week's European Community meeting in Birmingham, England, France's President, Francois Mitterrand, appeared unyielding in his opposition to any deal that would require further concessions to Washington.
 
Periodic Meetings
 During the prolonged stalemate, negotiators, trade ministers and national leaders have met periodically and expressed hope or optimism that the impasse could be broken -- with little evident progress.
Still, the expectation that a compromise would be reached "in a matter of days" was the most optimistic statement yet.
The officials meeting here said they expected the breakthrough would come when the United States Secretary of Agriculture, Edward Madigan, meets with Ray MacSharry, the European Community Agriculture Commissioner. They are expected to meet this week, probably in Washington.
The global negotiations involving 108 countries, known as the Uruguay Round because they began in that nation in 1986, are under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based world trade organization.
It was not clear how to reconcile the apparently intractable French position with the optimism shown by the trade ministers at their weekend meeting at an Ontario country estate here called Langdon House, about a 90-minute drive west of Toronto.
Asked about the apparent conflict, Frans Andriessen, the European Community's External Relations Commissioner, referred reporters to the final communique from the Birmingham meeting, which "invited the commission to work within its existing mandate for an early, comprehensive and balanced GATT agreement by the end of the year."
"I think we will be in a position to make a deal within the mandate we have been given," Mr. Andriessen stressed. He noted that Mr. Mitterrand was among the signatories of the Birmingham communique.
 
'Progress Has Been Made'
 Joined by ministers from the United States, Japan and Canada, he told a news conference here that the optimism was "based on the determination to bring things to a good end and secondly the fact that progress has been made in all the sectors concerned."
The community has refused so far to accept deep cuts sought by the United States in payments to growers of wheat, oil seeds, dairy products and other foods. Washington, with support from most other farm exporting nations, contends that the subsidies lead to grave distortions of world trade and impoverish treasuries of rich and poor countries alike.
Mrs. Hills, asked if the European and American farm ministers were about to meet, said Mr. Madigan and Mr. MacSharry had been "in contact," though she added that she was "aware of no meeting that has been firmly scheduled."
 
Seeking a Framework
 The issue now, she said, was whether the major trading nations could "create a framework to agree among ourselves to go to Geneva." The formal negotiations broke off earlier this year, and a return to the multilateral bargaining table would be a sign that the parties believe a full-scale accord is close.
"We're looking for a breakthrough in those issues that have blocked progress to date in a matter of days," Mrs. Hills said, "and that would then take the negotiations to Geneva where other parties must make their contribution."
Mr. Wilson of Canada, the host at Langdon House, said the ministers discussed accelerating the negotiations.
"With the impending conclusion this year, it's important to move expeditiously," he declared. Another sign of the American optimism is a United States decision to hold back on retaliation against the European Community in a six-year old dispute over oil seeds.
The Bush Administration calculates that oil seeds subsidies paid to European farmers cost American and other exporters about $2 billion annually, and under strong Congressional pressure has threatened to retaliate against $1 billion of European exports to the United States.
But Washington has yet to push the reprisal button. "We are weighing our future steps very carefully," Mrs. Hills said. "Quite honestly, we are very much beyond time, but we're trying to look for a solution because a settlement would be in the interests of the U.S. and Europe."

HEADLINE: Deficits Bring More Splits, Less Progress

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 16

 BODY:
As if things were not bad enough for the states, counties and cities of the New York City region, the deep recession of the early 1990's is underscoring an unhappy lesson of government: When times are tough, partisan bickering only makes things worse.
"It takes difficult times to bring out the worst political cheap shots," said Robert W. Burchell, a fiscal-policy analyst at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. Earlier this month, his state laid off 1,500 government workers in the aftermath of a heated partisan dispute and legal battle over lowering the state sales tax. 
 To be sure, political tension is all but inevitable during times of economic hardship, when governments must weigh cutbacks against additional taxes at a time when paychecks are shrinking. Still, a comparison of the response of state and local governments in the region shows that while some are locked in fiscal and political paralysis as the recession lingers, others have made painful progress toward solutions.
While the Connecticut cities of Bridgeport and West Haven are near bankruptcy, New York City's finances are, in some ways, the envy of the region. And while state officials in New Jersey are locked in fiscal warfare, Connecticut's finances appear to have stabilized after a politically bruising overhaul of its state tax code.
"It is clearly the case that tough economic times can disrupt the process of government," said David Viser, a spokesman for Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive. Nassau ranks among the nation's wealthiest suburban enclaves even in times of recession, but it was forced this week to seek $665,000 in new debt just to pay the utility bills at the Nassau County Medical Center.
 
Anger Over Taxes and Cuts
 Nowhere in the region have the politics of austerity come closer to gridlock than here, the Nassau County seat. Partisan infighting began last year when Mr. Gulotta, a Republican who was supported by a majority of the county's Board of Supervisors, anticipated revenue shortfalls and submitted a plan to raise property taxes.
But late last year, fearing anger from taxpayers, Republican supervisors who had been allied with Mr. Gulotta rejected the tax increases and presented him with an ultimatum in the form of a sharply reduced 1992 budget, about $2 billion. That led the county to send out 2,500 layoff notices in January and February.
Inevitably, the partisan bickering became even more heated. Faced with mass demonstrations by county employees, Nassau stopped eliminating jobs by March, and Mr. Gulotta called for a slight increase in a mortgage-recording tax and a smaller increase than had earlier been sought in the property tax.
But no consensus has been reached. Mr. Viser says the county's plan now is to borrow money to pay salaries and other bills until Nov. 1, when it can reshuffle its finances by withdrawing funds from the accounts of some departments and programs to pay the bills of others. "We are in a logjam," he said.
In New Jersey, the layoffs on Oct. 5 continued a heated political fight that began in 1990 when Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, took office. Faced with a $600 million deficit in the state's $14 billion-plus budget, he pushed a package of tax increases, including an increase in the state's sales tax, through the Democratic-controlled Legislature.
 
Rollback of Sales Tax
 The new taxes generated enough money to pay off the deficit by last year, but they were wildly unpopular. A public backlash helped to give control of the Legislature to the Republicans, who had affinity for Mr. Florio or his new taxes.
In June, the Legislature rolled back the sales tax from 7 percent to 6 percent. To make up for the anticipated budget shortfall, it ordered the layoffs, and specified that state employees making more than $50,000 a year should be first on the layoff list.
The political dispute escalated into a legal battle, not yet resolved. Although the courts said earlier this month that New Jersey could impose 1,500 layoffs, the state is involved in other suits that challenge the Legislature's power to designate which employees should be cut.
In contrast to New Jersey's continuing turmoil, an even bigger battle over fiscal policy appears to have been resolved in Connecticut. It began in January 1991, when Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. took office. Confronting the prospect of a $250 million state-budget deficit, he pushed a reluctant General Assembly into approving the state's first personal-income tax.
 
Harsh Medicine Has Effect
 The measure met stiff resistance because Connecticut had long prided itself on having no income tax and had benefited in the past by attracting wealthy New York City commuters. But the need for harsh fiscal medicine had become apparent by the end of 1991, with Connecticut in deep recession and its projected deficit soaring.
Now, with the income tax gaining grudging acceptance, the deficit has been eliminated. The state ended its most recent fiscal year on June 30 with a $110 million budget surplus, and a spokesman for Mr. Weicker, Avice Meehan, said the state had accumulated a surplus of $4 million so far this fiscal year.
New York State, meanwhile, broadened its sales tax in 1991 to include taxes on rental cars and some other services and has been forced by the recession and a fiscal squeeze to postpone income-tax cuts that had been approved in 1987. The state's personal-income-tax rate -- now 7.875 percent -- was to have been lowered in successive steps to 7 percent by 1991, state officials said.
Even with the higher tax rate, the state has still had to borrow to pay its bills, continuing a policy that has become routine under the administration of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Although the state said it had a balanced budget for the fiscal year that ended March 31, it said it would sell bonds to raise the $531 million necessary to pay its bills. The state's budget is $56.5 billion.
 
Municipal Malaise
 Among the most fiscally troubled governments in the region are Bridgeport and West Haven, Conn., each grappling with large budget deficits and under the supervision of state-controlled review boards.
Bridgeport's deficits began piling up in the 1980's and reached a peak with a $58 million shortfall in 1988. The city, with an almost $320 million budget, filed for bankruptcy protection last year but later withdrew its application. Although its finances have improved, Bridgeport reported a $7 million deficit at the end of 1991.
In West Haven, fierce partisan battles between a former Republican Mayor and the City Council led last year to adoption of a budget of about $85 million that far exceeded the city's ability to raise revenues, resulting in a $10 million deficit at the end of 1991.
Among all large government jurisdictions in the region, analysts say New York City has presented its taxpayers with the most welcome surprises over the last year. The administrations of Mayor David N. Dinkins and his predecessor, Edward I. Koch, had made a tradition of vastly overestimating the revenues needed to cover their budgets; as a result, they often ended up reporting surpluses at the end of each fiscal year. But the huge surpluses of prior years had shrunken steeply to a $20 million surplus at the end of the fiscal year ending March 31, 1991.
 
Caution in New York
 By the end of the most recent fiscal year, however, Mr. Dinkins was able to report a $550 million surplus. It came only months after he had announced a freeze on property-tax rates until 1994, promising little or no increase for property owners. Officials are now working on the city's estimated $29.5 billion 1994 fiscal-year budget.
Analysts attributed the city's surplus to unexpected success in cutting costs through a combination of layoffs and job cuts through attrition and hiring freezes in the Parks Department, the libraries and other city departments. The city's payroll has been reduced by 10,000 since 1991.
Despite the surpluses, fiscal analysts caution that city's long-term financial status remains precarious.
"The surplus is not a sign of good fiscal health," said Dean Mead, senior research associate for the Citizens Budget Committee, a watchdog group, who added that severe problems that continue to plague New York City's economy may force more spending cuts.
Nonetheless, he added that the swelling balance in the city's bank account over the last year "is a sign that it is doing a good job of reining in the budget."

LENGTH: 1226 words

HEADLINE: Workers Say U.S. Program Took Their Jobs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DECATURVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 18

 BODY:
The west Tennessee hills are turning red, orange and gold, adding fall color to this ailing town where the most prosperous business is said to be the funeral parlor. Life was never easy here, but it has been a whole lot harder since last year, when the town's biggest employer, a clothing factory, closed and took away 306 jobs from this town of 1,000 people.
But this is not just another recession story about discouraged workers. Instead, it is a story about workers who say they are angry and feel betrayed because of what they have learned since the plant closed: that the Federal Government helped the company move to a new plant in El Salvador through a special subsidy program that is supposed to nurture capitalism in Central America. 
 "I'm not pinching pennies, I'm squeezing them to death," said 46-year-old Lynn Johnson, who was a sewing machine operator at the plant for 25 years. When the plant closed, she was making $300 a week. She has just completed a course to become a licensed practical nurse and says she hopes to get a job on the night shift in a hospital in Jackson, about 60 miles west of here.
 
Ire for Quayle
 Emily Ann Vise, 63, got a $2,500 lump-sum retirement benefit for her 28 years of work at the factory. She is living on a $525-a-month Social Security benefit and $175 of that goes for health insurance. Her husband, James, is a 67-year-old farmer, and he has no retirement plan other than Social Security. "We raise a garden and freeze and can food," Mrs. Vise said.
The way the Decaturville workers lost their jobs was the focus of a segment on the CBS News program "60 Minutes" on Sept. 27 and a source of friction in the Vice-Presidential debate last week when Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, the Democratic candidate, mentioned the town and criticized the Bush Administration for using tax dollars to shift American jobs to other countries. Vice President Dan Quayle dismissed the accusation with a chuckle, and, after giving his rebuttal, said, "That's just totally ridiculous."
The Vice President's response did not play well here in Decaturville. "Quayle was laughing, and we're down here dying," said Brenda Johnson, a secretary with a local government agency. "He really hurt me, and I wish I had been there to stand up and say my piece."
The factory had been the lifeblood of this town since 1961, when the residents contributed to an industrial development fund to convert the burned-out remnants of a school gymnasium. When the town could not persuade companies to look at the factory, they tracked down manufacturers, finally signing up the owners of one clothing company, the Meltzer Brothers, while they were passing through the Nashville Airport in 1961, Decaturville's Mayor, Margaret Alexander, recalled.
 
Factory Was Profitable
 The Meltzer factory evolved into Decaturville Sportswear, a subsidiary of the Marcade Group of New York. And, at its height in the 1970's, the factory employed 1,500 people or about 15 percent of the people in Decatur County.
The plant closed in May 1991 with only seven weeks' notice. Factory officials had always said publicly that the plant was a profitable and high-quality operation that made women's sportswear for the J. C. Penney Company and Sears, Roebuck and Company.
The "60 Minutes" program prompted Congress to enact legislation earlier this month ordering the agency that provided the subsidy to Decaturville Sportswear, the United States Agency for International Development, not to finance any more overseas projects that could result in jobs being lost by Americans. Congress has also asked the General Accounting Office to investigate the program, which has spent more than $1 billion on the program since it was started by the Reagan Administration in 1981.
The agency describes its subsidy program, nicknamed Trade, Not Aid, as a foreign aid program based on the theory that economic development will stabilize Central American governments and ultimately create more consumers for American exports. But critics, like union leaders, say the program has hurt some American workers, particularly those who work in labor-intensive industries like clothing manufacturing, which has lost half a million jobs in the last 12 years.
The subsidy programs have encouraged 58 clothing factories, including Decaturville Sportswear, to close and shift 12,000 jobs to Central America in the last two years, said Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Committee for Worker and Human Rights in Central America, which represents 21 labor unions.
The National Labor Committee said the subsidy program provided grants to a trade organization in El Salvador to recruit the Marcade Group. The program also paid for the construction of a $5 million manufacturing plant and provided low-interest loans for the company's costs of starting up and $1.1 million in insurance, the Labor Committee says, adding that the new factory did the same work that was done by the plant here.
El Salvador also exempted the company from corporate taxes and shipping duties, the Labor Committee says. The group also says the current hourly wage for apparel workers in that country is about 45 cents an hour, while most apparel workers in the United States start at the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour.
Marcade officials did not return telephone calls. But officials from the development agency asserted that there was no connection between the closing of Decaturville Sportswear and the expansion of manufacturing in El Salvador by another subsidiary of Marcade.
An agency spokesman, Kelly J. Presta, said on Friday, "The only relationship between these two companies is that they were acquired by the same holding company."
But the residents of Decaturville see it differently. "The bottom line is that the Government used our tax dollars to take our jobs away from us," said Elicia Jo Stain, 29, an unemployed worker. "It's not fair for the Government to pull something like that."
Decaturville, the county seat of Decatur County, has a single stop sign and five short blocks of brick and concrete block buildings, all but one, a single story high.
 
Loan Delinquencies Double
 When Decaturville Sportswear closed, the unemployment rate for Decatur County shot to more than 20 percent and loan delinquencies at the local bank doubled. "Things are not that good in good times, but it's devastating when you lose your major employer," said James A. England, president of Decatur County Bank.
The laid-off apparel workers have been receiving about $125 a week in unemployment benefits, and the benefits are about to expire, leaving only welfare as an option for many.
People are discouraged, but they are determined to keep the town afloat. Last year, as the factory and then some shops closed, Mac Johnson, Brenda Johnson's husband, and five other Decaturville residents invested $125,000 to open a general merchandise store called Big D Dollar Store on Main Street. "It's a risky situation, but, hell, it's our town," said Mr. Johnson, who owns an auto parts shop in the town.
The Mayor said she was on the telephone every day looking for new business. "You may hear people say we should turn the lights off and leave Decaturville, but the lights would not go off so long as there is a breath in me," Mrs. Alexander said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Independent;
While Perot's Economic Plans Are Detailed, Other Positions Remain Vague

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 18

 BODY:
When it comes to slashing the Federal deficit and spurring the economy, Ross Perot has cooked up a meaty stew of specific tax increases, spending cuts and tax incentives. But when he moves into the noneconomic areas of public policy, he serves up ideas that might evoke a cry from a past Presidential election: Where's the beef?
As specific and as bold as Mr. Perot has been on the economy and the deficit in his book, "United We Stand," and in his two 30-minute television presentations, his positions on issues like education, governmental reform, crime and health care have tended to be either vague, not completely worked through, of dubious constitutionality or devoid of any suggestion of how much they might cost or who would pay. Some issues, including affirmative action and gun control, have not been addressed at all. 
 Vagueness is also characteristic of many proposals put forward by President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton, but outside the economic realm, Mr. Perot's ideas tend to seem more nebulous than those of most Presidential candidates because he has taken virtually no questions from reporters or others that might shed more light on his proposals. In at least one area, controlling spiraling health-care costs, Mr. Perot's lack of specificity calls into question whether he could actually achieve his stated goal of balancing the Federal budget in five years.
 
Clear but Incomplete
 On the highly contentious issue of abortion Mr. Perot is very clear. He comes down unequivocally on the side of a woman's right to terminate her pregnancy and for Federal financing of abortions for low-income women.
But while supporting the right to an abortion, Mr. Perot has never commented on limitations like a 24-hour waiting period or parental notification for minors seeking abortions.
The difference between Mr. Perot's specificity on deficit reduction and his tentativeness in other areas reflects the importance he assigns to economic issues. "He had never really formulated positions on what he considered the secondary issues, which was basically everything other than the economy," said Doug Austin, a graduate student at the University of California School of Public Policy who worked on civil rights proposals as part of a task force Mr. Perot hired to help him formulate positions on issues.
 
Issues Development Interrupted
 He and other former members of the task force say they had virtually completed a plan to shrink the deficit but had not finished work in other areas when the Texan dropped out of the race in July.
"We hadn't gotten that far," said John P. White, an Eastman-Kodak vice president who headed the issues staff. "Our focus was to get started on priorities and concentrate on the centerpiece, which was the economics. We were going to get more involved in other issues once we got that out of the way."
Because Mr. Perot's noneconomic platform is a work in progress, some of its features raise questions about his vow of balancing the budget. For example, in the half-hour of television time he bought this weekend, Mr. Perot suggested that $268 billion could be saved by changes in Federal entitlement programs. He said that slightly more than half of those savings, about $141 billion, would come through capping the rising costs of health care, which would result in less money being spent on Medicare and Medicaid.
But Mr. Perot does not provide details on how such savings could be achieved. David Parkhurst, a policy expert who worked on the entitlement section of Mr. Perot's platform, said the $141 billion figure was a goal and represented a 50 percent reduction in the projected increase in health-care costs over five years after discounting for inflation. But "we never got to the point where we could put together a solid health-care plan," said Mr. Parkhurst, a public policy analyst for a Washington law firm.
In his book and in public appearances, Mr. Perot expresses general support for free trade. But like Mr. Clinton, Mr. Perot says he would seek to insure that the North American Free Trade Agreement did not result in the loss of American jobs to Mexico.
 
Similarity in Education Plans
 In education, Mr. Perot's plan is remarkably similar to President Bush's America 2000 proposal. Having pushed through ambitious changes for the Texas school system in the 1980's, Mr. Perot advocates expanding a national program of early childhood education, though he does not say whether it would be open only to low-income children.
He also proposes national tests to measure student progress, more autonomy for schools and opening the certification process so that business people, legal professionals, military personnel or others could become teachers without the normal training.
Siding more closely with President Bush, Mr. Perot advocates allowing parents to choose whether to send their children to public, private or parochial schools; while he does not mention the use of vouchers to pay for this, it seems implicit. Unlike the President, Mr. Perot says pilot programs should be carefully analyzed before a school-choice program is adopted nationwide.
"We won't know if this will work until several states try it on a pilot basis," he says in his book. "The time for debate is after the results are in."
In his book Mr. Perot makes high priorities of changes in both the Government and the way Federal elections are conducted. He has proposed measures like eliminating political action committees, making it illegal for foreign companies or interests to contribute to election campaigns and holding Presidential elections on weekends.
Yet some experts, including the policy analyst who worked on the issue for Mr. Perot, doubt that some of his major proposals are constitutional. In a 1976 case, Buckley v. Valeo, the Supreme Court ruled that PAC contributions could be restricted. But the Justices have never ruled on whether PAC's can be eliminated.
Given the current makeup of the High Court, a number of experts say they believe Justices would find that doing away with PAC's violated the First Amendment's protection of free speech and freedom of association.
"I think the PAC issue would have raised a red flag for the Court," said Mr. Parkhurst, who worked on the issue for Mr. Perot.
 
Many Whats, Few Hows
 Mr. Perot's proposal to outlaw contributions from foreign interests was studied by the Federal Elections Commission two years ago. But the commission's staff determined that it would be difficult to enforce, in part because it would restrict the rights of American employees of foreign-owned businesses that operate in this country.
In the area of crime, Mr. Perot argues for increased emphasis on drug treatment but does not say how it would be financed. He also advocates mandatory drug testing and counseling for all prisoners, parolees and for those on probation, mandatory life sentences without parole for anyone convicted of three violent crimes, and a requirement that any inmate be literate and have a marketable skill before being paroled.
Andrew Wise, an aide to a Republican Texas state legislator and the analyst who worked on Mr. Perot's crime proposals, said the thrust of the candidate's ideas is to reduce the nation's high recidivism rate. But Mr. Wise said that he did not have the opportunity to work through questions like how much Mr. Perot's program would cost, how to get states to implement them, and what would be considered a marketable skill for prison inmates.
"We knew that as we put some of these ideas out for debate, we would have gotten a lot of questions from reporters, and that would have forced us to refine what we said," Mr. Wise said.

HEADLINE: Goodbye, Dime Call?;
25-Cent Toll Sought in Connecticut

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 18

 BODY:
When Andy Keleman was growing up in the 60's, his mother would regularly tell him, "When you go out, always take a dime for a phone call."
When Mr. Keleman, a computer consultant from Ridgefield, used a pay phone at the railroad station here, the call still cost a dime. But, under rate increases proposed last week by Southern New England Telephone, the 10-cent phone call in Connecticut would vanish after 39 years into the same nether world as the 5-cent ice-cream cone, the $1 movie ticket and 25-cents-a-gallon gasoline. 
 The proposed price increase to 25 cents, which the phone company is to file with state regulators on Nov. 12, is part of a package intended to increase revenues by $160 million in the next three years. If it takes effect next summer, it will mean that Arkansas will be the only remaining state where local calls of unlimited duration will still cost a dime.
 
New York Went Up in 1984
 In New York State, the cost of a pay-phone call jumped to a quarter from a dime in 1984. New Jersey Bell raised its rate to 20 cents from a dime in 1982. But pay phones not owned by New Jersey Bell may charge more.
Although some users of Connecticut's 25,000 pay telephones say the increase will make little difference, others say that a 150 percent increase is outrageous.
"It bothers me a lot, because I use pay phones frequently and I'll have to keep using them," said Robert Taylor, a Stamford mechanic.
Richard Minio, a recent college graduate from Danielson who does much of his job-hunting via pay telephones, said: "I travel all around the state looking for jobs, and I'm on pay phones all the time. So the additional 15 cents will add up."
Besides the increase for pay-phone calls, Southern New England Telephone is proposing changes in its rates to reduce the difference between what it charges its 1.3 million residential customers and its 563,000 business customers. It would increase most residential rates, and the charge for directory assistance would rise to 40 cents from 24 cents.
 
5.5% in the First Year
 "Business rates are three times as expensive as residential rates now," said William Seekamp, a company spokesman. "We're proposing to close that gap to try to help Connecticut businesses succeed in this tough economy."
Mr. Seekamp said that the specifics had yet to be settled, but regulators said the increases would amount to 5.5 percent in the first year and 12 to 15 percent over three years.
The company, which had a 4.8 percent, $48-million-a-year rate increase in March of 1991, is proposing the increases because it is not earning as much as is permitted under state regulations, Mr. Seekamp said.
"We're significantly under-earning," he said. "The state authorized a level of return on our in-state investment of 11.26 percent and we're currently earning 9.68 percent." He also said that the increase would help cover costs of new equipment.
 
'Why Charge More?'
 But some ask why the company needs to increase its revenues.
"If they're making money already, why charge more?" said Christian Planton of Westport. "It's just another thing you can't do anything about."
The State Department of Public Utility Control, which will hold public hearings on the proposed increases, will evaluate the proposals based on the degree to which the company is investing in "infrastructure modernization" and whether more competition should be permitted, said Louise Rickard, an agency spokeswoman.
However, to many Connecticut residents, the likely demise of the dime phone call signals more than just the inevitable passing of a surprisingly long era of price stability.
"It's losing a tradition," said Mr. Keleman. "It won't mean as much any more to say that you're down to your last dime."

HEADLINE: Seeds of Murder Epidemic: Teen-Age Boys With Guns

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
A new study has found that while the number of adults arrested for murder has declined since 1985, there has been a stunning increase in the number of boys under 18 charged with homicide.
"Murder is plunging to a much younger age group," said James Alan Fox, dean of Northeastern University's College of Criminal Justice and a co-author of the report. "What is so dangerous about this is that a 15-year-old with a gun in his hand is a much more volatile individual than a 40-year-old or even an 18-year-old," Mr. Fox said. 
 The study, by the National Crime Analysis Project at Northeastern University, found that the number of 17-year-olds arrested for murder climbed 121 percent from 1985 through 1991, and the number of 16-year-olds arrested rose 158 percent. But the biggest increase -- 217 percent -- was in the arrest of 15-year-olds. Even the number of arrests of boys 12 and under soared 100 percent in that time.
These figures are the clearest statistical confirmation of what had been just anecdotal evidence, Mr. Fox said.
 
Most Violent Group to Grow
 But even more important, Mr. Fox said, the figures suggest that the United States is on the verge of a vast new epidemic of murder, similar to one in the late 1960's and early 1970's, when the rate of violent crime doubled in five years.
The reason is that because of a decline in the number of babies born in recent years, the proportion of people in the 18- to 24-year-old age bracket, historically the most violence-prone segment of the population, has been declining, he said. "Right now, we have the fewest 18- to 24-year-olds we've had since 1965, but next year they will start to go back up."
"What we've seen in the past few years is nothing compared with what we'll see in the next decade and on into the next century as the resurging adolescent population mixes with changes in our society, our culture and our economy," Mr. Fox said.
In fact, because the percentage of the population age 18 to 24 declined to 10.4 percent in 1991 from 13.2 percent in 1980, the United States received a demographic dividend that should have resulted in a drop in the murder rate, Mr. Fox said. In the late 1970's, he predicted such a decline, but he now admits, "I've got egg on my face."
 
Upsurge Brings Distress
 The arrest rate for murders did decline from 1980 to 1985, as the percentage of young people fell. But since 1985 there has been a 24 percent increase in the homicide rate and a 36 percent increase in overall violent crimes largely because of the unexpected upsurge of violence among young boys, Mr. Fox said.
The report was based on data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Uniform Crime Report.
Alfred Blumstein, dean of the John Heinz School of Public Policy and Management at Carnegie-Mellon University and president of the American Society of Criminology, said the new figures were "terribly distressing."
"This should have been a period of improving conditions based on the age shift," he said. "Now the murder rates are likely to grow further."
Mr. Fox, Mr. Blumstein and other experts pointed to a number of reasons for the sharp increase in killings by younger boys, including the drug epidemic among the urban poor, the growing number and firepower of guns, the eroding quality of public schools and the glorification of violence on television and in movies.
 
Breakdown of Families
 Most important, they say, is the continued breakdown of the American family. Mr. Blumstein said many young people are poorly socialized and are more vulnerable to problems like drugs, violence on television, and the easy availability of guns.
"The glorification of violence on television has little effect on most folks, but it has a powerful effect on kids who are poorly socialized," Mr. Blumstein said. "It dehumanizes them and becomes a self-fulfilling process."
Mr. Fox is skeptical of the current vogue of imprisoning people as a solution to crime, noting that the number of people in prison in the United States has doubled in last decade to 1.1 million. "People say, 'Let's just try these kids who kill as adults and lock them up,' " Mr. Fox said.
"But that won't work," he said. "They don't care. They don't think about the consequences, and they don't have a long-term perspective. They face death every day on the street and even at school, so why should they be afraid that maybe the police will catch them and maybe they will be executed?"
 
'Loss of Childhood'
 Marvin Wolfgang, professor of criminology and law at the University of Pennsylvania and director of the school's Sellin Criminology Center, said: "What we're seeing is the loss of childhood. These kids are growing up too fast into the subculture of violence."
"They are learning at an ever-younger age that violence is not only tolerated, but often expected and sometimes required," Professor Wolfgang said. "If you don't respond aggressively to a slur on your mother or your manhood, you're a coward."
Mr. Blumstein said that resolving the problem of younger and younger boys' committing murder would be "a major challenge to the American system of family values. It will take some hard thinking and some radical solutions which we are not doing much about now, so it is reasonable to anticipate that the problem will get worse." Any solution, Mr. Blumstein said, "would require a considerable investment in the socialization process, which we have heretofore left to the family." This would be both expensive and intrusive, and therefore unpopular, he said.
In the Northeastern study, even males in the 21- to 24-year-old segment showed a relatively small increase compared to the younger boys.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Going Their Own Way, Candidates Ignore Bush

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONGMONT, Colo., Oct. 18

 BODY:
More than at any time since 1964, Republican candidates across the nation are putting distance between themselves and their party's Presidential ticket.
They usually explain their failure to mention President Bush, appear with him, or use his picture in their fliers as something dictated by their discerning constituents, who differentiate between Presidential and other races and want the candidates to campaign on their own. But at bottom there is a basic political fear of going down with Mr. Bush as Republicans did 28 years ago with Barry Goldwater and as Democrats did with Jimmy Carter in 1980. 
 An unusually open explanation was given here last week by Terry Considine, a Senate candidate who hardly uses Mr. Bush's name. Jeff Thomas, a reporter for The Longmont Daily Times-Call, said that when Mr. Considine was asked why he did not use Mr. Bush's name, he replied scornfully, "I think George Bush will be our Jimmy Carter."
In Illinois, another flagging Senate candidate, Rich Williamson, debated his opponent, Carol Moseley Braun, the night after the first Presidential debate. He approvingly quoted Ross Perot twice and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas once. He did not quote Mr. Bush.
In Louisville, Ky., a Republican House challenger, Susan Stokes, did not bring up the President in several appearances on Monday. When high school students asked her for whom she would vote, she replied unenthusiastically, "I probably ought to vote for President Bush."
In New York, the two-term Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, has been trying for several days to portray his views as close to those of Mr. Clinton. In a debate Saturday with his Democratic opponent, State Attorney General Robert Abrams, Mr. D'Amato scarcely mentioned President Bush, and that only in the final moments.
What these Republicans and others are trying to avoid was demonstrated Thursday in Portland, Ore. The Democratic Senate candidate, Representative Les AuCoin, startled his Republican opponent, Senator Bob Packwood, in a debate Thursday when he asked him, "Are you going to vote for George Bush, and if so, why?"
Mr. Packwood, after a brief pause said he would because "this is a man of decency," whose mistakes on the economy came from listening to bad advice from economists.
Mr. AuCoin pounced: "There you have it. They're teammates."
But Republicans long ago abandoned the idea of campaigning as one big team. All through the spring and early summer, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 House Republican, promised that in October all Republican House and Senate candidates would join Mr. Bush on the steps of the Capitol to demonstrate unity and promise to fix things in Congress. The idea has been quietly dropped.
Instead of trips to Washington, politicians are making explanations like the one offered by Dora Kingsley, campaign director for Joan Milke Flores, a House candidate in Southern California. Speaking of Mr. Bush, she said, "In no circumstances have we used his name, his likeness or any campaign themes particular to the Bush-Quayle campaign." She said, "We're running on issues of concern to our local constituents."
Historically, Mr. Bush has had no more political coattails than a golf jacket has. His lonely landslide in 1988 was accompanied by slight losses by his party in the House and Senate, and Republicans lost seats again in 1990. But in neither year did the candidates avoid him.
What is happening now resembles the way Democrats tried to dissociate themselves from Michael S. Dukakis four years ago. As Eddie Mahe, a prominent Republican consultant in Washington put it, his candidates have stopped attacking Mr. Clinton as planning to increase taxes by $154 billion and hanging "support for that tax increase around our opponents' necks." But with Mr. Clinton apparently assured of majorities in Mr. Mahe's candidates' states, the Republicans know that they have to get some of his voters to win and see no sense in offending those Clinton supporters.
 
Some Stand With Bush
 There are some Republicans who volunteer their support for the President. Their North Carolina candidate for governor, Jim Gardner, knows that his party rarely wins statewide if the Presidential ticket does not win big, so he goes out of his way to hail Mr. Bush, as he did Friday in Rocky Mount, crediting him with bringing an end to the Berlin Wall and overseeing the dissolution of the Soviet Union. But some other North Carolina Republicans are less involved. For example, the party's Senate candidate, Lauch Faircloth, was not seen when Vice President Dan Quayle toured the state last week.
Representative Philip M. Crane of Illinois, a very conservative Republican who is no intimate of the President, tells voters in his district that Mr. Bush deserves re-election and lambastes the Democratic candidate as "Slick Willie."
Tommy Hartnett, a Senate candidate in one of Mr. Bush's best states, South Carolina, supports him eagerly.
But except for places where Mr. Bush looks like a sure winner, the degree of Republican support tends to be inversely related to the closeness of a Republican's own race. In Missouri, Senator Christopher S. Bond has kept his distance, concentrating on his own contest. Senator John C. Danforth, who is not running this year, is campaigning for Mr. Bush.
 
Some Direct Criticism
 While most concerned Republicans simply keep quiet about Mr. Bush, some criticize him directly. Representative Wayne T. Gilchrest of Maryland has complained about the Administration's environmental record. Another freshman, Representative Scott L. Klug of Wisconsin, said in a debate last week that he would like to see "George Bush take two steps to the center."
Some Republicans have found heroes to substitute for Mr. Bush. Donna Peterson, a House challenger in Texas, invokes her state's Senator Phil Gramm. In New Hampshire, Gov. Judd Gregg, seeking the Senate seat of retiring Senator Warren B. Rudman, uses Mr. Rudman in television commercials. The candidate's blunt-spoken father, former Gov. Hugh Gregg, speaks caustically of the Bush campaign in the state. "There's nobody in charge," he told The Concord Monitor.
Occasionally Republicans like Senator D'Amato in New York even identify with Mr. Clinton. Mr. Packwood argued in the debate that Mr. Clinton's health-care ideas were closer to his own than to Mr. AuCoin's. Senator Bob Kasten of Wisconsin told The La Crosse Tribune on Friday "I am closer to Bill Clinton than Russ Feingold," his Senate opponent, on the economy and the death penalty.
But generally the tactic is one described by Don Totten, a veteran Republican Party official in Schaumburg, Ill., "I have noticed a number of candidates who have pictures taken with Bush but who have kept them on the shelf."
For example, there is Jennifer Dunn, a former Washington Republican chairman. In her Congressional primary this summer, she used a picture of Mr. Bush in a campaign brochure. No longer. Her campaign manager, John Meyers, said she had not "felt the need to keep using the picture."
But she has not cut all her ties to the White House. Her latest brochure has a picture of Barbara Bush, who, Ms. Dunn says, "represents my view on abortion, that the woman should make the decision."
