HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues -- Building and Rebuilding;
While Bush Is Satisfied on Public Works Spending, Opponents Call for More

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
While Ross Perot and Gov. Bill Clinton both call for increasing public works spending by tens of billions of dollars a year, President Bush insists that he has already done enough to expand Federal investment in what many economists call the foundation of the nation's economy: transportation routes, communications lines, waterworks and the like.
The Administration's commitment to cutting Federal spending and not raising taxes would lock into place the moderate rebuilding program put into effect during the first term. 
 The Clinton program, by contrast, calls for increasing spending on public works by additional $20 billion a year. Some of that money would come from tax increases and the rest from cuts in military spending.
 
A Philosophical Difference
 But the debate over "infrastructure" -- a word that campaign rhetoric traditionally pairs with the adjective "crumbling" -- goes well beyond the most evident question of how much money to spend.
The debate also casts light on a philosophical difference that divides President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle from Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore -- a split over shaping the nation's technological future.
The Democrats want to emphasize projects like high-speed intercity trains propelled by magnets, a computerized central nervous system wiring the nation together by fiber optics and pollution-control devices that might create a growth industry out of products designed to satisfy stringent environmental regulations here and abroad. The Republicans, loath to setting a national industrial policy, have only cautiously supported such ideas.
There are also differences about how to balance the Federal Government's role with that of states and private industry, although a close examination shows that the candidates' approaches are more similar in some ways than they are willing to admit as they try to display their differences.
 
Calls to Spend More On Public Works
 "Infrastructure," at its heart, means public works, and about half of the Federal Government's estimated $45 billion annual expenditure in this area is in transportation.
More than a dozen studies in as many years have called for substantial increases in this kind of spending. And an emerging common view is that the nation needs to spend about twice what it has been spending. The bulk of public works expenditures are at the state and local level, but the Federal Government plays a crucial role by providing seed money, matching grants, financing for interstate programs that are too big for local governments and incentives for private partnerships with government.
Public works spending has two important benefits: it creates jobs in the short term, although not immediately; and it enhances economic efficiency by driving down the costs of transportation, spurring growth and productivity over the long haul. Creating jobs gives public works spending considerable appeal in an election year, but economists consider the long-term benefits more important.
When it comes to transportation programs, the Bush Administration, by virtue of its incumbency, can claim to have a detailed prescription already in place. At the same time, Mr. Bush's opponents have not spelled out in much detail what they would do.
The Bush record, paradoxically, includes both new taxes and new spending on transportation. The President raised user fees like taxes on airplane tickets and gasoline to finance programs for air and ground transportation. Mr. Bush now says he would not do that again.
"The President has outlined a plan for transportation investment that Congress has adopted, and the states understand and want to implement," said Transportation Secretary Andrew H. Card Jr., who added that unlike the opposition the Administration has a proven track record.
But Gene Sperling, the Clinton campaign's economic coordinator, said: "If you think everything is fine, in terms of infrastructure maintenance and modernization, then you have your candidate. If you think we need new investment, need to think more to the future, toward the 21st-century equivalent of what highways were to the 20th century, then Bill Clinton is your candidate."
Mr. Card said that even if more money was made available, local governments could not use it quickly. But organizations of city and state leaders have said they have projects worth many billions of dollars ready to go, and only need money to get them started.
"Unless you get considerably more money, you can't do what needs to be done out there," said Francis B. Francois, executive director of the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, whose members come from both parties. "We hear Governor Clinton saying we should be doubling expenditures on the highway program. Yeah, that's about right. But the downside of that is, how do you do it, given the resources in the highway trust fund?" That fund collects gasoline-tax revenues and funnels them to the states in the form of transportation grants.
"The kind of action you need is probably the kind of thing that Mr. Perot is talking about," Mr. Francois added. "He says there should be a 10 cent increase in the fuel tax each year. That is the kind of funding we need, and he is the only one who is really talking about it. The reality of doing it is very, very difficult."
 
Increasing Spending, But by How Much?
 Mr. Perot says he would raise $158 billion over five years with gasoline taxes, spending most of it to rebuild highways, build high-tech transportation networks and an advanced telecommunications system. Beyond that, Mr. Perot has said little about the details of his plan.
Mr. Clinton's prescription, while not elaborately spelled out, is simple enough to state. He calls for adding $20 billion a year to the current Federal public works budget, using it not just on transportation but also communications and water projects. (Total Federal outlays for major public physical capital was $46.5 billion in fiscal 1992, including things like military construction, prisons and other Federal buildings, and other construction. Of that, $28 billion went into transportation.)
Mr. Clinton's actions would be somewhat easier than Mr. Perot's to predict, since they would probably include some programs that Senator Gore has backed while in Congress, notably a telecommunications program meant to link the nation's computers.
Mr. Bush's plan also calls for increases in spending, but the Administration points out that the transportation increases are already included over a six-year period by the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, which the Administration helped shepherd through Congress in 1991. (The Administration cannot claim sole authorship of the plan; it was drafted in close consultation with the Democratic Congress.)
That law increases spending to about $151 billion by 1996, and the Administration does not believe in expanding surface transportation spending beyond those levels.
The bill was criticized by some for emphasizing highways over mass transit. But it also won praise because it allowed local governments to shift much of the money from highways to mass transit at their discretion.
And although Democrats have criticized the Administration for not requesting as much money as it might have since the bill establishing and extending transportation programs was enacted, the Administration points out that Congress, in its spending bills, cut the President's budget request even further. That was done because the budget agreement did not permit shifting money from military programs to highways, as some in Congress wanted to do, and as Mr. Clinton has promised.
 
How the Candidates Would Pay for Plans
 The question of how to pay for public works projects helps differentiate the candidates' programs. Mr. Perot is the only one who would favor a big tax increase on gasoline.
The Administration, which generally favors making the users of public works projects pay as much of the costs as possible, agreed to a 5-cent-a-gallon tax increase on gasoline as a way of financing the transportation program now in effect. Future tax increases of this sort have all but been ruled out.
Governor Clinton would continue to use gasoline-tax revenues for highway programs, but his aides say he would not increase the fuel tax further to raise more money for public works.
Rather, the Clinton program envisions paying for rebuilding out of the general pool of tax revenues, which would be expanded mainly by increasing income taxes on people with high incomes and by increasing taxes on foreign corporations doing business in the United States. That has risks for the public works program, which would have to compete as a priority with other programs.
Mr. Clinton also says the savings achieved by his proposal to cut military spending more sharply than President Bush should be diverted to public works spending. He would divert $60 billion over five years in this way.
Economists say that spending on transportation and other public works projects typically creates more jobs than spending on military programs, so Mr. Clinton's proposal should help create jobs. But it is not likely that many people would move directly from, say, an aerospace plant to a bridge project, so the change might still be painful for many.
 
Making Industry More Competitive
 Job creation is just one reason for spending on public works. All the candidates agree that improving the efficiency of transportation, communications and the like will also make American industry more competitive.
One often-cited study says United States industrial productivity would have been 50 percent higher today if the nation had kept investment in highways, bridges and the like at the same level during the last 20 years, instead of allowing them to decline. Others say the cause-and-effect relationship cannot be proven.
According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which keeps data on developed countries, the United States spends a much lower percentage of its gross national product on public works than do other leading industrial nations.
But each of the candidates sees the vision of investing in prosperity through his own ideological filters.
For President Bush, the private sector's role is of crucial importance.
The Administration's national transportation policy emphasized this, encouraging, for example, the wider use of privately financed toll roads to ease traffic congestion. When it endorsed the development of high-speed rail projects in a few places around the country, something the Clinton campaign has effusively praised, it called for research studies but not a huge amount of Federal money. The rail systems would have to pay for themselves and should be run by private operators, the Administration suggested.
Mr. Clinton's camp speaks frequently of using Federal spending to "leverage" private investment, providing money up front for projects that could be financed in part through pension funds, as is suggested by the financier Felix G. Rohatyn. This is an extraordinarily complex proposition, but it has not escaped consideration by the Bush Administration, which under the transportation legislation has convened a commission to analyze just this sort of idea.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "CANDIDATES ON THE ISSUES: Rebuilding America"
 There is a broad consensus among experts that public spending on roads, water works, communications and the like must double. By doing that, the Government could create jobs in the short run, increase future productivity and developing new technologies. President Bush's commitment to reducing Federal spending and avoiding new taxes prevents him from promising big spending increases. Governor Clinton would sharply increase spending, switching military funds to these public programs and using part of the tax increases he has identified for this purpose. Ross Perot says he would steadily increase gasoline taxes to finance public works spending.
 
The Records
In his first term, Mr. Bush agreed to increase gasoline taxes and other fees to pay for investments in transportation. In 1991, the Administration pushed through Congress a bill allocating $151 billion over six years on surface transportation. Although the bill dedicated much of the money to Interstate highway improvements, it also authorized increased spending on mass transit while giving cities and states leeway to choose between highway spending and other forms of transportation.
In Arkansas, Mr. Clinton also increased gasoline taxes to pay for highway programs. His running mate, Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee, has been a leader in Congress in calling for new Federal investment in telecommunications, including a modernized network of computer lines to speed the flow of information around the nation.
 
Prospects
Mr. Bush argues that the program already in place for the next four years is adequate, and that states could not spend more than is being provided even if the Federal budget were increased.
Mr. Clinton believes that cities and states have already identified many worthwhile projects that are ready to go as soon as money is provided.
 
Scorecard
With the advantage of incumbency, Mr. Bush points out that he has already increased spending on transportation programs, which make up the bulk of Federal infrastructure spending. But his Administration has been much less willing to boost Federal spending for other types of public works, such as environmental controls.
Mr. Clinton's ideas are more in tune with those economists who contend that it is important to bolster public-sector investment. But this notion comes at a cost: If Public spending on transportation is increased, the deficit will not be reduced as quickly.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Voters;
AMERICANS SIGN UP IN RECORD NUMBERS TO CAST A BALLOT

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 18

 BODY:
After months of dismissing the Presidential campaign with a mix of cynicism and apathy, Americans have become invigorated by the race, registering to vote in record numbers and clinging to every word of the debates and election coverage.
Throughout the country, election officials say they are swamped by voter registration forms -- most enrolling as Democrats -- as well as by requests for absentee ballots and by their quick return. 
 Here in Bernadillo County, 10,000 people signed up in the last week of voter registration alone. Florida's Hillsboro County, which takes in Tampa, estimates an increase in registration of 60,000 voters since the March primary, more than twice the increase in the same period of the 1988 Presidential election. New Jersey reports the same huge rise over 1988's new registrations, in part because it now allows registration at state motor vehicle offices but mostly because of heightened voter interest.
 
'Overwhelming Response'
 The story is the same in cities and suburbs alike: Los Angeles ran out of its two million absentee ballots and had to print more. New York City has added 613,000 voters, bringing its rolls to 3.2 million, the highest in 20 years. In Snohomish County, Wash., north of Seattle, election officials are too busy even to come to the phone. "We are currently experiencing," a recording says, "an overwhelming response with regard to voter-registration cards and absentee ballots."
The voter interest plays out in other forums as well. On television, the first Presidential debate and the Vice-Presidential debate exceeded the ratings of the debates four years ago. In bookstores, sales are skyrocketing for a book by Ross Perot and another by Gov. Bill Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, that lay out plans for America's future. Both works are at or near the top of best-seller lists.
"After 20 years of steady voter decline, this is going to be the year when we'll turn it all around," said Pauline Kezer, the Secretary of State in Connecticut, where voter registration ends on Tuesday and is projected to be a record. "People are not coming to our tables mad and saying, 'I don't give a damn.' They're saying, 'Yeah, count me in.' "
Once again, voters are proving wrong the pundits, who had predicted loudly and often that voters' anger and disgust would lead them to pull back this election year, not dive in. Just what accounts for the enthusiasm is not fully clear. But in part, it seems driven by fear.
In interviews with voters around the country, they say they are scared about the economy. And in part, it stems from voters' belief that for the first time in more than a decade, they have a genuine choice between the Republican and the Democrat. Michael S. Dukakis, the 1988 Democratic candidate, is ridiculed in many interviews as a nonentity.
But perhaps the single biggest reason for the voter enthusiasm can be summed up in one name: Ross Perot. Most people say they are not going to vote for him. Yet over and over in interviews they make clear that he has awakened them, poking at their guilt and reminding them that control of the country really is theirs for the taking.
 
The Recently Registered
 "Perot may not be who people are going to vote for," said Fran Nover, the chief deputy clerk who oversees voter registration in Bernadillo County. "But he sure is who they're talking about."
Here on Friday at the Pantry Cafe on Route 66, the lunchtime conversation from table to table of blue- and white-collar workers was of politics, with some diners among those who had recently registered.
"I just got to the point where I lost interest over the years. But we registered two weeks ago," said 35-year-old Nancy Moya, pointing to two co-workers she was having lunch with. "Perot's right. We have to worry about the future. I have a couple of children."
Ms. Moya registered as a Democrat, as did her two friends, Mary Jojola and Patricia Shepard. All three of the women, who work in the business department of a local television station, said they would vote for Mr. Clinton.
Why Clinton? "Because he's young and cute," said a fourth office mate, Lila Trejo, 35.
With that, it was laughter all around.
"No, seriously, we need a change," said Ms. Shepard, 41, who last voted for Jimmy Carter. "There are homeless everywhere."
 
'Bush Doesn't Care'
 Ms. Jojola, 38, agreed. She had once been registered Republican but could not remember when she last voted. She registered two weeks ago as a Democrat. "Bush doesn't care about things here," she said. "He kept looking at his watch in the debate. He was bored."
Indeed, in a signal that does not bode well for President Bush, most of the new registrations throughout the country are Democratic, though they have increased for both parties, as well as for independents. Here in the Albuquerque area, Democratic rolls are up 20 percent, unaffiliated 16 percent and Republican 12 percent. Democrats have always outpaced Republicans in number of registrants here, but with the new registered voters the lead is greater. With 123,000 voters, Democrats now have a registration lead of 30,000 against Republicans, compared with 20,000 earlier in the year.
Polls show Mr. Clinton ahead in New Mexico, a state that has not voted Democratic in a Presidential election since 1964. Based on the return of absentee ballots, turnout on Election Day is expected to surpass 80 percent.
In California, even in Republican strongholds like Orange County, Democrats are outdoing Republicans in the registration of new voters. For the first time in 20 years in California, Democrats have registered more new voters than Republicans have -- albeit, by a small margin. Since June, Democrats have increased a percentage point, to 49 percent of registered voters, while Republicans have fallen a point, to just under 38 percent.
 
Expecting a High Turnout
 In every Presidential election year, voter interest tends to rise as Election Day nears. But this year, the rise has been greater. According to New York Times/CBS News polls, the number of registered voters paying "a lot" of attention to the race rose from 17 percent in January to 54 percent in October -- a figure that is likely to rise still more by Nov. 3. In 1988, the number rose from 13 percent in January to 45 percent just before Election Day.
Although higher registration does not necessarily turn into higher turnout, experts on voter behavior think it will this time. "All the indicators lead me to believe that" voter turnout will be high, said Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate.
In general, get-out-the vote efforts throughout the country have been extensive this year. "We're up to our knees," said Naomi Bernstein, a spokeswoman for New York City's Board of Elections, where stacks of 30,000 forms await processing. "Everybody is doing a voter-registration drive. Doctors are sending out registration forms with their bills."
Many of the efforts have been nonpartisan. For example, the ABC program "Good Morning America" has repeatedly broadcast deadlines for voter registration. But many others, while officially nonpartisan, have the effect of bringing in more Democratic than Republican voters. MTV, for example, has repeatedly run advertisements urging its viewers -- young, hip and mainly Democratic -- to vote. In the Chicago area, registration drives aimed primarily at blacks have signed up to 250,000 people since March 17.
 
'It's Exciting'
 After being out of influence for 12 years, liberal groups want the Democrats to win so badly that they can taste it, as their intensive registration efforts prove. In San Francisco, one of the country's liberal bastions, election official estimate a phenomenal 95 percent of eligible voters are now registered. Many of the new Democrats around the country are really old Democrats, some of them liberals from as far back as the 1960's, who had simply tuned out politics. Now, it is as if they have awakened from a long sleep.
"We have a lot to catch up on," said Andrew Shows, a 41-year-old art gallery owner here in Albuquerque who recently registered to vote. "The things we wanted to come together for years are coming together now. It's exciting. I feel at one with all the people who want social change."
Republican registration drives have been nowhere near as sweeping as the Democratic ones. Still, many Republicans sense their party under siege and are rallying. "Bush's values are a lot more in line with mine than Clinton's," said Charlie Love, 23, who works making elevators here. "Believe me, I'll vote."
And registration figures are not always what they may seem. Mr. Clinton spoke here recently at the University of New Mexico, where hundreds of students registered to voter. But not all of them are going to vote Democratic. "It looks like it's voting Republican for me," said Rob Haulenbeek, 18. "Clinton didn't say anything when he spoke here. He scares me."
For all the hoopla about the election -- all the talk and interest among voters -- there is little physical sign of it on the streets, except for conversations. In the San Francisco area, lawn signs dot neighborhoods and bumper stickers label cars. But elsewhere those are mostly few and far between, although signs for local elections are everywhere. It is as if the Presidential race this time out is too important to be cheapened by signs.
"This election is on a whole different level," said Anita Lopez, 35, the supervising probation officer at Federal court here. "It's much more serious, I think because of Perot. You get the feeling that this time, it's not a game."

HEADLINE: WESTFIELD JOURNAL;
Student Newspaper Finds Bottom Line Is a Hard One

DATELINE: WESTFIELD, N.J.

 BODY:
SADDLED with a $7,700 debt and the weight of a nearly 60-year tradition, the staff of this community's high school newspaper is learning the hard way that even a free press can be expensive.
The Westfield Hi's Eye is one of only a handful of high school newspapers in the country that is published weekly, a distinction compounded by the fact that the paper is entirely student-managed and receives no money from the local school board. 
 But the deficit the four-page tabloid has amassed over the last several years, if not reduced considerably by the end of the year, will mean an end to its weekly publication next fall. The students have been told that to continue weekly publishing, they must raise the money themselves without borrowing from student accounts.
Though cutting back publication would break a revered local tradition, school officials say the change may be necessary to honor another tradition, that of uncensored journalism, which the Westfield students have practiced since the first Hi's Eye was published in 1934.
"I like to say we have a longer history of free press here than in most countries," said the high school's principal, Robert Petix. "Once the school board comes in and gives the money, you can no longer guarantee they won't have an influence over what the students publish."
Of nearly 28,000 public and private high schools in the country, 70 percent publish student newspapers. Of those, fewer than 5 percent publish weekly and most of the rest publish monthly, said Tom Rolnicki, executive director of the National Scholastic Press Association in Minneapolis.
"They're a rare breed and getting rarer," Mr. Rolnicki said, adding that an entirely student-financed newspaper is "especially unusual."
School officials say the Hi's Eye debt reflects the larger problems faced today by small newspapers, many of which are facing cutbacks, redesigns and closings as a result of declining advertising revenue and circulation. In many ways, officials say, the student newspaper is yet another casualty of a troubled economy.
In Westfield, the circulation of Hi's Eye has fallen as the "baby boom" trailed off in the last decade and the school's enrollment fell. The number of students dropped from a high of 2,300 to 1,250, even after the school expanded to include the ninth grade. Now, the newspaper's circulation stands at about 800.
During that time, expenses rose while the advertising rate stayed flat. And the deficit has been passed along for years, always leaving the next class accountable.
"This year, we finally acknowledge the problem," said Lori Chelius, a senior who is one of three editors at The Hi's Eye. "Once we pay it off, we'll work on making sure it doesn't happen again."
School officials believe the newspaper's attempts to erase the debt is as much a part of the students' journalism training as writing editorials.
"In a real newspaper, they would have to pay the debt or close," said the newspaper's faculty adviser, Charles Soriano. "Nobody would bail them out."
Mr. Soriano believes the staff can meet their challenge. "They have pride in this tradition. They know this is something other schools don't have."
This year's goal is to raise $3,000 above the approximately $15,000 required to publish. Money is raised through sponsorships and advertising, which has grown to such an extent that recent issues have only had space for one news story beyond the front page.
The students, who also have plans for fund-raisers like a rake-a-thon, are optimistic. The 28-member Hi's Eye staff, which is drawn from a journalism program at the high school, is propelled by pride in their tradition of aggressive, uncensored journalism.
After attending a statewide Student Press Association meeting last week, Amanda Kong, a junior and one of the three editors this year, said she realized Westfield was doing something unusual.
"It's a really good feeling to see how other papers have a sense of respect for you," Ms. Kong said. As Westfield prepared to publish its seventh edition of the school year last week, she said, other schools in the area had not yet published one.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record;
Arkansas Struggles to Deal With Rising Health-Care Costs for Poor

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Even as Gov. Bill Clinton promises a sweeping expansion of health-insurance programs in his Presidential campaign, his own state is cutting health-care benefits for poor people and payments to doctors in its Medicaid program.
To the Bush Administration, the moves reflect a basic incompatibility between what the Arkansas Governor advocates on the campaign trail and what he does as chief executive in Little Rock. 
 To Mr. Clinton, however, Arkansas's struggle to meet the soaring cost of its medical program simply underscores the need for the kind of radical changes in health care that he has proposed for the entire nation.
Arkansas's experience illustrates the agony of many states reeling under the burden of Medicaid, the program for low-income people financed jointly by the Federal Government and the states. The cost of the Arkansas program shot up $207 million this year, to $912 million, as the number of recipients rose 31,958, to a total of 311,015.
When the program ran short of money earlier this year, employees of the state's Department of Human Services were furloughed for five days to alleviate the crisis.
 
New Limits on Payouts
 In other cost-cutting moves this year, Arkansas cut Medicaid payments to doctors and dentists by 20 percent, imposed new limits on prescription drugs, home health care, doctors' visits and other services, and reduced the number of hospital days covered. It also made fewer people eligible by lowering the cutoff level of income -- 33 percent above the poverty level, compared with 85 percent above the poverty level in the past. For example, a family of three can qualify for Medicaid only if its income is below $14,444, while the same family could have earned $20,091 under the old rules.
A confidential memorandum, written in June by Kenny Whitlock, a senior official in the Arkansas Department of Human Services, acknowledged that many of the cuts "will severely impact our most vulnerable clients."
In August, a Federal judge blocked the reduction in Medicaid fees for obstetricians and pediatricians, saying it could irreparably harm pregnant women and young children by curtailing access to medical care. In issuing a preliminary injunction, Judge Susan Webber Wright of the Federal District Court in Little Rock said the new payment rates were so low that Arkansas doctors were quitting Medicaid.
Dr. E. Michael Finan, who works at a clinic in Hot Springs, testified that the cut in payments "forced us to cease rendering prenatal care to Medicaid recipients, leaving hundreds of pregnant women to find the care elsewhere." Nancy C. Chrisman, the administrator of a women's clinic in Jonesboro, said it stopped taking new Medicaid patients for four or five weeks in July and August after the state cut payments for obstetrical care by 20 percent.
Bush Administration officials say the problems of the Medicaid program in Arkansas result, in part, from mismanagement by Governor Clinton. They say he makes the same error on a bigger scale when he underestimates the cost of his proposal to cover 35 million uninsured Americans.
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said in August: "Bill Clinton can't even control the Medicaid costs in his own state. Now, the thought of him therefore trying to reform the nation's health-care system is certainly enough to make me sick."
 
State Reflects National Ills
 But Arkansas officials say their woes reflect national problems. President Bush, they say, failed to rein in medical costs, and the number of people on Medicaid soared because of the nation's economic slump.
Moreover, Arkansas officials say it is hypocritical of Federal officials to attack them for trying to balance the state budget when the Federal Government, under Mr. Bush, is running record budget deficits.
"Federal officials have no standing to criticize our fiscal management because their record is much worse," Ray Hanley, director of the Arkansas Medicaid program, said in an interview. "At least we operate under a balanced budget."
States have wide discretion in deciding the scope of Medicaid benefits and setting payment levels, subject to Federal approval. The Bush Administration recently rejected some of Arkansas's new limits on prescription drugs and home health services, saying they would violate a Federal law that guarantees a minimum set of benefits.
As the Democratic candidate for President, Mr. Clinton promises universal coverage: health insurance for all through employers, through groups formed to buy private insurance for nonworkers or through Medicare, the Federal program for the elderly.
 
Need to Control Costs
 Mr. Clinton says the nation cannot afford universal access to health care until it gets health costs under control, and he wants to set an overall limit on health spending, with a separate limit for each state. "That's a prerequisite," said Mr. Hanley, the Arkansas Medicaid director, who added that the Legislature would have to consider a tax increase for Medicaid next year.
Under Federal law, state Medicaid programs must cover certain services like hospital care, doctors' services, X-rays and family planning. States may provide any of more than 30 optional services like prescription drugs, eyeglasses, optometry and dental care.
As part of its cost-cutting campaign, Arkansas recently eliminated many optional services for adults.
Nationwide, Medicaid finances health care for 30 million Americans, including 14 million children. States together pay 43 percent of the program's total cost of more than $127 billion this year. The state share rises with a state's per-capita income and ranges from 20 percent in the poorest state, Mississippi, to 50 percent in the most affluent states.
Arkansas is one of the poorer states. With a median household income of $23,435 in 1991, it ranked 48th among the 50 states, trailed by West Virginia and Mississippi.
A major goal of Medicaid is to increase access to health care for poor people. Medicaid payments are supposed to be high enough to guarantee that care is as available to poor as to the general population.
After receiving testimony from Arkansas residents who had difficulty getting treatment for serious medical problems, Judge Wright concluded that the state appeared to be violating the equal-access requirement.
State officials insist that their actions were legal because no Medicaid recipient was "placed in a life-threatening situation as a direct result of the July 1, 1992, rate reductions."

HEADLINE: Bankers Sour on Economy, but Not Profits

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Most of the nation's bankers do not expect the economy to recover sharply in 1993 from its doldrums, but they are bullish about profits next year, according to a poll today of some 1,500 members of the American Bankers Association.
Of the bankers surveyed at the industry's annual meeting here, 78 percent said they expected their regions' economies in 1993 to be stable, with little growth or at most a slight improvement. Only 13 percent expected a strong economy in their regions next year, and 9 percent expected their area's economies to weaken. 
 But asked whether their banks would earn more next year than this year, 59 percent said they would do better, 15 percent said worse and 26 percent saw no change.
At meeting today, the bankers also heard John LaWare, a Federal Reserve Governor, call for a private study on modernizing the nation's banking system to break the long political logjam that has blocked efforts to reform the industry.
His call for a major overhaul of the banking system "before it is too late" was welcome news to bankers who are conducting trench warfare against government regulations.
"We are choking on paperwork," said Alan Tubbs, the association's president and head of the Maquoketa State Bank in Iowa.
The bankers gave Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady a cool reception today as he pledged to prune the industry's regulations. By the end of his 20-minute speech, nearly a third of the audience had left the hall at the Hynes Convention Center in downtown Boston, the site of the four-day annual event, which began Saturday.

HEADLINE: Economic Memo;
Administration Is Playing Blame Game on Recession

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
In unceremoniously announcing last week that it would dump its three top economic policy makers, the White House tried to lay the blame for the worst four years of growth since the Great Depression on the President's lieutenants.
But economists, Democratic and Republican, liberal and conservative, pin a large chunk of responsibility for the prolonged slump on President Bush and on another set of advisers, his political team, for ducking the tough, politically unpopular decisions that would help restore the economy's health. 
 The three economic officials -- Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers -- have long insisted that the blame lies elsewhere. They point the finger at Congress, the Federal Reserve, the global slowdown, the debt-plagued consumer, banks refusing to lend and corporations laying off workers.
Despite their protestations that they worked hard to create incentives for growth and to slash the budget deficit, growth has averaged an anemic seven-tenths of 1 percent over the last four years and the deficit soared to a record $320 billion in fiscal 1992.
To be sure, there is no scientific way to assess who deserves how much of the blame for the economy's woes. Certainly there were external factors, like the worldwide slowdown, but, most economists agree, the President, his political team and his economic troika share in the blame.
 
Dropped the Ball
 At many times and in many ways, it is generally agreed, the Bush Administration dropped the ball on the economy. While Secretary Brady, Mr. Darman and Mr. Boskin are awarded high marks in several areas, the Administration often receives low marks for not attacking the deficit as soon as Mr. Bush took office, for never getting an anti-recession plan enacted this year and for not developing and articulating an overall growth strategy until the re-election campaign.
"They could have protected themselves from some of the worst consequences of things happening in the economy, if they had a growth strategy of their own," William Niskanen, president of the conservative Cato Institute and a member of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, said. "But they never put together an overall strategy until the President's speech last month in Detroit."
In essence, Mr. Bush and his economic and political teams are proving victims of their own ideology -- they believe in a hands-off approach to economics.
To all the pleas, advice and recommendations from voters and experts that the Administration needs to take a hands-on approach, Administration officials often respond, "Just what are we supposed to do that won't make matters worse?"
Sometimes it seems Administration officials are so convinced that economic activism will have ill effects that their conviction paralyzes them. Early this year, for example, dozens of prominent economists called on President Bush to embrace a multibillion-dollar pump-priming plan to create jobs and speed growth.
But Administration officials reflexively shudder at such a Keynesian notion, insisting that fiscal stimulus will aggravate the deficit, push up long-term interest rates and be squandered on pork-barrel projects.
In January 1989, the month President Bush took office, he clearly made a big mistake by not attacking the budget deficit with gusto, most economists agree. If he had, they say, then the economy would not be in deep mud today.
Administration officials say Mr. Darman, who was willing to swallow higher taxes, and Mr. Boskin, who backed a flexible freeze on spending, were eager to tackle the deficit early on. But the President, his former chief of staff, John Sununu, and his political advisers quashed the idea.
 
 
'Great Opportunity'
 "When he came into office he was faced with a great opportunity," Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution and an official in the Carter Administration, said. "He had a very strong economy, which is the right time to attack the budget deficit. I fundamentally hold Bush guilty for passing up that opportunity. The game was lost when he made his 'no new taxes' pledge."
Tackling the deficit early on might have prevented the recession that began in the summer of 1990 and at worst would have cushioned it. And that would have enabled the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates in 1989 rather than raising them out of fears of economic overheating.
But Mr. Bush did not get serious about the deficit until the middle of 1990, when he was forced into it. But then, the 1990 budget agreement, which cut spending and increased taxes, helped pull down the economy when it was already sliding toward recession.
Droll is the word some critics use when they hear Bush Administration officials say that if only they had not inherited a huge deficit from President Reagan, the economy would be in infinitely better shape today. Such an excuse seems to forget that Mr. Bush signed on to Reaganomics when he was Vice President and ran on a Reaganomics platform in 1988. "He was Vice President back then, and he has to take some responsibility for the terrible mistakes made during the early 1980's," Isabel Sawhill, an economist with the Urban Institute, said.
 
Democratic Flak
 Now, in the heat of the campaign, the Administration faces heavy Democratic flak for hardly lifting a finger to fight the recession, and even some conservatives agree. "I think they deserve some blame for not taking more action to help the economy in 1992," Herbert Stein, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Nixon, said.
Administration officials insist that they worked vigorously for a growth package, pointing to the plan the President trumpeted in January. That package included a cut in the capital gains tax, an investment tax credit and a tax credit for first-time home buyers.
"We have put forward a growth package that we think will stimulate savings and investment and help entrepreneurial capitalism and small business, but that plan has been stopped by Congress," one senior Treasury official said.
Many critics of the Administration say that package foundered because of the Administration's fixation on a capital gains tax cut. Many Democrats embraced the proposed investment tax credit and home buyers' credit, but they enacted higher taxes on the wealthy to offset the gains a capital gains tax cut would mean for the well-off. The President vetoed the anti-recession package because of that tax increase.
In effect, the Administration's insistence on capital gains tax cuts torpedoed the growth package. But Mr. Bush's political advisers warned him not to jettison the capital gains measure to rescue the package, saying hard-right conservatives, like Representative Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia and the minority whip, might mutiny.
Still, Mr. Bush's allegiance to capital gains tax cuts was not enough to prevent many conservatives from castigating his economic policies. Conservative think tanks often said the President talked a good ball game about cutting spending, but acted like a Democrat in letting spending scamper upward. For this, they pin much of the blame on Mr. Darman.
 
'He Hired Them'
 "The only individual more responsible for the economic mess than his three top economic officials was George Bush himself," Edward L. Hudgins, deputy director of economic policy at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization, said. "He hired them in the first place, and he kept them on."
Traditionally, the maestro of economic policy is the Treasury Secretary. As a result, many critics say Mr. Brady, more than other economic officials, deserves blame for sins of omission and commission.
One big strike against Mr. Brady was that lacked the charisma of his predecessor, James A. Baker 3d, who became Secretary of State and is now the President's chief of staff. Still, Mr. Brady is widely praised for forging the legislative package to clean up the savings-and-loan mess and for helping bring the third world debt crisis under control.
As for Mr. Boskin, he was the junior member of the policy-making trio. Many economists note that he never had the power of Mr. Sununu or Mr. Darman; Mr. Boskin threatened to resign last year when the President and his political advisers ignored his downbeat readings on the economy, worrying that the President's happy talk made him sound out of touch with Main Street.
Yet however much economists criticize Mr. Brady, Mr. Darman and Mr. Boskin, they sympathize with them, too. "The way these three economic leaders were tossed over the side of the ship was really shameful," Mr. Stein, the Nixon Administration official, said.

HEADLINE: Europe's Blitz on U.S. Earnings

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
As European currencies churned and heads of state squabbled a few weeks ago, the United States calmly stood back, an ocean away from the turmoil.
For America's largest manufacturers, however, the United States now seems like an unsafe haven from European recessions and currency woes. Companies like Ford and I.B.M., which depend heavily on Europe, have begun reporting pinched profits and crimped sales. 
 Many economists and analysts warn that for such companies the worst is yet to come. Most of the major European economies were already in recessions or on the brink before the currency crisis exploded and customers ran for cover, avoiding even purchases they had planned.
"People froze," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers. "Firms could plot it -- it was like falling off a cliff."
 
'People Just Stopped Buying'
 The International Business Machines Corporation, for example, last week blamed a sudden halt in European orders as the prime reason that its third-quarter operating earnings of $86 million came in at only 20 percent of what had been expected.
"I did not anticipate -- and by the way, I think I'm probably in pretty good company -- the effect on business of the enormous currency turmoil that took place in Europe," Frank Metz, the company's senior vice president for finance, told analysts. "People just stopped buying things."
Europe's somewhat unified, somewhat fractured economy is the largest foreign market for American goods, and the principal foreign host of American plants. Many of the best-known companies, the General Motors Corporation among them, in recent years have often been more profitable in Europe than the United States.
Exports, bolstered by a weak dollar that lowers the prices of goods sent abroad, have for much of this year been one of the few sources of United States economic growth. But in August, according to the latest trade figures, American shipments to Europe and the rest of the world were down sharply from the previous month. Lower exports can both retard the recovery and batter some stock prices, Mr. Shulman said.
 
Revising Estimates Downward
 Few economists expect Europe's economy to resume growing before the second half of next year, if then. Among American companies, they say, the makers of automobiles, chemicals, computers and other electronics will be the hardest hit. Analysts are grinding out lower earnings estimates as fast as their secretaries can work the fax machines.
Besides I.B.M., with 40 percent of its sales in Europe, other vulnerable makers of office equipment include the Xerox Corporation, also at 40 percent, and the Unisys Corporation, where total foreign sales are 60 percent, said Daniel Mandresh, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.
The Ford Motor Company also startled investors by saying that slow European business -- with the British market the worst in 40 years -- would leave the company with losses through the end of the year.
Harvey Heimbach, an auto industry analyst at Merrill Lynch, returned from the recent auto show in Paris with word that European auto companies were warning of a weaker 1993 there than Americans who follow the industry had expected. "The outlook is, it's going to get worse before it gets better," he said.
Although General Motors reaps only 21 percent of its sales in Europe, compared with 31 percent at Ford, G.M. has been more dependent on European earnings to offset large losses in the United States, Mr. Heimbach said. The Chrysler Corporation is the least vulnerable, with relatively low sales there.
 
Other Industries at Risk
 The fourth quarter will show the full effects of canceled and postponed orders, Mr. Shulman of Salomon Brothers said. Besides makers of autos and computers, he said, many aluminum, paper and chemical companies risk earnings disappointment.
The major chemical companies, which account for the largest trade surplus of any American industry, achieve between 20 and 35 percent of their sales in Europe. Few have been safe from the blows to earnings estimates delivered by Harvey S. Stober of Dean Witter, recently back from a trip there. "Du Pont we did several weeks ago," he said Friday. "PPG we did this morning. Dow we did a couple weeks ago, Monsanto we have done too."
The food, beverage and tobacco makers are relatively safe from European calamity; recession-bound consumers can still afford a soda or a smoke. But for the third quarter, even the Coca-Cola Company reported double-digit volume declines in some European markets.
Some analysts see falling European interest rates reviving the region and American earnings there next year. But Stephen Cooney, director of international investment and finance at the National Association of Manufacturers, tempers his optimism so much that he sounds almost morose.
"I don't think the future looks too bad," he said, stopping to ponder it. "But I can't predict when the future will arrive."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Election Day Initiatives May Affect Bond Issues

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
In the tax-exempt bond market, traders and investors face political uncertainty even beyond the outcome of the Presidential election. At the state and local level, there are numerous spending and taxing initiatives that could affect the credit outlook for the state and local governments, which would have a major impact on bonds.
There are also about $10 billion in bond issues on state and local ballots that are waiting for the thumbs-up or thumbs-down from the voters. 
 The impact of the spending initiatives, like those awaiting voter decisons in Colorado and Michigan, would be limited to the bonds from the particular state. But the concern is great enough that the credit-rating agencies are closely monitoring the contests for their potential effect on local credit ratings. Investors, too, must proceed with caution. Already in Colorado there is a rush to get issues sold before Election Day.
And while the defeat or approval of billions of dollars in new bond issues is not likely to have an immediate influence on the municipal market, the results will provide a sense of voter sentiment that could affect the longer-term flow of bond issues, said James Cooner, a senior vice president at the Bank of New York.
 
A Vote on Spending Limits
 In Colorado, the initiative in question, known locally as the Taxpayer Bill of Rights, would limit both increases in spending and revenue at the state and the local level to the rate of inflation. Surpassing these ceilings would require advance voter approval.
Because the Colorado proposal would limit the flexibility of govenment to manage its fiscal affairs, "we are very concerned about it," said Ditmar Kopf, assistant vice president at Moody's Investors Service, the credit-rating agency.
Moody's said the proposal might not affect existing bonds. But the firm said in an analysis that "passage could seriously erode the credit quality of local governments because of the severe financial and debt management restrictions which would be imposed, as well as the uncertainty created by portions of the proposal."
 
Property Taxes in Michigan
 In Michigan, two proposals on the ballot could impair the credit rating of new bonds from state and local governments, some analysts say. One measure would cut by 30 percent the property taxes that pay for school operating costs and would limit growth in property tax assessments to 3 percent, or to the inflation rate if it is lower than 3 percent.
A second, competing, measure, which was placed on the ballot by the Legislature, would limit all property-tax assessment increases to 5 percent or the rate of inflation, whichever is lower. In the event both proposals are approved, the one with the most votes prevails.
 
Bond Votes' Negative Trend
 Regarding the actual proposed bond issues on the ballot, Mr. Cooner of the Bank of New York said that if the trend of the last two years continued, a major portion of the bonds on the ballot will be defeated. In 1990, 59 percent of the dollar value of state and local bonds were defeated and in 1991, 52 percent were defeated. These setbacks came after voters approved nearly 90 percent of the dollar value of bonds on the ballot between 1982 and 1989.
Mr. Cooner said the higher level of defeats the last two years indicated that voters "equated new bond sales today with increased taxes in the future." What is more, he said, "voting negatively on bond issues was a way of expressing dissatisfaction with state and local financial operations."
The $10 billion in ballot proposals is small compared with the total $200 billion of new state and local tax-exempt issues this year. But Mr. Cooner said that a defeat of many of them would be a good indicator of "voter comfort or discomfort with bond sales in the future."
Of the $10 billion, about half are on the ballot in California, including $1.9 billion in state general obligation bonds and $1.5 billion in bonds to be issued by Los Angeles. There is also an $800 million State of New York bond issue on the ballot and a $345 million proposal on the state ballot in New Jersey.
 
The Clinton Factor
 The Presidential election will have an additional impact on the municipal bond market if the Arkansas Governor, Bill Clinton, wins. His tax-increase proposal, which would raise taxes on people with incomes of $200,000 and higher, could drive more investors into the tax-exempt municipal market as they seek shelter from higher tax rates, analysts say.
As of now, a tax-exempt bond with a coupon of 6 percent has an after-tax equivalent yield of 8.69 percent. If the current 31 percent top tax rate rises to 36 percent, the after-tax yield for a 6 percent bond jumps to 9.37 percent.
"That is significant," said Clark Wagner, the portfolio manager for municipal bond funds at First Investment Management Company in New York. Although he argued that many of these high-income investors already have their money in tax-exempt municipal bonds, he said the tax increase surely would not hurt the municipal market.
But the election itself, if Governor Clinton wins, may swamp the reverberations from these other Election Day issues.
What investors are most afraid of right now, just over two weeks before Election Day, is Mr. Clinton's promise of a spending package to stimulate the faltering economy.
While investors may want a stronger economy, the resulting rise in the budget deficit and the threat of higher interest rates and rising inflation that it might bring is a cold shower for the entire bond market, from municipals to Treasuries.
But given the fall in the prices of municipal and Treasury bonds recently, including the 3/16 -point drop in the 30-year Treasury on Friday, much of the threat of a Clinton stimulus program may have already been priced into the market.
"Judging from the market reaction, it appears that they have thrown in the towel on Bush," Mr. Wagner said Friday, the morning after the second televised Presidential debate.

HEADLINE: Mr. Perot Presents Some Beef

 BODY:
Ross Perot's advertising blitz over the weekend was cause for admiration, regret and frustration. Admiration because he gave viewers a high-minded seminar on America's fiscal problems, and because he offered a serious and mostly honest program to address those problems.
Regret because Mr. Perot's ideas would surely have challenged his opponents and elevated the tone of the campaign -- if only he had presented them earlier and not cravenly quit the race in July when his candidacy had credibility. 
 Frustration because Mr. Perot insists even now on presenting his detailed remedies in hermetically sealed TV studios, avoiding cross-examination. In the public debates, by contrast, the man who professes to hate sound bites has spoken exclusively in brief and unenlightening generalities.
Almost all the ideas outlined by Mr. Perot in 30 minutes on NBC Friday and in a one-hour ABC broadcast on Saturday are in his book, "United We Stand: How We Can Take Back Our Country" -- a damning indictment of how America's $4 trillion debt has inhibited productive investment and burdened future generations. The television programs presented the numbers in greater detail.
Those numbers add up to a $754 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts that, Mr. Perot says, would yield a Federal budget surplus in six years. Answering critics, Mr. Perot took pains to say that the program could be phased in in ways that would not add to the woes of the current sluggish economy.
Mr. Perot's first priority is to reduce the deficit. He therefore offers far less than Gov. Bill Clinton does in terms of public investment to generate long-term economic growth. Still, on the deficit issue alone, Mr. Perot is much more credible than Mr. Bush, who won't raise taxes at all, and Mr. Clinton, whose spending and revenue projections are wildly optimistic.
His folksy presentation and impressive charts contained two evasions. First, $141 billion in savings comes from containing health care costs. But Mr. Perot did not say how he would do that. Second, he suggested that most of the deficit reduction would come from spending cuts.
Not so, according to the National Center for Policy Analysis. Many of Mr. Perot's "cuts" are in fact higher taxes, including stiffer Medicare taxes and premiums and increased taxes on benefits for upper-income Social Security recipients.
Otherwise, Mr. Perot spoke plainly. The man who once said he could end the deficit "without breaking a sweat" left no doubt that the job would require not just sweat but pain.
The question that his critics have asked him from the beginning, however, still applies: Does he have the courage to test his convictions in the political arena? The courage to allow the two men who have stayed the course from the beginning to examine him? Tonight's debate, the last of this campaign, could provide an answer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Clinton Health Plan Covers All Americans

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Bush-Clinton Health Reform" (editorial, Oct. 10) finally recognizes that Gov. Bill Clinton has long embraced the principle of competition in delivery of health care. But you continue to ignore enormous differences between the reform proposal advanced by Governor Clinton and that of President Bush. 
 Governor Clinton has pledged to secure universal financial access to health care for all Americans. President Bush's plan would leave roughly 20 million uninsured.
Governor Clinton embraces a national health-care budget that would contain growth of health-care costs. Limiting cost growth would spare the millions of insured Americans the fear they will lose benefits in the future. While President Bush's plan might achieve small, one-time savings, it does nothing to slow the continuing growth of health-care costs.
You do well to celebrate the joint adherence of Governor Clinton and President Bush to principles of competition. But you do a disservice to obscure the fundamental choice on reform of health care financing the American people face on election day.
 
HENRY J. AARON, ROBERT M. BALL
Washington, Oct. 12, 1992
The writers are, respectively, director of economic studies, Brookings Institution, and former commissioner of Social Security.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Magazine Ads Push Computer Commercials Out of the Picture

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
When Apple Computer Inc. ran its eye-popping "1984" commercial introducing the Macintosh during the 1984 Super Bowl, the controversial Chiat/Day ad set off a buying frenzy. When retail stores opened the next day, $6.5 million worth of Macintoshes were sold within four hours.
But changes in the market in the last several years have sharply altered the way in which personal computers are advertised today. 
 As personal computers have become commodities, an influx of new and hungry competitors, price wars and new sales channels have conspired to funnel market share away from leaders like I.B.M. and Apple. Long-running campaigns, like the hugely successful "Little Tramp" campaign for I.B.M., have become a thing of the past.
Promoting brand awareness has given way to product-specific advertising, and companies have for the most part abandoned television in favor of specialty publications with devoted readers.
 
A Big Decline
 Broadcast ad spending by personal computer makers fell to $30 million by the end of 1991, from $125 million in 1988, according to the Capra Research Group in Los Altos, Calif.
Personal computer makers discovered that most buyers made their decisions with help from PC Magazine, PC World, PC Week, Infoworld or any of the 400 other computer-related publications.
The telephone book-sized PC Magazine, for example, published 21 percent of all advertising for personal computers in 1991, or a total of $89 million worth. In 1988, the advertising totaled only $20 million.
"This is not the same as reading Time or Newsweek where the reader's interest is divorced from any advertising," said Marian White, vice president of research at Ziff-Davis, which publishes PC Magazine. "Every one of our readers is looking for something he is going to buy."
 
Detailed Product Information
 There are an estimated 60 million personal computers in business and home offices, and sophisticated buyers want advertising with detailed product information -- and plenty of it. "PC companies today are using advertising to close the sale," said Ted Voss, an advertising consultant with Creative Marketing Inc. in New York, who has worked with NEC Technologies and the International Business Machines Corporation.
The target buyers are information systems managers and technically savvy department managers who purchase personal computers, said Kelly Conlin, vice president of marketing at the International Data Group, publisher of PC World, Macworld and Computerworld.
In order to present so much information, many personal computer makers have abandoned the single- or double-page advertisement in favor of multipage full-color inserts, often with 12 pages of advertising.
"In the good old days, a full-color ad broke the clutter," said Gian Carlo Bisone, vice president of North American marketing for the Compaq Computer Corporation. "Now if you don't have a 20-page insert, you're just part of the noise."
And traditional advertising campaigns that might last for years have all but been abandoned by personal computer makers. "There are no campaigns today," said Grant Schneider, vice president of corporate communications at NEC Technologies Inc. in Boxborough, Mass. The market shifts too fast for that.
"The technology is changing so rapidly, you can't stick to any one particular campaign," he said. "You have to give the impression you are moving."
For I.B.M. and Apple, the recession forced severe cutbacks in advertising spending. According to Capra Research, I.B.M. reduced its advertising spending for personal computers to $32 million last year from $69 million in 1988, while Apple's spending dropped to $27 million from $48 million. Both companies are increasing their ad spending this year, however, particularly I.B.M., which is starting a separate business unit, the IBM Personal Computer Company.
Meanwhile, startup companies like Dell Computer, Zeos International and Gateway 2000 fueled explosive growth of their I.B.M.-compatible computers through bargain pricing, direct-mail promotions and extensive advertising in trade publications. The ads focused on price and product comparisons to I.B.M. or Compaq and boasted of faster and better delivery and service.

GRAPHIC: Photo: I.B.M.'s "Little Tramp" ads, left, were successful in the 1980's, but now companies like Dell are mainly emphasizing price and performance.

International
France sought to dampen hopes of an early breakthrough in world trade talks, arguing that the Bush Administration was in no position to close a deal before the Presidential election. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 MORGAN STANLEY
 STAYING IN NEW YORK
The Morgan Stanley Group, the financial services company that had been considering moving its New York City headquarters and as many as 4,100 employees to Stamford, Conn., will remain in the city for at least 10 years, company officials said. The city and state have agreed to $40 million in tax credits and other incentives over the next decade to help keep the company in New York, the officials said. A1.
 
 REDEFINING THE FAMILY
The traditional American family, a largely mythical political icon in the first place, has declined so far in New York City that married couples living with their own children now constitute only 1 in 6 households. The trend is neither new nor peculiar to New York. But a new analysis of the 1990 census has found that the typical family has been radically redefined. A1.
 
 THE EMBATTLED BOARD
The squabbling on the Board of Education took two new twists: the majority faction acknowledged that it had sought advice from a political consultant, while the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation warned that the infighting could affect how much money he will turn over to the schools. B3.
 
 In tight financial times, guidance counselors feel the pinch. B3.

 NEW ATTACK
ON CAR THEFT
The New Jersey State Senate unanimously approved a five-bill package to treat automobile theft and the ramming of police cars as serious crimes rather than juvenile pranks. The legislation, aimed primarily at Newark, where car theft by teen-agers has been at epidemic proportions, imposes mandatory sentences for thefts and "joyriding" in stolen vehicles. B6.
 
 AN ADULT APPROACH TO LEARNING
The poor economy has taken its toll on class rolls, but adult education programs -- with roots in the Americanization classes for immigrants 75 years ago -- remain popular. In the last decade, enrollment nationwide has doubled, to 15 million, with baby boomers and retired people signing up at colleges, public schools or independent programs for everything from acrylic folk art to yoga. Most commuters in central Westchester County are happy with the service on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, according to a survey conducted by Assemblyman Peter M. HEADLINE: Bond Rating For Nassau Is Lowered

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 19

 BODY:
After months of fiscal instability and political deadlock, the rating on $1.3 billion in Nassau County bonds was dropped two levels today, to the lowest investment-grade rating, and the lowest level in the county's history.
In lowering the rating, officials at Moody's Investors Service said that after months of inaction because of a "protracted and contentious political stalemate" the county was within six to eight weeks of running out of cash to pay its bills, unless it acted soon. 
 "There has been no ability of the different parties to move toward a meeting of the minds, there has simply been no program," said Michael Johnston, a senior vice president and manager at the rating agency "The political dispute at this stage appears to have no answer."
 
A Stunning Reversal
 It was a stunning reversal for one of the most affluent counties in the nation, where officials took turns for years bashing the fiscally troubled city to the west, with warnings of the "New York Citification" of the quality of life here.
The new rating of Baa, down from A, is a notch lower than New York City's current rating and is lower than any rating the city has had since 1985.
The rating -- the second downgrade in Nassau County this year -- is the lowest of any county in the metropolitan area, and the lowest for Nassau since Moody's began rating county bonds in 1938. In New York State, only three small upstate counties -- Cattaraugus, Oneida, Sullivan -- have the same rating.
County officials said that the downgrading could cost the county as much as $4 million in interest and insurance costs on $103 million in bonds scheduled for sale on Tuesday and "tens of millions more in the future," according to a statement by the county.
Republicans and Democrats on the county's board of supervisors responded to the latest news with recriminations, including pre-emptive news conferences and press statements, hours before the announcement was made.
Thomas S. Gulotta, the County Executive who has made New York City-bashing a staple of his campaigns, placed the blame for the downgrading on a Democratic Supervisor, Lewis J. Yevoli of Oyster Bay, who did not show up this morning at a meeting with the rating agency.
 
'Fiscal Chaos'
 "The Democratic Supervisors, for political reasons, are creating fiscal chaos, causing a loss in the county's credit and forcing a real property tax increase," said Mr. Gulotta, a Republican.
Mr. Yevoli, in turn, said years of mismanagement by the Republican political machine, which has controlled county government for 75 years, was responsible for the county's fiscal problems.
"Tom Gulotta is scared and he is looking for someone to blame," Mr. Yevoli said. "All he has to do is look in the mirror. He is blaming the newest member of the board for the county's ills."
Asked about the downgrading, Philip R. Michael, the New York City budget director, said that New York City was "on the way up" and he hoped to see the city's bond ratings raised in the near future.
"I sympathize with Nassau County," he said. "I would rather be on the way up as we are than to have just dropped to that point."
Mr. Michael observed that Nassau County's rating dropped, even though Nassau and Suffolk Counties received favorable treatment from the State Legislature, and were given authorization to sell long-term bonds to cover their deficits.
But as a practical matter, in Nassau, where neither Republicans nor Democrats have a working majority on the Board of Supervisors, the board was never able to implement the state-approved plan to sell up to $65 million in bonds, and double a mortgage recording tax to pay for it.
 
Hit by the Recession
 While Long Island has been hit hard by the recession, Nassau has fared better and has a lower unemployment rate -- currently 7 percent -- than either of its neighbors, New York City and Suffolk County. In announcing the downgrading, officials at Moody's noted that the county continues to enjoy a "substantial tax base and affluence."
But Mr. Johnson said the county had "prolonged difficulties in tapping these resources" -- in short a political stalemate, characterized by an inability to raise taxes or cut spending.
The stalemate followed the election of Mr. Yevoli. His election was seen as an unsettling development by Republicans who began to fear a voter backlash over high taxes, including some of the highest property taxes in the country.
Late last year, the budget was cut deeply -- in a plan that would have required the elimination of as many as one in four county jobs -- but when the cuts proved unpopular, the worst of them were not carried out.
As a result, Moody's said the current deficit grew and is now projected to be $130 million or nearly 10 percent of county revenues.
With Democrats and Republicans split along partisan lines this year, Mr. Yevoli agreed to ask the State Legislature to authorize the bonding and the increase in the mortgage recording tax. But after the Legislature approved it, he refused to carry out the plan, saying the Republicans had refused to make deep cuts in what he called patronage jobs in the government.
Today, Mr. Yevoli did not attend a meeting between county officials and Moody's, though he spoke with officials of the rating agency later by telephone.
Tonight, John V. Scaduto, the county treasurer, summed up the situation this way as he struggled to put together the last details on the bond sale. "It's politics," he said. "The county is in fundamentally good shape, always was, and always will be."

HEADLINE: Plans for 14 Theme High Schools Begin Taking Shape in New York

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's plan to create small alternative high schools began to take shape yesterday with a decision to give planning grants for 14 proposals to groups including unions, church organizations and colleges.
The proposals, winnowed from 282 applications, offer a glimpse at what the schools might look like. One would be a School for the Physical City, where the students would study bridges, subways and tunnels. Another is a Health Opportunities Program School, where students would learn about science by working in hospitals with health workers. 
 Mr. Fernandez has promised that at least three to five schools will open by September. The schools, with 500 to 700 students each, are part of a plan to establish at least 30 schools over three years that are easier to manage and tailored more to individual needs than is the case now. Mr. Fernandez is also trying to address the overcrowding problem that has burdened many of the 124 high schools.
"Planned from the ground up by the community, parents and teachers, the schools will foster student choice and innovative instruction," Mr. Fernandez said in a statement.
 
Selection by Fund
 The applications were sent by community organizations, parents, public agencies, unions, community school districts, teachers, colleges and cultural institutions. The selection was directed by the Fund for New York City Public Education, which channels money to the school system from foundations and other contributors.
The high schools operated by the community groups are but one componet of the Chancellor's plan to create small thematic schools. Other components include schools begun by the system's high school division and those to be started by two advocates of change in education, Theodore R. Sizer, a professor at Brown University, and Deborah Meier, founder of three schools in East Harlem. A handful of the schools operated by the high school division have opened.
For the health school in the Bronx, planners say they want to incorporate a six-day school week and an introduction to more than 250 health-care careers in the seventh through 12th grades. The school would use Herbert H. Lehman College and the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center. "Our objective is to start to tap the largest sector of employment in the Bronx, the health-care industry," said Miguel Garcia, president of New Directions in Community Revitalization, a development corporation.
 
Church and Social Courses
 One plan, "Enter to Learn -- Depart to Serve," would unite parents and residents who are members of the Abyssinian Baptist Church and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies in teaching students nonviolent social change.
Another proposal is for a New York City Museum School, where clusters of students would be assigned to a museum and spend one day a week in Community School District 2 to exchange experiences and study. The grants, from the Aaron Diamond Foundation of New York, are to be used to find project directors, identify grade levels, curriculums and staff members, as well as to decide the sites of schools.
