HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
Bonds Drop on Fears of Clinton's Economic Plan

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market fell sharply yesterday, as investors and dealers were said to be positioning themselves for the likelihood that Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas would win the Presidential election and would try to stimulate the economy with increases in Government spending.
The plunge in the market suggests how difficult it may be for whoever wins the election to push through a program to reinvigorate the economy. The message from investors, traders and dealers is that bondholders will sell if a stimulus package is deemed too aggressive, pushing the Federal deficit much higher. And if they sell, they could force market interest rates higher and offset any benefits from the stimulus program.
 
 
Persistent Selloff
 The market's selloff has been persistent since the first week of October, when investors and dealers were disappointed that the Federal Reserve chose not to lower short-term interest rates another notch after weak September employment figures were released on Oct. 2. The Fed's reluctance to move has had a significant impact on Treasury bills and intermediate-term notes. 
 Since then, a growing feeling that Mr. Clinton will win the election has focused attention on his intention to propose a program of Government spending on projects from roads and bridges to communications to create jobs and get the economy moving. The perception that such a program might raise the deficit in the short term has affected mostly long-term notes and the 30-year bond.
All this has led to selling that has wiped out much of gain from the strong rally of July, August and September, when yields on the 30-year bond fell to six-year lows and short-term interest rates plunged to 30-year lows.
But since the beginning of October, the yield on the 30-year bond has jumped a quarter of a percentage point, to 7.56 percent, as prices have dropped. The yield bottomed out at 7.21 percent on Sept. 8.
The jump in the yield on the five-year note has been even more pronounced, soaring half of a percentage point, to 5.68 percent. The yield on the 10-year bond is up almost half of a percentage point, to 6.68 percent.
Also impressive has been the rise in short-term interest rates. In the weekly auction of the three-month and six-month bill yesterday, the average discount rates jumped. On the three-month bill, the average discount rate was 2.94 percent, compared with 2.58 percent on Oct. 1, and the rate for the six-month bill was 3.10 percent, compared with 2.73 percent at the beginning of October.
The Fed's decision earlier this month not to cut rates further explains these changes. At the beginning of October the discount rate on three-month bills was below the Federal funds rate of 3 percent in expectation of another cut by the Fed. Now it has moved up to 3 percent again as investors decided the Fed would not act until after the election.
 
 
Selling Seen as Overdone
 Traders and analysts said there was no new news to prompt the selling yesterday, except that more and more investors and dealers appeared convinced that Governor Clinton would win the election.
Several traders and analysts said that they thought the selling was overdone and that the worry about a Clinton victory had pushed prices much lower and yields much higher than they should be, based on the economic fundamentals. A slow-growing economy and low inflation are generally regarded as positive for the bond market.
"Somewhere in here there is a real buying opportunity," said Joseph Liro, chief economist of S. G. Warburg & Company in New York. "Fundamentally, the circumstances do not warrant the yields that are being built into the short end" of the yield curve.
Mr. Liro argued that while he expected an economic stimulus program if Mr. Clinton was elected, "there are limits to how aggressive a fiscal policy the Democrats will be willing to adopt." One of those limiting factors, he said, would be the reaction of the bond market.
Peter McTeague, fixed-income analyst at Thomson Financial Services in Boston, added, "Maybe the market is overdoing the Clinton worry."
 
 
Notes Are Hit Hard
 In trading in the secondary market yesterday, the 7- and 10-year notes were hit hardest. The price of the seven-year note dropped 28/32 to yield 6.24 percent, compared with 6.09 percent on Friday. The price of the 10-year note fell 24/32 to yield 6.68 percent, compared with 6.57 percent on Friday.
Traders said there was talk that widespread selling of the 10-year note stemmed from some holders' belief that the Treasury might decide to issue more of this note. There has recently been a severe shortage of the 10-year note, and the Treasury has said it will sell additional securities, if necessary to end a squeeze.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said in September that it had been gathering data on the shortage of the 10-year note, which would be the first step toward determining if the Treasury needed to take special action.
The price of the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was off almost 17/32 , to 9725/32 , to yield 7.56 percent, up from 7.52 percent on Friday.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: New York Finds Typical Family Being Redefined

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
The traditional American family has declined so far in New York City that married couples living with their own children now constitute only one in six households.
The trend is neither new nor peculiar to New York. But a new analysis of the 1990 census has found that the typical family has been radically redefined. 
 The share of married couples living with their own children in the city declined from 19.2 percent of all households in 1980 to less than 17 percent in 1990. Among the nation's major cities, it appeared that the percentage of so-called traditional families was lower only in San Francisco.
 
Beyond Immediate Families
 During the last decade, one phenomenon has contributed mightily to the change: the share of New Yorkers living with aunts, uncles, grandparents and other relatives beyond their immediate families rose by 27 percent, or more than 300,000. As a result of family breakups, the rise in foster care, unaffordable housing and an influx of immgrants with extended families, the number of persons in family households living with other relatives soared from 1.1 million in 1980 to more than 1.4 million a decade later. Of all households, they accounted for 20 percent, up from about 16 percent 10 years earlier.
"This is a significant increase, this is big," said Joseph J. Salvo, deputy director of the population division of the Department of City Planning, which released the new analysis yesterday.
Fully one in four whites do not live in family households at all -- a reflection of the growing number of elderly people who live alone, of unrelated roommates living together to share costs, and, perhaps, of gay and lesbian couples, whom the Census Bureau does not recognize as a separate category.
And one in five households are headed by a woman with no husband present. Female-headed households account for 8 percent of white and of Asian households, 32 percent among blacks and 31 percent among Hispanic people.
 
Median Age Edging Up
 The department's study confirmed two other trends with profound economic, social and political implications.
The median age of New Yorkers edged up, from 32.8 years old to 33.7 during the decade. The median ranges from 40 for non-Hispanic whites to 28 for Hispanic people. Black and Hispanic New Yorkers registered the largest increases in median age -- nearly three years among both groups.
The analysis also found severe overcrowding in rented housing, particularly houses and apartments occupied by immigrants.
Citywide, 15 percent of New Yorkers in rented housing lived in overcrowded quarters in 1990, compared with 9 percent in 1980. Among people identifying themselves as Korean, nearly half live in overcrowded housing, which is typically defined as one or more persons per room. The figure ranged from 5 percent of whites to 38 percent of Asians.
 
Positive Trends
 The analysis also found evidence of two positive trends.
The sharp increase in households headed by women with no husband appeared to have halted, although that may be, in part, because more of them have moved in with other relatives.
And the number of New Yorkers who own their own homes -- typically considered a measure of economic and social stability -- increased substantially. Renters accounted for nearly 77 percent of New Yorkers in 1980, but only 71 percent 10 years later. Asian-Americans recorded the largest gains in home ownership: in 1980, 80 percent lived in rental housing; in 1990, 69 percent did.
Nearly one in three people now own their own home or apartment. That includes 38 percent of whites, 21 percent of blacks, 12 percent of Hispanic residents and 31 percent of Asian-Americans. Some of the increase resulted from the record number of transformatioms of rental apartment buildings into cooperatives during the 1980's.
Earlier census analyses found evidence of a growing black middle class and income gains that enabled blacks in Queens to achieve parity with whites.
Big disparities remain, though, in the median value of owner-occupied housing. It ranged from $209,000 for Asians and $202,750 for whites to $156,000 for blacks. Among whites living in Manhattan, the median was $622,000.
But rents also rose. The median, in 1990 constant dollars, jumped from $340 a month in 1980 to $447 in 1990. Median monthly rent ballooned to $503 from $380 for whites, to $404 from $302 for blacks, to $396 from $300 for Hispanic people and to $535 from $373 for Asian tenants.
 
Jails Overshadow Dorms
 Wide variations were also found among the separate Asian and Hispanic groups analyzed by City Planning Department demographers. Puerto Ricans paid the lowest rent among Hispanic people; Mexicans, the highest. Chinese reported the fewest people living alone; Japanese, the most, with 42 percent -- presumably because so many are business executives whose families remained in Japan.
The city's analysis gleaned these other nuggets from the 1990 census:
*Nearly as many people are housed in correctional institutions in New York City as in college dormitories. Among blacks, more than four times as many are in jail as are living in college dorms.
*More New Yorkers are over the age of 70 than under age 5. More are 62 years old or more than are younger than 10. About one-third of elderly people in the city live alone.
*The percentage of New Yorkers over the age of 15 who are separated, widowed or divorced rose from 16 percent in 1980 to 20 percent in 1990. The 43 percent who are married includes 47 percent of the whites, 32 percent of the blacks, 39 percent of Hispanic people and 58 percent of the Asians.
*The number of persons per household -- 2.5 citywide -- did not change appreciably during the decade. Manhattan recorded fewer than two per household, lower than any county in the country except one in Hawaii that is home to a leper colony.
Among the more than 10,000 homeless people "visible in street locations" in the city, half were black and about one-third were Hispanic people. The census counted three people who identified themselves as Japanese.

HEADLINE: Nationsbank Profits Surge; Chase's Earnings Rise 29%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Nationsbank Corporation announced yesterday that its third-quarter profits had quadrupled because of a sharp decline in losses from bad loans, while the Chase Manhattan Corporation reported a more modest 29 percent profit increase, mainly attributable to strong gains in foreign-exchange trading.
Profits of $350 million at Nationsbank, whose acquisitions have made it the country's fourth-largest banking company, were almost twice the $176 million at Chase, which has slipped in the last two years to sixth place from third. 
 Nationsbank's profit, a record for any quarter in its history, puts it on track to earn more than $1 billion this year, the first time its profits will cross that threshold. Chase Manhattan has benefited from rapid growth of its consumer and computer back office businesses the last few years, but its quarterly profit leaves it well behind its performance in 1988, when it earned more than $1 billion.
The earnings reports were better than expected at both companies. Nationsbank's common stock rose $1, to close at $45, while Chase rose 75 cents, to close at $23.25.
While both Nationsbank and Chase were hurt by the downturn in commercial real estate prices and subsequent defaults on loans by developers, the problems appear to be lingering longer at Chase.
Nationsbank wrote off as a loss $141 million of loans, the same amount as in the second quarter, but only half the $280 million write-off in the third quarter of 1991. Nonperforming loans, those which are badly delinquent or not expected to be repaid in full, fell $55 million in the third quarter to $1.7 billion, and are $203 million lower than a year ago.
At Chase Manhattan, the bright spot in its earnings was $120 million of revenues from foreign-exchange trading, up from $61 million in the second quarter and $48 million a year ago.
In other parts of Chase's business, it wrote off as a loss $321 million of loans, up from $297 million in the second quarter, but well below the $656 million of a year ago. Although commercial real estate write-offs fell to $97 million from $120 million in the second quarter, this decline was offset by increases in domestic commercial loans and various kinds of foreign loans.
 
Credit Losses Likely
 Chase said that because of economic weakness in the United States and other countries and depressed real estate markets in the United States, "it is likely that the provision for possible credit losses will continue at relatively high levels." Its $2.23 billion of nonperforming domestic commercial real estate loans was down $130 million from the second quarter, while other kinds of nonperforming loans rose $49 million, to $865 million.
Because Chase's reserves for absorbing loan losses equal only about half the loans it has identified as troubled, many investors assume that its earnings will be hobbled for many quarters to come by a need to write off bad loans and set aside reserves to cover expected loan losses.
The perceived need to increase reserves is one reason that Chase stock sells at only 73 percent of its book value compared with 100 percent or more for most other large banks. Book value is a bank's capital divided by the number of shares. It assumes that a bank's loans are worth the amount shown on its balance sheet and do not require additonal write-offs or reserves.
Nationsbank also reported its first quarterly increase in loans in more than a year. Hugh McColl, its chairman, said loan demand over all was weak but noted that the third quarter average of $67.7 billion of loans was $885 million greater than the quarter ended June 30, with most of the increase coming in loans to businesses. Consumer loans rose $305 million in the latest quarter, mostly from mortgage lending, while commercial real estate loans declined by $305 million.
Nationsbank, which in the last few years has accumulated more than $25 billion of securities because of what it said was weak loan demand from businesses and consumers, has told analysts that it expects to increase profits in coming quarters as increasing loan demand allows it to shift money from securities yielding 6 percent and less to higher yielding loans, particularly consumer loans yielding more than 10 percent.
 
Network of Buyers
 At Chase Manhattan, loans averaged $64.1 billion, down $500 million in the second quarter. Richard Boyle, vice chairman at Chase, said the decline was primarily caused by the sale of loans and noted that sales to other banks had been strong because "they are feeling the same lack of loan demand that we do." After spending years to develop a network of buyers for its loans, he said Chase had resisted the temptation to stop supplying those buyers and keep larger amounts of the loans it makes.
Looking ahead, Mr. Boyle said Chase's success in increasing its capital left it well positioned to provide funds to borrowers when demand increases.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Profits Rise at 2 Bells, But Are Flat at Pactel

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Two regional Bell telephone companies reported higher third-quarter profits yesterday. But another had posted virtually flat earnings earlier.
The Bell Atlantic Corporation, which serves Northeastern states from New Jersey to Virginia, said its net income rose 16.6 percent from a year earlier. U S West Inc., which serves the Pacific Northwest and some Midwestern states, said net income rose 5.2 percent. 
 But the Pacific Telesis Group, which serves California and Nevada, reported last week that its third-quarter earnings rose less than 1 percent.
Following are the details of the companies' third-quarter earnings:
 
Bell Atlantic
 Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, said third-quarter net totaled $386.6 million, or 90 cents a share, compared with $331.5 million, or 78 cents a share, a year earlier. Quarterly revenue totaled $3.17 billion, up less than 1 percent from $3.15 billion.
Quarterly results would have risen less -- by only 9.3 percent from the year-earlier operating profit of 75 cents a share -- without a one-time gain, the company said. The gain of 8 cents a share is from the sale of an investment related to the acquisition of Metro Mobile, a cellular carrier.
Bell Atlantic said its operating expenses totaled $2.5 billion, down nine-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, partly as a result of the early retirement of 3,200 managers.
The carrier reported strong increases in subscribers to its cellular services. It had 617,300 subscribers as of Sept. 30, up 29 percent from a year earlier. Cellular revenue totaled $153.8 million, up 22.5 percent from the year-ago quarter. The company did not disclose cellular earnings.
Bell Atlantic's shares slipped 37.5 cents yesterday, to close at $47.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
U S West
 U S West, based in Englewood, Colo., said quarterly earnings totaled $283.4 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with $269.3 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue dropped 2.1 percent, to $2.56 billion from $2.62 billion. Excluding the company's real estate operations, which are being phased out, revenue rose 1.9 percent, to $2.6 billion.
The company said operating expenses totaled $2 billion, down 1.5 percent from a year earlier, mainly as a result of a 14.1 percent reduction in the cost of services and products.
U S West also reported a strong rise in the number of cellular subscribers, to 372,200, up 40.5 percent from the 1991 quarter. Quarterly cellular and pager revenue totaled $105.3 million, up 23.4 percent from the year-earlier $85.3 million. The company did not disclose cellular earnings.
U S West shares lost 25 cents yesterday, to close at $38.75.
 
Pacific Telesis
 Pacific Telesis, based in San Francisco, said its quarterly earnings totaled $277 million, or 70 cents a share, compared with $275 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose less than 1 percent, to $2.51 billion from $2.5 billion.
The quarterly figures include a restatement of first- and second-quarter earnings resulting from a $56 million refund ordered by the California Public Utilities Commission to settle a dispute over Pacific Bell's development of certain telecommunications services. Pacific Bell supplies ordinary telephone service, the source of most of its revenues.
The company blamed the quarter's comparatively poor results on the persistent recession in the state, which is the nation's largest.
The company said its operating expenses rose 3.6 percent, to $1.49 billion from $1.44 billion.
Pacific Telesis, with the nation's largest cellular market, reported a 28.1 percent increase in the number of subscribers, to 656,000, up from 512,000 in the 1991 period.
Pactel Cellular reported that quarterly net income was flat at $23.2 million. While quarterly cellular revenue rose 20.4 percent, to $181.3 million from $150.6 million, operating expenses rose 26.5 percent, to $141.4 million from $111.8 million, preventing revenue gains from leading to profits.
Pacific Telesis's shares dipped 25 cents yesterday, to $42.625.

HEADLINE: Many Reasons Send Adults to One Place: School

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 19

 BODY:
While the debate over the study of Western Civilization rages among the dons from Columbia to Stanford, Philip Dogon remains steadfast in his teaching goals: to help even the clumsiest homeowner learn to rewire a lamp or repair a toilet.
He does this in nine Tuesday nights at the Ridgewood Community School in course No. 502: "Be Your Own Fix-It Handyman, It's Really Easy." His specialty is one of about 170 courses or lectures this fall in this suburb's version of a perennially popular form of learning, the adult education program. 
 With roots in the community forums of the 19th-century Lyceum movement and the Americanization classes for immigrants 75 years ago, the modern adult education program has come to reflect who Americans are, what they want and what they need. And while the poor economy has taken its toll on class rolls in the last four years, the overall picture is strong and growing stronger, said Julie Coates, information director for the Learning Resources Network in Manhattan, Kan., which helps track trends in the field.
In the last decade, she said, enrollment nationwide has doubled, to 15 million, with baby boomers and retired people signing up in large numbers at colleges, public schools or independent programs for everything from acrylic folk art to yoga.
 
Fad, Fashion and Necessity
 The curriculum, from a few dozen courses in some towns to a few hundred offerings in others, is usually a reflection of the community it serves, as well as of fads, fashions or, at the moment, of economic necessity -- the need to find a job in a tenacious recession.
In cities like New York, adult courses are intended primarily to provide access to trades, office jobs or the health-care industry; instruction tends to be skill-related and offered free or at nominal cost. Of the city's 50,000 adult students, 20,000 are learning English as a second language, according to the Board of Education. There are no electives like "Realistic Options in Hair Restoration" (Ridgewood); "About Men -- What Do They Want? For Men Only" (Scarsdale, N.Y.), or "My Aching Back" (taught by a local chiropractor in Milford, Conn.).
Across the country, Ms. Coates said, two-thirds of those enrolled are women, many have college degrees and most have some college experience and higher-than-average incomes. Recently, she said, men and women between the ages of 28 and 46 have been attracted to courses that provide what she called "catered experiences." She cited an apocryphal "gourmet canoeing" class, but also said that lessons in stand-up comedy, dress for success or self-esteem for women were gaining popularity.
 
Lifetime Learning
 Growth has also been rapid among older people.
"They want to remain part of contemporary life and communicate with their grandchildren," Ms. Coates said. "Some want to learn to do spread sheets, to learn what they need to do to manage their own finances in retirement." Some, she said, are engrossed in writing their family histories and want to learn word processing to continue the project.
Ms. Coates said she was also seeing record enrollments in courses on backyard ecology, "hands-on things that individuals can do to help the environment." Ridgewood offers eight of these, but another class on learning to install an underground sprinkler system was canceled for lack of interest. Other big draws are parenting classes, courses on how to communicate with teen-agers and financial planning for retirement or for a child's college education.
Home improvement courses, like Mr. Dogon's, always have an audience. "These classes saw a surge of popularity about four years ago as baby boomers started, in great numbers, to buy the dream home or renovate the old home," Ms. Coates said.
But business, finance and computers seem to hold the edge in popularity, and schools are also branching out to do on-site training in new technology or management techniques in suburban office parks.
 
A Turn Toward the Serious
 "We've become more serious, particularly in the last two years," said Dr. Ronald Verdicchio, executive director of the Ridgewood program. "People are coming to us to be retrained. While we have some crafts and recreation, our focus tends to be substance. That's changed with the economy and the times."
Ridgewood, whose adult program began under private auspices in 1948 and became part of the public school system in 1970, sent its 38-page fall bulletin to 60,000 households in the northern Bergen County area and has a current enrollment of 12,000, though it has been as high as 15,000 in recent years. Like most schools of its kind, it is self-sustaining, based on tuition, and holds classes in public schools as well as churches or other public buildings. It returns about $120,000 a year in rental fees to the Board of Education.
"Our enrollment has eroded over the past two years," Dr. Verdicchio said. "Partly that has to do with changes in our program, but we also got hurt by the Gulf War. The phones stopped dead. People were glued to their television set that winter, and we really took a shot.
"We're also local-economy sensitive. Last October, we took a pretty good hit. People were careful about writing the checks. Adult education is a very competitive business, and it is a business."
 
Practical Skills
 Many schools like Ridgewood's rely on local talent to teach courses, paying, on average, about $15 to $20 an hour. Mr. Dogon, who ran a hardware store in Passaic for 20 years, is perhaps typical of instructors in the hands-on courses.
Lecturing on sockets and friction tape before a dozen eager disciples in a corner of the cafeteria at Benjamin Franklin Middle School, he holds the suburban night-school equivalent of a tenured chair in physics at M.I.T.
And like a large number of the 140 faculty members, his qualifications come not necessarily from a college education but from career paths or simply passionate interest.
"When you have a small hardware business, you spend half your time telling people how to fix things," said Mr. Dogon, who has taught the course for five years. He emphasizes humor, simplicity and repetition in a course that covers door locks, lamps, toilets, window glazing, patching and plastering and faucets.
"There are no handymen anymore," he said. "They're all contractors and they charge a fortune."
Which is why Astrid Baruth of Park Ridge and Ray LaRocco of Ridgewood were rewiring an old lamp under Mr. Dogon's watchful gaze.
"There are lots of things that need to be fixed at my house, and I'm divorced," said Ms. Baruth, explaining her motivation for enrolling. "If I have to call people in to fix things, it would be the end."
Mr. LaRocca, who grew up in New York, said, "I'm from a family where nobody ever used a screwdriver in their life." When he bought a home, though, the need to be self-sufficient became self-evident. "It's nice to do something small," he said.
 
An Inexpensive Getaway
 Although many students are motivated by economics, many just want to have fun. Ms. Coates said that interest in personal enrichment classes was booming this fall. "The reason is that people want to forget their troubles," she said. "Life is hard and life is bleak and they turn to these kinds of programs to give themselves something to get away."
In Milford, Conn., a grim economy has turned the town's adult education classes into a great and inexpensive night's entertainment. Most courses cost $25, about a quarter of a college course.
"This is a night out for me," said Karen Czajkowski of Milford, who was enrolled in a French class. "And it's just not a white-knuckles, pressurized class. It's just a wonderful time learning."
Her friend, Karen Simses, said, "I would love to use the language in France someday, but I think I'd have to be in the investments class down the hall in order to get myself there."
In Scarsdale, N.Y., where class fees range from $10 to $80, the philosophy remains what it was in 1938, when the first course was offered, according to Anita Malina, the curriculum coordinator: "one-third intellectual, one-third self-improvement and one-third hobby courses."
Administrators in Scarsdale and Ridgewood are typical in the way they select courses. Both communities have a board of advisers that meets to suggest ideas. Students are surveyed. Some people come forward with new proposals or teacher recommendations, which are sometimes unrealistic.
"Every year in curriculum meetings," Ms. Malina said, "we have new people who don't understand why we can't have Henry Kissinger."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The curriculum of adult education courses usually reflects the community it serves. Walt Fehrle restored an old chair during a course on upholstery at Ridgewood High School in Ridgewood, N.J. (Ray Stubblebine for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Some Gains, Especially Against Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher yesterday on world currency markets, putting in its best performance against the British pound.
Gold prices also gained ground across the board. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $342.70 an ounce, up 30 cents from Friday. Republic National Bank said gold added 20 cents an ounce, to reach a late bid price of $342.40. 
 Traders said the dollar remained within very tight ranges before gradually drifting higher late in the session. Most of the dollar's gains were attributed to problems with other foreign currencies rather than any fundamental strength of its own.
 Traders said the pound was in the spotlight, falling sharply amid worries over the British Government's economic woes and its perceived lack of leadership.
An announcement that the Government was backing down on a plan to close 31 coal mines, which would result in the loss of 30,000 jobs, was seen as "a U-turn in policy," according to a senior London dealer. "The Government's credibility is slipping," he added. Parliament was told only 10 mines would close and a moratorium would be put on further closings until the New Year.
"We're in the throes of a shift in focus," Frank Pusateri, a vice president at the Bank of Boston, said. "We're moving from trading the dollar down on weakening U.S. fundamentals to selling the European currencies on weaknesses in their economies. The dollar will be the beneficiary of other people's troubles."
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 120.05 Japanese yen from 120.53 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 119.75 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 120.45 yen, up from 119.50 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6330 from $1.6548 late Friday and to 2.4225 marks, from 2.4457 on Friday. In New York it cost $1.6225 to buy one pound, down than Friday's $1.6495.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates included: 1.4990 marks, up from 1.4798; 1.3395 Swiss francs, up from 1.3220; 5.0865 French francs, up from 5.0250; 1,316.50 Italian lire, up from 1,302, and 1.2456 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2451.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Preserving G.M.'s Blue-Chip Credit

BYLINE: By Doron P. Levin

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
WHEN Robert C. Stempel, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, was taken to a Washington hospital last week, his illness was diagnosed as hypertension.
Fortunately, Mr. Stempel felt well enough to return to work by week's end. But the enormous pressure to restructure G.M. that is swirling about Mr. Stempel and other senior G.M. executives will not dissipate as quickly. 
 An immediate concern is protecting G.M.'s blue-chip status in the capital markets. G.M.'s common stock and $85.5 billion worth of fixed-income securities have been trading at sharply discounted prices in recent weeks, partly because of uncertainty whether the company's cost-cutting will be successful, worries over economic weakness, and questions about the auto maker's relations with the United Automobile Workers union.
Last week, the Standard & Poor's Corporation warned that it might lower the ratings on G.M. bonds and commercial paper by mid-1993 "in the absence of clear signs of a turnaround in the financial performance of its core automotive operations." S.& P. now rates G.M.'s senior debt and commercial paper A-, a notch lower than the rating assigned by Moody's Investors Service Inc., which earlier warned of a possible downgrade.
Then on Friday, G.M. disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its third-quarter deficit would be large; analysts say it may top $500 million. Yesterday, G.M.'s common stock slipped 25 cents a share, closing at $29.125, well below its 52-week high of $44.375 and near its low of $26.75.
Some bond traders, who spoke on condition of anonymity, viewed the S.& P. warning as optimistic, since they were bracing for a downgrade as early as year-end. "G.M. is getting a reprieve," one trader said.
G.M.'s outside directors have been pressing Mr. Stempel and Jack Smith, G.M.'s president, more forcefully to cut costs -- leading to the inevitable suspicion that Mr. Stempel's illness reflected the strain.
Yet the pressure bears most directly on Mr. Smith. As head of North American operations, he and a group of executives have been sequestered since April, trying to revamp the auto maker's product strategy. Many inside G.M. and on Wall Street expect word before the end of the year, perhaps soon, detailing which G.M. car and truck models will be canceled and which plants will close.
The national leaders of the U.A.W., though unhappy, are reconciled to more G.M. plant closings and cost-cutting. The question is whether closings will worsen tensions between local unions and plant managers, which erupted into two strikes in September. Despite these tensions, Wall Street regards the shutdown of unused G.M. capacity -- and the retirement or layoff of nonessential workers -- as absolute prerequisites to confirming G.M.'s credit rating.
"We'll be assessing competitiveness in the market sense, and labor will be an important component of that," said Scott Sprinzen, a director of corporate finance for S.& P.
Last week, G.M. and the U.A.W. were negotiating early retirement terms that would allow the auto maker to buy out the contracts of excess workers, instead of paying them until they are needed again. The union would prefer to keep workers on the payroll, but G.M. has some leverage: a fund that pays the salaries of laid-off workers is running low, and G.M. does not have to replenish it.
Just a few years ago, G.M.'s financial strength was thought to be a shield against almost any catastrophe. No more. Ronald Glantz, an automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco, said flatly, "If the union won't allow the company to match its competitors' productivity, Chapter 11 is possible."
He hastened to add that he believed the U.A.W. would permit productivity increases, and he is recommending the stock for long-term appreciation in the belief that Mr. Smith will lead the stock to outperform rivals.
What the U.A.W. will fight, according to a spokesman, is any plans to send work to Mexico or to nonunion vendors in order to evade the union. When productivity is competitive, the U.A.W. expects G.M. to bring more work into its factories, which will insure employment for the rank-and-file who have survived cost-cutting.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Securities Priced By News Corp.

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The News Corporation, the global broadcasting and publishing company headed by Rupert Murcoch, has announced the pricing for its public offering of senior debt securities, reduced to $850 million, from $1 billion, because of recent volatility in the United States debt markets.
The company said the coupon rate on $550 million of senior notes due on Oct. 15, 1999, would be 9.12 percent and the rate on $300 million of senior debentures due on Oct. 15, 2012, would be 10.12 percent. 
 The debt offering is part of a sweeping debt-reduction program. Last week, the company raised $697 million through an offering of 40 million common shares.
"The net proceeds of the debt and equity offering will be not less than $1.5 billion," the company said. "The company intends to use all of the proceeds, together with the net proceeds of the $185 million from sale of The San Antonio Express News, to repay bank debt."
The senior notes and debentures are being offered through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The News Corporation owns the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, Sky Broadcasting of Britain and large newspapers in Australia, Britain and Hong Kong.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Low Inflation: Is It the Culprit?

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
"MAY I suggest: 'The Great Recession'?" wrote Jeff Connor, commissioner of the New Jersey Banking Department, in response to a recent Business Scene column that reported on the search for a label that adequately describes the economic slowdown. The standard labels -- stagnation and recession -- fail to capture the hardship that many Americans say they are suffering. "Silent depression," "depressed recession," and "cycle of cycles" were among the other names suggested by readers.
But for many, the real question is the source of the problems. "I must say that a descriptive name for America's present economic difficulties seems far less important to me than a correct diagnosis of these difficulties," wrote Samuel M. Greenhouse of Boca Raton, Fla. And among the numerous diagnoses, a new one is appearing that goes a long way toward explaining the national hardship. It is the falling inflation rate. 
 Not since the mid-1960's has the Consumer Price Index hovered for so long a period -- 18 months now -- at an annual rate of 3 percent or less. But while low inflation was a boon in the 1960's, suitable to the times, it is a heavy burden today, helping to explain why the economy fails to revive.
"The downward trend causes the trouble," said Albert Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, a business organization. Going from a 5 percent inflation rate in 1990 to 3 percent today, he said, "is much more disruptive than having had low but steady inflation for a considerable period, as was the case in the 1960's."
The problem today is different for individuals than for companies. Average wages for individuals have virtually stagnated, the Labor Department reports, but some major household expenses have sharply risen: health care, college tuition, home repair, utilities and property taxes. That plus heavy consumer debt loads, a burden absent in the 1960's, squeezes Americans, making them reluctant to buy, a prerequisite for an economic revival.
American corporations, on the other hand, suffer from almost no inflation at all in product prices. Unable to get price increases for a great variety of goods, they have preserved profits by cutting costs, especially labor costs. The results are wage and hiring freezes or outright layoffs, that have prolonged the hard times for workers. What's more, wholesalers and retailers decline to stockpile goods, depressing production. Why stockpile shoes at $50 a pair if the price three months from now won't change, or might even drop?
The corrugated box industry illustrates the problem. Some 95 percent of all packaged goods are shipped or sold in these boxes. But the price of $624 a ton is still well below the $664 selling price in 1989. A recent 3.3 percent increase, to $624, was the first increase in three years.
"We think the resistance has to do with the inability of our customers to pass price increases along to their customers," said Timothy McKenna, an executive at the Union Camp Corporation.
Union Camp, as a result, has stopped hiring and has also installed labor-saving machinery. That did not happen in the 1960's when price increases were also hard to get. With much less foreign competition, American output and sales kept rising, and so did productivity, the amount produced by each worker. The rising productivity -- at a much greater rate than today -- generated revenue for healthy wage increases. But even then, a sluggish economy, in part a result of low inflation, prompted President John F. Kennedy to push through the nation's first investment tax credit.
More important, the 1960's escaped deflation entirely. Prices might not have risen much, but they did not fall, as home prices have fallen in recent times, particularly in California and the Northeast. A home purchased for $500,000 in 1988 might sell for only $375,000 today, often less than the outstanding mortgage.
A family that owns such a home, with a $400,000 mortgage, is forced down one of two paths. If income is sufficient, the family can stay put, maintaining payments on the mortgage. But if the family cannot keep up the payments, because of job loss or wage cuts, the forced sale of the home for $375,000 may mean defaulting on the mortgage. And mortgage defaults are rising.
In either case, some inflation in the value of the home would relax the family. And in a more relaxed mood, family members might become more avid consumers. "With asset values falling, people are stuck with their debts, and that spills over into consumption," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist.
Some economists argue that allowing inflation to rise even a little might set off an inflationary spiral. But others offer a contrary view: Instead of rising, the inflation rate will continue to decline, hurting the economy. And the evidence increasingly suggests that this might happen.
"Like it or not, we have caught disinflation," said Robert Barbera, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "Let's say the next President wants to raise inflation to between 4 and 5 percent; I don't think he can."

HEADLINE: U.S.-VIETNAM TALKS MOVE TIES CLOSER

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Vietnam and the United States have moved closer to establishing diplomatic relations after two days of talks in Hanoi between a high-level Bush Administration delegation and Vietnamese leaders, the State Department said today.
During the meetings, Hanoi pledged to open to American inspection all archival material relating to American servicemen unaccounted for since the Vietnam War, according to a joint statement issued by Vietnamese officials and the leader of the United States team, John W. Vessey Jr., a retired Army general. 
 "General Vessey indicated in the context of accelerated cooperation to resolve the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue, the U.S. would move more rapidly toward normalization," said Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman.
The talks were hurriedly arranged by the Administration after Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Manh Cam, was invited to Washington two weeks ago for talks with Acting Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.
 
Photos Shown to Vietnamese
 At that meeting, the United States apparently presented the Vietnamese with information from Vietnam's own files that revealed Hanoi knew more than it has acknowledged about some cases of missing Americans.
According to officials involved in independent investigations of the issue here and in Southeast Asia, the material shown to the Vietnamese included photographs smuggled out of the country depicting gruesome scenes of Americans mutilated in crashes and military encounters or executed by their Vietnamese captors.
Information that has emerged in recent hearings of the Senate Select Committee on P.O.W.-M.I.A Affairs has also indicated that Hanoi may have information it has withheld from American officials for nearly 20 years.
A resolution of some cases of missing Americans has been the last hurdle to lifting an American economic embargo and recognizing Hanoi.
 
November Visit by Senators
 Some Pentagon officials said they believed that Vietnam might also be preparing to release more American remains in the next few weeks, perhaps in advance of a committee visit to Hanoi planned for mid-November.
General Vessey, the President's special envoy to Hanoi, will brief Mr. Bush on his visit on Wednesday or Thursday, the White House said today.
The timing of these new moves is the subject of speculation here among both supporters and critics of improved relations with Vietnam. Experts say Vietnam's leaders are uncertain of what to expect from a Clinton Administration, while they are on a clearly defined "road map" to recognition devised by the Bush State Department.
Douglas Pike, the scholar who has written a history of the Vietnamese Army, said today that Vietnamese leaders in Hanoi asked him over the summer what more they could do to close this issue.
 
Vietnamese Politics Are Cited
 "I would just advise them to overwhelm us with candor," he said, citing the example of Russia. Mr. Pike, director of the Indochina studies at the University of California at Berkeley, said objections to sharing more information had apparently come from civilian security officials in Vietnam and not the military.
He said that in the mid-1980's, military objections to "doling out bones" were reliably reported to have been overruled in the Vietnamese Politburo by civilians in control of policy toward the United States.
"My general sense is that they were deliberately not telling us things they knew, and I think the basic reason was politics."
In Washington, the Bush Administration has been under pressure from American businesses to end the embargo so that they can compete in the rebuilding and industrialization of the country before all the contracts go to the Japanese, Koreans, Taiwanese and Europeans, most of whom have embassies in Hanoi.
Virginia Foote, director of the United States-Vietnam Trade Council, an independent organization supported by American companies, said today that Vietnam, which would like to involve American oil companies in the development of a block of offshore oil concessions in the South China Sea, is being pressed to award contracts soon.
"If Vietnam awards those blocks, that will be pretty much the end of the American role in development of the Vietnamese oil industry," she said.
She added that Japan, in addition to trading with Vietnam, is preparing to resume direct foreign aid in contravention of American wishes. France is at the same time trying to arrange for Vietnam's return to the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, where Washington had consistently vetoed aid to Hanoi.

HEADLINE: British Prime Minister Retreats on Mine Closings

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Facing mass public protests and a mutiny among among members of his own Conservative Party in Parliament, Prime Minister John Major reversed ground today and sharply reduced the number of coal mines and miners' jobs scheduled for elimination by the Government.
Less than a week after state-owned British Coal said it was closing 31 of 50 mines and laying off 30,000 workers -- more than three-quarters of Britain's remaining miners -- Michael Heseltine, Secretary for Trade and Industry, told a jeering, raucous session of the House of Commons that the Government now intended to close just 10 mines, at a cost of about 7,500 jobs. 
 Under the revised plan, British Coal will shut down the 10 least viable of its mines, after a 90-day statutory consultation period. Originally, 27 mines were to be closed outright and 4 mothballed over the next five months.
The sharp turn in policy was the latest in a growing number of embarrassments for Mr. Major, whose Government has come under pointed attack in recent weeks for appearing to be adrift and uncertain, just six months after the Prime Minister led the Conservatives to a fourth straight national-election victory over the Labor Party.
Although Mr. Heseltine said the case for closing the intended 31 mines remained "compelling," given the fading market for British coal, he acknowledged that the move had been made too suddenly and caused too much dislocation. As a result, he said, the Government will observe a moratorium on additional closings, pending a public review of the coal industry.
The Prime Minister and members of his Cabinet appeared stunned in recent days by the intensely angry reaction to their announcement last week that they would lay off 30,000 mine workers over the next five months, at a time when as many as 8,000 jobs a week are already being lost in the country's worst recession since the 1930's.
Coal miners and other workers have threatened strikes; tens of thousands of protesters plan a mass march and rally in London next weekend, and newspapers considered to be staunch defenders of the Tory cause have berated the Government, demanding that it reverse course.
By backing off today, Mr. Major hoped to avoid a humiliating rebuff from Conservative back-benchers in the House of Commons, many of whom have threatened to oppose him on Wednesday, when the house is scheduled to vote on the mine closings.
If Mr. Major loses that vote, despite his party's 21-seat majority in Parliament, opposition legislators are likely to seek a vote of no confidence. But while Tory rebels might oppose the Government's coal policy, they are almost certain to rally to Mr. Major on a confidence measure to assure that the Conservatives are not brought down, forcing a new election.
The decision today was the second time in a month that Mr. Major was forced to make a humiliating reversal in economic areas. In mid-September, as turbulence in the international currency markets spread doubts on the future of European union, the Government withdrew the pound from a grid that tied its value to that of other European currencies.
Mr. Major has also been fighting a bitter battle with fellow Conservatives, including former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who are opposed to his support for the Maastricht treaty on European union. The Government faces a battle in the House of Commons when the accord is submitted for ratification this year, as Mr. Major has promised to do.
Several Conservative members of Parliament who had declared that they were determined to oppose the Prime Minister on the proposed coal-mine closings said today that they would now support him in the vote on Wednesday.
"I think the Government has given us 90 percent of what we wanted, and that is an opportunity for a proper examination of what happens next," said one such Tory, Gary Walker.
But Winston Churchill, grandson of the wartime Prime Minister, said that despite the shift, he still intended to oppose Mr. Major's policy on Wednesday. Mr. Churchill and others called on Mr. Heseltine, the architect of the coal policy, to resign.

HEADLINE: CHINESE SHAKE UP TOP PARTY GROUP; FREE MARKET GAINS

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The Communist Party announced a sweeping change in the makeup of its highest executive body today, promoting several enthusiasts of free markets to the seven-member committee that is supposed to rule China for at least the next five years.
The reshaping of the all-powerful Politburo Standing Committee is an important victory for those trying to tug the party toward a new world of free markets -- for goods, though not ideas. The shake-up, which included the retirement of two leading hard-liners, sends a clear signal that the party intends to focus its energies not on ideology but on economic restructuring.
 
A Future Power Struggle
 The selection of the seven men as members of the new Standing Committee prepares the battleground for the huge power struggle expected after the death of Deng Xiaoping, China's 88-year-old paramount leader. The seven men will have far more weight than any one else in determining the direction of China after Mr. Deng dies.
While Mr. Deng holds no official position, he clearly was the prime force in picking the new Standing Committee. But as his health deteriorates, he is unlikely to be able to influence it in the way he has in the past.
Mr. Deng emerged today to congratulate the new leaders, in his first televised appearance in eight months. He seemed very frail and his facial expression barely changed. Still, he managed to walk about and wave to the cheering delegates of the just-ended Communist Party congress.
 
Helped by His Daughter
 "The congress was a great success," Mr. Deng said, according to the official New China News Agency. "I hope all people will continue to work hard."
Mr. Deng is known to be virtually deaf and to have difficulty articulating his words, and from the Chinese television footage it appeared that his daughter Deng Rong, who held his arm the entire time, had to repeat his remarks on some occasions so others could understand him. She also spoke into his ear to tell him what people were saying to him.
While Mr. Deng is said to be more alert in the mornings, it is still not entirely clear how a man in such a physical state can exert such a grip over national affairs. One partial answer to this puzzle is that he focuses only on setting broad policy guidelines and on choosing personnel at the highest level. Even so, some Chinese wonder if those around Mr. Deng may be manipulating him or else manipulating the country by sometimes speaking in his name.
It is impossible to know how the new leaders will act once they are freed of Mr. Deng's supervision. But so far there is no sign that they favor a political liberalization to go along with the economic changes that have opened large segments of the Chinese economy to market forces.
Jiang Zemin, the Communist Party General Secretary, remains the head of the Standing Committee. As a stereo system played "Descendants of the Dragon," a ballad that ironically was written by a pro-democracy campaigner expelled from China two years ago, Mr. Jiang strode into a large room in the Great Hall of the People and introduced the other members of the new Standing Committee to several hundred foreign reporters.
 
A Different Atmosphere
 Five years ago, the newly chosen Standing Committee walked around the room, bantering with journalists, but this time the atmosphere was entirely different. As soon as they had been introduced, the members hurried out of the room, some looking nervously over their shoulders at the mobs of journalists shouting questions at them.
One of the most important appointments today was the elevation to the Standing Committee of Zhu Rongji, a former Shanghai Mayor who is sometimes labeled "China's Gorbachev" because of his aggressive efforts to restructure the economy. Mr. Zhu, who is 64, has risen very rapidly and is the leading candidate to replace Prime Minister Li Peng if Mr. Li is edged out when his term expires next spring.
"Now the reformers finally have some advocates in the highest ranks," a Western diplomat said. "It's unrealistic to think that they will lead to a Western parliamentary system. But there probably will be dramatic changes in the economy, and that will lead to political changes even if they don't want that to happen."
The youngest of the new Standing Committee members is Hu Jintao, the 49-year-old party secretary in Tibet. Mr. Hu has played a central role in crushing dissent in Tibet, where troops have fired machine guns on protesting Buddhist monks and nuns, and yet he is generally considered a reformer.
In part this is because Mr. Hu endorsed the repression for practical rather than ideological reasons. Moreover, he was a protege of Hu Yaobang, a former Communist Party leader who sought far-reaching change. On the other hand, Hu Jintao was also promoted early in his career by Song Ping, a hard-liner, and so the accuracy of the labels is open to question.
The other new addition to the Standing Committee is Gen. Liu Huaqing, a 76-year-old army veteran who has tried to make the military forces professional and modern rather like those in the West.
Three other party leaders have been retained from the previous Standing Committee: Mr. Li, the Prime Minister; Qiao Shi, who is in charge of internal security, and Li Ruihuan, who looks after ideology and propaganda. Most Chinese regard Li Peng as a hard-liner and Li Ruihuan as a reformer, with Mr. Jiang and Mr. Qiao somewhere in between.
Those dropped from the Standing Committee were Yao Yilin, the head of the central planning apparatus, and Mr. Song, the hard-liner who has been in charge of party organization.
In addition to the seven chosen to serve on the Standing Committee, 13 others were chosen regular members of the Politburo. The full Politburo meets about once a month, with many other party officials present as well.
The Standing Committee, on the other hand, normally meets at least once a week, with much less ceremony. It is by far the more important body.
Aside from the seven serving on the Standing Committee, 11 officials were elevated to the full Politburo for the first time: Ding Guangen, Mr. Deng's bridge partner; Li Lanqing, the Trade Minister; Qian Qichen, the Foreign Minister; Yang Baibing, a general; Wu Bangguo, the party leader in Shanghai; Zou Jiahua, a Deputy Prime Minister; Chen Xitong, the Mayor of Beijing; Jiang Chunyun, the party leader in Shandong Province; Wei Jianxing, the Minister of Supervision; Xie Fei, the party leader in Guangdong Province, and Tan Shaowen, the party leader in the city of Tianjin.
Two others who had served on the previous Politburo were retained on the present one: Tian Jiyun, who oversees agriculture, and Li Tieying, the Education Minister.
There is a sense in Beijing that other changes -- in policies and personnel -- are likely to follow soon. At People's Daily, for instance, an official spokeswoman paused when she was asked if the hard-line publisher, Gao Di, was still holding his job.
"Well," she said uncertainly, "I have no information that he's no longer serving as publisher."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, making an appearance at the end of the party congress. (Associated Press) (pg. A1)
 
Chart/Photo: "7 Men to Watch in China"
 
Jiang Zemin
 Communist Party General Secretary since 1989 . . . Chairman of the Central Military Commission . . . Deng Xiaoping's supposed successor as the paramount leader of China, but many Chinese doubt that he will survive the power struggle after Mr. Deng is gone because he has little power base of his own.
 Sixty-six years old . . . A Russian-trained electrical engineer . . . Worked as a factory director and government minister . . . Became the Mayor of Shanghai, China's largest city, in 1985 . . . . Communist Party leader in Shanghai in 1987.
 Summoned to Beijing to be party leader in June 1989, after the bloody crackdown on the Tiananmen Square demoncracy movement.
 
Li Peng
 Prime Minister since 1983 . . . Widely hated because of his leading role in the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown . . . Once a hard-liner, he has moderated his speeches over the last year . . . Term as Prime Minister expires next spring, and a fight is expected over whether he gets another term.
 Turns 64 on Tuesday . . . Son of a Communist who was killed when Li Peng was a small child . . . Raised with other orphans by Prime Minster Zhow Enlai . . . A Soviet-trained engineer . . . Boosted throughout his career by members of the revolutionary generation who are now dying off . . . One of the few top Chinese leaders who has never allowed his children to use connections for personal profit
 
Qiao Shi
 In charge of internal security apparatus . . . Apparently a relative moderate, initially reluctant to use police force against 1989 Tiananmen demonstrators . . . Later supported martial law and the army crackdown.
 Sixty-eight years old . . . Joined the Communist Party in Shanghai at the age of 16 . . . Student protestor in the 1940's . . . Worked in the international liaison department of the party . . . Because of his control over police and party files, could become a formidable figure in any power struggle.
 
Li Ruihuan
 Promoted to Standing Committee in 1989 after Tiananmen crackdown . . . In charge of ideology portfolio, but is known for his pragmatic approach to economic reform . . . Charged with carrying out a compaign against "bourgeois liberalization" in 1989, he turned it from a hard-line attack on intellectuals into a campaign against pornography . . . Has made several bold speeches for change.
 Fifty-eight years old . . . Never attended a university and is sometimes looked down on by intellectuals for that reason . . . Worked as a carpenter . . . Twice named a national model worker . . . Appointed mayor of Tianjin in 1982 . . . During 1989 student protests, Tianjin gave student demonstrators free rail tickets to Beijing so that they would go protest there.
 
Zhu Rongji
 Newley promoted to Standing Committee . . . Also a Deputy Prime Minister and head of the Economic and Trade Office, an economic super-ministry . . . One of the few Politburo members who seems to generate genuine respect among young people.
 Sixty-three years old . . . Trained in electrical engineering . . . Denounced as a "rightest" in 1957, after making mild criticisms of the Communist Party . . . Rehabilitated in 1978 . . . Rose very rapidly, becoming Mayor of Shanghai in 1987 . . . Shook up Shanghai and began major infrastructure projects . . . Equally admired by the public for getting things done and detested by the bureaucracy for rudeness and impatience . . . Refused to call in troops against student protestors in Shanghai in 1989.
 
Lui Huaqing
 Newly promoted to Standing Committee . . . Deputy Chairman of the Central Military Commission . . . Has spent 62 of his 76 years in the military . . . The oldest member now on the Politburo . . . An ardent advocate of creating a more modern and professional armed forces.
 Joined the Red Army in 1930 . . . Political Commissar of a Red Army brigade under Deng Xiaoping's command . . . Transferred to Navy after Communists won and received naval training in the Soviet Union . . . Attacked in 1968 during Cultural Revolution for his work in a national defense commission . . . Elected a member of the Central committee in 1982 but resigned after three years . . . Has visited the United States at least twice.
 
Hu Jintao
 Newly promoted to Standing Committee . . . Last served as Communist Party Secretary in Tibet, but spent most of his time in Beijing . . . In charge of Tibet since 1988, a time of harsh representation, but it is unclear what his role in it was.
 Forty-nine years old, a fast-rising star in the Communist Party . . . A decade ago, became the youngest Central Committee member at the time . . . Five years ago, became the youngest provicial party secretary . . . Newly appointed to Communist Party Secretariat.
 University degree in Hydraulic engineering . . . Promoted early in this career by Song Ping, a hard-liner . . . Promoted later by Hu Yaobang, a party leader who sought far-reaching change . . . Has a reputation as a reformer. (pg. A12)
