PUB-DATE: October 20, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1821 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Debate;
BUSH PUSHES HARD IN 3D DEBATE BUT FOES PUT HIM ON DEFENSIVE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The last of the three Presidential debates ended last night with President Bush still on the defensive about his first-term record and laboring to revive his campaign by warning that Gov. Bill Clinton lacked the leadership, the record and the character to be President.
In their most spirited, direct exchange yet, Mr. Bush assailed Mr. Clinton's record in Arkansas, his economic proposals and what Mr. Bush asserted was a habit of trying to have it both ways on issue after issue. 
 Mr. Clinton, responding to the President's attacks, hammered Mr. Bush's economic stewardship and resurrected his broken pledge from 1988: "I really can't believe Mr. Bush is still trying to make trust an issue after 'read my lips.' "
 
Focus on Iraq Conflict
 The Democratic Governor also joined with Ross Perot, the independent candidate, in opening a withering critique of Mr. Bush's handling of events leading to the conflict with Iraq.
Mr. Bush, who entered this debate with a clear and persistent deficit in public opinion polls, gave his most aggressive performance yet but did not appear to deliver the devastating blow to Mr. Clinton that Republicans had hoped for. [Transcript, pages A20-A23.]
Mr. Bush contended, repeatedly, that Mr. Clinton was a throwback to Democratic big-government and tax-and-spend policies that were abhorrent to the voters. "Mr. and Mrs. America, when you hear him say we're going to tax only the rich, watch your wallet because his figures don't add up, and he's going to sock it right to the middle-class taxpayer and lower, if he's going to pay for all the spending programs he proposes," Mr. Bush declared.
 
Bush Chided on Baker
 In one of the sharpest exchanges of the evening, Mr. Clinton criticized the President for initially saying that James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff and former Secretary of State, would return to the foreign-policy post and days later saying that Mr. Baker would be in charge of the economy.
"I'll make some news in the third debate," Mr. Clinton said. "The person responsible for economic policy in my administration will be Bill Clinton."
Mr. Bush responded hotly: "That's what worries me. He's going to be responsible."
And striking a persistent theme from last night -- reminiscent of the Republican attack against Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in 1988 -- he added that Mr. Clinton "would do for the United States what he's done to Arkansas."
 
Defending His State
 That remark prompted Mr. Clinton to interrupt "to defend the honor of my state" and defend his record.
But Mr. Clinton also delivered a biting critique of Mr. Bush's economic stewardship, saying that the President's "trickle-down economics" had been a failure. He defended his accomplishments as Governor and presented himself repeatedly as a man committed to easing the lot of the middle class.
"We're a low-spending, low-tax-burden" state, he said. "We dramatically increased investment, and our jobs are growing. I wish America had had that record."
In a sharp response to Mr. Bush's assertion that he had repeatedly waffled on important issues, Mr. Clinton reminded the national television audience that Mr. Bush had once described Ronald Reagan's economic proposals as "voodoo economics" only to embrace them when he joined the ticket in 1980.
 
Direct Attacks Avoided
 Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton avoided direct attacks on Mr. Perot, reflecting the belief of strategists in both camps that many of the Texas billionaire's supporters would drift away in the final days and be up for grabs.
And Mr. Perot, who remains mired in a distant third place in the public opinion polls, used his closing statement to urge voters to disregard the pundits who say he is not electable.
"You got to stop letting these people tell you who to vote for," he said. "You got to stop letting these folks in the press tell you you're throwing your vote away."
Mr. Perot also returned to one of his strongest appeals. "Who would you give your pension fund and your savings account to to manage?" he asked.
A CBS News Poll of 553 registered voters taken immediately after the debate found the race virtually unchanged since the previous CBS Poll taken over the weekend. The new poll, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points, found Mr. Clinton with 48 percent, Mr. Bush with 33 percent and Mr. Perot with 16 percent.
 
Attacked on Strong Suit
 The third and final debate, held at Michigan State University in East Lansing, and moderated by Jim Lehrer of PBS, was the first in which the candidates had energetically squared off on a foreign-policy issue, and it came on a subject that Mr. Bush's camp had long considered a strong point: the Persian Gulf war.
Mr. Perot maintained that Mr. Bush had given the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, a green light to seize the Kuwaiti oil fields just across the border from Iraq. Mr. Bush interrupted to "defend the national honor" and denied Mr. Perot's accusation.
But most of the skirmishing of the night occurred around taxes: the subtext was Mr. Bush's attempt to box Mr. Clinton in as a tax-and-spend liberal and Mr. Clinton's attempt to cast his proposals as a third way between traditional Democratic and Republican economic philosophies.
Mr. Clinton maintained that he would limit any tax increases to the very wealthy, flatly asserting, "I will not raise taxes on the middle class to pay for these programs." But he refused a questioner's invitation to pledge to forswear, under any condition, tax increases on the middle class. "I am not going to tell you, 'Read my lips,' " he said. "I can't tell you what emergencies are going to develop."
Mr. Bush, in his case against Mr. Clinton, emphasized the Democratic challenger's draft record less than he has in previous encounters. But he repeatedly tried to connect Mr. Clinton with the high inflation and high-interest rates of the Carter Administration.
"We remember what it was like when we had a spending President and a spending Congress and interest rates -- who remembers that? -- they were at 21.5 percent under Jimmy Carter and inflation was 15," Mr. Bush said. "We don't want to go back to that."
At one point in the debate, Mr. Clinton tried to turn one of Mr. Bush's favorite issues against him, saying, "He is the person who raised taxes on the middle class."
Mr. Bush responded, "I think everybody's paying too much taxes."
 
Focus on Arkansas
 In their most spirited, direct exchange yet, Mr. Bush assailed Mr. Clinton's record in Arkansas. He carefully prefaced his critique by saying, "It's not dirty campaigning" to take a hard look at the Democrat's state and asserted, "Arkansas is doing very, very badly against any standard."
Mr. Clinton responded by reciting his litany of accomplishments as Governor, including a rating that put Arkansas No. 1 in the creation of jobs in the last year.
The exchange led to the evening's first laughter as Mr. Perot made his contribution to the discussion. "I grew up five blocks from Arkansas," the Texas entrepreneur said. "It's a beautiful state." But he said it was also so small and atypical that "it's irrelevant," and compared the leap from its governorship to the Presidency to the difference between running a corner grocery and running Wal-Mart.
The state's Governor took offense. "I think it is highly relevant," Mr. Clinton said. "I think it's been pretty impressive."
 
Bush Objects to Question
 Mr. Bush was on the defensive when Mr. Lehrer asked whether he ignored domestic problems like race and health care until they became crises. "I don't think that's a fair shot," the President said.
Mr. Bush also took pains to blame Congress for frustrating the promise of his domestic proposals. Mr. Clinton tried to present himself as a man who would enter office with a brisk, 100-days agenda for domestic needs.
The President suggested that voters look back at the last time there was a Democrat in the White House.
"The misery index went right through the roof," he said. "Remember the question, 'are you better off?' " Mr. Bush asked. "Well, is a home buyer better off because he can refinance a home because interest rates are down? Is the senior citizen better off because inflation is not wiping out their family's savings? I think they are.
"Is the guy out of work better off? Of course he's not, but he's not going to be better off if we grow the government, if we invest, as Governor Clinton says, invest in more government."
Mr. Perot also bridled at a question from Mr. Lehrer, who asked whether he was a perennial quitter. As evidence of his commitment, he said, he would spend more than $60 million of his own money on the campaign.
"I'm here tonight, folks," he added. "When you asked me to come back in, I came back in. I've put my wallet on the table for you and your children."
The candidates clashed on the North American Free Trade Agreement, a pact reached by the United States, Mexico and Canada. Mr. Bush accused Mr. Clinton of straddling the fence on the issue after Mr. Perot condemned the agreement, which awaits Congressional approval.
The draft issue arose in the second half of the debate, when the questioning was done by a panel of reporters: Helen Thomas of United Press International, Gene Gibbons of Reuters and Susan Rook of CNN.
 
Suspicions Over 1990
 Mr. Clinton said his decision in 1969 to avoid the draft was not a mistake and would not affect his ability to command the armed services. But he also acknowledged that he had not adequately handled the questions that surfaced about how he had avoided military service.
"If I had it to do over again, I might have answered the questions a little better," he said.
During a round of questions about whether more women should serve in high government positions, Mr. Perot said the Bush Administration had withheld information about whether the American Ambassador in Baghdad, April C. Glaspie, had encouraged Saddam Hussein to invade Kuwait in the summer of 1990.
"We told him you can take the northern part of Kuwait," Mr. Perot said.
Mr. Bush interjected angrily, "We did not say to Saddam Hussein, Ross, that you can take the northern part of Kuwait."
In response to criticism from Mr. Perot, Mr. Bush strongly defended his decision to reach out to Iraq in the years before the war in the Persian Gulf. He repeated his assertion that offering loan guarantees and other assistance to Mr. Hussein was part of an effort, albeit a failed one, to bring Iraq into the "family of nations."
He portrayed the growing scandal over United States-Iraqi relations as politically motivated and fomented by Democratic members of Congress who had initially supported his overtures to that country.
Mr. Clinton praised the President for his leadership during the Gulf war. But he said the Administration had gone too far in courting a dangerous dictator.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 918 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis;
A Late-Round Flurry for Bush
But Shape of Race Appears Unaltered

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
The last Presidential debate, the politicians and pundits said before it began, was President Bush's last best hope to shift the tone and the dynamics of the campaign. Do something different, they told Mr. Bush, or prepare to lose the Presidency on Nov. 3.
He changed his ways for the better. There was no looking at his watch in last night's encounter in East Lansing, Mich., as there had been last week, and no suggestion of languor. His message was clear. He did his best to make voters think about character and trust, rather than blaming him for costing them their jobs, even invoking Horace Greeley to the effect that character counts most. 
 But by the end of 90 minutes, the President had plowed little new substantive ground, and it appeared doubtful that he had done enough to alter the course of a campaign in which his own economic record had been a political millstone and Bill Clinton had taken a commanding lead. Instant polls suggested that he had not.
Because Mr. Bush is behind in so many states, he had hoped to lift his national standing in the debates, then go after individual states with big blocks of electoral votes in the remaining two weeks. If it turns out that he failed, he faces longer odds in picking up the swing states that he badly needs, like Ohio, Michigan and Illinois.
The President's job was made harder because he was under attack not only from Mr. Clinton this time but for most of the evening from Ross Perot as well. On Iraq, Panama and the savings and loan scandal, Mr. Perot blamed Mr. Bush for blunders that had cost the nation dearly.
Mr. Perot provided much of the evening's fireworks and, as before, most of its sparse supply of humor. He tried bravely to shake the label of "quitter," from which he had suffered since his sudden withdrawal last July, with an account of his steadfastness in earlier crises. But he offered few specific programs of his own.
 
Little Excitement, No Blunders
 Once again, Mr. Clinton was calm, well-organized and direct, and he stood up well in the crunch. If he generated little excitement, he also ended his three long confrontations with his rivals without having made any significant misstatements or errors.
Mr. Bush, trying to walk a fine line between manifesting Presidential dignity and an underdog's aggression, laid out his arguments with a new vigor, particularly his assertions that Mr. Clinton had been a failure as Governor of Arkansas and would fail again if elected President.
A Clinton victory, he argued repeatedly, would give the nation "a spending President and a spending Congress" like those he said it had had when Jimmy Carter was in the White House in the late 1970's and both taxes and interest rates were high.
Seeking to portray Mr. Clinton as slippery and indecisive while winning himself a degree of absolution for the recession, Mr. Bush kept saying, "If I make a mistake, I admit it," and he kept accusing Mr. Clinton of working both sides of every issue.
 
Perot Cites Noriega and Hussein
 But in one of the most dramatic moments of the nationally televised debate, Mr. Perot swiftly counterattacked, accusing Mr. Bush without mentioning his name of using taxpayers' money to bring Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and President Saddam Hussein to power, and calling on him to admit those mistakes. That weakened Mr. Bush's point considerably.
Mr. Perot also accused the President of having told Mr. Hussein that he could annex northern Kuwait and demanded that he release relevant papers. Mr. Bush reacted with a flat, heated denial, and the impact of that exchange was difficult to discern.
The President kept his concentration sharp. There was "a pattern," "this pattern," "your pattern" of indecision and inconsistency, he argued, trying to fix that word and the ideas he associated with it firmly in voters' minds as a description of Governor Clinton.
Twitting Mr. Bush for having said his chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, would take charge of a second-term economic program, Mr. Clinton said he would be the one to take charge of such a program in a Clinton Administration. The President deftly shot back; "That's what worries me. He's going to be responsible." 
 
Composure Unshaken
 But the Democratic candidate's composure was never shaken, and he returned Mr. Bush's fire, round for round. It was the President, he said, who had signed a big tax increase after promising not to; it was the President who had embraced Ronald Reagan's economic policies after denouncing them as "voodoo economics."
Mr. Clinton also found a number of ways to suggest that he and Ross Perot, the independent candidate, were talking about the issues while President Bush sought to return to the kind of personal attacks that voters had complained about.
Clearly, Mr. Bush and his strategists had concluded that he had to get tough. In his own terms he did so, taking the fight to Mr. Clinton with lines like "watch your wallet, because his figures don't add up." Breaking the rules agreed to by his representative, Mr. Bush responded immediately and directly to Mr. Perot's accusations about Iraq.
But in the end the President is not a slasher, any more than Mr. Clinton is. That role belongs to Mr. Perot in this year's electoral melodrama. Mr. Bush's basically easy-going nature peeked through his carefully constructed plan when, after attacking the House of Representatives, he said of the Democratic speaker, Thomas S. Foley, "very able, decent fellow, I might add."

MORGAN STANLEY TO REMAIN
Morgan Stanley Group, which had been considering moving its New York City headquarters and as many as 4,100 employees to Stamford, Conn., will remain in the city for at least 10 years, company officials said, after the city and state agreed to almost $40 million in incentives over the next decade. A1
 
SHRINKING FAMILIES
The share of married couples living with their own children in New York City declined from 19.2 percent of all households in 1980 to less than 17 percent in 1990, a census analysis showed. The trend, which is not new or unique to New York, shows that the family has been redefined. A1

HEADLINE: Brochures, Fliers, Polls, Ads: Politics as a Business Slumps

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19

 BODY:
There will be many winners come Election Day, but it is already clear who the big losers in politics are this year.
They are the people who print the brochures, mail the fliers, take the polls and broadcast the spots for the candidates. Election Day is to this industry what Christmas is to retailing, and neither Democrats nor Republicans are buying big this season. 
 The recession has changed the rhythm and character of campaigning in America. In almost all parts of the country, candidates squeezed by dwindling contributions are saving their scarce advertising dollars for the last minute and looking for more efficient ways to harvest votes.
 
Crying the Blues
 As a result, voters are getting a measure of merciful relief from months of hortatory advertising and other political schlock, though it might not seem so during this final election blitz. But the consultants, printers, advertising agencies, television stations, newspapers and others who drink at the trough of commercialism that has replaced old-fashioned campaigning are laying off people, cutting costs and crying the blues.
"This always seemed like a recession-proof industry," said Frank L. Tobe, president of Below Tobe & Associates of Marina del Rey, Calif., a vendor of computerized voter lists and other technical services to Democratic candidates nationally, including Gov. Bill Clinton. "But this time it really has affected us. You learn a lot in a year like this when people don't have money."
Here in California, with two important races for United States Senate, the four major candidates only recently began to advertise -- just a month before the election. A continent away in Connecticut, Paul Horgan's Ace Printery in Hartford is having its worst political year since 1970. Only 6 of the 10 or 11 Democratic state senators he usually prints for are doing mailings this year, meaning billings are down 40 percent.
"The political season is usually the boost my guys look for," Mr. Horgan said. "It comes right before Christmas and gives them some extra money. This year, there's no boost."
The recession is also speeding technological changes in campaigning in a year scrambled by redistricting and an anti-incumbent mood. With contributions way down, candidates are using new communications and computer techniques to aim at certain voters rather than relying on costly broad-based advertising.
While President Bush and Governor Clinton get Federal campaign funds, candidates for nearly all other offices, from Senate to local city council seats around the country, depend largely on local givers. And it seems that nearly everybody, even the proverbial fat cat, is broke.
 
Few Real Estate Dollars
 "Four years ago in Massachusetts, 25 percent of the Democratic dollars raised came from people connected to real estate development," said Michael A. Goldman of Goldman Associates, a consultant in Boston. "This year it's been about 5 percent. Nothing is being developed. When a candidate who hopes to raise $300,000 raises only $150,000, everybody gets hurt."
Thus, radio station WLLH, which serves the Merrimack Valley cities of Lowell and Lawrence, Mass., has had to beat the bushes for political advertising. Its five-member sales staff solicited about 50 candidates and got business from 20. "It used to be a walk-in business," said Perry G. Kapiloff, general manager. "But this year nobody had money. They said, 'I want to do more, but this is what I've got.' "
And in Portland, Ore., The Oregonian, the state's largest newspaper, has cut its rates for political advertising in half -- with only marginal results.
Republicans, normally flush, have been hit especially hard, given both the recession and President Bush's weakness in the polls. "In 1988, with Bush riding high, you had a coattail situation," said Jay Severin 3d, an advertising consultant in New York who works for Republican candidates in New Jersey. "Even with money tight, people would buy into that. Now the coattail resembles an anvil." He said his revenues were down about 15 or 20 percent.
In California, the four United States Senate candidates are each having to make do with a fraction of the $16 million that Pete Wilson, now the state's Republican Governor, raised to run for the Senate in 1988. According to Kam Kuwata, campaign manager for Dianne Feinstein, one of the Democrats, the campaign is not going to come anywhere near the $10 million it thought it needed. Her Republican opponent, Senator John Seymour, is in much the same boat.
 
Cutting Direct Mail
 In the past, advertising started here almost the day after the June primary; this time not until October. Also, Mr. Kuwata said, to save money direct mail is being used much more narrowly than before, just at the crucial "swing" voters who typically make the difference.
Some companies have capitalized on the downturn. John J. Jarrett, owner of Button King in San Jose, Calif., said orders were up by 30 to 40 percent. He attributed this to two factors: Badges are used as a cheap reward for unpaid volunteers, and many campaigns are selling them this year, rather than giving them away.
Orders for essentials like posters and yard signs are good, according to Herbert Barker, president of the Barker Specialty Company, a printer in Cheshire, Conn., but almost nobody is buying novelties like emblazoned litter bags, refrigerator magnets and pencils.
To be sure, the big pros in the business are not going broke. "But they are all saying they're working harder for the same amount of money," said Jerry Hagstrom, a Washington-based author writing a book on political consultants. "The very top firms are doing as well as ever in the numbers of clients. But for ones starting out it's really rough."
The uncertainties injected by redistricting and anti-incumbency have given a certain boost to outfits like the Garin-Hart Research Group in Washington, which polls for many incumbent Democratic Senators and Representatives.
 
Redistricting Has Helped
 "Political funding is off," said George Shipley, a consultant in Austin, Tex. "But redistricting has destabilized the American political system and most consultants benefit by that instability."
But whatever their ideological differences, Democratic and Republican candidates share the frugality platform. In Bellingham, Wash., the campaign to re-elect Al Swift to an eighth term in Congress has saved $18,000 by designing its own campaign brochures instead of using graphic artists, and has told some of its nine paid staff workers that they may be let go before the election.
"If it's a choice between an extra four television commercials and one staffer, I have to factor in which expenditure is going to reach more voters," said Jeffrey Morris, campaign director for the Democratic Representative. "This is the first year where incumbents, including Al, are on the phone saying 'I need help.' "
This kind of thing is bad news for big vendors like Below Tobe & Associates. Out of its quarters near the colorful yacht harbors at Marina del Rey annually come millions of pieces of political mail and voter lists for campaigns in New Hampshire, Missouri and dozens of other states. But this year the staff is down to 25 from 40 four years ago.
The company mainly works for political consultants. The consultants have cut back substantially on the slate cards they sell to candidates and which are a staple of Below Tobe's business. "Many of our major clients cannot get money from their candidates," said Mr. Tobe, the president, adding that the industry was being convulsed by breakneck changes in technology, such as broadcast faxing, satellite interviews and raising money through "800" numbers.
 
Shedding Its Mainframe
 "This is truly the year of technological change," he said. "All these things are contributing to faster response, smaller universes, more focus -- and less volume." The day after Election Day, the 21-year-old company will shut its big mainframe computer room, saving $20,000 a month, and shift to cheaper personal computers.
Four hundred miles to the north on Mission Street in San Francisco, Winning Directions, one of the nation's leading direct-mail houses, is struggling, too. The imaginative creations of its chief designer, Ted Cabarga, are coveted by candidates nationally. But this year, according to its president, Anthony Fazio, the company is doing more campaigns than ever but business is still down because each customer buys less than before.
Normally, he said, a candidate for, say, county supervisor in California would buy six to eight mailings, one early in the campaign, another about a month before Election Day, followed by a blitz of four or five in the final two weeks. "Now we're lucky to do four," Mr. Fazio said.

HEADLINE: At Edge of Campaign, Jackson Labors On for Democratic Victory

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLAINE, Wash., Oct. 18

 BODY:
In a howling rainstorm at the far western edge of the continent, the Rev. Jesse Jackson huddled under a tent. If he searched the length of the United States, he probably could not find a place more removed from the hot lights of national politics than this small town on the Canadian border.
"This is a season of pain," Mr. Jackson told several hundred union members from both sides of the border who had gathered to protest provisions of the North American Free Trade Agreement. "We must turn our pain into power." 
 For Mr. Jackson, a central figure in Presidential politics for the last 12 years, a man who has always had an acute sense of his daily standing in the rough drafts of history, this year may appear to be one long season of pain as he works the periphery of the main campaign.
With the help and occasional guidance of the Democratic National Committee, which has provided Mr. Jackson with a private plane, he has been to 27 states, sometimes visiting five towns in a single day. His tour has taken him in the last week from Colorado to Montana to rural Washington and Oregon. These are not the kinds of places, he said, "where you talk about Sister Souljah," referring to the rap performer who became a focal point of the differences between him and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. But Mr. Jackson, in scheduling his itinerary, has chosen places like the Northwest.
 
Heavy Schedule of Touring
 At age 51, Mr. Jackson has visited more places this year than the touring rock star Axl Rose, his aides point out. But if the tour's goal is registering voters, as was stated early on, his presence in states like this one where the deadline for voter registration has long passed raises questions.
"One of my jobs is to generate enthusiasm for a big turnout," he said in an interview. Mr. Jackson said he was in the distant Western states in the closing days of the campaign rather than populous Eastern states because other issues and candidates, like gay rights in Colorado and Oregon, a close Congressional race in Montana and free trade in Washington, are also part of his agenda.
With Mr. Clinton appearing to be on the verge of achieving what Mr. Jackson could not, forging a diverse coalition to win the ultimate electoral prize, Mr. Jackson shows only a hint of envy. He may be on the sidelines, but the issues he has long stressed, like health care, education, job losses and racial division, are winning the race for Mr. Clinton, he said.
Mr. Jackson scoffs at the oft-heard claim that Mr. Clinton has been able to regain the Democrats who voted for Ronald Reagan by distancing himself from Mr. Jackson and the liberal wing of the party.
"I talked to Governor Clinton two days ago," Mr. Jackson recalled. "I said: 'You're not winning because you're giving blacks the elbow. You're winning because the objective economic circumstances are so bad, because Anita Hill energized women and because Bush is running an inexplicably weak campaign.' "
The two men talk frequently on the telephone, he said, asserting that his substantive differences with Mr. Clinton have been resolved.
"We said there had to be a big-tent strategy, that there was not enough campaigning in the cities, not enough association with blacks," he said. "These concerns have been largely met."
Some political friends say Mr. Jackson has put most of the pain of this year behind him. Still, there are sore points.
 
'A Separate Standard'
 "When Ross Perot entered the race, nobody talked about his lack of electoral experience, but that's one of the main criticisms you've always heard about Jesse," said Charles Rolland, an aide to Mayor Norm Rice of Seattle. "I guess there's a separate standard for billionaires."
The Democratic National Committee credits Mr. Jackson with helping to register an enormous number of voters, particularly in the South, where the Presidential race is considered to be close in many states.
But he is not just registering new voters. He literally led voters to the polls last week in Colorado. It is one of two states where the general election is stretched out over several weeks to allow voting similar to absentee balloting. After a rally in Denver, he led a parade to the voting booths. He plans to lead a similar march in Texas, which also allows early voting.
And the payoff for Mr. Jackson? "I'm not looking for a job," he said. "I'm looking for a President." The Clinton campaign has not talked to him about a possible Cabinet post, he said.
On the stump, Mr. Jackson seems more passionate when criticizing President Bush than when he is praising Governor Clinton. What really gets him excited, he said, is the prospect of electing 40 blacks to Congress this year, up from 25.
He said the electorate had been transformed from four years ago by redistricting and the rise of female candidates that followed Prof. Anita Hill's testimony in the Supreme Court nomination hearings of Judge Clarence Thomas.
"You see, Gov. Clinton is reaping something he didn't sow," he said. The collapse of Communism, which weakened the Republicans' appeal to the need for military strength, and the bad economy made this year tailor made for a Democrat, he said.
When asked if he would have preferred to be that Democrat, Mr. Jackson said he had no regrets. But he did point out how much better he did in many states than Senator Al Gore, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, when they sought the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988.
"Our concern right now is Clinton versus Bush," he said. "But another struggle begins Nov. 4. It is a struggle for the soul of the country. I don't think it will be a hostile struggle."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
It's Your Choice, Lilian: The Cad or the Cluck

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

Folly
By Susan Minot
278 pages. Houghton Mifflin/Seymour Lawrence. $19.95.
In her latest novel, Susan Minot, the acclaimed author of "Monkeys" and "Lust," takes a step backward into the past, to the years between World Wars I and II. But while "Folly" is set in a different era from her previous books, it takes place in a familiar world of old families and genteel wealth, and it tackles familiar themes of familial and romantic love. 
 At the age of 18, Ms. Minot's heroine, Lilian Eliot, is a pretty, optimistic girl, the daughter of one of Boston's good Beacon Hill families. Her life takes place within the circumscribed social rituals of her parents' circle: holiday get-togethers at the houses of friends, skating parties in the winter, the occasional concert and Historical Society tour.
Though she has vague yearnings for a wider world, though she is sometimes amazed "by the amount of feeling sloshing about inside her," Lilian is basically a conventional young woman. She knows that her choice of a husband will define her, and once she marries, she knows her husband's choices will "determine her life." "Not only did she not think of making certain choices herself," writes Ms. Minot, "she was completely unaware of having the desire to do so."
This theme of a young woman's coming of age in a strict, highly stratified society, was of course a favorite of writers like Edith Wharton and Henry James; and like those authors, Ms. Minot seems interested in using her heroine's sentimental education to explore the consequences that the strict social mores of an earlier age could have on a malleable young mind.
As depicted by Ms. Minot, Lilian's Boston emerges as a stultifying, suffocating place. The women chatter mindlessly at teas and luncheons about clothes and hair and the latest news: "who was engaged, who had cut whom, how the children were behaving." The men spend their free time golfing, playing tennis and drinking.
When Lilian sees people walking up and down Beacon Street or Tremont Street, she notices that none of them reveal "anything of what was going on inside." They seemed to be "putting their feelings in one hidden place and the rest of themselves out in life."
Then, suddenly one evening, everything changes for Lilian when she meets a friend of a friend from New York, an intense, fiercely independent man by the name of Walter Vail. Lilian's parents are put off by Walter's abrupt manners and overall "look," but Lilian is smitten. Even when he breaks a date to have dinner with another woman, Lilian remains steadfast in her infatuation. Walter makes her feel "like someone else," someone more exciting and vivid, and she resolves to wait for him when he goes away to war.
The war eventually ends, but Walter does not return, and for years Lilian hears nothing further from him. While her friends marry and begin having children, she resigns herself to being a spinster. Just as she has begun to abandon all hope of connecting to another man, she meets Gilbert Finch, a quiet, agreeable fellow, who impresses her with his decency and reserve. Gilbert fits in easily with Lilian's family and friends, and in his presence, she feels herself "returned to herself."
The pair announce their engagement, marry, set up housekeeping in Boston, and -- in a fast-forward leap -- have three children. Although Gilbert has a nervous breakdown at one point, he eventually recovers, and life in the Finch household soon settles into a predictable routine. It's a boring, emotionally empty routine, but Lilian is determined to be a dutiful wife. Her life seems "airtight, all the seams sewn up," with "little space for anything new" -- that is, till Walter Vail unexpectedly resurfaces and once again insinuates himself in her life.
As "Monkeys" clearly demonstrated, Ms. Minot has a gift for delineating her characters' inner lives with economy and precision, and she does a nimble job here of tracing the emotional arc of Lilian's life, revealing her gradual move from innocence into awareness and eventual disappointment.
Unfortunately, the people surrounding Lilian are little more than sounding boards, two-dimensional automatons who are meant to give her something to react to. Her Boston girlfriends, for the most part, are a shallow, unremarkable lot, differentiated only by their different styles in flirting with men. Her parents are cliches: her father is a cold, intolerant patriarch; her mother, a parody of the passive, long-suffering wife.
Worst of all are the two men in Lilian's life, who are crude stereotypes of the charming cad and the ineffectual dolt, types epitomized, for many readers, by Heathcliff and Linton in "Wuthering Heights" and by Rhett and Ashley in "Gone With the Wind." It's apparent from the first that Walter is a complete ne'er-do-well: his charm is smarmy and insincere; his cynicism, all too apparent. As for Gilbert, he's a simpering wimp: weak, self-absorbed and crushingly dull. Perhaps their portraits are meant to be satiric; perhaps their two-dimensionality is simply a result of Ms. Minot's difficulty in creating a full cast of characters in period emotional dress.
Whatever the reason, both Gilbert and Walter are so broadly drawn that we have difficulty understanding why Lilian would spend an afternoon (much less a lifetime) with either one, a fact that can't help but undermine our sympathy for her.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Business at the Tracks Is Beating the Odds

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
New York racing closed its 42-day autumn meeting at Belmont Park yesterday with no further erosion of attendance or betting, and officials were optimistic that the full year might show the first gain in attendance in 10 years.
The year's totals will depend on what happens during the next 62 racing days at Aqueduct in Queens, where the New York season will be resumed tomorrow. Between then and the end of the year, nine races a day will be run six days a week, with 33 stakes offering more than $4 million in purses. 
 Racing people were clearly pleased with business at Belmont for the last seven weeks because it seemed to be stabilizing after years of recession in the horse industry. At least, attendance and betting were only fractionally off last year's totals for Belmont's fall season.
The average daily attendance was 10,601, which was almost identical to last year's total, and the betting handle averaged $2.4 million, which was about $8,000 below last year's average. And for the 251 days of racing so far this year at Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga, attendance has gained slightly more than 1 percent over last year.
"There is something positive happening here," said Jerry Lawrence, executive vice president of the New York Racing Association. "If we can keep it going for the rest of the year, we will accomplish something that hasn't happened here in over a decade."
Lawrence noted that New York's racing business has held its own despite the extensive series of betting programs begun at the Meadowlands track in New Jersey, where bets can be placed on races from as far away as England and Scotland.
"It's no secret that money is tight right now," he said, "and there is increasing competition for the entertainment and gambling dollar. In spite of increased competition for the New York City bettor with full-card simulcasting day and night at the Meadowlands, it is an outstanding accomplishment that our business figures remained level."
Lawrence also said that the quality of racing was energized when Belmont bunched stakes races on Sept. 19 and Oct. 10 as previews for the Breeders' Cup, which will be held Oct. 31 at Gulfstream Park in Florida.
"We were able to re-establish New York as the center of fall racing with our two Super Saturdays," he said.
The autumn meeting also crowned a new riding champion: Jerry Bailey rode 37 winners and edged out Chris Antley, who rode 33, with Mike Smith and Julie Krone next. The leading trainer was Shug McGaughey, who saddled 17 winners, three more than Peter Ferriola. During five weeks at Saratoga this summer, McGaughey saddled only two winners during an unlikely dry spell.
Aqueduct will put a dozen juveniles on stage tomorrow for its opening stakes race, the $100,000 Cowdin at seven furlongs. The early favorite: the McGaughey entry of Not for Love and Ferociously, half-brother to the similarly well-named Furiously.
 
FINISH LINE
 When you're hot, you're hot. And ANDRE FABRE, the French trainer, is hot. He won the Arc de Triomphe two weeks ago and then headed to America, where he won the All Along Stakes at Laurel on Saturday, the Long Island Handicap at Belmont on Sunday and the Tidal Stakes there yesterday. He also finished first in the Rothmans International at Woodbine on Saturday, but his horse was disqualified for crowding and was dropped to third. Fabre scored at Belmont yesterday with the 3-year-old filly Revasser, who stayed off the lead until the homestretch, when she ran down Honor Rajana and beat him by two lengths, with Time for Lightning three lengths back in third. The winner ran the mile and three-eighths on the turf in 2:14 3/5 and paid $8.20 for $2 to win as second choice to Stagecraft, who faded to seventh.
 
Arazi Classic-Bound?
 LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Arazi is expected to run in the $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic and would lead three European 3-year-olds in the premier race on Breeders' Cup Day at Gulfstream Park on Oct. 31, an English newspaper reported today.
The Racing Post today quoted Allen Paulson, a co-owner of Arazi, as saying that the French-trained colt was likely to enter the mile-and-a-quarter Classic.
"Francois Boutin favors it," Paulson said, referring to Arazi's trainer. "He says Arazi is back to his old self, has never been better."
Rodrigo de Triano, winner of the English 2,000 Guineas and Champion Stakes, is set for the Classic, as is St. Jovite, the Irish Derby winner.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
BELL LABORATORIES HIRES 27 RUSSIAN RESEARCH SCIENTISTS

 BODY:
A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories, in its second such venture, said yesterday that it had hired 27 more Russian scientists, this time from St. Petersburg. The scientists, working under a one-year contract from Bell Labs, are from the A. F. Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute. They will conduct fundamental research into semiconductor physics and semiconductor lasers. As the Russian economy collapses and government subsidies disappear from huge scientific enterprises, many Western companies, including those in the United States, have become concerned that Russian scientific work would founder for want of paychecks. 
 The value of the new A.T.& T. contract is less than $100,000, including salaries, travel expenses and equipment. In May, A.T.& T. and Corning Inc., announced separate agreements in which each hired the services of more than 100 Russian scientists in the field of fiber-optic research.

HEADLINE: An Asian Voice for Democracy

 BODY:
Few people doubt that foreign broadcasts contributed powerfully to the democratic ferment in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. Why shouldn't American radio programs do the same in the still-Communist countries of Asia and for the unfree Burmese?
A special Congressional commission makes a persuasive case for creating an Asia Democracy Radio or Asia Information Radio to provide the kind of coverage now offered in the West by Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty. 
 Such programming could fill a conspicuous gap at modest cost. "Radio is an instrument of peace, not a weapon of war," declares the Commission on Broadcasting to the People's Republic of China. "It is inexpensive and it maims no one."
And radio is king in China: there were 200 million sets in 1989, compared with 30 million television sets. Of 350 hours of foreign broadcasting to China each week, only 15 percent is in Chinese -- and more than half of that comes from Taiwan, much of it hard-line propaganda.
Hence there is room for balanced, professionally prepared programming, in native languages, that would cover internal developments in China -- and in North Korea, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam and Myanmar, the new name given to Burma by its military overlords.
The commission's report follows the very different recommendations of another high-level panel concerned with the future of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, based in Munich. That panel urged, unwisely, that these stations be phased out and television be given higher priority than radio. But that overvalues TV, slights radio and too readily dismisses the case for independently managed stations that would cover day-to-day events within the listeners' own country.
A majority on the Asia commission reasonably holds that the proposed new service should be organized like Radio Free Europe, under a separate board, independent of Voice of America, thus assuring diversity of voices. Part of the start-up cost could be met, the report argues, by closing down TV Marti, a failed Cuban service that Fidel Castro has effectively jammed. Given America's immense political and economic stake in the Pacific, Asia Democracy Radio deserves a trial.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
No Hiding Place

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Now we have to hurry up and decide for ourselves the one critical question about a candidate's fitness to hold the Presidency that the debates failed to answer.
Can he walk and chew gum at the same time? 
 Spelled out: Can he recapture Americans' faith in their economic future and at the same time deal properly with "foreign" problems that will become American problems whether we like it or do not like it?
In the last debate Ross Perot put in a vivid reminder of the Bushbaker appeasement before the war. But that was a maverick moment in a series in which the world outside America was made to disappear. The assumption of questioners and candidates was that for the next few years the President could concentrate solely on domestic matters while the world stood docilely by awaiting his eventual attention.
That is startling naivete. So here are a few examples of minefields Americans might want to think about now, because after Inauguration Day we will be watching our President try to walk his way through them:
1. Russia is going down. Many old Communists are ready and eager to put on their other face, never really hidden. If the United States cannot get its eye off its economic navel we will spend billions confronting a Fascist Kremlin instead of a Communist Kremlin -- hardly a great example of cost-efficiency.
2. Proliferation. China has become the supermarket of third-world dictators hunting for missiles and nuclear technology.
China not only produces and sells modern weapons and nuclear technology but is getting more of both at discount prices from Russia. Adding a decent markup, it sells them to customers like Syria and Iran.
From Czechoslovakia and other Eastern European buffets various Middle Eastern dictatorships snap up good cheap tanks and other delicatessen of war.
The problem is, we sell billions in our own death specialties, like fighter planes, to Taiwan and freedom-loving Saudi Arabia, among other countries. So it does get difficult to put an anti-proliferation squeeze on the Russians or East Europeans.
Still, the life and death issue of the years ahead will be whether West and East will again arm dictatorships to the point where they can start war. That will be far more important economically to us than owls or even capital gains cuts.
3. Beijing is ditching some of the economic ballast of Communism but not its political noose. Hitler and Japan showed what the combination of dictatorship and state capitalism can bring in domestic oppression. Economic sanctions could force Beijing to ease off on brutality against its own people. But that could mean less grain sold to China, fewer cheap-labor products on the American market. Are we ready?
4. Europe has the military power to deal with the Bosnian horror. But, surprise, Europe took a walk.
American jets attacking Serbian artillery and military planes could still prevent more massacres. Well?
5. Cuba. During the next four years, there's likely to be a revolt against Castro's oppression. The rebels will ask for United States help. Then?
I think if I were an editor whose team of reporters forgot to ask candidates about these things I might be real annoyed. But we will just have to find our own clues.
Mr. Bush would rely on James Baker to "coordinate" the economy -- to chew while he walks. Presumably that would leave Mr. Bush to devote himself again to foreign affairs.
History will remember Mr. Bush as the man who organized and won the victory in the Persian Gulf. It will also remember him as the man who threw the victory away and who tried to revive the Soviet corpse when it was dead and stinking.
Mr. Clinton has solid government background, but no important foreign policy experience. But he does have something important. He seems to know where he is going.
In his foreign affairs talks is a sense of constancy. It is the belief that promotion of democracy abroad is in America's interests, that dictatorships cannot be appeased, that in their very nature lie the genes of war.
I voted for Mr. Bush but have found it increasingly difficult to understand his political philosophy about the conduct of world affairs or where consistency and constancy exist. I no longer know what he is telling us, and where he is walking.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Singling Out Blacks Where Few Are to Be Found;
Amid Hills of Rural New York, Students From Inner City Find Not-So-Hearty Welcome

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ONEONTA, N.Y., Oct. 17

 BODY:
Derrick Forbes's first day at school was like a page torn from a journal of the old South.
The afternoon he arrived here from Brooklyn two years ago, the lanky, soft-spoken soccer player waited downtown for a bus. When it arrived, Mr. Forbes said, a police officer blocked his way, forcing him to wait until all the whites had climbed on. 
 "I was wondering if the cop was drunk, or if he had something personal against blacks," Mr. Forbes said. "He couldn't know me at all."
A small city of Victorian houses in upstate New York, Oneonta has become emblematic of the rural towns across New York that draw thousands of blacks from the inner cities to college campuses every September, promising a tranquil path to mainstream America. But the city youths arrive as aliens in a distinctly white world, and say they remain on its fringes, feeling unwelcome in its stores, on its streets and in its bars.
 
Sense of Existing Apart
 The sense of existing apart from the community, a buried discomfort for many of the black students and faculty, surged to the surface six weeks ago, when the State University of New York's College at Oneonta supplied the names of all its black male students to police officers investigating the attempted rape of a 77-year-old white woman who had described her assailant as a young black man. With a few keystrokes on a computer, the school transformed 125 students into suspects in the criminal investigation, solely on the basis of color. To the consternation of government and business leaders, the action catapulted race to the front and center of the local agenda.
For blacks here, the college's action was a watershed, exploding the internal dams that kept frustration and anger at bay. In looking at the way they lived, students, faculty and longtime residents recalled a torrent of indignities, subtle and profound, that together betrayed the underside of a rustic town's charms. They realized their small decisions were often circumscribed by race.
And whites reacted with such astonishment that an outsider could wonder whether the two races were living in the same town at all.
"The last time something like this happened," said Kevin Slater, who has worked as a consultant to the school on multicultural programs, was in 1955 in Montgomery, Ala., when Rosa Parks refused to give up her bus seat to a white person "and it became a national issue."
"That one situation made people look at the whole fabric of society," he said.
Last week, the students began describing their experiences in Oneonta to a team of lawyers from the American Civil Liberties Union, who will likely bring a class-action suit on behalf of those whose names were given to the state police.
Providing the list, the college's president, Alan B. Donovan, has acknowledged, violated the Family Right to Privacy Act of 1974. It appears, however, that the Civil Liberties Union may bring suit on broader grounds.
"Their birthright entitles them to equal protection under the law," said Scott N. Fein, a partner in the Albany firm of Whiteman, Osterman & Hanna. "This appears not to be a universally held view in the community."
Officials here say that beyond releasing the list -- which they deplore as a humiliation and a political blunder -- they do not feel black students are regarded with suspicion. Aside from a party that grew too loud and went too late a few weekends ago, the town's population of 15,000 -- 97 percent white -- has never had to deal with disturbances from the 400 or so black students at Oneonta. It is far more accustomed to weekend noise and violence from the school's 5,100 white students, said Police Chief John H. Donadio.
"There's discrimination against students," he said. "We realize they're crucial to the economy, but they build resentment, an awful resentment, among people here."
 
Matters of Race
 Chief Donadio denied that officers harassed blacks or ignored their complaints, and he labeled Mr. Forbes's description of his first day in Oneonta "preposterous." David W. Brenner, the Mayor of Oneonta, laments that the issue of race has "contaminated the environment."
But black students like Derrick Forbes, Frederic Sanon and Lawrence Plaskett -- who came to these picturesque hills to learn far from New York City -- say the environment here has always been contaminated by matters of race, it was just that the whites never had much reason to notice.
Mr. Forbes said he had had several jarring run-ins with the Oneonta police. A soccer star, he reversed the team's losing streak when he joined. One night, he went out drinking with the team after a winning game. His teammates threw their arms over his shoulders. "They said I was their lucky charm," he recalls, and smiled.
But when they left the bus, five police cars waited, with officers accusing him of selling drugs to his teammates. They searched him for drugs and found none, he said.
"If there's a black guy and white guys hanging around him, he must have something they want," Mr. Forbes said. "That's my perspective on how they thought."
 
'A Very Wrong Decision'
 Chief Donadio does not deny that some of his men may be prejudiced, but he said they were professionals who would not let it affect their work.
Come June, Mr. Forbes plans to leave Oneonta. "Right now, I think coming to Oneonta was a very wrong decision," he said.
Frederic Sanon complained that shopkeepers tended to watch black customers more closely than whites, as if they expected them to shoplift.
"When you go shopping, you make sure you don't have a book bag, no loose pants, nowhere they could say I put something on me," said Mr. Sanon, a sophomore from the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. "I feel on edge. Every time I go shopping I check myself."
Mr. Sanon was arrested for disorderly conduct last spring after he asked to see a copy of the store policy when the manager of a supermarket demanded he check his knapsack.
"When he threatened to call the police, I said, 'Go ahead,' because I thought the cops would agree that it wasn't fair," Mr. Sanon said. But the police officer upheld the store's position, and Mr. Sanon shouted epithets labeling Oneonta and the store as racist. "That's it. You're under arrest," he quoted the police officer as saying before hauling him away.
The police chief said Mr. Sanon's arrest "was not a matter of race."
"We got a call for disorderly conduct," he said, "and when we got there, that's what we found."
Mr. Sanon thinks about going back to Bushwick, but wants to finish his studies here. "If I go home I'm just going to be partying with my friends, and my chance of getting in trouble is great," said Mr. Sanon, who is majoring in political science. "Here, I know if I just do my work, I'll make it."
"You come to the point where you expect the city to harass you," added Mr. Sanon. "But what hurts is to learn your own school is furnishing a list to help them harass you. School's supposed to be like your family. They are supposed to help you through."
Kevin Slater, the multicultural consultant, said that many disputes between blacks and whites in Oneonta entailed the overt or unspoken threat to call the police. And that reflex, he added, was driven by fear.
"All the images you see on television and film, up until a few years ago, were of black men as big, destructive and threatening," he said. "Police see themselves as protectors of the whites. When it comes to blacks, they see themselves as suppressing an insurrection."
Mayor Brenner attributes the tension to the behavior of black students, who he says are quick to take offense.
"A part of that is the place from which they came, the baggage they bring with them, the heritage they bear," he said. "The white student is less likely to answer viscerally. He doesn't feel threatened as much as a black person would."
As a move toward healing, Mayor Brenner said the police force would hire its first minority officer.
However, the Mayor noted that some things are not easily changed. He confessed that he had spoken with a top executive of Bresee's, the 93-year-old family-owned department store that anchors Main Street, who told him the store had a policy of following blacks and those who display suspicious behavior.
"In her mind, she combined the two," Mayor Brenner said. At weekly community meetings on race relations, the store's practices are the topic of regular discussion, as is a possible boycott. Mark Bresee, the owner, denied his store had a policy of following black customers, but he said sales people were instructed to call security "if they felt intimidated." Most of the shoplifters the store catches are white, he added.
Mr. Bresee, like many whites here, said there were no racial problems in Oneonta. He appeared shocked to hear that the black students and residents have felt persecuted, and presumed they were viewing unrelated slights through a prism of race.
Mr. Bresee said most disturbances were among white students on weekend nights. Clashes between fraternities have left three white students hospitalized since school started. He recalled a visit to the store by 20 drunk fraternity brothers who frightened sales people. But one of the youths explained they were hazing a new member, who had to try on women's underwear.
"Of course, I let them do it," he said. "There were 20 of them and they'd been drinking."
But black students asked to imagine themselves in the same situation said they could not. "That's like saying I want to go to jail," said Lawrence Plaskett, who said he had been thrown off a bus in a downpour because he refused the driver's order to leave his candy bar at the front. "For a candy bar, they had sirens running for me."
Barbara J. Potter, executive director of a community dispute resolution center called Mediation Services Inc., said she believed that many whites in Oneonta were unaware that race dictated their reactions at all. "This belongs to the realm of things that you don't know you don't know," Ms. Potter explained.
Earl W. Roberts 3d, pastor of the Elm Park United Methodist Church, said he knows he is not striking a responsive chord when he sermonizes about blatant racism.
"I tell them that racism is not just in the K.K.K. or in the neo-Nazis, it's in nice people who wouldn't knowingly discriminate against anybody," he said and smiled sadly. "Most people in my congregation would say they're not racist, without thinking about what goes on inside of them when they step into a bus with black passengers and feel frightened."

 CORRECTION:
Because of transmission errors, an article yesterday about race relations in Oneonta, N.Y., referred incorrectly to the police chief and to an incident in which officers accused a student of selling drugs. The chief is John J. Donadio; the incident occurred as the student was leaving a bar, not a bus.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Pledges 4-Year Corporate Tax Freeze

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Saying he wanted to make the city more hospitable to business, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday promised to freeze New York City's general corporate tax for the next four years.
Although Mr. Dinkins already assumed in the city's financial plan covering the next three years that there would be no rise in corporate taxes, his pledge yesterday to freeze the current rate of 8.85 percent for four years carried a far greater commitment and was meant to send a soothing message to a jittery business community, mayoral aides said. 
 In the words of one aide, Mr. Dinkins had moved from "a silent assumption" to a firm "policy announcement" in the financial plan that corporate taxes would not rise. "It's a commitment versus an assumption," said the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Barry F. Sullivan. Mr. Sullivan, a former banker who is perceived by many in the business community as their voice at City Hall, was crucial in persuading the Mayor to hold the corporate tax rate, mayoral aides said.
Mr. Dinkins said that at the least, his promise amounted to extending his tacit commitment on corporate taxes for a year beyond the three years in the financial plan. But he said he hoped that by announcing this policy he could create "a pro-business environment" in the city.
"I won't ask you to read my lips," he said. "We all know where that got us. But I am committing this administration to a four-year freeze on corporate tax rates."
Executives said the Mayor's pledge marked a watershed in his evolving relationship with big business, which was not part of the coalition of unions, minority groups and liberals that elected him in 1989. Several said the high corporate tax rate and a bevy of other business taxes unheard of anywhere else in the United States were major reasons behind the departure of so many companies.
"I think it's sending out a message that he recognizes the future prosperity of New York depends on retaining businesses," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York Chamber of Commerce.
Lewis Rudin, the real-estate developer who heads the Association for a Better New York, called Mr. Dinkins's vow "a positive signal that international and national companies have to think very seriously before leaving New York."
 
Courageous or Safe?
 Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier and chairman of the state Municipal Assistance Corporation, said the announcement, coupled with news that Morgan Stanley, the financial services concern, had agreed to stay in the city, would encourage businesses that for a variety of reasons -- high crime, poor schools, high taxes -- are thinking of pulling up stakes. "The Mayor is very courageous in doing what he's doing," he said.
But others said Mr. Dinkins's pledge was a fairly safe strategy because, with the national recession continuing to crimp corporate profits, it is unlikely the city will lose much revenue by freezing the corporate tax rate for four years. Losing businesses to other cities and states might hurt city revenue more. In addition, there is little support in Albany or the City Council for raising taxes on businesses in any case.
"It's a nice reassurance for economically tough times that doesn't come at great cost to the city," said the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messenger. "It's not all that big a deal."
The general corporation tax accounts for 5.5 percent of tax revenue in the current budget, or about $912 million. The rate has been reduced in the last 15 years from 10.1 percent in 1974 to the current 8.85 percent.
 
Some Complaints Remain
 But businesses still complain that it is too high, city officials and business executives said. Companies also groan that they are saddled with two other taxes unique to New York: Enterprises that rent their premises pay a tax on their monthly rent and unincorporated partnerships must pay a special business tax, so that partners in effect find their salaries taxed twice. New York is also the only American city with a progressive personal income tax.
Mr. Sullivan, who joined the administration last spring, has taken aim at many of these taxes in his effort to make the city, in his words, "a friendlier, more customer-oriented location for businesses." Though it is not possible to reduce or to eliminate these taxes in the present climate, Mr. Sullivan said, in the long term he would like to see many business taxes decline, especially the rent tax and the unincorporated business tax.
"If I had my druthers, I would deal with the most unpopular stuff," he said.

An article on Tuesday about Mayor David N. Dinkins's promise to freeze New York City's general corporate tax for the next four years described the city's progressive personal income tax incorrectly. It is not the only such tax; at least one other city, Yonkers, has one.

HEADLINE: New York Incentives For Morgan Stanley Prevent a Relocation

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The Morgan Stanley Group, a major financial services company that had been considering moving its New York City headquarters and as many as 4,100 employees to Stamford, Conn., will remain in the city for at least 10 years, company officials said yesterday.
The city and state have agreed to almost $40 million in tax credits and other incentives over the next decade to help keep the company in New York, city and state officials said at a news conference yesterday at Morgan Stanley's midtown offices. At the same news conference, Mayor David N. Dinkins also promised to freeze the city's general corporate tax rate for the next four years. [page B9.] 
 Morgan Stanley pays between $90 million and $100 million a year in taxes to the city and state, and will pay an estimated $911 million in taxes over the next 10 years, said Mayor Dinkins, who contended that the tax incentives were a modest investment given the financial returns that Morgan Stanley's decision to stay will mean for the city.
The company's flirtation with Stamford was very public -- two years ago, it took an option to buy a parcel of property in that city's downtown -- and the city and state's pledge of tax breaks was the latest in a series of incentive packages offered this year to keep major companies in New York.
In August, Prudential Securities promised to keep its headquarters in lower Manhattan for 20 years, after looking into relocating to Jersey City, Houston, San Francisco or Los Angeles. The brokerage is to receive at least $106.2 million in tax incentives and energy savings over 20 years.
Also in August, four of New York's five commodities exchanges reached final agreement on a plan that prevented their moving to Jersey City. They will move to a city-owned site near their current location in the World Trade Center. The state will invest $27 million in the project and the city will provide a $26 million grant and $22 million in capital construction financing.
Last month, though, a financial services subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation announced it would leave Manhattan next year for Jersey City, taking 1,000 jobs with it. After negotiating with the company, city officials dropped out of the competition, saying they could not match the terms offered by Jersey City.
Morgan Stanley's decision to stay in New York was described by one senior business representative as a "watershed," because if the company had left, it would have forced many other large financial services companies with whom it competes to re-examine whether they should leave.
Ronald K. Shelp, the president of the New York City Partnership, a business group, said that when his organization studied the financial services industry several years ago, a top official of a major company said that if any of his competitors moved out of the city, he would also have to consider doing so to cut costs and remain competitive. So far, Mr. Shelp said, none of the major companies in the industry has moved its headquarters, although many have relocated back-office operations.
 
Dinkins Praises Agreement
 At the end of the First Chicago negotiations last month, city officials said that they would have had to offer an incentive package worth $50 million to match the terms of New Jersey offer -- or $50,000 for each of the 1,000 jobs. The cost to New York City for even the most generous incentives offered in the past was no higher than $20,000 per job, city officials said.
The $39.6 million in incentives negotiated with Morgan Stanley would be worth slightly less than $10,000 for each of the 4,100 jobs. For Prudential, which made a commitment to stay twice as long, the cost was $11,600 in tax incentives for each of the 5,000 jobs retained, or $21,000 per job if the energy savings -- realized through the purchase of low-cost energy from the state power authority -- was figured in.
Mr. Dinkins said he was thrilled by Morgan Stanley's decision. He said the company generates $2 billion in economic activity in New York each year, and he argued that the symbolism of its determination to stay was even more significant than the financial value of the commitment.
"It sends an invaluable, priceless message to the world's businesses," the Mayor said, "that New York City is the place where businesses do their best business, where the giants and the leaders choose to headquarter themselves."
 
Plea From Businesses
 So critical was the company's decision viewed by other political and business leaders that, at a breakfast meeting sponsored two years ago by the New York City Partnership and held at The New York Times, many of the city's business, political and cultural leaders implored Morgan Stanley officials to remain in New York.
In briefly explaining the announcement yesterday, the company's chairman, Richard B. Fisher, said, "The key reason for our decision is that New York leaders, in our view, are committed to making the city a hospitable place to do business."
Morgan Stanley's president, Robert F. Greenhill, noted that the company's officers have an obligation to shareholders to control costs. He also said that what he described as the city's "deteriorating social and economic" climate in recent years had caused many corporations to consider alternatives.
In the end, though, company officials did not say precisely why they had decided to stay in New York, and they did not indicate whether their decision was based entirely on financial comparisons.
 
Incentives From Connecticut
 The state of Connecticut offered incentives as well, said city officials, who added that they did not know the details of Connecticut's offer. A telephone message left for Stamford Mayor Stanley J. Esposito late yesterday was not returned.
Mr. Shelp of the New York City Partnership said that for most companies it is less expensive to operate outside New York. The corporations that decide to stay in the city usually do so for several related reasons, including New York's intense concentration of business services and talent, its cluster of potential clients and its transportation and communications advantages.
The ability to interact face-to-face with customers keeps many companies in the city, he said. "There are a lot of factors other than cost that go into it," Mr. Shelp said. "It is still the place to be, the financial services center of the world."
The $39.6 million incentive package offered by the city and state to Morgan Stanley includes $4.2 million in what officials called real-estate tax stabilization, in which the city would limit property-tax increases; $17.2 million in credits on the company's commercial rent tax, and $18.2 million in relief on city and state sales-taxes, largely for the purchase of equipment.
In return, Morgan Stanley will remain for at least 10 years in its headquarters at 1251 Avenue of the Americas, near 49th Street, as well as in office space it rents in two other midtown buildings and in Brooklyn Heights, where it moved its back-office operations several years ago.

An article on Oct. 20 about a financial services company's decision to remain in New York City rendered the company's full name incorrectly in some copies. It is the Morgan Stanley Group.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Debating Done, Bush and Clinton Begin Final Push

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPARTANBURG, S.C., Oct. 20

 BODY:
No longer able to hope that Presidential debates would lure swarms of voters back to his ranks, President Bush and his advisers dropped the pretense today that campaigning as usual would win his re-election two weeks from now.
Now it is trench warfare, and the battle plan became evident today along the railroad tracks and picture-book crossroads of small-town Georgia and South Carolina. 
 Campaigning by passenger train one day after his best debate showing, an energized Mr. Bush hit Mr. Clinton with everything he had.
To throngs that filled main streets and spilled into alleys, the President assailed Mr. Clinton's record as Arkansas Governor, attacked his economic proposals, warned over and over that he "flip flops" on difficult issues and recalled the "sorry" history of his avoiding the Vietnam War draft.
 
Polls Shrugged Off
 Mr. Bush and his aides appeared to be buoyed by the debate on Monday in East Lansing, Mich., in which the President struck many of the themes he repeated today. They shrugged off polls taken after the debate, some of which suggested that Mr. Bush's performance had still not won over wavering voters.
Saying he was glad to be "in the land of the free and the home of the Braves," Mr. Bush told about 7,000 people at the crossroads in the center of Norcross, Ga., an Atlanta suburb, with a few thousand others outside a roped-off security area. "Forget about all these polls.
On this two-day swing through three Southern states, Mr. Bush is going to 10 towns and granting six television interviews. His press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said he would campaign nonstop until Election Day, often speaking in three or four cities a day.
"You have seen the future," Mr. Fitzwater said as Mr. Bush spoke in Norcross, "and this is it."
 
Enthusiastic Crowds
 It was evident by the time his 20-car train reached Spartanburg late this evening that Mr. Bush was drawing some of the largest and most enthusiastic crowds of the campaign. There were almost 15,000 people here, waiting for him and for an elaborate fireworks display.
When Mr. Bush spoke of his own plans, it was only to contrast them with what he called Mr. Clinton's philosophy of "tax more and spend more." When he mentioned the economy, it was to remind people that the slowdown is not just in this country but global, and that other nations have it worse.
"Our data show this thing is coming down to taxes and trust," said the Bush campaign's political director, Mary Matalin. "The people are not down to that choice stage yet."
In his four stops in Georgia and South Carolina today, Mr. Bush focused repeatedly on what he called "a vast difference in experience," character, and philosophy between himself and Mr. Clinton. "Character is important, and you cannot in that Oval Office be all things to all people," Mr. Bush said to several thousand cheering supporters in Cornelia, Ga., northeast of Atlanta. "Governor Clinton tries to be on every side of every issue, and you cannot have that as President of the United States."
Earlier, in Norcross, Ga., Mr. Bush's charges about Mr. Clinton during the Vietnam War, while forceful, largely avoided the stridency of his earlier suggestions that the Arkansas Governor was unpatriotic in opposing the war, and focused instead on Mr. Clinton's varying explanations.
Campaign aides said later that they believed the issue of Mr. Clinton's credibility was beginning to register with voters after weeks of effort.
"Baseball is like politics," Mr. Bush said. "On Election Day we're going to show America that it ain't over until Cabrera swings." He referred to Francisco Cabrera, whose pinch-hit single in the ninth inning carried the Atlanta Braves to the World Series last week.
Ms. Matalin said Mr. Bush could still pull off a comparable feat by winning the sizable number of voters who still have reservations about Mr. Clinton. She assumes that Mr. Bush will capture 210 electoral votes in the normally Republican South and West, and pick up 60 more in contested states in the Midwest and border regions, for the 270 that are needed to win.
Republican strategists say an unusually large number of voters, perhaps a third, have still not committed themselves to a candidate. That raises hopes that a volatile electorate could swing to Mr. Bush as the safest choice in a year without compelling favorites.
More important, Mr. Bush campaign's chairman, Robert M. Teeter, said Mr. Clinton's support remained unusually soft. He said in an interview today that perhaps a fourth of Mr. Clinton's backers were wavering.
Aides also say Mr. Perot, whom Mr. Bush dubbed "the feisty little guy from Dallas" in one speech today, remains a wild card. With 15 to 20 percent in many polls, "we think that helps us and hurts Clinton," Mr. Teeter said.
But the depth of the President's plight is suggested by the itinerary of this railroad trip through Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina, the very core of support that Mr. Bush is supposed to have locked up. Like much of the South, these states have left the Republican fold in 30 years only for Jimmy Carter or Lyndon B. Johnson.
 
Assessment of the South
 Senator Strom Thurmond, the South Carolina Republican, who was aboard the Bush train today, predicted that the President would carry his state. But even he allowed that Mr. Bush was trailing Mr. Clinton in Georgia and even with him in North Carolina.
Ms. Matalin also acknowledged that the gap between the President and Mr. Clinton, even in the Bush campaign's own internal polls, had not yet narrowed much, but instead has only bounced up and down between about 8 and 15 percentage points.
As recently as this weekend, after Mr. Bush's slack performance last week in the second debate, the gap was in the double-digit range, she said. But she added that it had dropped since then and that she expected the margin to dwindle further.
Even as Mr. Bush rallied the faithful today, his aides worked the press corps seeking to repair damage done to the President's foreign-policy record last night by Ross Perot.
At Mr. Bush's first stop, his National Security Adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said Mr. Perot "had shot from the hip" when he accused Mr. Bush of hiding the White House instructions to coddle Iraq's leader, Saddam Hussein.
A State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, echoed Mr. Scowcroft's view and said the United States never suggested to Baghdad that Irag could seize part of Iraq.
The campaign will also begin using new television commercials on Wednesday, some offering upbeat messages about a second-term agenda and others with man-on-the-street interviews to hammer at Mr. Clinton.
