HEADLINE: Women Advance in Politics By Evolution, Not Revolution

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
In this acidic political season in which Anita Hill has become a shorthand for outrage and the "Year of the Woman" is a familiar refrain, it is easy to believe that revolution is at hand.
But come November, when the voting is over, there will be no storming of the gates.
Even a wave of victories by female candidates will not give women dominance on Capitol Hill. Should a female candidate win in every possible race, the 103d Congress would still be 80 percent male. 
 More likely, many women will lose, leaving the United States still well behind most European countries in female representation. Yet women have made steady gains in politics since the early 1970's, and this year they will make more. Already, half again as many women (108) have won Congressional primaries as ever before. (The previous record was 70 in 1990.)
Eleven women, a record by one, are running for the Senate. State legislatures will be changing, too. In California, women will run in 74 of 120 races. Every victory will bring another woman experience that may some day propel her toward a higher office.
 
Patience, Patience
 Those gains have been the stuff of sweat, not spontaneous combustion. Though women have clearly been beneficiaries of voters' enthusiasm for change, actual victories at the ballot box will be not so much a result of sputtering anger as of the long, little-noticed efforts of a band of well-spoken political guerrillas.
Undaunted by early defeats, scrounging money from mailings stamped "Urgent!," this loosely knit community has worked for well over a decade to recruit and elect female candidates. Its members have guided campaigns and gathered in hotel rooms to study everything from hairdos to handshakes and help women in a competitive world they tend to enter later and with less professional experience than men.
As long ago as the early 1970's, groups like the National Women's Political Caucus gathered candidates for seminars in the building blocks of fund-raising, stump speaking and other campaign fundamentals. Then, that group and others gave that most essential of campaign lubricants: money.
The groups' common goal is as difficult as it sounds simple: never to quit until women, who make up almost 52 percent of the population, have something like 52 percent of the clout.
"We've got the objective reality that women vote differently than men on important issues," said Patricia Ireland, the peripatetic president of the National Organization for Women. "It is women who experience sexual harassment on the job. It is women who experience violence in the home. It is women who are still the primary care givers. If we are going to have a representative government, we have to have women in office."
Studies of voting patterns conducted by the Rutgers Center for the American Woman in Politics show that women vote differently from men on many issues.
Ultimately, the advocates believe, having more women in office can make the difference between a bill's passage and its defeat. According to a NOW study on female legislators and social policy, 71 percent of women -- but only 52 percent of the men -- in Congress voted unsuccessfully to override a Presidential veto of the Family Medical Leave Act.
More recently, when Congress sought to override President Bush's veto of a bill that would have allowed federally financed family-planning clinics to provide information on abortion, women voted overwhelmingly to override but failed to carry the day.
 
'Tribes on the Hill'
 "It's not like we are taking over the country," said Harriett Woods, the president of the National Women's Political Caucus and a two-time losing senatorial candidate from Missouri. "But men left to themselves are like tribes on the Hill. We just want to try things our way."
The groups operate on a first-name basis in a loose yet complementary community. Still, disputes simmer. Some women believe that political contributions should be invested only in candidates with a good chance of winning. Others say that victory is impossible to predict, so the more the merrier. Some believe women should not run against each other and cite the bitter New York Senate primary in which Geraldine A. Ferraro and Elizabeth Holtzman were defeated. Others say that men do, so why shouldn't they?
This year, such questions have eased a bit. Despite the recession, the groups' bank accounts are brimming as never before. The stumbling economy and the resulting focus on domestic concerns have pushed issues like family and medical leave, health care and abortion rights to the fore. High-profile candidates like Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein in California, Carol Moseley Braun in Illinois and Lynn H. Yeakel in Pennsylvania have now made the goals seem more reasonable.
 
Democrats Benefit More
 The boon, however, has gone primarily to the Democrats. The Republican Party, split over a conservative platform that would outlaw abortion and perceived this year as almost hostile to women's rights, has alienated some Republican women and missed out on some of the energies generated by the Anita Hill-Clarence Thomas controversy. President Bush may have compounded that problem Thursday during the debate in Richmond when, noting that most female candidates are Democrats, he said, "I hope a lot of them lose."
This year, 10 of the 11 women running for the Senate are Democrats who represent the mostly liberal ideals shared by the women's political groups. Democrats dominate races for the House of Representatives as well, 71 to 37.
There was no real beginning. Instead, the effort to move women center stage has been propelled by a series of losses, setbacks and moments of recognition so complex and varied that no one date suffices.
In 1973, when the Women's Political Caucus, a group devoted to furthering women's participation in government, held its first national convention in a hotel in Texas, the front desk refused to page one of the participants on the ground that only a prostitute would answer a hotel summons.
Year by year, more women were willing to face such invective and challenge the odds against them. Year by year, most of them lost.
 
New Surge of Energy
 Then 1982, the year that saw the equal rights amendment drift past its deadline and into virtual defeat, brought a new surge of energy. Activists with the women's movement suddenly turned their sights toward mainstream politics. While Ms. Woods's commitment was triggered by lessons learned through her own defeat, other figures such as Eleanor C. Smeal, then the president of the National Organization for Women, decided to move away from street protests to pull more traditional levers of power.
The E.R.A.'s demise and the election year itself had sent two powerful messages:
First, studies done after the E.R.A. deadline passed showed that female legislators had voted in favor of it more often than men, with a gap of up to 40 percentage points in some states.
Second, 1982, like 1992, was a post-census election year that had more open seats than usual because of redistricting. A study of the winners showed that women (like all challengers) made better gains in reconstructed or open districts than they did fighting against incumbents.
 
Finding and Financing
 The lessons and strategic refinements of the following years held the seeds of a conflict that still simmers.
Early political groups like the National Women's Political Caucus and the Women's Campaign Fund built their work around the notion that it was up to them to find and finance the best candidates they could. Working with limited resources and plenty of heart, they stormed the country looking for women who would run. Then, fearing that a woman's loss was actually a double loss -- once for the candidate herself, and again for those women who might follow -- they tried to determine who would win.
In 1985, Ellen R. Malcolm, a straight-speaking, independently wealthy Washingtonian who had watched Ms. Woods's second defeat with dismay, founded Emily's List to raise money and finance women's candidacies. Taking its name from the phrase "early money is like yeast," and contributions from a loose network of women sympathetic to the cause (10 percent of the group's members are men), Ms. Malcolm devised a novel fund-raising strategy. Convinced that every dollar must be fired like a rifle, Ms. Malcolm requires candidates to provide polling data and proof of a well-organized campaign.
The stakes are huge. Those candidates who win the group's backing gain a certain celebrity status along with bundles of checks. The fund-raising strategy this year is expected to raise $6 million in contributions, making that group by far the best financed.
"If we took money and gave it to 150 women equally instead of the 35 we thought could win," said Ms. Malcolm, "then some of those 35 wouldn't win."
But some feminists say this rifle-shot approach penalizes deserving candidates. "You can't predict winners," said Ms. Smeal, the former NOW president. "Politics isn't like that."
In 1987, she founded the Fund for the Feminist Majority, and began a nationwide drive called "the feminization of power" to encourage women to aspire to positions of power in everything from student councils to the White House. Though the fund does not contribute to candidates because of its tax status, this year it dispatched a team of fierce lieutenants through California, New York, Arizona, Oregon, Tennessee and South Carolina to identify potential candidates.
Using a slick campaign, huge mailings and a sizable staff, it spreads the message that a major surge in representation can be obtained only by "flooding" tickets with women on the ground that some will win, some will lose and everyone will learn something in the process.
In Georgia, Cynthia McKinney, a charismatic Democrat from a predominantly black district, said her campaign team had estimated that it would have cost about $50,000 to provide the data, information and structure that Ms. Malcolm's group required.
"We only had about $20,000 in the bank," Ms. McKinney said. Instead, Ms. McKinney's campaign received help from the National Organization for Women. "They had confidence in my candidacy when other groups didn't," she said. "NOW really came through for us." An endorsement soon followed from the Women's Campaign Fund, and now, having won the primary for an open seat, she is given a good chance at victory.
Groups teach everything from how to organize a campaign budget to how to make a stump speech.
At Emily's List, once a candidate is endorsed, she is coached. "Women candidates are very serious," said Ms. Malcolm. "They learn and learn. It's like they are trying to pass their S.A.T.'s."
Someday, perhaps, such remedial training will no longer be needed. Someday, too, in the far distant future when women fill the halls of Congress and the Senate has finally built a women's bathroom (female senators now use the wives' lounge) someone, sometime may sputter and declare that it is high time, really, for a "Year of the Man."
But that will be another generation's battle.

HEADLINE: Tempers Flare as Pennsylvania Rivals Debate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The sparks flew today as Senator Arlen Specter and his Democratic opponent, Lynn H. Yeakel, met face to face for the last of two debates after bombarding each other with negative advertising for weeks.
The hourlong morning radio debate offered the candidates an open format to present their views and interrupt each other at will. And that is precisely what they did. 
 The two moderates discussed jobs, the economy and health care. But mostly they got bogged down in accusations about how each side was distorting the other's positions and maligning each other's character.
Mr. Specter, a former District Attorney, repeatedly tried to impugn Ms. Yeakel's character by reminding listeners that her family belonged to a country club with no black members, and that she was a member of a church whose pastor had once made unfavorable comments about the Israeli Government.
 
Accusation of Lying
 Ms. Yeakel dismissed Mr. Specter's accusations, saying at one point, "You just keep lying."
They repeatedly attacked each other's negative advertising campaign. Mr. Specter defended one of his television commercials as accurately reporting that Ms. Yeakel had waited 10 years before paying more than $17,000 in Philadelphia income taxes. Ms. Yeakel said the assertion was misleading because she voluntarily paid the taxes after her lawyer brought the situation to her attention last fall.
For his part, Mr. Specter said an advertisement referring to him as having a "slimy campaign style" and as being "the single most obnoxious man in the Senate" was simply mudslinging. A nonpartisan organization reached the same conclusion about Ms. Yeakel's advertisement on Monday.
But perhaps the crucial moment of the debate, broadcast by KYW, took place in the following exchange between the candidates, when their voices rose and choked with anger:
MS. YEAKEL You know, Arlen Specter is in the mud pile with George Bush. He has been attacking my character since the day after I won the primary.
MR. SPECTER That's not true.
MS. YEAKEL He has been diverting attention from the real issues of this campaign, and I want to tell you something. He is not running for prosecutor, he is running for the United States Senate. And he is not going to sit here and humiliate me the way he humiliated Anita Hill.
MR. SPECTER I've been waiting for that for a long time.
MS. YEAKEL I know you have.
MR. SPECTER Here we are back to the single issue.
Political professionals said the debate was a campaign milestone because it was the first time Mr. Specter had attacked his opponent so strongly.
Mr. Specter, whose popularity plummeted after the Senate confirmation hearings of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court, has criticized Ms. Yeakel as a one-issue candidate and has questioned her character, but never so boldly as he did today. It was also the first time that Ms. Yeakel attacked Mr. Specter in person for his tough questioning of Prof. Anita F. Hill, who accused Judge Thomas of sexually harassing her when they were colleagues at two Federal agencies.
"The gloves are coming off now," said G. Terry Madonna, director of the Center for Politics and Public Affairs at Millersville State University in Lancaster. "This debate may be the dramatic turning point in the race because it shows Specter now feels strong enough that he can sharply criticize Yeakel without Anita Hilling her, and without worrying about a backlash."
Similarly, Randall M. Miller, a professor of political science at St. Joseph's University, said Ms. Yeakel's forceful reference to Professor Hill during the debate indicated that she now felt strongly enough to rekindle voters' anger about the hearings in the final two weeks of the campaign.
Until today, Ms. Yeakel had hewn closely to the Clinton-Gore campaign themes of creating jobs, enacting universal health insurance and bringing change to Washington. But the Hill-Thomas hearings have motivated her entire campaign, which she began shortly after the hearings. "
Despite the highly emotional notes hit by Ms. Yeakel, public opinion polls reflect Mr. Specter's strength. A Pittsburgh Post-Gazette poll conducted Oct. 8 through Oct. 11 and made public last week showed Mr. Specter leading Ms. Yeakel by about 10 percentage points.
Professor Madonna said, "Specter, emboldened by the polls, believes he can go on the attack."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, and his Democratic opponent, Lynn H. Yeakel, preparing for the start of their hour-long radio debate yesterday in Philadelphia. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Issues;
Debates Leave Some Holes, But Also Clear Impressions

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
For the relatively few Americans who listen to campaign speeches and read position papers, the Presidential debates left big gaps and plenty of unresolved arguments.
But for the tens of millions of others who watched, the 270 minutes of debate offered a first and rather solid look at where the candidates stood on important issues. 
 On some issues, like gun control, trade, term limits and automobile pollution standards, the lines separating the three candidates were clearly drawn.
On other matters, like how to pay for a new health care system, the distinctions remained fuzzy.
President Bush was forced into a discussion on Iran and Iraq that he would have preferred to avoid. Gov. Bill Clinton was unable to describe how he could do all he was promising and still get the deficit under control. Ross Perot kept saying there were plenty of plans on everything, but he never let on which ones he favored.
And a major issue -- abortion -- was never mentioned. Neither was the question of what qualifications the candidates would look for when they picked nominees for the Supreme Court.
 
'A Sense of Priorities'
 Still, said Charles O. Jones, a political science professor at the University of Wisconsin and a student of the Presidency, the debates were of great value to voters. "You got a sense of priorities," he said. "You got a sense of their personal engagement in different issues. They're not all engaged in the same issues. You got a sense of the depth of their understanding of the issues. And you got a general sense of direction."
But people who have been closely following the candidates found that little new ground was broken.
One possible exception came Monday night, when Mr. Clinton suggested that some affluent people should pay higher taxes on Social Security benefits. The Arkansas Governor discussed the topic last spring before the Florida primary but has mentioned it little if at all since then.
Mr. Clinton's campaign staff said the comment about Social Security was a statement of philosophy rather than a specific proposal.
Mr. Perot has also suggested taxing a larger portion of the retirement payments of the more affluent beneficiaries. Mr. Bush opposes the higher taxes.
On issues where voters are likely to have fixed opinions, the three candidates took firm positions:
*Mr. Clinton supports a waiting period to allow police checks before handguns can be bought. Mr. Bush opposes the measure. Mr. Perot says it is not very important.
*Mr. Bush likes the free-trade agreement with Mexico. Mr. Perot opposes it. Mr. Clinton supports it with modifications.
*Mr. Perot wants a higher tax on gasoline. The other two oppose such a tax.
*Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot favor term limits for members of Congress. Mr. Clinton does not.
*Mr. Clinton wants stricter limits on auto emissions. Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot oppose such a measure on the ground that it would cost jobs.
But on more complicated issues, the candidates often bobbed and weaved. Perhaps it was because they did not want to let on that the public might have to pay a price. Perhaps it was an indication that the candidates themselves had not sorted out where to stand. The best illustration of this is the question of how to pay for medical care.
The three candidates agree that the health care system should be changed so that insurance is more widely available and affordable and medical costs do not rise so much. Outside experts say it could cost $20 billion a year or more to meet those goals, but neither party's candidate was able to say during the debates how they would meet the additional costs.
Mr. Clinton talked about taking on insurance companies and bureaucracies. Mr. Bush kept bringing up the high cost of malpractice lawsuits. Mr. Perot answered a question about this on Oct. 11 the way he answered questions on several other matters: "We've got plans lying all over the place in Washington. Nobody ever implements them. Now I'm back to square one. If you want to stop talking about it and do it, then I'll be glad to go up there, and we'll get it done."
His record on the economy aside, if Mr. Bush could have avoided one topic, it would doubtless have been the questions Mr. Perot raised Monday night about Mr. Bush's policy toward Iraq before the war in the Persian Gulf.
For his supporters, the President's highest cards have been his record of leadership during that war and his reputation for telling the truth. The questions about Iraq could have planted doubts in voters' minds on both matters.
The hardest question for Mr. Clinton was probably the first one Monday: how could the public possibly believe that as President he could create jobs, cut taxes for the middle class, reduce the deficit, change the medical care system, build big new public works projects and guarantee college educations for everyone who is qualified and pay for it all just with higher taxes on the very wealthy and foreign corporations?
Mr. Clinton said the middle class would "have their fair share of changing to do and many challenges to face."
But he did not say exactly what he meant and never answered the question directly.

HEADLINE: Study Could Be Prelude To Private Owner for OTB

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
Faced with shrinking profits and renewed criticisms of mismanagement, New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation is being studied by an outside company, a move that may bring the independent government agency closer to private ownership.
For much of this year, officials in state and city government have increasingly suggested the sale of the 22-year-old agency, which operates offtrack horse-race betting in the city, arguing that it could be more efficiently run in private hands. Even Mayor David N. Dinkins, who has been a strong supporter of the OTB president, Hazel N. Dukes, has indicated he favors selling the agency. 
 Ruby Ryles, an assistant press secretary for the Mayor's office, said yesterday that she expected the appraisal, which is being conducted by Morgan Stanley & Company, to be finished in the next several weeks. "Upon the completion of that study and its evaluation, the city will make a determination about the future of OTB," she said.
 
A Search for Options
 Mr. Dinkins, in his city budget proposal for the next fiscal year, suggests a transaction in which the agency would bring $55 million in revenue to the city, without specifying details. Mr. Dinkins can initiate an OTB sale with the approval of the Legislature, a city spokeswoman said.
But OTB officials cautioned against speculating that a sale of the agency was in the works. "We are not looking for a buyer," said Marjorie W. Longley, OTB's senior director. "We are simply having Morgan Stanley investigate what our worth is."
She said the study was intended to give OTB a detailed look at itself as it further streamlines its operation, which has been strained in recent years by a poor economy that has hurt gambling across the board, experts say. She also indicated that the study might be used to provide the agency with figures to help it refute claims that privatization would be good for OTB and the city. Proponents of private management contend it would enhance OTB's efficiency and its profit margins.
The news of the Morgan Stanley study was first reported in Crain's New York Business on Monday.
Since its creation by the State Legislature in 1970, OTB has handled $17.4 billion in wagers, Edward Lewis the OTB Chairman, said last week during a meeting of the Advisory Commission on Racing in the 21st Century. More than 75 percent of that amount was used to pay winning customers, he said.
From its profits during those years, OTB has distributed $937.4 million to the city, $362.2 million to the state and some $156 million to other local governments, he said. Another $918.1 million has gone to the New York racing industry.
But last year, OTB gave the city $600,000 in profits, the lowest in its history. The agency's highest single-year profits for the city was $40 million in 1977, the New York State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said in a report earlier this month, in which he called OTB "a prime candidate for privatization."
Meanwhile, Mr. Regan said OTB should close 21 of the least profitable of its 93 branches, which could save the agency up to $15 million a year.
Perhaps sensing an opportunity in OTB's loss of revenue last year, the New York Horse Racing Association, a private, nonprofit group, made a tentative offer to purchase the agency for $45 million to $55 million. But no deal was made.
Gerald Lawrence, executive vice-president of the horse-racing association, refused yesterday to say if his association would make a new offer.

GRAPHIC: Chart:
 
"Background: 2 Decades of OTB"
 The New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation was created as a public-benefit corporation in 1970 by the State Legislature. The operation and management of OTB, including the selection of sites for betting branches and the types of branches that are built, are regulated by state legislation.
OTB operates 93 branches in the city's five boroughs.
Since it has been in operation, OTB has handled $17.4 billion in wagers, three quarters of which was paid back to winning customers.
The agency is governed by a five-member board of directors, which includes the OTB President, Hazel N. Dukes.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Clinton and Bush Agree on Trimming Armed Forces, but Their Paths Vary

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton agree that the United States military in the post-cold war era should be a smaller force prepared to respond quickly to regional contingencies with the most advanced weaponry.
But the two candidates offer slightly different paths to reach roughly similar goals. Mr. Bush would shrink the active-duty military from 1.9 million now to 1.6 million troops by 1995. Mr. Clinton would match that cut and reduce the force level by 200,000 more by 1997. Already, the military is shrinking by 100,000 troops a year. 
 Mr. Bush proposes military spending of $1.42 trillion between now and 1997. Mr. Clinton calls for spending $1.36 trillion in the same period, a difference of about 4 percent. Most of the difference would come from troop cuts and reductions in the "Star Wars" anti-missile defense system.
"Our forces must be more mobile, more precise and more flexible, and they must have the technologically advanced weapons they need to prevail and to prevail quickly," Mr. Clinton told the National Guard Association convention on Sept. 15.
 
Clinton Gives Few
 This line could have been borrowed from speeches by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney or Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Mr. Clinton has deliberately hewed close to the Administration's position on military spending to defuse Republican accusations that Democrats are soft on national defense and to deflect questions about the Arkansas Governor's avoiding the draft during the Vietnam War.
Beyond those generalities, Mr. Clinton has given only skimpy details of what his proposed military of the future would look like, and campaign advisers say that was done deliberately to avoid committing to troop levels that may have to be changed later.
Because the candidates share relatively similar positions on military spending and the size of future armed forces, national security issues have not been a major part of the campaign debate.
Nor has Ross Perot focused closely on military reductions. In his book, "United We Stand: How We Can Take Back Our Country," Mr. Perot calls for $40 billion in cuts beyond those proposed by Mr. Bush (or about $20 billion less than Mr. Clinton's). Mr. Perot would have American allies, like Germany and Japan, pay a larger share of the cost to station American troops in those countries for their defense.
 
Visions on the Future
 Mr. Perot and Mr. Clinton favor lifting the ban on homosexuals in the military. Mr. Bush does not.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton do diverge in their vision of how to help former service members, and what role the Government should play in helping America's military industry adjust to smaller Pentagon budgets.
Mr. Bush would rely mainly on existing programs in several Government agencies to cushion the pain for military personnel leaving the armed services, displaced military factory workers and communities affected by base closings. By most estimates, though, these programs are inadequate to cope with hundreds of thousands of former service members flooding a weak economy.
Still, the Bush Administration has demonstrated a pronounced reluctance to interfere with the free-market forces that are buffeting military contractors and throwing thousands of people out of work. Mr. Cheney has said the Defense Department should not be a "social welfare agency."
 
Relying on Lawmakers
 But Mr. Clinton does not think the Government is doing enough. He favors transferring Pentagon spending to expanded job retraining and community assistance programs. He says he favors continued production of several major weapon systems, like attack submarines and fighter aircraft, to keep that technology readily available in times of crisis.
In crafting his strategy for military spending and national security, Mr. Clinton has relied heavily on three centrist Democrats in Congress: Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee; Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee; and Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee.
A Clinton Administration would cut the number of aircraft carriers to 10 from the 12 called for under Mr. Bush's plan. Mr. Clinton has not described the number of Army divisions or Air Force fighter wings he would want, though he does favor building new aircraft like the F-22 fighter, C-17 transport plane and V-22 Osprey aircraft.
Mr. Bush, meantime, had spelled out a detailed "base force" he would keep -- 12 aircraft carriers, 12 active-duty Army divisions and 26 fighter wings. He, too, supports modernization of existing weapons systems, including the F-22 and the C-17.
Both candidates embrace a new buying strategy that focuses on developing prototypes and forestalling full production until an affordable system is built and a clear need can be demonstrated. The military industry complains that this approach is impractical, and neither candidate has given details on how to make this strategy profitable.
Under both candidates, the American military would be an increasingly United States-based force, less reliant on foreign bases and sea power, and -- particularly under Mr. Clinton's plan -- more dependent on improved sealift and airlift to send troops and equipment to a conflict quickly.
Mr. Bush would keep 150,000 American troops stationed in Europe after 1995. Mr. Clinton proposes reducing that force to 75,000 to 100,000 troops, a position Congress has endorsed. Both candidates would retain some American forces in Japan and South Korea.
 
Disagreeing on Jobs Lost
 Clinton campaign advisers say that the Administration's plan is just a smaller cold war force. President Bush responds that Mr. Clinton's plan cuts too deeply into "the muscle" of American forces.
Mr. Bush's assertion that under a Clinton Presidency one million additional jobs would be lost in the military industry misrepresents a University of New Mexico study on which the claim was based. The author of the study, Avi Shama, a professor of management, wrote in an article for The New York Times last month that one million defense industry jobs would be lost under Mr. Bush plan and nearly 1.6 million jobs would be lost under Mr. Clinton's cuts.
As with conventional forces, the candidates generally agree on how they should reduce America's nuclear arsenal, while still keeping about 3,000 warheads for strategic deterrence.
Mr. Bush supports missile defenses, from improved Patriot missiles to missile-killing rockets orbiting the Earth. Mr. Clinton endorses an improved Patriot but would cut $15 billion to $20 billion from the Bush Administration's proposed $37 billion "Star Wars" program, mainly from space-based weaponry. Mr. Clinton would also slow development of a ground-based missile-defense site until the need for such a system is clear.
Advisers from both campaigns concur that candidates have fundamentally different views on how, or whether, the Government should help the military industry adjust to shrinking Pentagon budgets or convert production to more commercial goods.
The Bush Administration "is letting major production lines go cold, for everything from tanks to planes to submarines, often ignoring the capacities they represent," Mr. Clinton said in a speech last August to the Foreign Affairs Council in Los Angeles.
Moreover, the two candidates differ on how to help former service members. Mr. Clinton says he would find jobs for displaced workers by devoting Federal money to communication, transportation, new environmental technology and other infrastructure projects. He supports using redirected Pentagon spending for this purpose.
This month, Congress approved a $274.3 billion military budget bill for the 1993 fiscal year that included $1.5 billion for these kinds of programs.
Mr. Cheney said the Administration had programs in place providing $7.1 billion to help people or regions affected by military cuts. Of that $7.1 billion, which is over two years, about $2.2 billion is in severance pay and $3.4 billion in unemployment benefits. The Administration is spending the remaining amount on a combination of job retraining, community assistance and improved G.I. Bill benefits. And in a separate program the Administration has also proposed spending an additional $1 billion over the next five years for similar programs.
But beyond that, the Administration has a questionable record when it comes to spending money earmarked in the Pentagon budget for conversion purposes. In October 1990, Congress ordered the Pentagon to transfer $150 million to the Labor Department for retraining programs, and $50 million to the Commerce Department for community assistance.
But the Labor Department did not receive the money until September 1991, and has spent only $30 million of the $150 million. The Commerce Department did not receive its money until February 1992 and has spent $1.9 million of the $50 million, according to Commerce Department officials.
On balance, though, campaign advisers and military analysts say the shape, size and mission of the armed forces in the future would not be radically different under Republican or Democratic administrations.
An assessment of Mr. Clinton's national security proposals by Georgetown University's National Security Studies Program concluded: "A Clinton Presidency would not fundamentally alter the current content of U.S. national security policies."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Candidates on the Issues: Differing Routes to Similar Military Goals"
 
The Themes
Mr. Bush says that as the leader of the international coalition that defeated Iraq, he should be trusted as an experienced commander-in-chief. He supports a smaller post-cold war military ready to respond to regional contingencies with the most advanced weaponry. Mr. Bush says his Administration has already taken steps to ease the transition for people and areas affected by military reductions.
Mr. Clinton acknowledges Mr. Bush's experience in national security issues, but holds that national security is now linked closely to domestic economic strength. He, too, supports a smaller post-cold war military with a size adequate to respond quickly to regional conflicts. But Mr. Clinton would use more Pentagon spending to cushion the effects of military reductions and assert a larger Government role in helping American military industries in the transition.
 
 The Proposals
Mr. Bush endorses the Pentagon's "base force" of 1.6 million active-duty troops by 1995. He would spend $1.42 trillion between now and 1997 on the military's budget. He supports modernizing American military technology and a an anti-missile program that includes defenses in space.
Mr. Clinton would cut an additional 200,000 troops by 1997 and proposes spending $1.36 trillion by 1997, about 4 percent less than Mr. Bush. Most of these reductions would come from troops cuts and reductions in the missile defense system, mainly those in space.
 
 The Scorecard
Mr. Bush faces a losing battle with a Democratically controlled Congress on maintaining his proposed spending levels for the military. An agreement between the White House and Congress that prevented the transfer of Pentagon spending to domestic programs expired this year, making deeper Defense Department reductions likely in 1993.
Mr. Clinton has deliberately stayed close to the Bush Administration's position on military spending and strategy, largely to avoid charges that Democrats are soft on national security. He has not described in detail the shape of his post-cold war military, but Congress is likely to support his more aggressive programs to assist workers and regions affected by base closings.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
New York City Prices $844 Million in Bonds

 BODY:
New York City priced yesterday about $844 million in bonds for sale to the public.
The city's bond offering consisted of two parts: $759.2 million of general obligation bonds through a group of underwriters led by Lehman Brothers,, and a total of $85.12 million of tax-exempt and taxable capital appreciation bonds through Prudential Securities. 
 Earlier this week, the city received good news when the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit-rating concern, affirmed its A- rating on New York City debt. The agency said that while its ratings outlook for the city remained negative because of the recession, the city's budget was reasonably balanced. Despite this, yields have climbed above 7 percent on the city's tax-exempt bonds due in 15 years or more.
Traders and investors had been skeptical about how much the $759.2 million bond issue would save on interest costs, considering the weakness of the bond market and the size of the deal.
 
Sweetening the Deal>
 Although many investors want New York City bonds, which are exempt from Federal, state and city taxes for city residents, some traders quietly say investors may be unwilling to pay premium prices for them, since the city already has about $19 billion in publicly traded bonds outstanding. Indeed, to make the city's bonds more attractive, underwriters repriced and raised yields 5 basis points, or five-hundredths of a percentage point, on the long end.
Lehman Brothers is offering the general obligation bonds to yield a maximum 7.15 percent for bonds maturing in 2011 through 2018. For shorter maturities, the city is offering serial bonds at prices to yield from 3.9 percent in 1994 to 5.5 percent in 1997, 6.5 percent in 2002, 6.3 percent in 2007 and 7.1 percent in 2009 and 2010.
All the bonds are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by S.& P., except for the issues due in 2007 and 2008, which are insured by Financial Security Assurance and therefore rated triple-A by both rating companies.
The city's offering of $85.12 million in tax-exempt and taxable bonds represents the second sale of "NYC Bonds" aimed at smaller investors. These bonds can be purchased for as little as $1,400, with investors receiving $5,000 when the bonds mature in 15 years or more.
Of the total financing, $75.05 million is of tax-exempt zero-coupon bonds that if held to maturity will yield a maximum 7.25 percent for an issue due in 2011 and 2012, with the remaining bonds yielding from 5.6 percent in 1997 to 7.2 percent in 2009 and 2010.

HEADLINE: Better Earnings at Citicorp and Chemical

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Profits at Citicorp and the Chemical Banking Corporation improved considerably in the third quarter compared with a year ago while net income at Wells Fargo & Company dropped 72 percent. But the performance of the three was overshadowed by several other large banks across the country, which had earnings that were at or near record levels.
The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, reported a 33 percent gain in profits, to $186.2 million, while PNC Financial, owner of Pittsburgh National Bank, earned $135.1 million, up 26 percent. The Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis earned $133.9 million, up 21 percent, and the Mellon Bank Corporation, Pittsburgh, earned $156 million, more than double the year-earlier quarter. 
 These four regional banking companies are regarded as among the best run in the industry in recent years. By focusing on consumers and small and medium-size businesses, they have avoided the worst of the loans to large real estate developers, which badly hurt many other banks.
Among banks that have lost heavily from real estate loans, Wells Fargo earned $24 million, down from $86 million a year ago, which in turn was far below its profits of preceding years.
Among large New York banks, Citicorp's profit of $116 million was slightly above the range it had estimated earlier this month, and much better than the $885 million loss it reported a year ago. Chemical's profits rose 35 percent, to $282 million. Both companies benefited from cost cutting and increases in revenue from foreign exchange trading.
"The overall earnings picture for the industry has been pretty good all year, and that has continued in the third quarter," said Ronald Mandle, a banking analyst at Sanford Bernstein & Sons. He added that the key forces behind the record profits for the best-run banks were a decline in nonperforming assets like badly delinquent loans and real estate acquired through foreclosure, and an exceptionally wide spread between the interest rates banks charge borrowers and the rates they pay on deposits.
Profits at Citicorp were helped by a sharp rise in revenue for foreign exchange trading to $364 million from $193 million in the second quarter.
As it forecast earlier this month, Citicorp said it was making progress in cutting expenses, so that it now has a profit before the cost of bad loans to businesses of $1.9 billion in the third quarter, up from only $1.38 billion in the first quarter of 1991.
As the profit margin has widened, Citicorp's losses from loan write-offs, reserves to cover expected losses and costs of holding real estate acquired through foreclosure has fallen to $521 million, from $705 million in the second quarter and a peak of $792 million in the fourth quarter of 1991. Write-offs of consumer loans rose to $860 million, from $838 million in the second quarter.
 
Federal Examination Under Way
 Although Citicorp's losses from commercial loans have fallen in recent quarters, analysts and investors say the company needs more reserves and capital to absorb future losses. The need for more capital may become more apparent after an examination by Federal officials that is now under way is completed, said Christoper Whalen, director of the Whalen Company, a Washington consulting firm.
Citcorp added $1 billion to its capital through the sale of a preferred stock issue earlier this month, but still has a relatively thin cushion of capital and reserves compared with other large banks. Its shares closed yesterday at $15.125, up 25 cents.
Chemical Banking's profit of $282 million was equal to 98 cents a share, up from $209 million, or 95 cents a share, a year ago. The gain in earnings per share was reduced because the company issued 57.5 million additional shares earlier this year.
Foreign exchange trading profits at Chemical rose to $176 million from $49 million in the second quarter and $73 million a year ago. The company also benefited from an increase in the margin between the rates it collects on loans and the rates it pays on deposits to 3.84 percent, up from 3.69 percent in the second quarter and 3.27 percent a year ago.
The company said it had cut expenses by $65 million in the quarter, excluding one-time charges and the costs of real estate owned as a result of foreclosure. Its shares closed unchanged yesterday at $33.50.
Wells Fargo & Company, whose reliance on lending to real estate developers produced big profits in the 1980's and big problems in recent quarters, reported yesterday that those problems were continuing. In the third quarter its $24 million profit was equal to 21 cents a share, down from $86 million, or $1.59 a share, a year ago.
At a time when real estate experts say that prices of California commercial real estate have not stopped declining, Wells appears to be preparing itself for heavy losses on those loans. It added $400 million to its loan loss reserve, even though it wrote off only $264 million of loans as a loss during the quarter. A year ago, when its real estate loan problems were just emerging, it added $200 million to the reserve and wrote off $123 million as a loss.
Wells could afford the heavy loan losses and still earn a profit because of the earnings from its California consumer business, which analysts say is one of the most efficiently run bank branch systems in the country. The net interest margin remained high at 5.69 percent, which was unchanged from the second quarter but well above the 5.22 percent of a year ago. Wells also benefited from an increase in noninterest revenues to $285 million, from $224 million a year ago, with $45 million of the gain coming from the sale of securities. Its shares closed yesterday at $64.125, down 87.5 cents.

HEADLINE: C.D. Yields Are Mixed For Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit turned mixed in the week that ends today, giving depositors some respite from the steady drop in bank rates since July, when the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate and most large banks subsequently cut their prime lending rates.
Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, a Florida-based interest rate publication, said money market accounts slipped again, but yields on certificates of deposit were up at commercial banks and just slightly off at savings banks. 
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, the average discount rates rose to their highest levels since the end of August. And since the auction is often regarded as a reliable barometer of how banks will eventually set deposit rates in the weeks ahead, it may be a signal that a bottom has been reached.
According to numbers released by the Treasury, the average rate at auction for a three-month bill this week rose 6 basis points, to 2.94 percent from 2.88 percent, while the longer six-month bill rose 15 basis points, to 3.10 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The combined New York area average for yields in the latest week showed a smaller decline in the average money market account, down a basis point, to 2.81 percent, while a three-month certificate of deposit was at 2.86 percent for the third consecutive week, and a six-month certificate gained a basis point, to 3.01 percent.
Yields at commercial banks were mixed for the second straight week, with the average money market account off a basis point to 2.63 percent, and a three-month certificate and a six-month certificate up 2 basis points each, to 2.76 percent and 2.89 percent respectively.
While the news was good for commercial bank depositors, savings bank yields were again lower.Each category was down a basis point, to 3 percent for a money market account, 2.97 percent for a three-month certificate and 3.12 percent for a six-month C.D.
Large adjustments were made this week at First Nationwide, which dropped its money market account by 20 basis points, to 2.70 percent, and at the Bank of Tokyo Trust, which raised both its three- and six-month C.D. by 25 basis points, to 2.68 percent each. It is the second straight week that the bank has raised its C.D. yields so aggressively.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks surveyed were also mixed, with the average money market account off 3 basis points, to 2.69 percent, and a six-month C.D. up a basis point, to 2.87 percent.

Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only.

HEADLINE: Manager of Indian Tribe's Casino Quits

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 20

 BODY:
The chief executive of Connecticut's only casino, opened earlier this year by an Indian tribe, has resigned, citing philosophical differences with the tribe's leadership.
No specifics were available from a spokesman for the tribe, the Mashantucket Pequots, or the executive, Alfred J. Luciani. 
 His departure comes on the heels of an unusual proposal he made last week to state lawmakers, who are considering proposals for casinos in Bridgeport and Hartford. If the state would block such projects, Mr. Luciani told a legislative hearing, the tribe might be willing to share some of its profits with the state, which at present receives no income from the operations of the Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo & Casino in Ledyard under the terms of a compact with the tribe.
 
New Opportunities Cited
 A tribal spokesman, Bruce Macdonald, denied any link betwen Mr. Luciani's remarks and his resignation. "It's strictly a coincidence," he said today. "I know the timing suggests otherwise." Mr. Luciani has agreed to stay on until a successor can be named, Mr. Macdonald said, adding, "He wants to go on to new management opportunities."
Mr. Luciani was hired by the 250-member tribe last year to oversee development of the casino on tribal property in eastern Connecticut.
A former New Jersey prosecutor, he left law enforcement for the gambling industry and worked for the Golden Nugget and other casinos in Atlantic City. At Foxwoods, he installed a management team largely from Atlantic City, as well.
In an interview in December, Mr. Luciani remarked on the differences between his management philosophy and that of the Mashantucket Pequots. "I think in terms of quarterly profits and annual results," he said, "and they really think in terms of the millennium."
The casino has been very successful since it opened in February, attracting an average of 10,000 people a day to its 24-hour operation, which features poker, craps, blackjack and other games in a "natural" setting of bubbling brook-like fountains and a tree-filled atrium.
 
$100 Million Expected
 The casino, which won the right to open only after a long legal battle that was decided by the United States Supreme Court, projects gross revenue of at least $100 million by its first anniversary. Construction has already begun on a $142 million expansion, including a hotel, parking garage, additional gaming parlors, a theater and a shopping concourse.
Mr. Luciani, who announced his resignation on Saturday, could not be reached for comment today. An assistant in his office said he would be out of town for several days.
His proposal to the state, however, presents an intriguing problem for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who opposes casinos. It would enable the governor to block the development of additional casinos, while obtaining much-needed revenue for the state. His spokeswoman, Avice Meehan, said he would have no comment on the proposal, adding, "He has much more ambitious goals for the people of this state, in terms of long-term economic development."
 
Separate-Nation Status
 William DiBella, a State Senator from Hartford who supports building new casinos in Connecticut, said he thought Mr. Luciani's proposal would be difficult to apply because of the tribe's separate-nation status. '
'They cannot be taxed under that status," Mr. DiBella said.
He also said that he considered casinos not only sources of revenue for cities like Hartford, but also "an economic development tool and catalyst."
The tribe has agreed to reimburse the state for the cost of regulatory services like conducting security checks on casino employees. In the current fiscal year, the state expects to receive $2.58 million in such payments, Ms. Meehan said.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 2.43 at Close of Seesaw Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average ended slightly lower yesterday in a busy, seesaw session that reflected worries about rising interest rates.
But the broader market was higher, largely on favorable third-quarter earnings reports. On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by about 5 to 4. 
 The Dow index of 30 big-company stocks fell 2.43, to 3,186.02. The decline was attributed largely to Merck, which sank after a medical journal editorial played down prospects for its new prostate drug.
Volume on the Big Board totaled 258.2 million shares, compared with 222.2 million in the previous session.
Broader indicators were higher. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index gained 0.34, to 228.58, while the Nasdaq over-the-counter market's composite index rose 2.03, to 592.70. At the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index rose 2.86, to 371.40.
"The overall market is giving a better performance than the Dow," said Tom Gallagher, head stock trader at Oppenheimer & Company.
But uneasiness about rising interest rates restrained stocks. Higher rates attract investors away from stocks and into the bond market.
Bond prices have been lower in recent days, sending interest rates higher, on the belief that the election of Gov. Bill Clinton as President would eventually result in higher public spending, which economists fear could increase inflation and the deficit. Mr. Clinton has also said he intends to reduce the deficit if elected.
The Government's 30-year bond sank more than $8 per $1,000 in face amount, lifting its yield above 7.60 percent for the first time since July.
"They're selling off because the bonds are getting hit so hard," said Dudley Eppel, a senior vice president at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.
The Dow rose as much as 25 points in early trading before falling. The early gains came after the Commerce Department said housing starts rose 1.4 percent in September to their highest level in six months. It was the second straight monthly advance. The news was viewed as a sign the economy may be showing signs of growth. Analysts had expected a slight decline after an August increase of 12.6 percent.
Traders also appeared buoyed by a round of strong corporate earnings, a European newspaper report that Germany planned to lower some interest rates and gains in overseas stock markets.
Among active issues, Chrysler rose 5/8, to 25 1/2. The nation's No. 3 auto maker said it made $202 million in the third quarter, higher than analysts' estimates. Ford gained 1 1/8, to 38 1/8 and General Motors rose 3/4, to 29 7/8.
I.B.M., which has been battered in recent days, fell another 1/4, to 68 1/4.
Merck dropped 2 1/4, to 42. An editorial in The New England Journal of Medicine played down the potential of the company's new prostate drug, Proscar, for which analysts have predicted multimillion-dollar sales.
Compaq fell 1 1/8, to 39 5/8, after reaching a high for the year of 42 3/8. The computer company said it had earned $49 million in the third quarter, in contrast to a $70 million loss a year ago.
Citicorp closed up 1/4, at 15 1/8, as third-quarter earnings were higher than the company had predicted.
On the Nasdaq market, Amgen rose 2 3/8, to 66 1/8, after reporting that its third-quarter profits had increased nearly 70 percent.

HEADLINE: Campus Journal;
Presidential Debate Raises Students' Self-Esteem at Michigan State

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct.20

 BODY:
Students at Michigan State University live under a constant blue-and-maize shadow cast by their neighbors at the University of Michigan, often finding themselves obliged to explain that they attend that other
school in Michigan.
But the national spotlight fell, if only briefly, here on Monday when the Presidential race came storming into town. The campaigns, the Secret Service and hundreds of reporters all arrived to find a campus thrilled to be on the nation's mind for something other than the football team. 
 More than 1,000 student volunteers worked as ushers, drivers and escorts for the candidates' entourages and for several news organizations. Many others threw themselves into discussions, held parties, conducted surveys and got involved in other activities on campus related to the debate. Everywhere students cheered -- or booed -- the candidates. Others protested everything from United States policies toward Bosnia to abortion.
"To have a media event like this brings out the relevant issues to students," said Samir Singh, a senior from Livonia, Mich., who spent debate night organizing and distributing information on his group, Into the Streets, a community-service program.
Calling the debate a great success for Michigan State, Bradford L. Thaler, an international relations sophomore from Saginaw, Mich., said: "It drew a lot of positive attention to the campus. I woke up this morning and M.S.U. was still in the news."
When the debate was finally certain, the 41,000 students breathed a communal sigh of relief. For two months they were on a roller coaster of doubt, with the low point the cancellation of the initial debate schedule.
The ride officially began Aug. 14. The Commission on Presidential Debates named the university as one of three sites for the forums. The date was set for Sept. 22, at the university's Wharton Center for the Performing Arts.
But the first debate was quickly in doubt when President Bush declined to accept the terms of the commission and Gov. Bill Clinton refused to negotiate them. To add insult to injury, the university was told it would receive only 25 student tickets -- approximately one ticket for every 1,600 students on campus.
On Sept. 16, the ticket issue disappeared with the debate, which was officially canceled.
The consolation prize turned out to be Mr. Clinton, who vowed to be in East Lansing on Sept. 22 anyway. Mr. Clinton jogged through the area where thousands of students live off campus, shook hands and made a speech that many students viewed as one of the most lackluster of the campaign. For many on campus, the reaction was, "That's it?"
Behind the scenes, though, the university kept bargaining with the commission. On Oct. 2, the commission announced its new plan, and once again Michigan State made the cut, along with Washington University in St. Louis and the University of Richmond.
Disappointed once, the students felt apprehensive as well as excited this time. And the cost of the debate arose as an issue for many students, who had not long ago been handed a 12 percent tuition increase for the current school year. The university spent about $100,000 on the debate -- mostly for turning an athletic center into a giant press room. Although university officials said they hoped to recoup the costs through donations, less than half the figure has been made up, university officials said.
"The money's going to come back into the economy from all the visitors and participants," said Deirdre Brown, a junior in a pre-law program and the M.S.U. representative on the Michigan Collegiate Coalition, a statewide lobbying group. "Plus you can't beat the publicity it's bringing the school."
Tickets were again an issue, but the second round resulted in a minor victory. Slightly more than 200 tickets were set aside for students, after the university's interim president, Gordon Guyer, asked the commission for more student seats.
Ms. Brown said Mr. Guyer "really went to bat for the students," a risky maneuver when the commission could easily have found another location for the debates. Mr. Guyer said the debates were part of the students' educations.
"The students have gotten what's important in any good education -- good out-of-classroom experience," Mr. Guyer said. "That's exactly why we went to the mats for those young people. Through it all, we brought a historic event to Michigan State."

HEADLINE: Frank Curran, 79, A San Diego Mayor

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Frank Curran, a former Mayor of San Diego who was voted out of office after being acquitted in a bribery scandal, died Sunday. He was 79 years old.
His death, which was reported today by a Mercy Hospital spokesman, came almost three months after he underwent surgery for a broken vertebra suffered in a fall. 
 Francis Earl Curran was mayor from 1963 to 1971. A longtime Democrat who got much of his support from Republican businessmen, he campaigned to fashion San Diego into a gateway city for trade from Latin America and the Pacific Rim.
He also promoted the idea of forming an economic development corporation to attract new industries to San Diego, an idea that is a legacy of his administration.
On Oct. 8, 1970, Mr. Curran was indicted and arrested on bribery and conspiracy charges in what became known as the Yellow Cab scandal.
Mr. Curran was found not guilty of all charges by a Superior Court jury on Jan. 6, 1971.

HEADLINE: Rate of Home Building Up 1.4% in September

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Builders broke ground for new houses and apartments at an annual rate of 1,256,000 units in September, 1.4 percent faster than in the preceding month and the best performance since March, the Commerce Department reported today.
The rise, which was in the upper range of expectations, followed a 12.6 percent jump in August and was seen, as expected by the Bush Administration, and by some private analysts as well, as a sign of pickup for an economy managing only feeble growth. But others, including the chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, were less sanguine. 
 According to John M. Albertine, who heads a Washington forecasting firm, the figures on September starts, combined with a 3.7 percent rise in permits to build, represent "the first signal we've gotten in a long time that the beleagurered economy might poke its nose out of its recessionary hole." And Commerce Secretary Barbara Hackman Franklin said that starts in the third quarter had risen at a "solid" 4.8 percent pace.
 
Data Called Inconsistent
 But the housing trade group's economist, David F. Seiders, said that the figures did not square with other recent data on consumer home-buying intentions and construction spending and that a rise in interest rates since Labor Day already threatened the modest gains in housing.
He pointed to the rate of 8.57 percent quoted today for 30-year mortgages, up from 8.09 percent at the end of September and from a low of 7.91 percent on Sept. 9.
The report showed a wide disparity in September starts, , with the Northeast posting a 24.6 percent advance, to a 142,000-unit annual pace, the largest since January 1991, and the South a 7.1 percent rise, to 540,000.
But starts slumped 7.8 percent in the Midwest and 7.3 percent in the West, to rates of 284,000 and 290,000 units, respectively.
 
First Quarter Was Better
 Joan D. Schneider, senior domestic economist for Continental Bank, Chicago, noted that while third-quarter starts were better than those of the second quarter, they trailed those in the first three months of the year.
"We've seen most of the cyclical rebound that we're going to see," she predicted, noting among other things demographic trends that point to sluggish household formation and, thus, relatively weak housing demand.
She and other analysts, however, cheered what now appears could be the end of a long downward trend in construction of new multifamily dwellings.
In September, dwellings in buildings with five or more units were begun at a 154,000-unit pace after 150,000 in August. The average for June and July was 113,500.
 
One-Family Homes Up 1.2%
 For one-family homes, the September rate was 1,071,000, 1.2 percent above August's 1,058,000, the report showed.
The actual number of starts last month, without seasonal adjustment, was 110,000, down 500 from August.
The 3.7 percent rise in permits reflected gains in all four regions but those in the Northeast and West were less than 2 percent each while those in the Midwest and South were 6.1 percent and 4 percent, respectively.
Mr. Seiders said that permits were a poor predictor of future housing activity But that because permit data contained less statistical "noise," they might be a better gauge of current housing conditions.
In a lackluster market, many builders put up individual houses rather than speculative developments requiring many permits.
Hurrican Andrew, the Government said, had had "virtually no effect" on the September housing estimates despite an expanded definition of starts to include cases in which existing foundations are used.

HEADLINE: Perot in Debate: Too Hard on Airlines and Banks?

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Ross Perot, Presidential candidate, asserted in the Monday debate that the United States might, in effect, be dismantling its airline industry and raised the question of whether commercial banks are in worse shape than people generally realized.
The current situations in each industry suggests that though there are indeed problems, Mr. Perot has oversimplified the difficulties of the airlines and probably overstated current concern about the banks. 
 He is, however, certainly not alone in expressing the view that recent agreements by the airlines to form closer ties with foreign carriers may be "destructive," as he put it, to the airline industry.
But the validity of that concern depends on which airline you ask.
 
 
Foreign Links
 Northwest is seeking to strengthen its ties with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, and USAir wishes to do the same with British Airways. The two American companies contend that they need the ties to keep up in the competitive race with their bigger rivals -- American, United and Delta.
The big three, meanwhile, are cooperating in an intense effort to have the Department of Transportation turn down the two ventures unless American, United and Delta can get access to the fly to British cities and beyond to a similar degree that KLM and British Airways will have to the United States. They want Andrew Card, the Secretary of Transportation, to link the approval of the USAir and British Airways proposal to a willingness by the British Government to reopen its bilateral aviation agreement. Mr. Card, who left for London yesterday to try to get bilateral talks moving, said that there was a wide gulf between the two sides but that he would leave "no stone unturned" to get a more liberal agreement.
All major American carriers in recent years have sought to build large international route systems -- some by buying routes from failed carriers such as Pan American World Airways or struggling Trans World Airlines. Northwest and USAir have taken a different strategy. They see combinations with foreign airlines as a way to build global networks less expensively while also getting an infusion of money. USAir would get an injection of $750 million from British Airways, in addition to a new connection to a vast network of international air routes.
If the Department of Transportation approves the USAir deal without the liberalized bilateral agreement, there could well be a gradual erosion of traffic for the remaining large carriers. American, Delta, United and Federal Express have estimated that it could cost American carriers a minimum of $500 million a year in lost revenue and the loss of thousands of jobs. The four carriers employ about 350,000. USAir and Northwest employ about 94,000 workers.
If Mr. Card does get a liberalized agreement, the American industry will probably emerge strong. If not, and the USAir-British Airways deal is approved, there could, indeed, be serious damage.
Mr. Perot's questioning of the state of the commercial banking industry reflects suspicions many have expressed in recent months that a banking crisis is on the horizon but has been concealed until after the election. The idea has not gained credibility among those in the best position to known: bankers, analysts, investors or regulators.
On the other hand, the best case for such suspicions might be the undeniable fact that Federal and state regulators -- and Congress and others who should have known -- underestimated and, in fact, denied the problems of the savings-and-loan industry until after the 1988 elections.
 
Closer to the Mark
 Gov. Bill Clinton and President Bush both agreed that there are some weak banks, but said no banking crisis was looming. They seemed closer to the mark.
Unlike the savings-and-loan industry, which was insolvent in 1988, the banking industry has $250 billion of equity capital to absorb unexpected losses, plus $55 billion of reserves to absorb losses on loans already identified as troubled.
In addition, the commercial banks have regulators who have in the past few years forced the industry to recognize its problems by writing off bad loans and cutting dividends. Savings and loans, in contrast, had regulators in 1988 who overlooked weaknesses because they did not have to money to close the insolvent institutions.
Rather than continuing to weaken, as was the case with savings and loans, the banking industry appears to be growing stronger. Profits the first half of this year were a record $15.7 billion, and have remained at record levels this quarter. Moreover, banks are reporting modest declines in badly delinquent loans, which hurt them in 1990 and 1991.
The reports filed by banks do not indicate any significant retreat by bank examiners in their criticism of bad loans. To bankers' dismay, examiners continue to give very low grades to loans that are paying interest on schedule, but which the examiners say will never be paid in full.
Mr. Perot stopped short of predicting a crisis, but said he is concerned by a recent study reported on by The Washington Post. That study, however, makes several errors in calculating potential bank losses. It says real estate owned by banks, for example, is worth only 20 percent of the amount shown on their books, whereas many banks have been selling such real estate for prices about equal to book value.
George Salem, a banking analyst at Prudential Securities who accurately warned in 1990 and 1991 that banks' problems with commercial real estate loans would be very serious and costly, today says that the industry has turned the corner, and no crisis is looming. The level of badly delinquent loans remains high, and will cut into bank profits for several more years. But in most parts of the country, except for California, he says those problems are gradually declining.
 
Far From a Crisis
 A change in Federal law on Dec. 19 that requires closing banks that are not insolvent, but are very weak, will clearly cause a some additional closings. But the number and size of those banks are small compared with the bank failures of recent years and a far cry from a crisis.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation says that only 80 banks with about $30 billion of assets may be subject to early closing because of their financial problems. Assuming that the F.D.I.C.'s losses from those banks are heavier than normal at 20 percent of the banks' assets rather than the 17 percent historical average, the losses to the insurance fund of $6 billion would be easily covered by the reserves the F.D.I.C. established early this year.
But when the flurry of failures in the few months after Dec. 19 comes, analysts confidently predict that the closings will not be a shock to the economy or financial markets. The largest bank likely to be affected, First City National in Houston, has been in a well-publicized struggle to find a buyer or new investors for over a year, so its closing will hardly count as a surprise. With $8.8 billion to $9 billion of assets, First City is not among the nation's top 50 banking companies, and it is of a size that can be readily absorbed by another banking company.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Low U.S. Bond Prices Raise New York City's Cost of Debt

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Prices went from bad to worse in the Treasury market yesterday, but a important bond sale did not go badly for New York City.
On a day when the municipal bond market was driven lower once again by the sharp fall in the Treasury market, the city still managed to pull off an $844 million sale of bonds at the second-lowest cost for the Big Apple in 20 years. 
 Yet, the city might have done even better if it had not been for the spectacular fall in the credit markets in the last two weeks. So even with the city's success, there has been a real cost to the local taxpayer that can be attributed to a recent wave of selling in the credit markets. That selloff is seen as a response to the prospect that Gov. Bill Clinton will win the Presidential election.
Treasury prices fell so sharply yesterday -- the 30-year bond was off three-quarters of a point and the 10-year note a point and a quarter -- that the underwriters for the city had to reprice the issue to raise interest rates to a level that would make them more attractive to investors. Late in the day, Lehman Brothers raised the interest rate offered on most of the issue by 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
City officials would not discuss the exact cost of that repricing. But with approximately $500 million of bonds covered by the repricing, the annual cost is around $250,000 in extra interest.
The extra cost seems even higher if compared with the yields available in the municipal market as recently as last Thursday. Since then, the yield on the actively traded Florida Board of Education bonds due in 2025, for example, has jumped 11 basis points to 6.44 percent.
"It was a substantial issue in a tough market," said Stan Ciemniecki, managing director at Lehman Brothers said of the New York bond offering. "We did not expect the market to behave as poorly as it did today."
Darcy Bradbury, the deputy city comptroller, and Mark Page, the deputy director of the city's Office of Management and Budget, focused instead on the overall interest rate for the entire package, which was 6.8 percent, just above the 20-year low of 6.6 percent for the bond sale in August and still well below the 7 percent of last May.
"We're thrilled," said Ms. Bradbury. "This is not bad in this market that is a little unsettled by the election."
 
'The Market Is Paranoid'
 Traders and dealers would say that Ms. Bradbury was a master of understatement. The Treasury, municipal and corporate markets have been rocked by the prospect of a Clinton victory and the fear that as President he would propose an economic stimulus program that might raise the deficit and lead to a rise in inflation.
"This will continue for a while," said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist at Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "The market is paranoid about a Clinton stimulus program."
Jay Goldinger, a bond trader at Capital Insight in Los Angeles, added: "The market has gone straight south, and the compass seems to be broken. We are not doing anything before the election."
But there is some good news, he suggested. "There will be a relief rally after the election," Mr. Goldinger said, "and the farther we go down the more we can come back."
 
30-Year Bond: 7.64%
 While the election factor has tended to hurt longer-term securities, shorter-term notes and Treasury bills have been undermined by the conclusion of many traders that the Federal Reserve might not reduce interest rates any more because of the possibility of the big Government spending package to stimulate the economy.
In trading in the secondary market, the price of the 30-year bond fell 26/32 , to 9512/32 , to yield 7.64 percent, up from 7.56 percent Monday. This is the highest yield since mid-July and well over the six-year low of 7.21 percent touched in September.
Notes and Treasury bills were also off sharply. The price of the 10-year note plunged one point and 11/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 6.87 percent. That is up from 6.68 percent yesterday and 6.23 percent at the beginning of the month.
 
Yields Seen as Attractive
 Mr. Goldinger said that he was having a hard time believing that yields had jumped so much, but he said they were making the bond market very attractive. If yields on the two-year note, which jumped 21 basis points to 4.32 percent yesterday, stay at these levels he said he would "drive my truck up to the window" at the two-year Treasury auction next week and buy.
Yet, he acknowledged that the market is so skittish now that many investors are going to wait to see just how much farther prices can fall and yields can rise before they decide to become buyers again.
Both the municipal and corporate markets were also off yesterday and have fallen fast in the last several days. Traders said that the price of active issues in the municipal market dropped about three-quarters of a point.
Another sign of the weakness in the municipal market is that there were $148 million of California general-obligation bonds left unsold Monday when the syndicate, led by Merrill Lynch, that underwrote the $1.3 billion sale last week, broke up.
