HEADLINE: Gasoline Mileage and Jobs

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
President Bush is seizing on the issue of gasoline mileage rules in his re-election campaign, running radio ads in Michigan and Ohio that predict huge job losses at local auto factories if a Democratic administration tightens the standards. And some industry groups agree with him.
But efficiency advocates say that raising the standard, now at 27.5 miles a gallon, would actually create jobs in the auto industry and elsewhere in the economy, and Gov. Bill Clinton says he does not favor a law that would raise the standard above what the industry can achieve. 
 The two clashed on fuel economy in the debate on Monday evening, one of the few times they have mentioned energy issues.
The Bush radio ads say that Governor Clinton's "radical environmental proposals require increasing car mileage standards to 40 miles per gallon in 8 years."
 
Dropped by Congress
 Earlier this year, when Congress considered new energy legislation, it debated raising the current auto mileage standard, which was set in 1975. But in a political package deal, it dropped that idea, along with a proposal to let oil companies drill in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
The Motor Vehicle Manufacturer's Association asserts that the domestic industry would lose 150,000 to 300,000 jobs if the United States moved to a standard of 40 miles a gallon. But proponents of stricter standards said that the manufacturers had simply counted the jobs in factories that today produce cars that would not meet the new standard, and that the proposal gave the companies time to adjust.
The American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy, a Washington-based study and lobbying group, recently predicted that stricter mileage rules would generate jobs by giving consumers extra money that would otherwise have been spent on fuel, and would even increase employment in the auto business.
"The industry will retool and add energy-efficiency features to vehicles, and thereby add value to their vehicles, which means more engineers, more assemblers, more parts suppliers, and more revenue and economic activity for auto producers," said Howard Geller, the executive director.
Mileage gives small price incentive; the American Automobile Association's "average" car costs $5,865 a year to run, and raising its fuel economy by 40 percent would save less than $250, or about 4 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances as Traders Note Clinton Spending Plan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against most foreign currencies amid continued expectations that if Gov. Bill Clinton is elected President, his administration would increase spending to stimulate the economy.
Gold prices also rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $343.80 an ounce, up $1.10 from Monday. Republic National Bank said gold added $1.20 an ounce to reach a late bid price of $343.60. 
 Mr. Clinton has promised to increase Government spending, and various markets have been reacting in recent days. Bond prices fell again Tuesday, which means interest rates go up and the dollar becomes more attractive.
"Pre-election markets seem to be dragging U.S. interest rates higher, which is benefiting the dollar across the board," said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., agreed. "Even though monetary policy as directed by the central banks may be changing at a glacial pace, the markets themselves are anticipating events and creating higher interest rates in the U.S. and lower interest rates in Germany," Mr. Donney said. "This is causing the interest rate differential to narrow."
In New York, the dollar settled at 122.5 yen, up from 120.45 yen late Monday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing of 121 yen, up from 120.05 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 121.92 yen.
In New York, a British pound cost $1.6245, up from $1.6225 late Monday. In London, the pound fell to $1.6225 from $1.6330 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.516 marks, up from 1.499; 1.356 Swiss francs, up from 1.3395; 5.1435 French francs, up from 5.0865; 1,333.5 Italian lire, up from 1,316.5, and 1.23975 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2456.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday: 1.5205 marks, up from 1.4835; 1.3605 Swiss francs, up from 1.3215; 5.155 French francs, up from 5.026; 1.711 Dutch guilders, up from 1.67; 1,336 Italian lire, up from 1,300.5; 1.2378 Canadian dollars, down from 1.247.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $343.85 an ounce, up from $342.85 late Monday. In Zurich, gold was up to a closing bid of $343.40, from $342.65 late Monday. Earlier, gold was unchanged in Hong Kong at $342.60.

HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES;
When Ailing Pastime Meets TV Recession, Baseball Gets the K

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
Even as CBS's broadcasts of the World Series provide a compelling video window on the best that major league baseball has to offer, executives of the sport are preparing to negotiate new television contracts that are expected to end the prosperity previously wrought by TV.
Next season will be the fourth and final year of the bonanza that will bring clubs $1.45 billion from CBS and ESPN -- double the amount produced by the previous six-year deal. But baseball says it has no way to prevent television from drastically reducing its financial commitment to the sport. 
 "Our only leverage is we have the national pastime," said Eddie Einhorn, co-owner of the Chicago White Sox and a member of baseball's television negotiating committee. "Maybe it doesn't have the same value as before, but we're not going begging."
 
Single-Network Error
 Although serious negotiations probably will not begin until early next year, club owners and network officials are about to start informal talks. Baseball would again prefer to be on two networks, having found that being on just one was a long-term error.
Baseball has benefited in the short term from TV, but TV has suffered by gambling on baseball. CBS's estimated pre-tax losses from baseball are believed to be $500 million over the life of the contract, or nearly half of its $1.06 billion investment. ESPN, the cable network, is expected to lose nearly half the value of its $390 million contract.
"It would be great to justify the money we're getting, but it's real hard knowing the losses," said Einhorn.
Among the ideas being discussed inside baseball to enhance the value of a new contract with the broadcast networks and cable are interleague play; reducing the regular season by one week, and breaking up the league's two divisions into three conferences. This would create a round of wild-card playoffs, similar to those in the National Football League.
 
Three Major Headaches
 But these possibilities would create problems:
*Any made-for-TV enhancements would require the approval of the players' union at a time of labor-management tension when a spring 1993 lockout is possible. A work stoppage would play havoc with any TV talks and would quite likely reduce the value of a future deal.
*An additional playoff series would create more advertising time to sell, a daunting prospect for any network. But the idea is fancied by Bill Giles, the owner of the Philadelphia Phillies and a member of the TV committee. "This September tells me we need to create more interest in more cities," Giles said, referring to the lack of stirring pennant races.
*Shortening the season would reduce both gate and local TV revenues, which would have to be more than offset by more national TV income. Einhorn knows that local baseball telecasts now provide a more stable stream of cash and are more avidly watched than network broadcasts.
 
Decline in Ratings
 CBS, the incumbent broadcast network, and NBC and ABC, the previous rights-holders, are well aware of the financial losses on baseball since 1990. They know they can live without the game if the price is wrong.
Baseball has been devalued as a broadcast commodity because the sport has declined in national popularity. Regular-season Nielsen ratings have gone down from a 5.1 in 1989 on NBC to a 3.4 this year on CBS. ESPN's ratings have fallen from a 2.1 in 1990 to a 1.5 this season. Each rating point equals 921,000 television homes for the over-the-air networks and 614,000 homes for ESPN.
The roots of baseball's current problems can be traced in part to the current deal.
The sport unleashed a cable-TV schedule of 175 games on ESPN, allowed games on regional channels to compete on Saturday afternoons with CBS games and gave teams no control over the hundreds of games entering their markets via superstations like WTBS and WGN. Under these circumstances, no national TV game could be trumpeted as a special attraction.
 
Graying of Audience
 In addition, baseball's viewership has aged. The fan watching is not as young as the one watching N.F.L. and National Basketball Assocation games. Since 1989, viewership among young men aged 12-17 fell 24 percent while the N.B.A. was up 31 percent and the N.F.L. was up 16 percent in that category.
The changing demographics and the recession have made advertisers jittery about baseball, except during the World Series.
"The advertiser is saying, 'I can put money in the N.F.L., in the Skins Game or in the hot-rodders,' " said Jon Mandel, a senior vice president of Grey Advertising, which buys time for several baseball advertisers.
Of most immediate concern to baseball is what will happen with ESPN, which has until Oct. 31 to exercise its contract option. It can choose a fifth and sixth year, at $120 million and $130 million annually, or it can pay baseball $13 million to escape those two years and negotiate anew. Einhorn isn't optimistic. "The package we sold ESPN isn't worth what it was," he said.
 
ESPN to Cut Back?
 ESPN, which is expected to be the only cable bidder, is said to have recently offered a cutback from six weekly games to four and an annual payment of $50 million to $60 million, according to TV and baseball sources.
There is, said Einhorn and Giles, no rush to wrap up a deal with the networks.
Network officials indicate that no matter what baseball does, the sport is in for a financial fall. Unless they can see a guaranteed profit, they can walk away, a scenario almost unimaginable in the N.F.L. One network official said, "If they can get 70 percent of what they're getting now, they ought to be sent straight to Cooperstown."
The possibility of a return to a game-of-the-week format -- there were only 16 Saturday telecasts this season -- is much discussed, but it does not seem realistic. Only 6 percent of CBS's estimated $290 million payment to baseball this year goes toward the regular season, while 58 percent goes to the World Series, 30 percent to the league championship series and another 6 percent to the All-Star Game.
"A weekly game is political," said Einhorn, who explained that the only reason to resurrect it would be to accommodate the nearly 40 percent of the country that cannot or does not receive cable.
One way of resuscitating a weekly game would be to return to splitting baseball between two networks. If baseball is to develop any negotiating leverage, it might well play the networks against one another.
But the factors that induced CBS to outbid NBC by $380 million to get the current deal are not at play anymore. CBS's losses mean that no network will enter the talks wishing to merely break even. Or, as CBS envisioned, to use baseball as a loss-leader platform, enabling it to gain exposure for prime-time programs in October.
"I would have preferred two networks last time," said Einhorn. "That would mean two networks who cared about baseball. Now NBC and ABC don't care like they did when they had it. It was there to be done last time."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
The Politicizing of TV's Prime-Time Comedy

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
Nan Buffum (Mary Gordon Murray) is executive deputy director of the Bush-Quayle campaign. Her husband Whit (Gerrit Graham) works in a similar capacity for Clinton-Gore. Caught up in a personal swirl of political sniping and dirty tricks, they both want out of a marriage made in hell. Finally going before a judge, she snaps, "I'm the Republican, your honor. He's the ass."
On ABC at 10, tonight's episode of "Civil Wars," titled "Below the Beltway," reflects a marked acceleration over the past year or so in television entertainment's willingness -- and technical ability -- to tackle political subjects. In many instances, a pro forma bow is made in the direction of even-handedness, but the dominant tone comes unmistakably from the left. The subject of Hollywood's liberal bias may be hoary, but as Dan Quayle has discovered, it is hardly dismissible. In any event, as prime time gives "reality" further twists, the phenomenon goes well beyond the straightforward political satire found on NBC's "Saturday Night Live" or Fox's "In Living Color" and "Edge." 
 One of the unusual aspects of this episode of "Civil Wars" is that party affiliation is specified. Clearly, the producers are speculating waspishly on what could happen if the current romance between two real campaign aides, Bush-Quayle's Mary Matalan and Clinton-Gore's James Carville, evolves into marriage.
For the most part, prime time prefers to avoid labels and stick to generalities. But these days there's no mistaking the underlying message: time for a change. ABC's "Roseanne," the nation's most popular show, struggles from week to week with the recession. And several series have incorporated the Los Angeles riots in their plot lines as a way to comment on current anxieties.
Tomorrow at 10 P.M., "L.A. Law" returns on NBC with an episode called "L.A. Lawless." When the not-guilty verdicts in the Rodney King case are announced, Jonathan Rollins (Blair Underwood), a black lawyer, has to re-examine why he is running as a candidate for City Council from South-Central, scene of the worst rioting. He doesn't even live in the neighborhood. His boss, Leland McKenzie (Richard Dysart), recalls how when he was an assistant district attorney 20 years earlier during the Watts riots, he witnessed racism at first hand. He thought he'd make a difference. "When will we learn?" he asks sadly.
"A Different World," on NBC, continues efforts to spike its broad antics with serious issues. Two recent episodes found the honeymooning Whitley (Jasmine Guy) and Dwayne (Kadeem Hardison) trapped in the Los Angeles riots. Certain that this wasn't Selma, Ala., in 1965 and that "I don't spend my life under a gloomy cloud of oppression," a chastened Whitley later finds herself telling a television reporter that "I was living under the delusion that things were getting better for black people in this country." Another character on the show announces that she is going to law school "to study this system so that I can change it."
Of course the award for this year's most celebrated reality-fiction mix goes to CBS's "Murphy Brown," which turned a broadside from Vice President Quayle into blockbuster ratings for the start of its new season. That confrontation over family values has lasted for months.
One of the more important developments in television entertainment's co-opting, or exploiting, of reality is how fast producers are able to get topical material on the air.
Last year, after the Senate's Clarence Thomas-Anita F. Hill debacle, CBS's "Designing Women" rushed into production and broadcast a special episode that used actual television tapes of the hearings to trigger a debate among the regular characters on the series. One or two remarks were made in defense of Judge Thomas, but there could be no doubt that Linda Bloodworth-Thomason's script furiously supported Professor Hill.
In another instance, when President Bush said that as far as families were concerned, he preferred "The Waltons" to "The Simpsons," it was only a matter of a week -- thanks to a quick edit on the audio track -- before bratty Bart was noticing how the Waltons and the Simpsons were indeed quite similar -- both were living through a depression.
A record was surely set by Fox's "Roc" a couple of Sundays ago, only one hour after the first Presidential debate. Now broadcast live each week, the show was able to open with the irascible father, played by Carl Gordon, watching the part of the debate in which a defensive President Bush, now supplemented with a convulsive laugh track, was insisting that "there's good news out there," asserting that there was a drop in drug use. The puzzled old man looked directly into the camera and said, "I don't know whether to vote for Manny, Moe or Jack."
Being outspoken about politics and politicians is not entirely the order of the day. Oddly enough, "Hearts Afire," Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason's new hit on CBS (Mondays at 8:30 P.M.), is set in Washington and features politician characters but is more interested in a fairly standard affair between its two principal characters, a liberal woman (Markie Post) and a conservative man (John Ritter). In the HBO movie "Running Mates," starring Diane Keaton and Ed Harris, care was obviously taken to fudge the party affiliation of the Presidential candidate.
But, perhaps encouraged by the "Murphy Brown" incident, television is getting decidedly more frisky and alert in going for material that might once have been considered too sensitive or controversial. Coming up on Showtime on Nov. 1: "Mastergate," the Larry Gelbart play skewering the almost insane debasement of language in political discourse. This Sunday on NBC, the movie "In the Line of Duty: Street Wars" uses a violent portrait of New York City police pursuing drug pushers to explore a contemporary urban landscape of empty crack vials and bullet shells. The implied indictment of political leaders is unrelenting.
It's definitely getting tougher in prime time for anyone in public life. In this evening's "Civil Wars," Denise (Debi Mazar) the sassy secretary, listens to the Republican wife and Democratic husband savaging each other and concludes, "Personally, I think they're all con men; you know what I mean?"

HEADLINE: How to Keep Business in New York

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins deserves credit for encouraging the Morgan Stanley Group, one of the nation's leading financial services firms, to keep its corporate headquarters in New York City for at least the next decade. Had Morgan Stanley moved to a parcel it had optioned in Stamford, Conn., it might have led other large financial firms to consider leaving -- and thus jeopardized the city's status as the world's financial services center.
Mr. Dinkins and his Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Barry Sullivan, hammered out a reasonable package of tax credits and other incentives, worth $39.6 million over 10 years, that helped persuade the company to stay. In return, Morgan Stanley will keep its headquarters, and as many as 4,100 employees, in the city. Since the company is expected to pay nearly $1 billion in taxes over the next 10 years, the tax incentives appear relatively modest. And Morgan Stanley has a symbolic value that makes keeping it worth special effort. 
 The Morgan Stanley deal is only the latest retention coup for the Dinkins administration. In August, Prudential Securities promised to keep its headquarters in lower Manhattan for 20 years in exchange for at least $106.2 million in tax incentives and energy savings. Also in August, four of New York's five commodities exchanges reached final agreement on a plan that prevented their moving to Jersey City. Last month, on the other hand, First Chicago Corporation announced it would leave Manhattan next year after city officials decided it wasn't worth matching the rich terms offered by Jersey City.
The danger in granting such incentives is that they can whet the appetites of other companies for similar favors. But the Dinkins administration appears to be following a judicious case-by-case approach that need not lead to large-scale giveaways.
In another reassuring sign, Mr. Dinkins has pledged to freeze the city's general corporate tax for four years. The Mayor's financial plan covering the next three years already assumes no rise in corporate taxes. Still, if financial monitors approve, Mr. Dinkins thus expresses and extends a welcome commitment to economic stability.

HEADLINE: Clinton Pledge vs. Clinton Plan

 BODY:
I will not raise taxes on the middle class to pay for my programs.
With that ringing assertion, Gov. Bill Clinton gave Monday's Presidential debate what may be its most memorable moment. Asked to cite a specific income level below which he would not reach for more taxes, he made a ringing no-tax pledge.  
 And not just once. Provoked by President Bush's repeated accusations that his plan was little more than tax-and-spend, the Governor repeated his pledge four times in two minutes. This was no mere slip of the tongue.
The pledge raises worrisome questions. Suppose Mr. Clinton is elected and, as experts expect, his budget estimates go awry. What would he do? His Monday answer invites people to think that he would suspend programs to invest in infrastructure, worker training and education rather than raise taxes, even slightly, on the middle class. That would cut out the soul of the growth agenda that makes Mr. Clinton's candidacy so promising.
The beauty of Mr. Clinton's plan is that it emphasizes putting government firmly behind both private and public investment, the key to promoting productivity. Productivity growth is the surest way to raise living standards.
An economic plan, even one as detailed as Mr. Clinton's, is more metaphor than blueprint. The numbers are not offered with accountant's precision; they are useful most of all as a guide to a candidate's priorities. Ross Perot promises to eliminate the deficit no matter what the cost. Mr. Bush promises to cut taxes no matter what the cost.
But Mr. Clinton has promised a middle ground: Cut the deficit, but only by half over four years. That would leave room to pay for desperately needed public investment and even provide a small tax cut for middle-class families. The question now is whether Mr. Clinton is more committed to holding the line on taxes or, far more important, holding the line for growth.
Mr. Clinton left himself wiggle room. He didn't define middle class. He didn't define "my programs." And he didn't define the emergencies that would allow him to back away from his no-tax stance. But voters are not likely to be reassured by a candidate inclined to find refuge in loopholes.
No one asks Mr. Clinton to make a suicidal pledge, like that made by Walter Mondale in 1984, to raise taxes. But for Mr. Clinton to rule out tax hikes except under dire circumstances is to risk diving into the same policy straitjacket that has paralyzed Mr. Bush. The Governor told viewers Monday night not to read his lips. "Read my plan," he said. Fine, if only he sticks with it.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Prevailing Winds

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
The beginning of the end came at a moment of great triumph. The sound is what I remember best about the State of the Union Message George Bush delivered to Congress on Jan. 29, 1991, just two weeks after the gulf war began -- the sound not of his voice but of the huzzahs, the cheers, the roars that interrupted him time after time. No matter that the speech was long on the self-congratulation of a country engaged in foreign conflict and very short on a domestic program. The room was stuffed to bursting with approval, like helium, threatening to levitate the man.
Did he remember that night when he looked into the unforgiving eye of the camera Monday and pleaded with the American people to vote for him, a little plaintive, a little perplexed? 
 There is an omnipresent argument in civics: Is an elected official meant to follow his own principles or is he meant to be a surrogate, to stand in always for the desires of those he represents? In his public life George Bush has epitomized the latter, the man who puts a wet forefinger up to the prevailing winds. His repeated accusation in the final debate that Bill Clinton does not stand firm on principle is disingenuous. Unlike Mr. Clinton, George Bush has never been canny enough to cast his pragmatism as a signal virtue. But he has always been an adaptable man.
When the prevailing winds blew against Saddam Hussein in favor of an America puffed up by a battle against a detestable foe, the President was in luck. His approval ratings soared. He believed his press, and so did we. Over my desk hangs a column I wrote in March 1991 that contains the sentence "George Bush will be re-elected President in 1992." It is there to remind me of the dangers of hubris. Unlike Mr. Bush, I will not lose my job because of the miscalculation.
But what is a man to do when there are no prevailing winds? It would be a simpler matter if the voters could tell Mr. Bush what they require. But they don't know exactly, particularly within the complicated confines of economic policy. If only it could be like the Persian Gulf war: quick, decisive, sure-handed. It was easy for the President to pick out his friends and revile his enemies. It must be hard to realize now that the electorate can be both friend and foe.
Mr. Bush talked over and over again during the last debate about a Clinton pattern of constantly shifting positions. But the Clinton pattern that has loomed largest in this campaign is one of indefatigability. The women, the draft, the anti-war activities, the trip to Russia -- Bill Clinton has come to resemble one of those inflatable children's toys with sand weighting the bottom. You knock him over and he pops back up. It is a compelling image for voters battered by the economy and eager to get back on their feet. The attacks everyone thought would bring him down may just help elect the man in the long run.
The debates are done. There was a great irony to the idea that they were George Bush's best chance for salvation; he has never been a person who does well off the cuff. That was clear when he almost offhandedly evoked the "Are you better off than you were four years ago?" question. It is a question Mr. Bush should never, ever ask.
For me, the beginning of the end was that speech nearly two years ago, when the internal needs of the nation were drowned out by cheering for the Commander in Chief, drowned out for too long. And the end was in this final debate, a small moment really, when Mr. Bush referred to the state of Arkansas as the "lowest of the low." We all knew what he meant, that it is a poor state, a state with problems, a state whose Governor is not the political prestidigitator he claims. But that's not how it came out.
Paired with his heated defense of the "national honor" when Ross Perot asked some very pressing questions about the diplomacy preceding the gulf war, Mr. Bush's low blow made Arkansas seem disposable. The prevailing winds blow cold for a President who so clearly prefers statecraft to states. "Three weeks from now," the President began his closing statement, then looked skyward and began again, groping for how much time he had left. "Two weeks from tomorrow." November 3, Mr. President. That is the deadline for the invasion of Washington by opposition forces, if that makes it easier to remember.

HEADLINE: In Long Run, Family Leave Will Be a Bargain;
Women's Burden

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read your Oct. 7 installment of "The Good Mother" series, on family leave, with anger. I am sick and tired of the problems we face as women.
Economically, politically and socially we mothers are damned if we do and damned if we don't hold jobs outside the home. When I was a young mother in the 1970's, many of us could still stay home with the kids -- one paycheck could maintain the basics. Less than 20 years later most mothers must work outside the home. Yet we are made to feel selfish and inadequate by politicians and so-called "men of God." 
 What is wrong with a society and an economic system that punishes women and their children by forcing mothers to go into the workplace, work a 40-hour week, come home and then with minimal male assistance, conduct the work required at home? What kind of a society are we that we require most women to return to work six weeks after the birth of a child? What kind of family values do we really hold as a society?
It now generally takes two incomes to support a family. Why can't we give more support to families? If we value women and children, then it's time to pay for day care, enact a family leave bill and create skilled jobs that pay well.
I am sure that there are many men who empathize with the plight of women, but you're not likely to find prominent national focus devoted to the agonizing of men, as they go to the workplace each day, over whether or not they are neglecting their children.
 
KATHLEEN JACQUES
Marietta, N.Y., Oct. 5, 1992

HEADLINE: As More Earn Equivalency Diploma, Its Value Is Debated

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Jonathan Ledlow dropped out of Trenton High School a dozen years ago but promptly got his high school equivalent certificate so he could join the Navy, which was all that he desired at the time.
Now Mr. Ledlow is nearly 30 years old and subsists on $140 a month from the Mercer County welfare board. Along with his honorable discharge from the Navy, he is proud of having earned his equivalency degree, the result of passing a 7 1/2-hour comprehension test. It proves he was able to complete something in his life, he said, but he is not sure what good it is doing him now. 
 Given today's economy, Mr. Ledlow might be unemployed now even if he had completed high school. Still, a new study says, Mr. Ledlow and others who passed the General Education Development test are no better off than high school dropouts who did not take the test. And as his educational experience grows more common -- the G.E.D. in 1991 accounted for 14 percent of all high school graduates compared with five percent in 1968 -- more questions are being raised about the long-term value of the test.
The study, by a University of Chicago economics professor, shows scant difference between the incomes of G.E.D. holders and of high school dropouts with no certificates. And the Army, which pioneered the forerunner of the G.E.D. for World War II veterans 50 years ago, last year quietly stopped accepting the certificate holders into the service on the same basis as high school graduates. The reason: G.E.D. earners flunk basic training at twice the rate of high school graduates.
The test, designed to measure whether the test taker has the same level of comprehension as an average high school senior, requires no classroom work and can be taken without any preparation at all, although most people do study for it in some way. About 70 percent of those who take it pass it. This year, some 480,000 people will earn a G.E.D; about three million students will graduate from high school.
The G.E.D. Testing Service, which administers the G.E.D. nationwide, has been stunned by the sudden swell of bad news about a program that has long been regarded as a kind of saving second chance for millions of high school dropouts. The study on earnings, by James J. Heckman of the University of Chicago, is misleading, the service says.
 
A Lot Better Than Nothing
 Besides, the G.E.D.'s defenders note that they have never suggested that their certificate is as valuable as four years of high school, only that it is a lot better than nothing.
"I don't think the G.E.D. has ever been intended to be everything you get from four years of high school study," said Janet Baldwin, director of policy research for the G.E.D. Testing Service in Washington, which is part of the non-profit American Council on Education. "It has been intended to measure the equivalence of what you learn in high school."
Indeed, many G.E.D. holders use their certificate to become eligible for further education: community colleges and Federal and state job-training programs accept the certificate for admission. According to the Council, 25 percent of G.E.D. recipients complete a two-year college degree.
 
Necessary Social Fiction?
 Beyond that, the defense of the G.E.D. often includes a more subtle argument for accepting the notion of parity between the G.E.D. certificate and a high school diploma. G.E.D. holders are poorer than average, their parents are more likely to have been dropouts themselves and they are more likely to be members of minority groups. According to this argument, for the country to view the G.E.D. as equivalent to a high school diploma is a kind of necessary social fiction: not strictly true, but helpful to people whom life has dealt a hard hand to play, and who need some encouragement to press on.
"People who have not completed high school feel there is something important in their lives that they have not finished, there is a lack of closure," said Ms. Baldwin. "For a lot of them, getting that G.E.D. diploma gives them the feeling that they can go on.
"That is one of the reasons the Heckman report is so disheartening. It seems to blame people who have chosen to come back and get their diploma by another way."
Using figures from the Census Bureau's National Longitudinal Survey of Youth, Dr. Heckman compared the earnings of male G.E.D. holders at age 25 and at age 28 with those of other dropouts and those of high school graduates. While the G.E.D. holders earned somewhat more than other dropouts, Dr. Heckman ascribed the difference to G.E.D. holders' having, on average, attended one more year of high school than the other dropouts.
For 25-year-olds, Dr. Heckman found dropouts without the G.E.D. had average annual earnings of $10,379 per year in 1988 dollars. For G.E.D. holders of that age, the figure was $11,777, while high school graduates, to whom the G.E.D. holders are expected to be equivalent, earned $15,213.
At age 28, the gap between G.E.D. holders and high school graduates had widened, according to the study. Dropouts made $12,411, G.E.D. holders made $13,921, and high school graduates $20,195.
"The person who takes the G.E.D. typically has 11 years of school," Dr. Heckman said, giving his explanation of the wage advantage G.E.D. holders appear to have over other dropouts. "Those who drop out and do not take the G.E.D. have 10 years of school. When you make an adjustment for what an additional year of high school will do for your earnings, you will see that having the G.E.D. makes essentially no difference."
In his study, Dr. Heckman concluded, "Both dropouts and exam-certified equivalents have comparably poor wages, earnings, hours of work, unemployment experiences and job tenure." He added, "There is no cheap substitute for schooling."
Dr. Heckman noted that some G.E.D. holders did very well in life, calling it "the Bill Cosby effect," after one of the country's most successful G.E.D. holders. Others include Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, who took the G.E.D. in the Navy, and Waylon Jennings, the country singer. Nonetheless, he sees access to job training programs or to community college as the only economic benefit of the certificate.
Mr. Ledlow, the G.E.D. holder who is now on welfare and is seeking a job as a salesman, was dismayed to hear that the G.E.D. alone was no longer accepted by the armed services. "That's wrong," he said. "At least if you have the G.E.D., you can show somebody that you completed something in your life," he said.
But Col. John Meyers, director of advertising and public affairs for the United States Army Recruitment Command, said that G.E.D. holders were not longer welcome in the Army unless they first obtain 15 semester hours of college classroom time, or 540 "seat hours" in a vocational school. Each is equivalent to a half-year's schooling.
"We are looking for high school diploma graduates and there is no doubt about our intentions there," Colonel Meyers said, adding that for the past decade, about half of all G.E.D. recruits eventually flunk basic training and are kicked out of the service, as against about a quarter of high school graduates.
"We are not disputing the value of the G.E.D. process," Colonel Meyers said. "We are operating on our desire to be in the high school diploma market on hard experience with the difference in attrition rates between high school and G.E.D. holders once they access into the Army."
In fiscal year 1989, 10 percent of the new Army recruits were G.E.D. holders. This year, the number of G.E.D. holders admitted -- because they met the Army's new requirements for additional education -- amounted to less than half of one percent of the total number of recruits.
"This is the most controversial part of a credential assessment we did a few years ago," said a military personnel officer at the Pentagon who spoke on condition of anonymity. "You would look at a person who goes out and gets a G.E.D. and think that person would be able come into the military and be successful, but it has not worked out that way."
When disciplinary problems are removed as a cause for failure, the official said, G.E.D. holders flunk out of the military at about twice the rate of high school diploma holders, regardless of geographic origin, work experience or arrest record.
The G.E.D. Testing Service has been sensitive to charges that the availability of the G.E.D. may encourage some high school students to seek a short cut to a diploma by dropping out and sitting for the G.E.D. To prevent this, the G.E.D. Testing Service does not allow anyone to take the test before the date he or she would normally have graduated from high school, but about half the states allow exceptions for dropouts who receive a recommendation for the test from their former high school.
The lure of a quick G.E.D. instead of one or two more years of high school is clearly a temptation to disgruntled students, said Judy Myer, a guidance counselor at Jackson High School in Jackson, Mo., and the past vice president of the American School Counselors Association.
"For some students and for whatever reason -- poor grades or a chance for a full-time job quickly -- the G.E.D is an out," Mrs. Myer said. "Some say they have parents or friends who took the G.E.D. so it must be all right, and for others it's simply an escape. It's something they can say to the school office or to their parents: 'It doesn't matter if I drop out, because I can get the G.E.D. and it's just as good.' "
She hastened to add that some students drop out for reasons other than laziness or alienation, like pregnancy or the need to work to support a family. And once a student has dropped out, the G.E.D. is certainly a step in the right direction, Mrs. Myer said. But she emphasized her belief that obtaining a G.E.D. is simply not as good as staying in school.
"I just can't accept that the G.E.D. is equivalent to getting the full high school curriculum," she said.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 22, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart yesterday showing sample questions from the General Education Development high school equivalency test gave an incorrect answer in some copies for one question. The question, under the Social Studies heading, asked which type of business had the fewest customer complaints, based on a bar graph; the answer should have been D, supermarket, not C, car dealership.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The G.E.D. high school equivalency program has come under fire recently. A woman studied for the test in Tulsa, Okla. (Steve Jennings)
 
Chart: "A Quick Look at the G.E.D." shows some sample questions from the General Educational Development test.
 The General Educational Development test is multiple choice, lasts 7 1/2 hours and was designed by the G.E.D. Testing Service to measure competence in high-school-level academic skills.
Its five sections cover writing skills, social studies, science, mathematics and reading comprehension. The G.E.D. does not test raw factual knowledge -- the dates, names and formulas that high school students study and memorize for tests. Judging by a practice test provided by the service, most necessary information, including mathematical formulas, is provided with the test. The G.E.D. Testing Service gives sample questions to high school seniors each year to determine that the academic level of the G.E.D. questions is equivalent to senior-year courses of study.
Taking the test does not require any classroom preparatory work. According to the testing service, about 40 percent of G.E.D. test-takers sit for the exam without any preparation; the rest brush up by either reading how-to books available in bookstores or enrolling in pre-G.E.D. classes held at many night schools and community colleges.
The writing skills segment includes a 200-word essay on a given topic.

HEADLINE: Business Technology;
How the Offshore Rigs Rode Out Gulf's Storm

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
It was two days after the most savage hurricane of the century ripped through the Louisiana gulf waters and Scott Sewell, the chief Federal regulator of offshore oil production, was touring the region by helicopter, dreading the worst. He was amazed by what he could not find.
"The massive oil slicks that we didn't want to see weren't there," Mr. Sewell recalled recently. "There was very little environmental damage and, frankly, the losses were minimal given the ferocity of the storm." 
 Twenty years ago, a hurricane with 160-mile-an-hour winds and 71-foot waves might have turned Louisiana's southern shores into a catastrophe not only for thousands of birds, fish and other wildlife poisoned by oil slicks but also for the oil industry, which could have faced a financial and public-relations disaster like the 1989 Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska. But on Aug. 25, when Hurricane Andrew whipped up the water surrounding hundreds of offshore rigs, modern drilling-platform architecture stood up to nature's fury.
Although daily output of as much as 800 million cubic feet of natural gas and maybe 90,000 barrels of oil remain out of production while repairs continue on pipelines, older platforms and other storm-damaged gulf machinery, even some environmentalists are giving the oil industry credit for being technologically prepared.
 
Little Oil Is Spilled
 By the Government's count, 249 of 3,800 offshore platforms in Federal gulf waters were damaged by Hurricane Andrew, but spilled oil amounted to less than 500 barrels. Nearly half of that was skimmed up by recovery crews, and no slicks were found along the shoreline. By contrast, the Exxon Valdez wreck spilled 250,000 barrels into Prince William Sound, and the cleanup is still not finished.
A Texaco platform apparently caused the worst environmental damage after Hurricane Andrew ripped a rig called the Treasure 75 from its moorings. The wind and waves sent the platform sailing more than four and a half miles before one of its 30,000-pound anchors tore through a concrete-sheathed oil pipeline, spilling 300 barrels. The platform then ran aground in 35 feet of water.
Industry officials and structural engineers say that improvements in standards and techniques in platform design and construction over the last 20 years passed an important test by taking blows from Hurricane Andrew without fouling Louisiana's coastal waters or beaches.
The episode "should show that offshore drilling can be done safely, even when you have a 100-year hurricane," said William F. O'Keefe, executive vice president of the American Petroleum Institute, the Washington trade group financed by major oil companies. Oceanographers say storms with the winds and steep waves of Hurricane Andrew occur in gulf waters perhaps once a century.
 
Banned in Other Areas
 Offshore rigs are an entrenched part of the Louisiana and Texas economies. But Congress has banned drilling in areas off the Atlantic coast, the Florida gulf coast and the California coast -- areas that geologists say have large oil-and-gas reserves. The nation still faces a substantial risk from oil spills, however, because it imports so much of its oil in tankers, more than eight million barrels a day. Tankers have a far worse environmental record than offshore wells.
"The overwhelming evidence, just overwhelming, is that the industry takes all the precautions that are needed" for safe offshore drilling, Mr. O'Keefe said. "Future operations are bound to be safer as long as we keep investing in new technology."
Environmentalists concede that the industry's offshore drilling techniques have improved steadily since the disastrous 1969 spill off the coast of Santa Barbara, Calif., that was a flashpoint for the modern environmental movement.
"Whether it's been the industry pushing or environmentalists pushing from the outside is hard to say," said Thomas M. Miller, a spokesman for the Center for Marine Conservation in Washington. "Standards have been taking a gradual step up in the last couple of decades on offshore platforms. We applaud the industry, but it needs to keep improving the technology. Nothing is infallible."
The industry learned that lesson the hard way in 1965, when Hurricane Betsy washed away and destroyed 20 platforms in what then was a much smaller universe of Gulf of Mexico production; still, the storm produced no major spills.
At the time, most of the major oil companies had designed platforms with decks nearly 43 feet above the water level, or high enough so the decks would be missed by waves measuring 57 feet from trough to crest. A few companies built their decks lower, at about 35 feet above sea level.
By the late 1960's, most major companies had raised decks on new platforms in water depths of 300 feet or more to at least 50 feet above the water level. The Minerals Management Service, the Federal agency that governs offshore drilling, in 1972 adopted that level as the official standard.
In addition to putting more space between decks and gulf waters, engineers fortified the platforms with more and stronger steel legs known as piles -- as many as a dozen, instead of four. The steel footings for offshore platforms are thicker and longer, commonly driven 300 to 400 feet into the gulf's mud floor.
 
Little Amoco Damage
 Many platforms built before Hurricane Betsy also survived Hurricane Andrew unscathed because they had had been fortified with newer defenses over the years. The Amoco Corporation found damage to just one of its 80 platforms in the gulf, where waves surged above a deck about 50 feet above the water level. The few minor cracks in the steel template, or jacket, anchored to the ocean floor have already been repaired, said Dale Gilliam, an Amoco vice president in Houston.
Hurricane Andrew washed away three platforms belonging to the gulf's biggest oil-and-gas producer, the Chevron Corporation. Two others were crushed so badly that they were condemned. "The ones that were lost were installed before 1965, with the oldest in 1958," said Paul Versowsky, leader of Chevron's platform design group, in New Orleans.
Chevron switched to tougher platform construction standards the year after Hurricane Betsy. Most of its new decks are 60 feet or more above the sea level, and, as far as Chevron can tell, none of Hurricane Andrew's waves surged that high.
Mr. Versowsky said that virtually all offshore platforms in the North Sea, between Britain and Norway, where waves can reach 120 feet, were designed from technology developed in the Gulf of Mexico.
The flow of oil and gas from new wells is shut off manually when hurricane-force storms enter the gulf, which was the procedure followed before the August storm. Backup computer systems are designed to halt the flow automatically if necessary.
The industry now is working on platform designs that could have companies drilling at water depths of 6,000 feet or more in the next decade, as exploration moves farther offshore in the gulf. In a part of the gulf untouched by the hurricane, Conoco Inc. holds the current record, operating in 1,785 feet of water with a platform tethered to the gulf floor with flexible steel cables. Shell Oil, using similar technology, is installing a platform that will operate in 2,850 feet of water.
"If you stop and think of the major disasters we've had in oil spills, few have anything to do with offshore production," said Wayne Dunlap, associate director of the Offshore Technology Research Center, at Texas A & M University, in College Station, Tex., a center that receives financing from the industry and the Government.
"If I were transporting oil," he said, "I would want to do it through a pipeline, not a ship. I never thought there was an argument that the industry couldn't operate safely in other offshore areas. If you can put them in the North Sea, you can put them anyplace."

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about offshore oil and gas rigs that withstood Hurricane Andrew misidentified the owner of drilling equipment that caused a spill of 300 barrels of oil and described the equipment incorrectly. It was a rig, not a platform, and the owner was Wilrig of Lafayette, La., not Texaco Inc.

Diagram: "Standing Up to Heavy Weather"
 Design changes since the 1960's have made the typical offshore oil or gas rig more robust and more likely to survive a killer storm like Hurricane Andrew without sustaining serious damage. Diagram shows that the rig platforms built in the 1950's and 1960's were 42.5 feet above mean low water, and that their legs were 33 inches in diameter. In contrast, the rig platforms built in the 1970's and 1980's were constructed to be higher (50.5 feet above mean low water). They also were built with improved framing and joint design, better steel alloys, larger structural members (46-inch diamenter legs), and larger, deeper footings. Once in 100 years designers expect a storm that produces a 69-foot wave cresting 46 feet above mean low water. (Source: Chevron) (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: In Long Run, Family Leave Will Be a Bargain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Democrats are proposing a Band-Aid approach on family leave, while the Republicans oppose even a Band-Aid.
Psychiatric findings published about 45 years ago informed us that bonding of an infant with an affectionate mother is generally essential to establish healthy psychological growth in later years of childhood. Two years of bonding are ideal, but at least one year is tolerable. 
 Leading industrial nations in Europe subsidize paid (not unpaid) maternal leave, and they also provide heavily subsidized day care for infants and older children with carefully selected and trained personnel, who give children affection and the rudiments of social relationships.
The legislation prepared by the Democrats and vetoed by President Bush calls for short-term, unpaid maternal leave. Many working mothers could not afford to lose their wages during even this short term, and the time is far too short for bonding. President Bush will not approve any universal mandate for even unpaid leave and proposes only measures that evade reality.
The Democrats' proposal of a $1,000 tax break for day care expenses is another Band-Aid. It is impossible to buy a year's day care for a toddler with quality personnel for $1,000 in rural areas. The cost runs far higher for an infant, and in urban areas, the costs are still higher.
The divorce rate of more than 50 percent in our country and the malaise and psychological disorders we have among our schoolchildren do far more harm to our economy than what it would cost to prevent them with paid maternal leave and quality day care.
 
FREDERICK S. LIGHTFOOT
Greenport, L.I., Oct. 1, 1992

HEADLINE: Mob and Politics Intersect, Fueling Cynicism in Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 20

 BODY:
In 1987 Noboru Takeshita and his faction in the ruling party wielded immense influence in Japan -- more, some said, than the Government. But he was powerless to remove the last obstacle to his becoming Prime Minister: the loud, mocking attacks from a rightist group's sound trucks.
 Winning the endorsement of party elders hinged on his silencing the trucks, a fixture of political life here. 
Then, after all else failed, Shin Kanemaru, a powerful ally, took a remarkable step: He reportedly sought the help of a major organized-crime boss, Susumu Ishii. After Mr. Ishii met with Torao Inamoto, the leader of the rightist group running the trucks, the blare stopped, and Mr. Takeshita became Prime Minister.
 This episode was not the end of the relationship: Mr. Kanemaru admitted recently that he later accepted an illegal $4 million contribution from a trucking company with close ties to Mr. Ishii.
 The kingmaker escaped with a token fine, but he was forced to resign his position in the governing Liberal Democratic Party and last week he gave up his seat in Parliament, setting off one of the most revealing and damaging scandals in post-war Japanese history.
 
Present at the Creation
 "The most serious factor in the current situation, the factor that I take most seriously, is that the boryokudan was involved at the birth of the Takeshita Cabinet," said Ryutaro Hashimoto, a onetime Takeshita ally and former Finance Minister, using an expression for organized crime families.
 He added that, though he did not know if the reports were true, the appearance of these contacts could seriously harm Japanese politicians internationally as well as at home.
 "A lucky thing for us right now is that people in your country are focused on the election and have no time for Japan," Mr. Hashimoto said in an interview. "If it was a quiet time in the United States, there would be lots of criticism of Japan by your politicians."
 With the latest disclosures, a tale that once appeared to be about the mob's spreading influence has been transformed into what even the leaders of the governing party admit is a deeply unsettling glimpse into the nature of Japanese democracy.
 
Cruising
 The scandals that have hit the business and political worlds in recent years have added to the cynicism most Japanese show toward the power elite, but none have triggered as much outrage about how the system works.
 Rightist sound trucks cruise daily down the boulevards of Tokyo, extolling the Emperor, demanding a larger role for the military and playing patriotic songs. And rightist groups are often affiliated with organized crime families, known as yakuza, and sometimes the trucks are used to extort cash.
 The Japanese, however, seem to have been unprepared to find the trucks, the rightist leaders and a yakuza chieftain so close to the pinnacle of power, and many Japanese are ardently demanding greater disclosure of just how deep the relation is.
 According to the police, there are about 90,000 members of organized crime in Japan, belonging to more than 3,000 groups dominated by three large syndicates. Organized crime takes in billions of dollars a year -- mainly from gambling, drugs, prostitution, labor rackets and extortion, but also increasingly from legitimate business.
 
Soul-Searching
 Although no details have come to light on how Mr. Kanemaru may have used Mr. Ishii to silence the attacks on Mr. Takeshita, prosecutors, in the face of intense criticism, plan to pursue the trail of money to its roots, raising the possibility that more public officials will be implicated.
 "Because of these events we are going to have to think hard about the meaning of freedom and democracy in Japan," said Shokei Arai, a young member of the Liberal Democratic Party who has formed a splinter group to demand reform. "We have to think about the freedom we're losing."
 Neither Mr. Kanemaru nor Mr. Takeshita have commented on the highly detailed reports of their involvement with the yakuza. Mr. Kanemaru's guilty plea, which he made under tremendous pressure, permitted him to avoid questioning by prosecutors.
 Mr. Takeshita has said he will comment by the end of the month, and some opposition politicians have threatened to call him and Mr. Kanemaru to testify before Parliament. Mr. Ishii died in September 1991; Mr. Inamoto, who led the right-wing group, known as the Nippon Kominto, died in April 1991.
 Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest daily newspaper, said in an editorial on Sunday, "We think Kanemaru's connection with a late leader of a major crime syndicate -- before the formation of the Takeshita cabinet -- indicates corruption in the very heart of Japan's power structure."
 
$2 Billion Carries Weight
 Several facts suggest the relationship to Mr. Ishii was not casual. The intermediary Mr. Kanemaru used to contact him was Hiroyasu Watanabe, the former president of Tokyo Sagawa Kyubin, the trucking company that gave Mr. Kanemaru the illegal $4 million contribution. Mr. Watanabe reportedly provided Mr. Ishii and companies he controlled about $2 billion in loans and loan guarantees, a vast sum if Mr. Ishii did but a single favor.
 Mr. Watanabe is currently under indictment on charges that his loans to Mr. Ishii's companies, nearly all of which are now uncollectable, were made improperly.
 But Tokyo Sagawa Kyubin was not alone. A number of big financial institutions dealt openly with Mr. Ishii and his companies, in spite of his notoriety.
 Mr. Ishii was at the center of a different scandal last year when it was disclosed that he had received more than $200 million in loans from two of Japan's largest brokerage houses, Nomura Securities and Nikko Securities, which had helped carry out his vast stock investments. He had also begun to look to the United States for investments, hiring as a consultant Prescott S. Bush Jr., the brother of the President.
 One company he controlled is now suing Mr. Bush for reportedly not making good on a guarantee for an investment that became worthless. There are no indications that Mr. Bush knew he was dealing with organized crime.
 
Mobsters as Fixers
 Despite the growing expressions of outrage over the scandal, some political insiders dismiss the anger as misguided, or simply naive. Some maintain that the public is well aware of the role of yakuza members as fixers of particularly difficult problems, mediators in disputes and back channels to the far-right groups.
 "From Mr. Kanemaru's point of view, this was the only way to stop the trucks," insisted Shigezo Hayasaka, a political commentator who was a senior aide to a former Prime Minister, Kakuei Tanaka. "He is a pragmatic man and he did what he had to do.
 "The Japanese mass media is the essence of childishness," he added. "They don't understand that the real world is a mixture of good things and bad things. They don't exercise the logic of a mature adult when they criticize Mr. Kanemaru for his behavior."
 Even if Mr. Ishii did not enjoy a long-term relationship with top politicians, the ease with which he gained access to the top levels of the political and financial worlds provides a chilling subtext to the web of scandal.
 
Taking Care of Business
 His efforts reportedly began when he was released from prison eight years ago, after serving time for gambling and fraud convictions during his career in Japan's second-largest crime family. He surveyed the booming economy and moved to a new playing field: speculation in real estate, stocks and art.
 On Jan. 30, 1985, Mr. Ishii was reportedly introduced to Mr. Watanabe of Tokyo Sagawa Kyubin, whom he asked for financial help to enter the real estate business. Mr. Watanabe was involved in a struggle with the chairman and founder of his corporate group, who had the support of a major gang in Kyoto, so he was happy to build a new alliance.
 In the spring of 1985 Mr. Ishii formed the "business activities bureau" of Inagawa-Kai, the yakuza family to which he belonged, and he soon opened the Hakusho Sangyo Company, a real estate concern that became his first corporate vehicle.
 In just a few years he amassed investments worth more than $1 billion. He had a mansion full of Chagalls and Picassos, owned a country club and bought a helicopter. His accounts at Nomura and Nikko were handled by senior executives.
 
They're All Connected
 The yakuza's connections with the police and politicians go back decades. Tokutaro Takayama, the head of the Aizu Kotetsu, a big Kyoto gang, proudly describes how the police had asked him to help quell left-wing protests in the chaos after World War II.
 In fact rightists with a reputation for strong underworld links were instrumental in the founding of the Liberal Democratic Party.
 Yoshio Kodama, who was imprisoned several times for his violent militarist activities in the 1930's, earned a fortune during World War II in Manchuria procuring materiel for the Imperial Navy's Air Force. After serving a sentence as a war criminal, he used some of that money to help establish the governing party in the 1950's, and for years exerted influence among its leaders.
 Today those connections raise political concerns that the yakuza gangs' generally intolerant and aggressive approach may be influencing senior Japanese politicians.
 
Some Lines Are Open
 Some, however, do not hide their affiliations.
 Koichi Hamada, a senior party member and former chairman of Parliament's powerful Budget Committee, has admitted he was a yakuza member until he became a protege of Mr. Kodama.
 Mr. Kodama was ultimately prosecuted in the 1970's with Mr. Tanaka, the former Prime Minister, for accepting bribes from the Lockheed Corporation. Mr. Tanaka was forced to resign in disgrace.
 And Mr. Takeshita eventually got his big political break when he grabbed the leadership of Mr. Tanaka's powerful faction after Mr. Tanaka suffered a stroke in early 1985.
 That, in fact, was how Mr. Takeshita became the target of the rightists' sound trucks in 1987: The rightists seemed to feel Mr. Takeshita had usurped Mr. Tanaka's position.
 At a meeting with Mr. Ishii on Oct. 2, 1987, Mr. Inamoto, the head of the Nippon Kominto, which apparently instigated the sound-truck attacks, reportedly said they would stop only if Mr. Takeshita visited Mr. Tanaka at his home and apologized. That visit reportedly took place on Oct. 6.
 Mr. Takeshita ruled as Prime Minister for almost two years, until he was forced to resign after being implicated in a separate bribery and influence-peddling scandal, and Mr. Kanemaru inherited his faction's leadership.

HEADLINE: Mighty Menopause

BYLINE: By Helen E. Fisher; Helen E. Fisher, an anthropologist at the American Museum of Natural History, is author of "Anatomy of Love: The Natural History of Monogamy, Adultery and Divorce." 

 BODY:
"Be useful as well as ornamental" was one of my father's favorite sayings when I was growing up. And it looks as if I wasn't the only girl who heard it.
As we all know by now, it's "the year of the woman." More women than ever are running for political office. Experts commonly attribute the rise in women's political participation to the confluence of several events and trends: the Anita Hill-Clarence Thomas imbroglio, the chipping away of abortion rights, the growing presence of women in the work force. 
 But while these cultural phenomena are indeed sending women into politics, American demographics and natural biological forces are motivating them, too.
The demographic factor is well known: the age wave. Seventy-six million Americans were born between 1946 and 1964. Hail the baby boom, a mass production following World War II. These men and women have been moving through society like a pig through a python, changing social life since they were born. Their interests have been the country's issues.
Now, as boomer women enter midlife, menopause has become one of their concerns. Two generational spokeswomen, Gail Sheehy and Germaine Greer, have recently written books on the subject. Though the books broke new ground, another point needs to be made. In concert with the age wave, this change in female biology will certainly contribute to women's rise to political power.
As menopause proceeds, levels of the female hormone estrogen steadily decline -- unmasking natural levels of testosterone. Testosterone is one of nature's potent cocktails. The predominantly male hormone is linked with assertiveness in animals and people. Scientists have established that men (and male monkeys) of high rank often have elevated testosterone levels.
In many societies, middle-aged women (with relatively high levels of testosterone) gain influence in political, religious, economic and social life. As Margaret Mead once said, "There is no greater power in the world than the zest of a post-menopausal woman." So it is likely that boomer women will attain authoritative political positions as well.
Certainly, there are cultural reasons for women's midlife rise in status. Released from the constant chores of rearing children, menopausal women are freer to pursue activities outside the home. But biology, in this case, is working in their favor. How ironic, too, given the fact that science has historically been used to bar women from power. Menstrual cycles made us unreliable in combat, biology left us unfit to lead.
Will a rise in women's activism affect our home lives, too? While some things will be different, gender relations are unlikely to change as much as one might expect. Power in one segment of society does not necessarily translate into power across the board. For example, women who work outside the home still find themselves doing most of the housework. This is true around the world: even in cultures where women are politically and economically powerful, they still do most domestic chores.
Moreover, even if American women become much more powerful in politics, it's unlikely the sexes will be at each other's throats. Again, biology may play a role. As middle-aged women exhibit more assertiveness, middle-aged men display less of it. Men's testosterone levels peak when they're in their 20's; then the amount of the hormone steadily declines. This helps explain why men become more nurturing as they age.
Could the war between the sexes ebb as the genders mature? Given the cultural and biological forces that work together to build and break relationships, it's unlikely that a general rise in women's political power will dramatically alter women as wives and lovers.
Nevertheless, "the year of the woman" is here to stay. In fact, it may well be the decade of the woman. Society has positioned women to rise in political power. And the biological changes wrought by menopause will bolster their interest in power and increase their ability to use it. As usual, culture and nature go hand in hand.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
President, After 10 Cool Months, Is Catching Fire as a Campaigner

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 21

 BODY:
As President Bush likes to say, this is a weird election year, and now comes the latest surprise: after 10 torpid months, Mr. Bush has suddenly reawakened as a fist-shaking, stem-winding Presidential candidate.
On a two-day train trip through the South this week, the President seems finally to have found a message he believes strikes a chord. Gov. Bill Clinton cannot be trusted with the White House, he says -- "a pattern of deception" is the refrain at each whistle stop -- and President Bill Clinton would raise taxes on working men and women. 
Today in Kannapolis, N.C., Mr. Bush struck the themes that aides say will dominate the remaining days of his campaign. He talked of "a vast difference in philosophy, in approach to this great country of ours," and compared his record to that of Mr. Clinton as Governor of Arkansas.
"I've got to put it in perspective," Mr. Bush said. "Arkansas rates 50th in the quality of environmental initiatives, 50th in the percentage of adults with college degrees, 50th in percentage -- per capita spending on criminal justice, 49th in per capita spending on police protection."
"And Governor Clinton said the other night, 'I want to do for the country what I've done for Arkansas.' We cannot let him do that," Mr. Bush added to the crowd's roar.
In a turn of phrase that has resonated in this region, a hotbed of Atlanta Braves baseball fans, Mr. Bush compared Mr. Clinton's aspirations for the White House to "sending some Little League guy to coach the Braves."
 
New Sense of Passion
 Mr. Bush has said this before, probably thousands of times, but maybe never with the passion and directness that enliven his oratory on this trip.
On swing after swing this year, he has seemed to be almost oblivious to his growing political peril. Barely a month ago, he gave a rambling version of his message to conservatives in Orange County, Calif., in such wan fashion that his sparse crowd drifted toward the exits even before he finished.
By comparison, Mr. Bush is campaigning this week, tortured syntax and all, with the abandon of a Republican Hubert H. Humphrey, slapping at the pollsters and press who have written him off with almost the same fervor in which he attacks Mr. Clinton.
 
'These Nutty Pollsters'
 "Let me give you a little advice," he told some 15,000 supporters at an outdoor rally Tuesday night in Spartanburg, S.C. "Don't listen to these pundits telling you how to think. And don't listen to these nutty pollsters. Remember: things are decided in the last couple of weeks in this campaign. And now people are going to decide: Who do I trust to be President of the United States?"
At times, there are shades of candidate Bush in happier days, so visibly wrapped up in his oratory that he gets carried away by it, tossing away his memorized text.
He calls the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, Al Gore, "the ozone man," a jab at his devotion to environmental causes, and warns that a Clinton Presidency would mean "no timber workers, only a bunch of owls," and "no farmers, only a great, big, wet hole out there somewhere if you listen to him."
And he constantly rails against the opposition, telling listeners that "we are not a nation in decline" and that they should "not listen to the pessimists -- these liberal Democrats posing as a friend of America."
Today the Bush campaign began broadcasting three new commercials, two using person-in-the-street interviews to attack Mr. Clinton on the draft, his honesty and his credentials as a commander in chief. It seeks to hammer home themes that Mr. Bush emphasized Monday night in the final debate. A third advertisement takes the high road, showing soft images of the President in the Oval Office and with his wife, Barbara, and their grandchildren. It seeks to portray Mr. Bush as a man who was an international leader and now could help "do the same at home."
Vice President Dan Quayle carried the attack on Mr. Clinton's trustworthiness to two swing states badly needed for a Republican victory. Taking his bus tour through the small towns of central and southeastern Michigan and into northwestern Ohio, Mr. Quayle turned again to the expression he coined for the Vice-Presidential debate: "Don't pull a Clinton. Vote Bush-Quayle." The Democrats, he told students at Spring Arbor College in Jackson, Mich., are "a recipe for disaster."
By midafternoon, with Mr. Quayle's voice failing, his stump speech had taken on a pleading tone even in front of heavily partisan Republican audiences. He told a crowd at Monroe Community College in Monroe, Mich.: "Help re-elect George Bush. Help us out. Vote for us. Your future depends on it. Your future will be better with George Bush. It will be worse with Bill Clinton. Help us out and let's have four more years."
 
Change in Bush's Style
 The extent of the new assurance in Mr. Bush's campaign style is subjective, but the crowds, his largest to date, clearly react to it.
"He looks confident," George Stacey, a North Carolina insurance-company worker, volunteered after a stop today in Kannapolis, a textile-industry center near Charlotte. "That's a change."
"He's strong as he's ever been," Berry Hill, manager of a carving-company plant, said in the North Carolina furniture capital of Thomasville. "I don't know what more anybody could ask for."
It would be wrong to make too much of Mr. Bush's transformation, which comes very late, could prove temporary and has an unmeasurable impact on voters anyway.
Party faithful always rally to the standard-bearer in the final days of a race. Michael S. Dukakis spoke well and drew huge crowds in the last month of the 1988 Presidential contest; then Mr. Bush soundly defeated him. Bill Clinton remains a much better attraction on the campaign trail most days this time than the President.
Still, Bush aides who have noticed the transformation are overjoyed by it, calling it a sign that their man has finally begun the political stretch run that they have long predicted.
The prospect that Mr. Clinton, his opposite on deeply felt issues of military service and economic policy, may actually take away his job has the President both alarmed and angry, some aides say.
"He finally looked into the abyss and said 'Whew!' ", one aide said on Tuesday.
Other aides say Mr. Bush is pumped up by his success in challenging Mr. Clinton at Monday's Presidential debate in Michigan. Many advisers claim to believe that their stalled campaign turned a corner at the last debate.
 
White House View
 "The focus of the election has finally shifted off of where it was -- 24 hours a day on the economy," said the White House political director, Ron Kaufman. "Now a third to a half of the debate is on the fundamental choice in the election" between Mr. Bush's low-tax proposals and Mr. Clinton's Federal spending plans, Mr. Kaufman said. Rightly or wrongly, Mr. Bush and his aides feel that they can win that choice hands-down, and it is that issue that the President is flogging in his latest stump speech.
Then there is the undefinable romance of politicking by train, a mode that Mr. Bush, no fan of the campaign trail, is said to relish.
On these 40-mile-per-hour cruises through the backwoods, between leisurely pauses at postcard-quality small towns, the President passes time on the back landing of the last car.
Microphone and loudspeaker in hand, he whistles to mongrel dogs, calls out to schoolchildren trooped out to railside and waves to the thousands of people, with no evident political motive, who materialize out of nowhere just for the thrill of seeing a President pass by their farm or house.
 
'Good for the Soul'
 At the stops on these trips, Mr. Bush sometimes waxes emotional about the majesty of the Presidency and how he wants to be re-elected for the sake of the children. The crowd responds, and he replies, as he did in Thomasville today: "I hate to leave you. This is good for the soul."
These are the reasons his aides give for Mr. Bush's reinvigorated campaign style.
