HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton's Camp Says It Is Wary Of Perot Inroads

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PUEBLO, Colo., Oct. 21

 BODY:
Two weeks ago, Ross Perot was a footnote to the 1992 race. Now, Clinton campaign strategists say their private polls have raised concerns that he is cutting into the Democratic lead in states like this one.
"Certainly there's movement" in Mr. Perot's direction, said one senior campaign official, speaking on condition of anonymity. "I think it's because people don't know the facts about him." 
 The scope of any inroads Mr. Perot has made in specific states will not be known until the end of this week, when more polling will be finished. Another campaign official, also speaking on condition that he not be named, said the problem with Mr. Perot should be seen as real but limited to certain states, mostly the conservative Western states where Mr. Perot has always had his greatest strength, and where Mr. Clinton is campaigning today and Thursday.
 
Complacency Is Banished
 "Certainly, this has ended any sense of complacency," he said. "But it is not something that is viewed with alarm. It is something that is being studied, watched, thought about. We don't know enough about it yet."
It is perhaps a measure of the concern the Clinton campaign feels about Mr. Perot that campaign officials were privately telling reporters today that it was time that Mr. Perot faced a new round of examination by the press.
"As far as the debates were concerned, he got an uncritical look because he's entertaining and because of his seeming straightness," said one Clinton official.
It is in the best interests of the Clinton campaign to raise the specter of Mr. Perot as Election Day approaches to help ward off overconfidence. Many Democrats say they no longer perceive President Bush as a real threat to Mr. Clinton. That means the resurrection of Mr. Perot as a menace serves a tactical purpose.
 
Focus on the Independents
 But is is also true that, if Mr. Clinton is going to win by the margin his strategists hope for, he must also continue to fight for the independent voters who have made this election year so unpredictable, and there is some evidence that Mr. Perot is costing Mr. Clinton some of those voters.
Some national polls have shown Mr. Perot making slight gains in the last week. The polls show Mr. Clinton still the strong favorite, with 45 percent or more of those polled choosing him over Mr. Bush, whose support seems to have remained stuck at roughly 30 percent.
Despite the lack of movement by Mr. Bush, the Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee today began broadcasting new advertisements critical of the President on network television. The committee's commercials, one of a young man, the other of a young woman, have the principals describing how the economy has left them hard-pressed to find decent jobs.
 
Focusing on the Young
 The 30-second ads, designed for programs that are popular with people younger than 30, are intended to draw young people into the party and to vote for Mr. Clinton.
The Clinton campaign also released a 15-second ad that features Mr. Bush uttering his "read my lips" pledge on taxes at the Republican National Convention four years ago.
While the fact that Mr. Bush is not moving and that Mr. Perot is still below 20 percent in the polls is on its face good news for Mr. Clinton, it also reveals the nature of the potential problem with Mr. Perot.
In the past, the Texas billionaire has drawn support more or less equally from Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton. But at a certain point, the poll figures show, Mr. Perot takes all he can from among voters leaning to Mr. Bush and begins to draw almost exclusively from among the ranks of those who would otherwise support Mr. Clinton.
The explanation of this phenomenon is simple enough, the Clinton campaign strategists figure. Many of those voters who are still undecided are people who strongly believe there needs to be a change in direction, particularly in the Government's handling of the economy and trade. Those people long ago rejected the idea of voting for Mr. Bush, so any votes they cast for Mr. Perot are at Mr. Clinton's expense.
 
Prospecting in the West
 Nowhere is the dynamic at work more clear than in the Western states of Colorado, Montana, Wyoming, Montana, and Nevada, which Mr. Clinton is currently touring.
In Colorado, for instance, Mr. Perot stands at 18 or 19 percent in the polls, up from single-digit figures during the time he was out of the race. At about the same pace that Mr. Perot's support has grown, Mr. Clinton's has diminished, going from a high of a 14-point lead over Mr. Bush, to a lead of only 6 or 7 points, Gov. Roy Romer, a Democrat, said.
"Perot was very strong in Colorado when he was first in," Mr. Romer said. "When he dropped out, he plummeted, and when he got back in, he began to go up again. At a certain level, he began to start pulling votes completely from Clinton. These are people who want a change from Bush, and for whom the only question is what are the options for change. Every one of those votes comes off of Clinton."
Mr. Romer does not think there is any chance Mr. Perot could go much beyond his current level of support to come anywhere close to actually winning in Colorado, but he said he did think that in a state like his, usually Republican-voting but this year in play, too much support for Mr. Perot could mean the difference between a slim victory and defeat for Mr. Clinton.
"This race is going to be close here," he said. "And it's going to be close because of Perot, not Bush. Bush is not gaining. Perot is gaining, and his gain is Clinton's shrinkage."
 
The Task for Clinton
 To attract and keep these voters in normally solid Republican states like Colorado and Wyoming, one campaign official said, Mr. Clinton must drive home the message that he, like Mr. Perot, "has an economic plan, that he is a different kind of Democrat, and that he is the only one of the three candidates who has actually done the things that the others are promising to do, such as balance a budget."
Mr. Clinton addressed exactly those points in his speeches here, and later at the airport in Cheyenne, Wyo.
"Here in the West, where people are hard-headed and practical and open, we know the difference between talking and doing," he said in Cheyenne. "Of all the people running for President this year, only one has ever passed a balanced budget, and only one has ever taken on the lobbyists."
Mr. Clinton then went on to promise the audience, as he had in Colorado, that he was the sort of Democrat they could vote for, pressing his position on capital punishment, welfare reform and stronger penalities for first-time juvenile offenders.
"I know a lot of people out here in the West consider themselves Republicans the way a lot of people in my part of the country consider themselves yellow-dog Democrats," he said. "What I want you to do is tell all the people around you that may have never voted for a Democrat before, that there's a new Democratic Party and a new Democratic candidate."

HEADLINE: U.S. HOPE DASHED ON GLOBAL TRADE

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's lingering hopes for a pre-election breakthrough in world trade talks collapsed today as negotiations in Brussels broke down, leaving American and European officials much farther apart than before on trimming farm subsidies.
The failure of the meetings will certainly prolong and could conceivably doom six-year-old negotiations to lower trade barriers around the world. European officials have expressed growing reluctance to make a deal with a President who may soon be forced from office. 
 The American law that bars Congress from amending trade agreements struck by Presidents applies only to deals reached before next March 2, and Democratic and Republican trade experts alike say it is unlikely that Gov. Bill Clinton would be able to come to terms with the Europeans so quickly if he is elected.
Many economists say that a global trade agreement will expand world economic output by $100 billion a year or more because it would encourage each country to produce whatever it makes most efficiently and import the rest. Without the agreement, they say, the world economy will grow more slowly.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, has said that it would be "virtually impossible" for the Bush Administration to win the re-authorization of the 18-year-old fast-track legislation, under which the recently initialed North American Free Trade Agreement will also be considered. It is not clear whether a Clinton Administration working with a Democratic Congress would be more successful.
The collapse of the meetings in Brussels today will at least postpone the date when an agreement can go into force. Some experts also say that the lack of an agreement may foster trade wars, restricting international commerce and world economic growth.
But labor-intensive industries in industrialized nations, including American textile and steel producers, dispute the benefits of an agreement. They worry that a deal would drown them in a flood of imports from more efficient and sometimes subsidized foreign producers. Labor unions and a few economists contend that the United States will receive few gains from a global trade pact.
Despite speeches by French officials this week against any European concessions, some Administration officials were still optimistic this morning that a deal might be possible. "If agriculture breaks this week, we could finish the round by Christmas," an American official said.
But by this afternoon, senior Administration officials were gloomy about the prospects for any pact in the near future and quickly blamed the European Community.
 
No 'Breakthrough'
 "Whereas last week in the meetings," a senior official said, "it appeared that both sides had come closer to proposals that would have allowed a political breakthrough on agriculture, which would have allowed us to wrap up the other issues, it now appears that the community has substantial difficulties even with some of the proposals they were willing to explore last week. It doesn't appear we have the basis for breakthrough in the near future."
A European Community official said the community was prepared to continue talking. But a senior Administration trade official said no further meetings were planned.
This week's negotiations in Brussels turned out to be vital not because of who was attending but because of the positions the sides took.
The Agriculture Department staff and European Community farm experts now in Brussels are far less senior than the agriculture and trade ministers who met 10 days ago in Brussels or the ever-optimistic trade ministers who met last weekend in Toronto. But this meeting dealt in great detail with the highly technical disputes that are actually blocking a global trade pact.
The outcome was a complete impasse. C. Joseph O'Mara, the United States Agriculture Department's chief trade negotiator, flew home today while leaving several aides behind to work on minor issues.
 
Details of Disputes
 A person involved in the negotiations gave a detailed list today of the disagreements on condition of anonymity. The disputes center on how deeply the community should cut its crop subsidies and how extensively the United States will be able to challenge the farmer income support programs that the community is beginning to introduce.
The United States has been seeking a 24 percent reduction in the community's tonnage of subsidized exports, while the community has been calling for no more than an 18 percent reduction. Last week, European officials expressed a willingness to split the difference between the two figures.
But they said today that any increase from 18 percent would have to be coupled with new European taxes on imports of American corn gluten and the cancellation of the so-called Andriessen Understanding, under which the European Community has pledged not to subsidize meat exports to Japan and other East Asian markets now dominated by Australia and the United States.
Higher taxes on American corn gluten would limit United States exports and protect European farmers from competition. Repeal of the Andriessen Understanding -- which is named for Frans Andriessen, the European Community's External Relations Commissioner and chief trade negotiator -- would allow the Community to unload some of its huge meat surplus in east Asia at the expense of American ranchers.
Another shift in the European Community's position this week involved its introduction of direct payments to farmers, replacing crop subsidies, which encourage inefficient overproduction that has flooded world markets. The European Community now wants the United States to guarantee that most of these payments will not be challenged as illegal subsidies.
The European Community also refused to accept any change in its subsidies for the production of oil from seeds. The United States has threatened to impose punitive tariffs on $1 billion worth of fine French wines and other European exports but has delayed any action pending the current world trade talks.
The senior Administration trade official said that no decision had been made on whether to proceed with the tariffs now, which would upset the community even more.
The latest impasse over farm trade is particularly frustrating to negotiators because of recent progress in other areas of the world trade talks to expand the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which is actually a series of pacts laying out free trade rules for global commerce. American and European trade officials agreed in Brussels 10 days ago to broaden the GATT to include banking, insurance and other financial services, but small differences remain on free-trade rules for telephone service and shipping.

HEADLINE: Attack on Bus in Egypt Kills a Briton

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Gunmen believed to be Islamic militants killed one British tourist, the first foreigner to die in the current round of attacks, and wounded two others today after firing on a bus in southern Egypt.
The attack, which occurred some 170 miles south of Cairo, is the second on foreign tourists in Egypt in less than a month. It follows a statement by the underground Islamic Group warning foreign visitors not to travel to the pharaonic monuments in Luxor. 
 One tourist, Sharon Hill, 28 years old, died of her wounds, Government officials said. David Wilson, 24, and Mike Smith, 24, have been hospitalized in Dairut, where the shooting occurred. There were nine foreign tourists -- six Britons, two Australians and a Portuguese -- in the open, safari-type vehicle when it was attacked.
"At approximately 1 o'clock in the afternoon today as a South Sinai Company Tour bus was traveling on the circular road outside Dairut on its way to Asyut," said an official from the Ministry of Interior, "two extremists emerged from the fields opposite and fired on the bus."
 
Scene of Frequent Clashes
 The official said a search had begun for the two suspects.
The attack is part of a campaign by Islamic militants to cripple the tourism industry, which is Egypt's largest foreign-exchange earner, with some $3 billion a year, Government officials said.
One tour operator described the assault as "very destructive" to the future of the industry, which had predicted revenues of $4 billion this year.
As of late tonight, neither the Egyptian Government nor the United States nor British Embassies said they had any plans to issue a travel advisory, although embassy officials said no decision could be made until they had investigated the incident. There is already a general State Department warning to Americans traveling to the Middle East, because of increased tension in the Persian Gulf.
The Islamic Group is fighting to create an Islamic state in Egypt. The group has found many converts in the slums and rural villages, where there is high unemployment.
Southern Egypt has been the scene of frequent clashes between security forces and well armed Islamic militants.
 
Attack on Cruise Ship
 More than 60 militants, security officials, Coptic Christians, a prominent anti-fundamentalist writer and innocent bystanders have been killed in shootings this year.
Several thousand security troops were deployed in the south after a series of bloody encounters this spring, including one on May 14 that left 13 Coptic Christians and 1 Muslim bystander dead. The attack was the worst religious violence in Egypt in more than a decade.
There have been signs that attacks against foreign tourists might become more frequent.
 
'Campaign to Close Mosques'
 On Oct. 1, masked gunmen, suspected of being Islamic militants, fired automatic weapons at a Nile cruise ship carrying 140 German tourists. Three of the Egyptian staff members on the ship were wounded in the attack. The attack, which lasted about three minutes, occurred as the vessel left a jetty at Deir Mawas in Minya Province, 150 miles south of Cairo.
In August a gasoline bomb was tossed at a tourist bus, and in June two home-made bombs exploded in a pharaonic temple. No one was wounded in either incident.
The Islamic Group issued a statement at the end of August to foreign embassies, which several diplomats discounted as genuine at the time, warning officials "not to send their people to Luxor and Qena."
Qena Province is one of the most popular with foreign tourists. It encompasses the Valley of the Kings and Queens and the temples in Luxor, including the sprawling monuments and buildings at Karnak.
Egyptian officials say that the Islamic Government in the Sudan is behind a recent influx of weapons shipped across the porous border between the two countries to militant bands in southern Egypt.
One senior Egyptian official contends that some 2,500 Egyptian militants are currently undergoing military training in the Sudan, something the Government in Khartoum denies.
The attacks by the militants, most carrying automatic rifles, are well organized.

HEADLINE: Bush May Gain Little by Fuel Stance

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich. Oct. 20

 BODY:
During the last two decades, 23,000 people lost their jobs in General Motors' car, truck and parts manufacturing plants in Flint, and evidence of hard times is easy to see in crumbling roads, boarded up homes and a downtown blighted by empty buildings.
The Bush-Quayle campaign hopes to find fertile ground here for a campaign message spotlighting Gov. Bill Clinton's proposal for substantially higher gasoline mileage standards and warning that thousands more pink slips would be the price paid by Flint and other Michigan cities if it becomes law. 
 "Those fuel-efficiency standards of 40 miles per gallon," Mr. Bush said during the Monday night's Presidential debate, echoing months of newspaper and radio advertisements in Michigan, "that would break the auto industry and throw a lot of people out of work."
But just as Mr. Bush still lags in the polls in the Pacific Northwest, despite promising to rewrite the Endangered Species Act and open virgin forests to logging, the President appears to have gained little ground here by pushing an issue that he portrays as a choice between jobs and the environment.
Voters interviewed here this week say they no longer see environmental goals as an automatic threat to workers. Democratic campaign officials say that is part of the reason that a poll of Michigan voters taken by The Detroit Free Press just before the Presidential debates showed Mr. Clinton leading Mr. Bush by double-digit percentages. No Democratic Presidential candidate has taken the state since 1968.
Janice Karcher, the program manager at the Genesee Economic Area Revitalization, an economic development group here, said: "It's seen as a competitiveness issue. More fuel efficiency means better cars and could mean more jobs."
For months, the Bush-Quayle campaign has cited an automobile industry study predicting that raising average fuel economy standards to 40 miles per gallon from 27.5 today would cost up to 40,000 jobs in Michigan and 300,000 jobs nationwide. Auto workers here called the estimate wildly wrong, noting that it assumed that the only response by Ford, Chrysler and General Motors would be to stop manufacturing all large cars.
Far from fearing higher mileage standards, some union officials here said they welcomed them as a means of competing with foreign auto makers, who would be held to the same standards.
"Stricter mileage standards will produce a whole new industry for new methods, new equipment, new techniques and technologies," said Dave Yettaw, the president of the United Automobile Workers Local 599 here and a supporter of Governor Clinton. "Too often we think about the immediate problems and not the long term. And that's what's got us in our predicament in the auto industry. I think Clinton is right on this. He says we can have higher mileage cars and more jobs."
When told that Mr. Bush's contention was being rejected by many voters in Flint, the birthplace of General Motors and a center of manufacturing for some of the company's largest Buick and Oldsmobile models, Republican officials expressed surprise. "Listen, those are the same people who will be standing in unemployment lines if the Clinton-Gore proposals are put into effect," said John T. Truscott, the press secretary to Gov. John Engler, a Republican who is running the President's campaign in Michigan.
The clash between Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton focuses on corporate average fuel economy standards, or Cafe standards. Enacted by Congress in 1975, they first took effect in 1978. The law sets out a formula for measuring the average fuel economy of a manufacturers' products and essentially means that for every large low-mileage car like the Lincoln Town Car, Ford must build two high-mileage Escorts.
Manufacturers' fleets are now required to average 27.5 miles per gallon, though there are waivers in the rules to allow slightly lower average fuel economies. David L. Greene, a researcher at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, said the standards had saved consumers $250 billion in fuel bills. The Energy Department says average gasoline consumption is now 7.3 million gallons a day, 100,000 gallons a day less than in 1978, even though there are 50 million more cars and trucks on the road.
Even though auto companies fought the law's passage, asserting that it would lead only to small and uncomfortable vehicles, some executives grudgingly acknowledge that it helped the industry. New materials that reduced the weight of vehicles, innovations in aerodynamic design, developing front-wheel drive, manufacturing better radial tires, changing engine designs and a host of other inventions prompted by the law have helped American cars compete with Japanese cars in quality and fuel-efficiency.
"To some degree, Cafe standards helped us get a headstart on recognizing problems with our cars that we weren't paying attention to," David L. Kulp, the manager of fuel economy and planning at Ford, said in an interview in the company's headquarters in Dearborn. "It made us start to think about fuel economy and quality issues."
Still, Mr. Kulp said , he is worried about Mr. Clinton's idea about raising average mileage standards to 40 or 45 miles a gallon, a level he said was well beyond the technical abilities of American or foreign manufacturers. An exclusive group of top executives of Ford, Chrysler and General Motors expressed similar misgivings to Mr. Clinton in a private meeting in Detroit last August, and he has apparently taken their concerns to heart.
When he first proposed raising mileage standards during an Earth Day speech last April at Drexel University in Philadelphia, Mr. Clinton proposed to "accelerate our progress toward more fuel-efficient cars and seek to raise the average goal for auto makers to 45 miles per gallon."
Since meeting with the executives, Mr. Clinton has said he would be "flexible." Mr. Clinton's aides say he was also influenced by conclusions reached by a National Research Council panel of experts who published a study in April that said it might only be technically possible to raise the average fuel economy of American cars to 37 miles per gallon by 2006.
During the debate on Monday, Mr. Clinton further clarified his position."I said we ought to have a goal of raising fuel-efficiency standards to 40 miles a gallon, " he said. "I think that should be a goal. I've never said we should write it into law if there is evidence that that goal cannot be achieved."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Stricter mileage standards will produce a whole new industry for new methods, new equipment, new techniques and technologies," said Dave Yettaw, president of United Automobile Workers Local 599 in Flint, Mich., where 23,000 workers were laid off by General Motors in the last two decades. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Debate, Dodd Presses His Foe on Failing to Vote in Many Elections

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FARMINGTON, Conn., Oct. 21

 BODY:
Senator Christopher J. Dodd sharply questioned his Republican opponent, Brook Johnson, on his failure to vote in Connecticut elections in a debate here today. Mr. Dodd, citing town records, said Mr. Johnson had voted only twice in the last 10 elections in his hometown of Greenwich.
Mr. Johnson, a textile executive who came out of political obscurity five months ago, has acknowledged that he has not voted regularly, saying that the demands of his business kept him out of town for many votes. 
 The exchange came during the second of two debates this week, and was the first opportunity for residents who have seen the two candidates again and again in television commercials to compare how fast they are on their feet and how they take barbed questions.
The debate was sponsored by the Connecticut Broadcasters Association and shown on television throughout the state.
Mr. Johnson, who has peppered the state with commercials that trumpet his business achievement and plans for cutting the Federal deficit, sidestepped Mr. Dodd's charges on his voting record, asserting the issue of who could get results in Congress was the most important question.
Mr. Johnson's voting record has been reported by the news media in Connecticut, but he had never been confronted with it by his opponent. The debate format was the first to allow the candidates to question each other directly, and Mr. Johnson struck out at Mr. Dodd as well. He challenged the Senator's campaign contributions from special-interest groups and his record in voting to raise taxes.
But it was Mr. Dodd, looking more the challenger with points to prove than a two-term incumbent with a commanding lead in the polls, who kept up the pressure and the energy in the hourlong exchange.
"Where were you during the critical times when we faced difficulties?" Mr. Dodd asked at one point, after he had introduced the document that showed Mr. Johnson's voting record in Greenwich, and another document, which he said showed that Mr. Johnson had changed his primary residence to Florida last year. "Why did you not participate in the electoral process?" Mr. Dodd pressed.
Mr. Johnson said he had always been a resident of Connecticut, although he has had a home in Florida for 10 years, but he mostly brushed aside Mr. Dodd's attacks, often changing the subject to his favorite themes of campaign-finance reform, term limits for elected officials and a balanced-budget amendment.
"I came into this race as a businessman, 20 years in the American manufacturing industry," he said, responding to the question about his voting. "Commitment means a lot, commitment is important," he said at another point. "But a bigger issue is results -- what do you get done?"
 
Favorite Themes
 Throughout the hour, each man returned to what he presented as his strengths: Mr. Johnson, seeking to portray himself as a can-do business executive who would address the Federal deficit and change the Senate by helping impose term limits for Congress, against Mr. Dodd, who said he believed he had the experience and the record of achievement that Connecticut cannot do without.
The first debate, on Tuesday, sponsored by the Connecticut Daily Newspaper Association, was far more sedate. It was muted both by the format, which precluded any give and take by the candidates, and by the questions, which tended toward the ponderous. And the candidates were also asked about issues on which they more or less agreed.
The problem of poverty? Job creation must be a priority to get the economy going again, both men said on Tuesday. The rapid growth over the last decade in the size of Congressional staffs? It must be reined in, they both agreed.
Mr. Dodd and Mr. Johnson clashed at the first meeting only on questions they raised themselves, like the propriety of taking campaign money from special-interest groups. Mr. Johnson attacked Mr. Dodd as an incumbent beholden to political action committee contributors, and Mr. Dodd fired back, calling the Republican stance "disingenuous," because only a few years ago Mr. Johnson helped steer and finance a political action committee for the textile industry. Mr. Johnson's campaign is partly financed by the Republican Senatorial Committee, which is financed by political action committee donations.
 
Economy Cited
 And Mr. Johnson today also continued to focus on the Federal deficit and its implications. When the two men were asked whether the United States should intervene militarily in Bosnia and Herzegovina to help stop the fighting there, Mr. Johnson referred to economics while Mr. Dodd answered on a foreign-policy basis.
The European Community, Mr. Dodd said, must bear the burden of stopping the fighting, although the United States could perhaps assist in a limited role.
"We can no longer become globo-cop," Mr. Dodd said.
Mr. Johnson agreed that unilateral intervention by the United States would be a mistake, but he then immediately took the question as another opportunity to argue for deficit reduction.
"We can't afford to project might when our own industrial might and economic might is falling apart in our own country," Mr. Johnson said. "There is no superpower in the history of the world that lasted while it was broke."
One point of contrast in today's debate occurred when the moderator, Bill Hennessey, asked each man what he would push for as his first piece of legislation in the next Congress. Mr. Dodd replied that he would seek an economic-stimulus package to create jobs, including a targeted investment-tax credit to help businesses. Mr. Johnson said a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution would be his first effort.
"The main thing we have to do is stop the spending," Mr. Johnson said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Senate Race;
REPUBLICAN GAINS IN WISCONSIN RACE

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 20

 BODY:
A month ago Senator Bob Kasten appeared to face an impossible battle against an upstart state lawmaker who broadcast folksy television advertisements complete with an endorsement from Elvis Presley.
But now Senator Kasten, a two-term Republican, is fighting back with a slashing television campaign that has pushed him from about 20 points behind in the public opinion polls to within striking distance of his Democratic challenger, Russell D. Feingold Jr. 
 National Democratic strategists had counted on the race to help guarantee a gain of three Senate seats and a filibuster-proof 60-40 Democratic majority next year. Instead, the race has become a photo-finish competition between a witty appeal punctuated by "Roger and Me" style commercials and old-fashioned, take-no-prisoner negative campaigning.
The 50-year-old Mr. Kasten, who has championed supply-side economics, is on the attack with a bus tour and television advertisements accusing Mr. Feingold of promoting radical plans to tax the middle class and coddle criminals.
 
Many Grains of Salt
 In a televised debate last Friday night, Mr. Kasten associated Mr. Feingold's vote in the State Senate against a no-parole bill, which was enacted, with last week's early release of Gerald M. Turner, a local convict who killed a 9-year-old girl 19 years ago. Then, over the weekend, Kasten volunteers called voters to suggest that Mr. Feingold had voted against preventing serial killers like Jeffrey L. Dahmer from receiving parole releases.
"If we allow him to be the fresh telegenic face for change without any ideology," Mr. Kasten said in an interview, "he could sneak through."
Mr. Feingold says the Senator is knowingly distorting his positions. He says that he voted for a different version of the no-parole bill, and that he supports higher taxes only on the wealthy.
In a new advertisement, Mr. Feingold picks up a garden shovel to clean up a mountain of salt, and says, "The truth is, the Senator has made up something so big that a few grains of salt won't be enough."
 
Quips and Studied Bemusement
 Clever commercials, a vast repertoire of quips and an air of studied bemusement enabled Mr. Feingold to emerge from a crowded Democratic primary in which two other major candidates buried each other in mud. Discounted as an underdog, Mr. Feingold was attacked by no one until it was too late.
"I will not use negative campaigning even if I lose," he told a group of voters in Brookfield last Thursday.
But the dynamics of a two-way race are different, and there will be increasing pressure on Mr. Feingold to supplement his shield of humor with counterattacks.
The 39-year-old challenger -- a Rhodes scholar and Harvard law school graduate -- has portrayed himself as a humble outsider, granting interviews to reporters in a campaign van that has a leaky roof and curtains that hang from a single thread.
"This campaign is about seeing if a person not tied in with the power structure can win a seat in the Senate," he said. "The United States Senate is now more like the House of Lords than a representative body."
Mr. Feingold has issued detailed position papers on how he would cut the budget deficit and provide universal health insurance. But the Feingold message that most voters see on television is more glib than thoughtful.
A poll published in The Milwaukee Journal on Sunday reported that Mr. Feingold's lead had narrowed to only three points; with the poll's five-point margin of sampling error, that is statistically a dead heat. One indication that Senator Kasten's attacks are beginning to stick is Mr. Feingold's negative rating among voters: it increased to 32 percent from 10 percent in just five weeks, while his positive rating dropped from 58 percent to 48 percent.
But other polls show the difference between the two candidates ranging from 7 to 10 points, down from 20 points in recent weeks.
 
Thrusting and Parrying
 In the debate last week, in Green Bay, Mr. Kasten accused Mr. Feingold of staking out positions "out there in left field." Mr. Feingold fired back arrows dipped in wit. When the Senator accused him of opposing product liability reform because he was "in bed with the trial lawyers," Mr. Feingold parried, "I have no personal recollection of being in bed with a trial lawyer."
When he was called soft on crime, Mr. Feingold responded: "Senator, it's 10 days to Halloween. It's a little too early to be scaring the people."
After the debate, a local television reporter took Mr. Feingold aside to interview him while they watched a series of his commercials on a television monitor.
"They are fun ads, but where's the meat?" challenged the reporter. "Do you think people will vote for you because they laugh at your commercials?"
Mr. Feingold responded, somewhat uneasily: "The humor side is to make people remember the message. You tell me how to put my 82-point plan in a 30-second spot."

A campaign coincidence did not go unnoticed by Mr. Feingold as Mr. Kasten's bus passed by while the Democratic candidate greeted voters in Madison. (Morry Gash for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Prague Journal;
Kafka and the Jews in a Web He Would Recognize

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
Like K., the central figure of "The Castle," the Franz Kafka Society in the writer's native city is striving unceasingly to attain its destination. But, as in the book, this quest is proving vain.
The society's goal is the splendid Kinsky Palace on Old Town Square, whose use the Czech government granted to the group a year ago. 
 "We keep walking around it, but we can't enter," said Vladimir Zelezny, who seized the chance offered by the "velvet revolution" of 1989 to restore Kafka to honor in his native land.
 
Pride in Diversity
 The failure to honor the Jews' contribution to Czech culture is matched by a similar lack of success by Jews in reclaiming religious properties seized by the Germans during their occupation from 1939 to 1945.
The issue of a blend of traditions is an important one for the Kafka Society, which was formed by Mr. Zelezny. He is its vice president and principal promoter; one member is Vaclav Havel, ex-President, playwright and essayist.
"We want to recall the tolerant and pluralistic tradition of Prague that Kafka represents, the symbiosis that flourished of Czech, German and Jewish culture," said Mr. Zelezny, who was spokesman for Civic Forum, which Mr. Havel led, and for Premier Petr Pithart of the Czech republic, until he lost his post in elections in June.
Kafka's works were suppressed by the Communists as "subjective and pessimistic." This official rejection was enhanced by an atmosphere in which the authorities defamed Jewish intellectuals as alien and rootless. Most Jewish writers in Prague wrote not in Czech but in German, their preferred language since the days of the Austrian Empire.
The Kinsky Palace is a large, pink-and-white rococo confection that played an important role in Kafka's life: He lived nearby, attended school in the palace and often visited his father's dry-goods store on the ground floor.
What keeps the organization from occupying the palace is the resistance of the Czechoslovak National Gallery, which administers the building. The museum says its charter prohibits use of the palace by an unofficial organization. "We can't overcome the opposition of this typical, overgrown Communist institution," Mr. Zelezny said in an interview.
 
Tortuous Negotiations
 After a Kafkaesque year of more than 30 negotiating sessions with Milan Uhde, then the Culture Minister and now president of the Czech parliament, and with directors of the National Gallery to turn the Czech government's decree into reality, Mr. Zelezny said he felt like the Kafka character who never reached the mountaintop castle.
He said he had raised more than $7 million in pledges from foreign foundations for the society's program, but cannot put the money to use.
The facade of the palace was refurbished in the final years of Communist rule, when Prague was prettied up for tourists. But the building, from whose balcony the Communist leader Klement Gottwald proclaimed the party's takeover in 1948, is largely empty and in need of extensive restoration.
The Kafka Society intends to use it as a meeting place for scholars of Central European culture, for seminars and congresses, and as a museum devoted to contemporary Czech works. To help students who find that in a market economy books are often beyond their means, the organization plans to subsidize a bookstore.
 
Trying to Regain Property
 Prague's Jews have also been frustrated in their attempt to regain property. Nearly three years after the overthrow of the Communists, the state still owns the historic synagogues and cemetery of the Jewish Quarter, a collection of more than 30,000 religious and artistic objects and a library of 100,000 volumes, most of which were stolen by Germans in World War II from synagogues and from the homes of the 92,000 Jews who were deported to concentration camps, where 77,297 died.
This trove still belongs to the State Jewish Museum, which took over the Nazis' Central Jewish Museum. Reinhard Heydrich and Adolf Eichmann, the SS leaders in command of the genocide against Europe's Jews, planned to turn the Jewish Quarter into a museum of an "extinct tribe."
At the end of the war, 8 buildings in the Jewish Quarter and 50 warehouses throughout Prague were packed with Torah scrolls, ritual objects, musical instruments, paintings, furniture and other stolen items. In the brief postwar interlude of democracy, which was ended by the Communist takeover, the 13th-century synagogue was reclaimed by survivors.
In 1949 the Communists turned the synagogues and the cemetery into the State Jewish Museum. Although services were allowed in the old synagogue, it was regarded as part of the museum and male visitors were told they did not need to cover their heads to enter. Head coverings are now required.
Prominent Jews contrast the Czech government's slow response with the prompt return of buildings and other property to the Roman Catholic orders, which the Communists had outlawed.
The Federation of Jewish Communities and other organizations have requested the return of 106 properties -- synagogues, cemeteries and the collections of the State Jewish Museum. After initial resistance, the Czech government earlier this year agreed.
But the last parliament failed to act, and the government chosen in June has not followed up. Prof. Bedrich Nosek, former head of the museum's collections, said at least two speakers in Parliament accused "the Jews" of wanting to "steal" state property and sell it to Israel.
Professor Nosek, a Jew, now teaches Hebrew and Jewish studies at Charles University and the Hussite Theological Faculty.
He said he resigned from the museum because those who direct it have no interest, sympathy or qualifications for Jewish studies and hindered academic cooperation with Israeli scholars. The current museum director is an expert on textile art and the director of Judaica collections is an anthropologist specializing in Native Americans. Neither is Jewish.
Emphasizing that the Jewish community intends to maintain the museum, Professor Nosek said the items in storage should be returned to use. "It is absolutely immoral to pile up these things in storage," he said. "It is because at the museum there is no sense of the history and spirituality of Jews."

(Nicholas Kamm for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
Bush and Clinton Customize Their TV and Radio Ads in the Swing States

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, Oct. 21

 BODY:
George Bush "gave us the second biggest tax increase in American history," the announcer in a new Clinton campaign television ad intones. "Family income in Ohio, down $2,100. George Bush -- broken promises, forgotten Ohio."
Next door, the Bush campaign is delivering a special message to Michigan. "This year the issue is jobs," the announcer in the Bush campaign radio commercial says. "Let's see what Clinton's plan would do to jobs in Michigan. His radical environmental proposals require increasing car mileage standards to 40 miles per gallon in eight years. This would be a disaster for Michigan jobs." 
 This is the campaign you will not be hearing in New York. On the theory that one state's turn-the-channel issue is another state's hot button, President Bush and Governor Bill Clinton have begun sending out specially tailored appeals to voters in swing states like Ohio, Michigan, Illinois and Georgia.
Ahead in the polls, the Clinton campaign has the luxury of targeting some of its television ads. The Bush campaign, in contrast, has been doing its targeting in the less expensive -- and most experts would say less effective -- medium of radio. (Ross Perot, it should be noted, is still putting out the same message to everyone.)
Traditionally, radio has been a haven for inflammatory and even misleading ads, and this year would appear to be no different. The Bush campaign's targeted radio ads are among the most incendiary -- and the Clinton campaign would say deceptive -- commercials of the Presidential campaign season. A different one is airing in each of about a dozen states, all with a similar theme: the region will suffer dire consequences if Mr. Clinton is elected.
"The Motor Vehicle Manufacturing Association says Clinton's new-car mileage law would cost over 4,000 Kentucky auto workers their jobs," a Bush ad on the radio in Kentucky says.
"Bill Clinton, he says he's for change, but take a good look at the change he's really talking about," a Bush ad airing in Illinois says. "An independent analysis says that Clinton-Gore radical environmental taxes will drive up our annual utility bills $343. That would threaten 200,000 jobs in Illinois. It could cost you your job."
Aides to Governor Clinton say the radio ads have no basis in fact, that they extrapolate from proposals, like a carbon tax, that Mr. Clinton has not embraced, and that they rely on figures from biased sources like manufacturing groups. "This stuff is so half-cocked, they've chosen to put it on the radio, because on television they wouldn't get away with it," said Mark Longabaugh, the Clinton campaign's Ohio director.
 
Clinton Campaign Counters
 Nevertheless, following its unofficial credo of "don't get mad, get even," the Clinton campaign has responded to each of the Bush radio ads with an aggressive counterattack.
"When this campaign began, George Bush said he would do anything to win," a new Clinton radio spot airing in Michigan says. "Now he's proving it. Why is Bush attacking Clinton? Because he can't defend his own record. Let's look at what George Bush has done to the auto industry. According to the Department of Labor, the American auto industry has lost 89,000 jobs under George Bush, nearly 30,000 auto jobs right here in Michigan alone."
Aides to the President deny that the targeted ads are appearing on radio rather than television because the campaign did not want them to attract too much media attention. But they acknowledge something almost as damaging -- that the race simply isn't close enough in most states to warrant the extra expense of targeted television ads.
"When you've got a big, big mission," one Bush campaign aide said, "I don't know that it's cost-effective to be doing a lot of targeting."
 
Maintaining Secrecy
 In keeping with the Pentagon-like secrecy the campaigns maintain about their advertising plans, the Bush campaign in Washington refused to release transcripts of its radio ads, even though state Bush-Quayle campaign offices and the Clinton campaign were making them available. Similarly, the Clinton campaign declined to say where it was airing targeted television commercials.
Like many other Clinton campaign ads, the targeted commercial aimed at Ohio voters uses President Bush's own words as his undoing. Mr. Bush is shown in Columbus, Ohio, just before the 1988 election. "The Bush savings plan will keep this economic recovery going while making our future more secure," he says.
"Can we afford four more years?" the announcer asks.

HEADLINE: Bundesbank: Sound Money Bastion

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Should European monetary union some day become a reality, one of the world's most powerful and influential institutions -- the Bundesbank -- will be consigned to the dustbin of history.
Profound skepticism that this will ever happen steeps the sleek and quiet corridors of power at the Bundesbank's 13-story headquarters here these days. But in a way, the future of the central bank is partly what the recent turbulence on European money markets has been about. 
 France and Italy, German bankers say, want a European currency to replace the German mark and thereby gain a say in a new European central bank and free themselves a bit from the rigors of German economic and monetary domination.
 
Rates Fall Slightly
 Only after indications began to pile up that Germany was about to join the world recession did the Bundesbank begin to relax its monetary stringency, allowing interest rates to decline slightly on the money markets but leaving its discount rate unchanged. Its vice president, Hans Tietmeyer, said on Tuesday that the danger of inflation stemming from heavy borrowing to finance the costs of reunification was still not past, but that the bank was not "dogmatically" concerned solely about growth in the money supply.
"German monetary policy was certainly not the true cause for the development and turbulences of the past weeks," he insisted.
But if other European nations would like to be free of the German monetary discipline, there still exists in Germany a powerful consensus that a sound currency is the basis not only for sound economic growth but also for sound politics. Debasement of the money supply leads to debased politics, they believe; the Nazis came to power after a catastrophic bout of inflation destroyed the German currency in 1923. Ever since they began rebuilding the country after World War II, German leaders have been determined to prevent a repetition of this disastrous sequence.
 
Campus-Like Setting
 The Bundesbank is the vehicle for accomplishing this. The bank was established in 1957, by unifying the independent German state banks that had been established under Allied occupation. And it has had only one goal, set out in its charter: "the aim of safeguarding the currency." Today, its 18,237 employees -- scheduled to be reduced by a few thousand over the next several months -- work for an institution that singlemindedly serves that goal.
The atmosphere at the bank, a gray glass-and-concrete building set far away from the hurly-burly of the money exchanges in a campus-like preserve at the northern edge of Frankfurt, seems as solid, stable and unperturbed as the mark itself.
Despite the bank's many clashes over monetary policy with both German and foreign governments over the years, broad political support for the goal of German monetary soundness has never wavered. Germans who think of themselves as good Europeans also believe that they are doing the rest of Europe a favor, however much pain it causes at times. Inflation was a double-digit and widespread European ailment in the 1970's, and the Bundesbank has been administering strong doses of medicine ever since.
The bank's charter has one political nod, not to Brussels but to Bonn. "Without prejudice to the performance of its functions, the Deutsche Bundesbank is required to support the general economic policy of the federal Government," it says, but "it is independent of instructions from the federal Government."
But the bank is seldom really free from political pressure. Its head, Helmut Schlesinger, came under such heavy pressure to reduce interest rates at a meeting of European finance ministers and central bankers in Bath, England, last month that he wanted to walk out in anger, according to his aides. Past conflicts with governments in Bonn have usually come when the bank has tightened the monetary screws and kept interest rates high long enough to bring on a recession, something that many German economists believe may be about to happen again.
 
The Bank's Makeup
 The decision on whether to reduce them is entirely up to the Bundesbank's council, which is composed of Dr. Schlesinger, Dr. Tietmeyer and five other members of the directorate, plus the presidents of the nine German state banks.
Members of the directorate normally serve up to eight years, and are appointed by the German Federal President in Bonn after being nominated by the government of the day. Most of them come from within the bank itself. They are not removable by the Government or anybody else and are largely not answerable to it.
The Government in Bonn can press them to lower interest rates, but it cannot force them to do so -- unlike in Britain, where the Chancellor of the Exchequer makes the decision and the Governor of the Bank of England carries it out. French central bankers have somewhat more autonomy, but no other central bank in the Western world, besides the Federal Reserve in the United States, has as much as the Bundesbank.
And recently, as the financial world knows, the Bundesbank has kept nominal rates at their highest levels in postwar history, for fear of a wave of inflation caused by the huge Government and private borrowing to finance the unification of the country two years ago.
The bank's persistent refusal to give in to demands from Britain and the United States for lower rates was one of the reasons speculators began selling other currencies and buying marks this fall, gambling that the German currency would gain value. On the whole, the Bundesbank came under little pressure from Bonn to reduce rates, and after the spectacular collapse of the British pound on the currency markets, the mark did gain, just as the speculators predicted.
 
Technicians in Charge
 The bank has left its Lombard rate, which serves as a ceiling on short-term borrowing rates, at 9.5 percent, where it has been since September. But it allowed banks to bid down the rate the Bundesbank charges on short-term securities repurchase agreements from 8.9 to 8.75 percent, a step that will have the effect of continuing a downward trend on the money markets.
The Bundesbank is run, for the most part, not by cosmopolitan international bankers or politicians who might listen more closely to what their neighbors in other countries want, but by technicians whose main experience is limited to the German context.
But even within that German context, there is room for dissension. Dr. Schlesinger, for example, became president of the bank in August 1991 after the resignation of Karl Otto Pohl. Mr. Pohl resigned after Chancellor Helmut Kohl disregarded his warnings that monetary union with East Germany on the wrong terms would be a "disaster" -- a word Mr. Pohl used publicly to describe the results a few months after unification, prompting his resignation.
Mr. Kohl gave most East Germans marks at the rate of one for one, though Mr. Pohl, a plain-speaking former journalist who was appointed by the Chancellor's predecessor, protested that the Communist currency was practically worthless.
Dr. Schlesinger, who comes from a small Bavarian coal-mining town, has spent almost his entire career inside the bank, where he was in charge of its economic analysis section for years before Mr. Pohl groomed him as his successor. Dr. Schlesinger is not known for having a fine political hand, but he does have a professorial reputation for correcting people when they are wrong.
 
Britons Outraged
 The two qualities combined with explosive results last month in a defensive explanation by Dr. Schlesinger of the Bundesbank's efforts to defend the pound on the money markets in mid-September, an explanation that British Government officials found pedantically outrageous when it found its way into the newspapers. The controversy after the publication was followed by a further decline in the value of the pound, which has lost about a sixth of its value against the mark over the last month.
Dr. Schlesinger, a mountain climber who walks up the 12 flights of stairs to his office to keep fit, will be 69 years old next September and plans to retire then.
His successor will most likely be Dr. Tietmeyer, an economist who came to the bank in 1990 from the Finance Ministry in Bonn, where he advised Mr. Kohl on international economic policy. Dr. Tietmeyer's formative political years were spent under the tutelage of Ludwig Erhard, the author of the postwar West German "economic miracle," in the economics ministry in Bonn.
Dr. Tietmeyer, who is 61, has the reputation of being stiff and humorless, although politically adept. But he is seen as being no more likely than Mr. Schlesinger to allow open political considerations, such as what Germany's neighbors would like, to affect what the Bundesbank does on German monetary policy.
Otmar Issing, who held the chair of economics, monetary affairs and international economic relations at the University of Wurzburg until he came to the bank in 1990, is now the Bundesbank's chief economist, who also sits on the board.
 
Strict Monetary Targets
 Well-informed German bankers believe that he is the board member most insistent on setting the bank's strict monetary targets. Like other members of the directorate, he has shrunk from interviews since the acrimony of last month after the interviews given by Dr. Schlesinger. This year the bank set a growth target for the money supply of 3.5 to 5.5 percent, a target that has been exceeded by about 3 percentage points this year, fueling the fears of inflation.
Johann W. Gaddum, a former political associate of Mr. Kohl's in the Rhineland, and Gunter Storch, a former journalist, were joined on the Bundesbank board this year by two career bank staff members, Helmut Schieber and Wendelin Hartmann.
If Mr. Kohl names Dr. Tietmeyer president, he will be appointed to a term of eight years and paid a salary of more than 600,000 marks ($400,000.) The only thing that could lead to his removal earlier would be if the Bundesbank were replaced by a European central bank and a single currency.
Few within the bank, or anywhere else here in the German financial capital, expect that to happen, since the economic conditions necessary for having a single currency are nowhere near being met -- even if the treaty on European monetary and political union, which spells out a way to achieve a single currency by 1997, is ratified by all 12 European Community nations.
"It's a dead letter," one banker said, echoing similar thoughts heard along the carpeted corridors of the Bundesbank itself.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Al Gore;
Environment and Industry Can Flourish, Gore Says

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNION, N.J., Oct. 21

 BODY:
A day after President Bush attacked his positions on the environment, Senator Al Gore called today for a "new industrial revolution" in which stricter environmental standards would oblige businesses to adopt more efficient technologies.
Campaigning in Northern New Jersey this afternoon, Mr. Gore spoke in greater detail of his philosophy on the environment than he has in recent weeks. Although he did not deal with specific matters of policy, he said his stands on the environment and those of the Bush Administration present "as clear a difference as on any issue we face in this campaign." 
 "Bill Clinton and I believe that the economy and the environment are linked," he told a group of workers.
Mr. Bush labeled Mr. Gore's environmental stands as "strange" on Tuesday during a campaign stop in Georgia in which he mockingly referred to the Tennessee Senator as "Mr. Ozone."
 
What of Industrial States?
 Earlier today, Mr. Gore appeared on an MTV candidates' forum and was sharply questioned over whether he was softening his positions on the environment to avoid alienating voters in industrial states. He insisted that he was not.
During the MTV appearance, which Mr. Gore said was part of a Democratic drive to capture the youth vote, he also faced sometimes hostile questions about the campaign during the 1980's by his wife, Tipper, to get warning labels on record albums that contain profane or pornographic materials.
Mr. Gore traveled to New Jersey today at the beginning of a campaign swing that will take him to several states that have voted Republican in recent elections but that are now battlegrounds, including Georgia, South Carolina, Alabama and Florida.
As the setting for his speech on the environment today, Mr. Gore chose the New Jersey laboratories of the Englehard Corporation, a company that did early work in catalytic converters, now a standard anti-pollution device on American cars.
Addressing a small group of employees, Mr. Gore went beyond his frequently stated argument that the development of environmental-control devices will create new jobs.
 
Attacking Assumptions
 Instead, he attacked "comfortable and mistaken assumptions" that market factors alone will lead to improvements in the environment. Mr. Gore said that in a "new industrial revolution that focuses on environmental efficiency," businesses will find that as they eliminate causes of pollution they will increase their productivity and profits.
Mr. Gore has delivered pieces of his environmental message, but although he has promised to do so, he has yet to deliver a major address on the subject.
This morning MTV news reporter Tabitha Soren specifically asked him why he had not given such a speech, and after the candidate replied that he had talked about the environment many times, she suggested that he was holding back for fear of alienating industrial workers.
Later Ms. Soren said in an interview that in his best-selling book "Earth in the Balance" Mr. Gore took "a very apocalyptic tone" that he had not repeated since joining the ticket.
During a hour-long appearance on MTV's "Choose or Loose" program, Mr. Gore took questions from MTV reporters as well as from almost 200 youths assembled in the network's Manhattan studios.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Off the Trail -- Visits With Americans;
Campaign Is in Its Autumn, but a Season of Struggle Wends On

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 16

 BODY:
The pumpkins have a pundit's leer and the goblins lean like tired attack advertisements here on the porches of some of the humblest clapboard houses in America. The political season is winding down as Bill Belkner walks by on his way from the unemployment office.
"They got nothing in there for me," says Mr. Belkner, who has not had a job since July 1991, when the Presidential aspirants were many and their promises fresh. 
 There is a valedictory tang to the political autumn. Mr. Belkner admits he is in rough shape, living in a halfway house from which he must forage the streets of commerce, required as a condition of room and board to search every business day for a job he cannot find. Beyond such depressing rounds, he says, there is personal optimism for him in getting to vote for a President, in the idea of having any choice at all lately.
"This is Shelly and this is Ashley," he says, pointing to a lapel-pin photograph of his two young daughters that he wears on his overcoat like a campaign button. "This is a reminder that they need me and I can't let them down."
The button is a fleck of smiles and tawny color on the gray figure of the 41-year-old man. He walks down Lincoln Street from the unemployment office in a modest city of the sort that always seem misconjured in the campaign advertisements, plundered as a backdrop for simplistic tableaux of hope.
"So I had a drinking problem and fell down a bit," Mr. Belkner confides, but he has endured in New Hampshire, a state where the grand public optimism of the politicians is played out earliest in red, white and blue every four years. "I have to pick myself up and come back again," he says, taking heart in the parallel needs of himself and the nation for sober dedication to stop running away from the most obvious problems.
"I'm kinda hopeful, hearing the debates. The talk of taking chances and turning things around. Sure," he says, his daughters' smiles fixed below his edgy glance.
This troubled man makes the city seem thoughtful as the political season dies. The compromises with reality, more cautious than the politicians' own, are richly engaging in Manchester. The Tripoli brothers, Richard and Mark, run the Manchester Pawn Shop across from the unemployment office, and while they are teased by the promising antics of Ross Perot, they know better the cycle of borrowing and procrastination that keeps real people, hard-luck people, coming and going down Lincoln Street as the candidates are off talking of the future.
"These are people living on the edge," says Richard Tripoli, who is friendly and polite and not at all surprised as local craftsmen hock their tools on a Friday for a few weekend dollars. They will be back for the tools at the next odd-job opportunity, he says, just as musicians conversely redeem their instruments on a Friday for a weekend's work at entertaining.
"More of them are living in their cars, trying to pawn their junk," Mr. Tripoli says, measuring the descent of his customers and getting disgusted at what he says politicians don't know. "My customers pawned their best stuff two years ago."
Between the pawn shop and the unemployment office are some encouraging moments. A little girl jumps about happily in the back seat of a car as her father returns from Mr. Tripoli with the family VCR redeemed, some of life's promising fun restored.
Across at the unemployment office, Lucien Beauley patiently awaits another interview about his situation, his resume of his life tucked tight as a tourniquet under his arm. "A lot of people never see themselves in hard times," he says, including himself as one such amazed person, a 52-year-old computer consultant who lost his career job seven years ago when his company began laying workers off. He has since scrambled to survive as a self-employed businessman and then as an at-home consultant, but with no real paycheck to cash for more than a year now.
 
It's Something
 "It can get scary," says Mr. Beauley, nodding and impressed by what he has experienced. "It can get where you're barely making it." But he smiles slightly when contending that the political season does offer him something real, even if it is tiny and only glinting off to the side as he tries to marshal himself to go further into a long chain of days that consistently resist him.
"Confidence," he says, touching the word softly at the unemployment office. Not a mote of cynicism emerges as he subscribes to this priceless human commodity that candidates are promising to supply ever more insistently as the political autumn dwindles. "Everybody has some daily let-downs, setbacks, what have you," he said. "You have to motivate yourself to pick up something new each day to search for, some new endeavor."
At the pawn shop, Mr. Tripoli insists that the politicians, before they make big promises, should see people, voters, coming into his shop and leaving their frailest possessions hostage to some vague hope of an upturn. "The candidates are not even on the same planet," he complains.
Mr. Beauley says they are. "I saw the campaign planes coming in last winter," he says, admitting they gave him a touch of personal fervor that is with him now as the foliage spins down onto Lincoln Street in tandem with the last of the politics.

HEADLINE: Federal Work Force Declines as Military Cuts Back Spending

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The Federal work force shrank in 1991 for the second straight year, in part because of cuts in civilian jobs in the military, a Census Bureau study shows.
The study, issued Tuesday, also found that state and local governments continued to add jobs but that their rate of employment growth slowed as the economy struggled to emerge from the recession. 
 "While state and local government employment grew only 1.2 percent between October 1990 and October 1991, compared with a 3 percent increase the year before, Federal civilian government job rolls actually dipped a bit," said the report, "Public Employment: 1991."
Civilian employment in Federal, state and local governments in October 1991 was estimated at 18.6 million, up 1 percent from 18.4 million a year earlier. These payrolls had risen 2.7 percent from October 1989 to October 1990.
Federal employees totaled 3.1 million in October 1991, down 0.1 percent from a year earlier, when the number of workers fell 0.3 percent, the study showed.
 
Cuts in Military Spending
 The biggest decline in Federal employment was in a broad category of "national defense and international relations," down 1.8 percent or 19,000 positions. The military budget was sharply cut with the end of the cold war.
John A. Medina, who helped prepare the report, said Federal payrolls also fell 0.1 percent in both 1986 and 1982 and 1.4 percent in 1981, the first year of the previous recession.
While Federal employment was shrinking last year, the number of state and local government jobs grew 1.2 percent, to 15.5 million. State and local employment has grown every year since the previous recession, when it dropped 1.2 percent in 1981 and 0.5 percent in 1982.
The latest recession began in July 1990 and is widely believed to have ended in the spring of 1991, although the recovery is weak.
State employment grew by 0.4 percent last year, to 4.5 million, while local government payrolls expanded by 1.6 percent, to 10.9 million.
Total salary and wage costs outpaced the 1 percent increase in jobs, rising 5.1 percent, to $41.2 billion. They also grew faster than the 3.1 percent inflation rate for 1991.
Federal employees' salaries and wages rose 7.6 percent, to $9.7 billion. That compared with a 3.9 percent gain for state employees, to $9.4 billion, and a 4.6 percent rise for local government workers, to $22.1 billion.

HEADLINE: Drugs Cost Less in Canada Than in U.S., Study Finds

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The General Accounting Office released a study yesterday showing that the prices charged by Canadian subsidiaries of American drug companies were 32 percent lower than the same companies charged American customers.
The study, for the health subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, compared 121 drugs. It found that although the prices of 23 drugs were lower in the United States, 98 were higher here, most often by 50 percent or more. 
 Pharmaceutical industry spokesmen agreed that drug prices were lower in Canada, but they insisted that the study had exaggerated the gap by comparing "apples and oranges" in the two countries.
The subcommittee chairman, Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, said the disparity between American and Canadian prices was "another reason why we need a national health insurance system to get some control over the cost of health care."
He added: "Once again, the U.S. is behind the rest of the world in providing affordable health care to our people. Canada has found ways to control prescription drug prices. So have most countries." American consumers "are subsidizing the lower prices that Canadians and Europeans pay for pharmaceuticals," Mr. Waxman said.
 
Price to U.S. Consumers
 The American price of 27 drugs was at least double the Canadian price, the General Accounting Office said. The American price of the Upjohn Company's Xanax, a frequently prescribed anti-anxiety treatment, for example, was 183 percent higher than the Canadian price. The office, an investigative arm of Congress, compared American wholesale prices in May 1991 with those paid by the government of Ontario Province, which provides free drugs to elderly and low-income people.
Glaxo P.L.C.'s Zantac anti-ulcer drug was priced 30 percent higher in the United States. The American Home Products Corporation's Premarin, an estrogen drug for post-menopausal symptoms, was 162 percent higher.
By July 1992 the price gaps were even wider, said Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, who studies pharmaceutical economics at the University of Minnesota: 225 percent for Xanax, 40 percent for Zantac and 190 percent for Premarin.
The General Accounting Office said the biggest differential was in Isordil, an angina treatment made by American Home Products. The agency said Americans paid $17.41 for 100 10-milligram tablets, while Canadians paid only $1.63, or less than one-tenth as much.
John L. Skule, a spokesman for American Home Products, said a fairer comparison would be with the $4.33 Canadian wholesale list price. He added that Americans most often bought Premarin in 5,000-tablet bottles, which are "significantly lower" in price. Canadian prices vary across the country, he said. "They found the lowest prices" in Ontario, which is the largest Canadian market, he said.
Gerald J. Mossinghoff, president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group in Washington, said the comparisons were distorted because they were based on "our sticker prices," omitting discounts demanded by large American buyers like health maintenance organizations, and price rebates to Medicaid programs, which Congress requires.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Is Clinton Driving Bond Market?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Has the sharp fall of the bond market in October been a Clinton rout? And if so, was yesterday's sharp jump in Treasury prices -- with the 30-year bond up more than half a point -- a Clinton rally?
Or is citing Bill Clinton just an easy way for traders and journalists to explain what is going on in a $1.3 trillion market that can be buffeted every day by changing winds of fortune? 
 It is, in fact, a little of both. But there is no doubt that Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who is far ahead of President Bush in the polls, is getting more than his share of the blame -- or credit.
"I don't think it is all Clinton at all," said Joel Kazis, managing director for government trading and sales at UBS Securities in New York.
 
 
'Blame Somebody'
 "Traders have to blame somebody and the easiest thing to blame is uncertainty," he said, adding that Mr. Clinton had become synonymous with uncertainty.
Theresa Havell, the director of fixed-income securities at Neuberger & Berman in New York, agreed. "You have to focus on something, so you say it's Clinton," she said. "It might be that the market just had a big rally, and maybe this is just a correction. That would not be an atypical reaction. And markets usually assign a reason for it after the profit taking gets under way."
But John Costas, managing director of government trading and sales at the First Boston Corporation, disagreed. He blamed the Clinton program. And he said that one of the reasons the market had reacted so negatively is that most of the traders and dealers have worked only under the Republican Administrations of the last 12 years.
"People are having a hard time assigning values to the political changes that will occur," he said. "I have to attribute this whole downtrade to his program."
 One might say that if the last three weeks were the Clinton rout, then yesterday was a little Clinton rally. After falling sharply in trading in Tokyo, bonds, notes and bills rallied strongly in New York trading. The price of the 30-year bond rose in secondary trading by 19/32 point, to 9530/32 , to yield 7.6 percent, down from 7.64 percent Tuesday. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
Prices on Treasury notes were also up sharply and the discount interest rates on Treasury bills fell steeply. The price of the 10-year note jumped 31/32 , to yield 6.73 percent. It fell 111/32 points Tuesday, to yield 6.87 percent.
Mr. Costas said one reason for the rally was a report in The Chicago Tribune quoting a Clinton economic adviser, Robert Shaprio, who said that Mr. Clinton had not prepared an economic stimulus plan that would result in big increases in the Federal budget deficit.
It has been the fear of such a program, which would enlarge the budget deficit, increase Government borrowing and risk higher interest rates and inflation, that traders have said is the bogyman that has frightened the market.
But yesterday's rally was also just a natural rebound after such a sharp fall. "When things get cheap, people buy," one bond trader said.
If it was not all Mr. Clinton's fault, what did happen? One major factor in the rout has been the overreaction to the hope that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates another notch, reducing the Federal funds rate from 3 percent to 2.75 percent.
This expectation reached a fever pitch after the weak employment data for September was reported Oct. 2 and investors bought Treasury bills and short term notes, driving the prices up and the yields down.
When the Fed did not act, the disappointment was pronounced and the selling swift. By Tuesday, the discount rate on three-month bills had jumped to 3.02 percent from 2.73 percent on Oct. 1.
Another factor has been the approach of what traders call new supply -- the regular monthly auction of two-year and five-year notes next week and the much bigger quarterly auction of three-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds in November after the election.
While the amount auctioned has not changed that much recently, dealers who bid in Treasury auctions still have to sell the old stock of Treasury securities on their shelves to make room for the new ones. And in a market that is already vulnerable, this selling can have a strong downward force. (Yesterday the Treasury announced it would sell $10.75 billion of five-year notes and $15 billion of two-year notes, slightly more than last month.)
Some traders also noted that if there was so much fear of Mr. Clinton's programs the spread or differential between the yield on the 30-year bond and shorter maturities would have increased, which often is a good measure of unsettling political or economic worries.
But in October, those spreads have narrowed. The 30-year bond to 10-year note differential fell to 87 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, yesterday, down from 108 basis points Oct. 1.
