HEADLINE: 'Baby Bell' To Offer TV Service

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The Bell Atlantic Corporation announced plans today to develop what amounts to an electronic video-rental store, which would enable shoppers at home to dial up movies or television programs over ordinary telephone lines.
Technology developed by Bellcore, the research consortium owned by the seven regional Bell companies, makes possible a telephone system that may compete with cable television systems much more rapidly than experts had previously predicted. 
 Until recently, most experts assumed that telephone companies needed to replace their old-fashioned copper wires with optical fibers -- a job expected to cost between $100 billion and $400 billion nationwide -- before they could transmit television to customers at home. But Bellcore has developed a technology for transmitting a single channel of high-quality video over ordinary copper telephone lines.
 
Video on Demand
 The new technology represents a narrower approach than cable television companies currently use in offering video selections to the customer. Bell officials say that instead of sending dozens of channels to every subscriber, as cable companies do, the technology will make it possible for them to offer movies or programs one at a time, at the customer's request.
Viewers will not be able to flip casually around the dial between cooking shows, horror movies and reruns of "Kojak." Nor will they be able to watch live television, like the Cable News Network or a World Series game, because the system needs time to convert video images into digital form and store them in a giant "server" computer.
But Bell Atlantic officials say the technology will allow them to introduce a "video on demand" service that allows customers to browse from a potentially huge library of offerings and pick precisely when they want to watch their selections.
From an economic standpoint, the technology allows the telephone company to offer television service without having to rip up its existing wires. Bell Atlantic, whose phone companies provide service in New Jersey and other Middle Atlantic states, as well as Washington, said it would start a test system next summer involving 400 employees.
The company said it hoped to begin commercial introduction of the service in 1994. In the test system, viewers will be able to pick from a menu of about 100 programs and choose precisely when they want to watch them.
The new service marks the latest in a frenzy of new experiments to provide video-on-demand over telephone or cable networks. In New York City, the Nynex Corporation recently teamed up with Liberty Cable Television on a plan to deliver video-on-demand by running fiber-optic lines directly to a handful of apartments.
In Denver, U S West has joined forces with A.T.& T. and Tele-Communications Inc. to test such services over Tele-Communications' coaxial cables. And Bell Atlantic, in a previously announced experiment for Loudon County, Va., is working with the local cable company to test a "fiber to the curb" system.
But the system that Bell Atlantic announced today could speed up the race considerably, if it is successful, because it would allow telephone companies to jump into the fray without replacing thousands of miles of copper wire.
Yet many questions remain unanswered. No one knows who will make the huge computer jukeboxes that store and provide all the programming, and no one knows how costly they will be.
 
Demand, and Costs, Uncertain
 The market prospects are also unclear. Cable television systems are using fiber-optic technology to greatly increase the number of channels they can offer, allowing them to approximate video-on-demand by simply repeating programs many times a day. And satellite direct-broadcast services are also on the horizon, further increasing the competition for entertainment dollars.
Bell Atlantic officials refused to disclose how much money they plan to invest or how quickly they hope to deploy the new technology. Nor have they said which companies they hope will build the equipment or supply the programming. The Federal Communications Commission recently allowed telephone companies to provide what it called "video dial tone" service, but F.C.C. regulations still bar them from owning more than 5 percent of a programmer.
Such uncertainties notwithstanding, Bell Atlantic officials said they were committed to entering the market.
"This is the future of our business," said Arthur Bushkin, president of the company's Bell Atlantic Information Services unit. "The level of corporate commitment is complete and total."
As envisioned, video programs would be transformed into digital code using the same mathematical techniques used to store music on compact disks. The material would then be stored on a huge computer, which would in turn be linked by high-speed lines to central office switches operated by the local telephone company.
Company officials said the key innovation, developed at Bellcore, is a method of sharply increasing the capacity of ordinary copper phone lines for the last leg of the trip, from neighborhood switching stations to individual homes. New communication devices, akin to very high-speed computer modems, would be installed at both the switching stations and in each customer's home.
But industry analysts remained cautious. "This is a long process," said Daniel P. Reingold, a telephone analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. "It's not going to happen overnight."
"It is very much a black box," added Gary Arlen, a consultant in Bethesda, Md., who specializes in so-called interactive television technologies. "It could be very expensive to develop. We just don't know yet."

HEADLINE: Uncovered Short Sales Reach High on Big Board

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not covered had reached an all-time high between mid-September and mid-October, continuing a run-up that so far has lasted seven straight months.
At the end of the period, on Oct. 15, the short positions stood at 948.3 million shares, up 4.5 percent from the 907.5 million shares reported in the previous month. With that increase, short interest has jumped an astounding 34 percent since the monthly increases began in mid-March. 
 The short interest figures are widely watched on Wall Street because they act as a gauge of investor sentiment, reflecting a growing pessimism among some investors about the condition of the markets and the economy.
Professional short-sellers make their money scouting out companies whose shares they consider overvalued. They borrow these shares and sell them, essentially making a bet that the stock will fall and they will be able to buy back the shares at a lower price.
The growth in uncovered short sales did not spread to the American Stock Exchange, where short interest continued a decline that began the month before. The number of shares sold short dropped by 2.1 percent in the month that ended on Oct. 15, ending with 69.1 million shares, compared with 70.6 million in the previous month.
Despite the abandon with which short-sellers dived into the Big Board listings during the month, most of these traders were said to have been hurt badly by poorly timed bets.
"A lot of shorts are suffering a lot of pain right now,," said Steve Kibbey, a vice president of Centurion Capital in La Jolla, Calif. "If this market were to really jump, that high short interest could really turn into fuel that pushes it even more" as short-sellers rush to buy stocks to cover their positions.
A large part of the problem for short-sellers in the period was the recognition of how well such investors did last month. In that period, which also set a record, many short- sellers made a lot of money because of falling prices. That success enticed more investors to sell short this month -- when fewer of the heavily shorted stocks moved down.
"A lot of guys came in after early October," Mr. Kibbey said. "And the guys who came to the party late are, at least at this point in time, suffering the most."
Even some of the recent favorites among short-sellers proved to be traps during the month. For example, the U.S. Surgical Corporation, a maker of surgical equipment that has been a profitable short for months, got its revenge in the most recent period. The stock, which was trading as low as $57 a share earlier in October, closed yesterday at $69.875, down 50 cents. But the short interest in the stock climbed during the month, to 5.5 million, from 4.9 million in the previous period.

Short Interest Tables Explained
 These tables show issues with a short interest position in the current month of at least 200,000 shares.
 Cover ratio represents the number of days, at average volume level, that it would take to purchase the number of shares sold short.
 A -- American Stock Exchange.
 N -- New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices of Energy Decline On Weak Demand Outlook

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Energy prices sank yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid perceptions that demand is too weak to make a dent in the current abundant supply of oil and natural gas.
Philip Verleger, a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics, said the oil market was slumping because of widespread economic weakness coupled with projections for higher production. 
 On Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute reported that United States crude oil stocks rose a sharp 3.65 million barrels in the latest week, while heating oil stocks declined. Also pressuring prices were persistent rumors that Iraq would resume export sales embargoed since the Gulf War and that OPEC production would increase in the fourth quarter.
"Over all, there is a background factor of rising OPEC production," said Andrew Lebow of E.D.& F. Man.
December crude oil lost 44 cents to close at $21.61 a barrel on the Nymex; November unleaded gasoline fell 0.63 cent, to 58.72 cents a gallon, and November heating oil dipped 1.56 cents, to 62.65 cents a gallon.
Oil experts said the depth of the price retreat would hinge on how cold the weather turns as winter nears in the Northern Hemisphere.
The 10-month bull market in natural gas, in which prices more than doubled, shows signs of exhaustion. November natural gas lost 8.3 cents, to close at $2.488 per million British thermal units. December closed off 6.1 cents, at $2.378.
December coffee reacted to the slowdown in exports from Brazil to settle up 0.35 cent, at 65.20 cents a pound. The Brazilian Government has cut coffee sales abroad due to internal price incentives.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, December soft red wheat led a decline, dropping 4 cents to close at $3.50 a bushel against a dismal export scene.
Speculation that the United States Department of Agriculture will reject another Russian bid for 1.6 million metric tons of wheat and that China will delay its long-awaited wheat tender until after the United States elections put pressure on wheat prices.
December corn closed off 2 1/2 cents, to $2.07 3/4 a bushel, and November soybeans ended down 2 1/2 cents, to $5.43 3/4 in the middle of the harvest season, which is pointing to record crop yields.

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Details Withholding On Retirement Withdrawals

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Workers who take early withdrawals from employer-sponsored retirement plans will be subject to tax withholding even if the money is needed for an emergency, the Internal Revenue Service has ruled.
The I.R.S. said Congress had given it no authority to allow a hardship exclusion, even though many pre-retirement withdrawals are made to pay medical costs and meet other emergencies. Other workers take an early withdrawal when they change jobs. 
 The announcement was made on Tuesday as the I.R.S. proposed regulations spelling out how a new law imposing 20 percent withholding on lump-sum pension distributions from 401(k), profit-sharing and other retirement plans would be administered.
The law was passed in July to help finance an extension of jobless benefits for the long-term unemployed. The regulations will take effect on Jan. 1, but they could be amended after an I.R.S. hearing scheduled for Jan. 15.
 
20% to Be Withheld
 The new law requires employers to withhold for taxes 20 percent of lump-sum distributions unless the money is shifted directly into a new pension or an individual retirement account.
Under the old law, a person could take a lump-sum distribution once a year and incur no immediate tax liability or penalty so long as the money was rolled over into another I.R.A. or pension account within 60 days. Any money not rolled over is subject to immediate taxation, plus a 10 percent penalty if the withdrawal is by a person under 59 1/2 years of age.
Some tax experts expressed surprise that the I.R.S. did not allow special treatment of hardship withdrawals. But Andy Zuckerman of the accounting firm Grant Thornton in Washington said the real problem is the new law, not the I.R.S. regulation.
"If you withdraw, have 20 percent withheld and later decide to put the money into an I.R.A. or into a plan of another employer, you'd only have 80 percent to roll over and you'd have to write a check for the remainder," Mr. Zuckerman said today.
On the other hand, he said, "it probably will cause people to leave the money in their retirement plan longer."
"If you consider taking the money to buy that Corvette or take that vacation," he said, "this will force you to realize you are losing 20 percent right off the bat unless you roll it over."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Funds Off; Taxable Yields Are Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields were mixed in the latest seven-day period ended yesterday, as IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report surveyed more than 862 tax-exempt and taxable money market funds. Tax-exempt funds had lower yields, while taxable funds posted slight gains.
The decline in tax-exempt yields came from strong investor demand for short-term municipal debt, which drove prices higher and yields lower. But the pattern is likely to reverse itself as investor appetite diminishes, forcing prices down and yields higher, and the supply of new issues begins to outpace demand. 
 Assets of tax-exempt money funds increased by $149 million for the week, to a total $96.9 billion, with the average number of days left to maturity of securities in fund portfolios down one, to 66, IBC/Donoghue's analysts said.
The seven-day average compounded yield fell to 2.15 percent from 2.33 percent last week and simple yield fell to 2.13 percent, from 2.31 percent.
The 30-day average, which reflects any rise or decline over a much longer period of time, is still showing the drop in yields from cash pouring into the money funds. But analysts expect yields to rebound some and move up in the next couple of weeks as the cash influx is absorbed.
For the 30-day period, the compounded yield is down to 2.47 percent, from 2.56 percent in the previous week. The simple yield is down to 2.44 percent, compared with 2.53 percent.
Not assuming state taxes, this means that the taxable equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield is about 3.23 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 3.38 percent for investors in the 31 percent tax bracket.
In its survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. in Milwaukee, was the best-performing fund, with a yield of 2.81 percent.
Assets of taxable money market funds grew by $6.4 billion, to $493.7 billion. Institutional money funds accounted for much of the growth, as their assets rose by $4.7 billion, to a total $174.1 billion and retail assets grew by $1.7 billion, to $319.6 billion.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue, says there was still a chance for another easing by the Federal Reserve. But he does not expect it to happen until after the Presidential election, when the next employment report is due. "How well the markets receive the next rate cut, if it comes, will depend on who was elected into the Oval Office," Mr. Frank said.
 
Taxable Yield: 2.83%
 The average seven-day compounded yield for a taxable money market fund was 2.83 percent, up from 2.81 percent last week, and the simple yield was 2.79 percent, up from 2.77 percent.
Over a 30-day period the average compounded yield is 2.86 percent, down from 2.88 percent a week ago; the simple yield is 2.82 percent, down from 2.84 percent.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable portfolios fell by one, to 64. The Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company in New York, was the top returner among general purpose funds with a yield of 3.80 percent. For government-only funds with assets under $100 million, the United Services Government Securities Savings fund, distributed by United Services in San Antonio, was tops at 3.99 percent.
The average yield on bank money market accounts fell to 2.80 percent this week, from 2.82 percent last week.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed on Questions About German Rate Moves

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed yesterday on world currency markets, buffeted by speculation over whether Germany will cut its interest rates.
Gold prices posted slight gains worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $344.10 an ounce, up 30 cents from Tuesday. Republic National Bank said gold rose 15 cents an ounce to a late bid of $343.75. 
 The dollar initially fell after comments by a Bundesbank official, who warned against excessive expectations that the German central bank would cut interest rates. Lower German rates would help the dollar by making dollar-denominated securities more attractive to investors.
Those comments sent the dollar lower in Europe. But when trading shifted to the United States, the scene turned around. Word that the Austrian central bank had cut its interest rates, a move that typically precedes a cut in German rates, helped lure traders back to the dollar.
The dollar ended the United States session near its highs for the day in relatively active trading.
Andrew Busch, a trader with Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, warned, however, that the dollar would remain volatile until a clear trend in the direction of European interest rates is firmly established.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 122.38 Japanese yen, from 121.00 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 121.75 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.60 yen, up from 122.50 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6140 from $1.6225 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.6067 to buy one pound, down from $1.6245 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5195 German marks, up from 1.5160; 1.3575 Swiss francs, up from 1.3570; 5.1575 French francs, up from 5.1435; 1,335.00 Italian lire, up from 1,333.50, and 1.2399, up from 1.2398.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.5075 German marks, down from 1.5205; 1.3480 Swiss francs, down from 1.3605; 5.1186 French francs, down from 5.1550; 1.6975 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7110; 1,329.75 Italian lire, down from 1,335.00; 1.2378 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $344.35 an ounce, up from $343.85 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $343.70 from $343.40. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.08 to $343.68.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Profits for Times Mirror and Knight-Ridder

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company said yesterday that its earnings increased 6.8 percent in the third quarter, although a drop in advertising revenues at The Los Angeles Times was a drag on the company's results.
Meanwhile, Knight-Ridder Inc. said its third-quarter profits rose 11 percent, in large part a result of increased advertising at The Miami Herald after Hurricane Andrew. 
 Following are details of the two companies' results:
 
Times Mirror
 Times Mirror said its net income for the latest quarter increased to $43.8 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with $41 million, or 32 cents a share, in the 1991 third quarter. Revenues rose 2.8 percent, to $914.4 million, from $889.5 million a year earlier.
"The strong financial performance in the third quarter of all business segments, except newspaper publishing, was sufficient to offset the earnings declines in our newspaper operations," said Robert Erburu, chairman and chief executive.
He said the Los Angeles-based company was concerned about the weak economy in Southern California and its effect on advertising volume for The Los Angeles Times.
The newspaper publishing unit posted a decline of 2 percent in third-quarter revenues, as a result of the drop in advertising at The Times.
Broadcast television revenues jumped 20 percent, while cable television revenues grew 10 percent, and revenues at the book and magazine unit rose 7 percent.
Times Mirror also publishes Newsday and New York Newsday, The Baltimore Sun and other newspapers.
Times Mirror's shares gained 62.5 cents yesterday, to close at $30.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Knight-Ridder
 Knight-Ridder said its third-quarter earnings increased to $31.4 million, or 57 cents a share, compared with $28.3 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. The Miami-based company said revenues at its newspaper unit edged up 2.5 percent, to $469.2 million. It reported total revenues of $564.9 million, up 3.9 percent from $544.4 million a year earlier.
 "This was the best year-to-year newspaper advertising revenue performance we have seen since 1990," said Robert Singleton, chief financial officer. "However, we have not seen any clear signal that the end of the recession is at hand."
He said that when the hurricane hit Florida, The Miami Herald became the main "community bulletin board" and the primary means for insurance, electric and telephone companies to communicate with stricken people in south Dade County.
Knight-Ridder's shares fell $1 yesterday, to close at $57, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Refereeing The Blame Game

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
"THE economy, dummy," reads the now-famous sign in Clinton headquarters, an unsubtle reminder of where the candidate's main chance lies. Even President Bush seems to agree that he has hopelessly botched the recession thing: If re-elected, he has promised to pack his senior economic advisers onto the first Learjet leaving town.
But reality is more elusive. While independent analysts might not give Mr. Bush high marks for bravery, few claim that his decisions seemed foolish at the time, or that the recession on his watch has been more debilitating than those of the 1970's and 80's. Nor, for that matter, do many think that the long-term economic prognosis is really worse today than in the what-me-worry 1980's. 
 A more plausible explanation for the public's wrath is that the recession has served as an overdue catalyst, diminishing expectations long after the events that foretold stagnating living standards. Plainly, whoever is elected on Nov. 3 is going to have a tough time coping with the disillusionment.
Could George Bush have spared Americans 7.5 percent unemployment -- and spared himself the unusual role of incumbent Republican underdog? Perhaps, if he had boldly negotiated a credible deficit reduction deal with Congress in the first months of his Presidency, and then persuaded the Federal Reserve to turbocharge the money supply. Perhaps, if he had gone against the advice of traditional conservatives early this year by jumping at Congressional feelers for a bipartisan, budget-busting fiscal stimulus.
But hindsight is a test that Americans in a more forgiving mood would not apply. And in any case, the employment hole that Mr. Bush was an accomplice to digging was not very deep -- at least not by the standards of the 1974-75 and 1981-82 recessions. Why, then, is the President in such serious danger of receiving a pink slip with his next pay check?
John Taylor, a Stanford University economist who worked in the Bush White House, believes that voters have simply lost perspective. He points out that "the last recession was so long ago, few people remember it was far worse."
Alan Blinder of Princeton, rumored to be in line for an economics post in a Clinton White House, is less charitable. He notes that this recession started, and seems to be ending, with a whimper. Thus, while it was no deeper than the average recession, the periods of high unemployment on each end have been longer and more demoralizing -- indeed, the end of what Mr. Blinder dubs "the growth depression" is not yet in clear sight.
Both the Taylor and Blinder arguments complement a broader theory, one that traces today's voter malaise to a long-delayed recognition of the slowdown in productivity growth in the mid-1970's.
Certainly the Ford and Carter one-term Presidencies were victims of what proved to be a halving of productivity growth from the postwar norm of 3 percent a year. But Paul Krugman of M.I.T., another Clintonaut-in-waiting, notes that the downward shift in the long-term trend in those years was obscured by two nasty recessions.
And if anyone was trying to sell the idea of a chronic drag on productivity, hardly anyone outside the ivory tower was listening. Indeed, President Reagan's supporters were peddling just the opposite view, successfully attributing everything bad that happened before the trough of the recession in 1982 to Jimmy Carter, and everything good that happened after to a Reagan-induced supply-side miracle.
And therein, paradoxically, may lie the origins of George Bush's undoing. Measured from 1982 to the peak of the economic cycle in 1989, median family income grew by about 12 percent -- in sharp contrast to the slight decline in the Bush years. But measured from peak to peak (1979 to 1989), as most economists would recommend, median family incomes rose a scant 4 percent. And if Mr. Bush, heir to the Reagan political coalition, were in a position to tarnish the halo of The Big Guy, his own record could have been cast in far more sympathetic light.
David Hale of Kemper Financial Services suggests that the ironies run even deeper. President Bush's ability to fight the recession has been hamstrung by chronic budget deficits, which made fiscal stimulus problematic, and the savings and loan debacle, which has led to an implosion of bank credit. But while both evil flowers blossomed during the Reagan years, Mr. Reagan paid no political price for either. To the contrary: Both the tax cuts that led to the $4 trillion debt and the real estate boom that was fed by deregulated, run-amuck lenders, generated windfalls in personal income that postponed the day of reckoning on productivity.
Where does that leave the next President? With a giant productivity problem no one really knows how to solve, and an even bigger political problem. The best hope, perhaps, is that the productivity gods who laughed with Ronald Reagan and laughed at George Bush will roll up their sleeves and get back to work.

HEADLINE: POOL-HOPPING WITH: Kelly Klein;
Reflecting A Lovely World

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL

 BODY:
WAITING, in the back of a limousine half a block long, is Kelly Klein. She sits behind the blackout windows, hands folded, thoroughly composed. Escape? No. Obsession? Never. Her signature fragrance could only be Serenity.
Mrs. Klein, who has been married to the designer Calvin Klein for five years, is showroom perfect in a dark brown sweater, dark olive jacket, dark taupe pants and dark brown suede shoes -- which would make most women look like an algae-covered mudslide. But the earth tones pick up on her tawny hair, which complements her moderate tan, which highlights her mind-boggling ring. Part of her collection of the Duchess of Windsor's jewels (Mrs. Klein was pictured last year in Vogue wearing the Duchess's pearls with jeans), the double-banded gold ring surrounding emerald-cut diamonds was given the name "Eternity" by Prince Edward when he presented it to Wallis Simpson. Which is how Mr. Klein's Eternity fragrance got its name. 
 The only item that matches her eyes, a remarkable sky blue, is lying on the seat opposite. It is "Pools," her new $100 coffee-table book of vintage and contemporary pool photographs (Alfred A. Knopf), which will be in stores next month. It takes up the whole seat.
Mrs. Klein, who is 35 years old, is a novice at solo publicity, which is hard enough for those with more practice. But over all, she just doesn't seem used to talking to strangers. Her conversation shows her world to be a small and safe place that operates on an almost childlike premise that everything will be all right. She's something like the good family china -- expensive, beautiful and only out on special occasions.
Born in Michigan, raised in Westport, Conn., until she was 10, Mrs. Klein then moved to Manhattan, where she attended the Dwight School. "At one point, when I was very young, my family had a lot of money," she once told Vanity Fair. "Then, I don't know, it just seemed to disappear." To the extent that she worked part time after school to help pay for her horse's upkeep. Her parents divorced when she was 10. Her father, a former director of television commercials, lives in Middleburg, Va., where he is also an avid rider. The day after graduating from the Fashion Institute of Technology, in 1977, she began work as a design assistant to Ralph Lauren, where she stayed for five years before going to Calvin Klein, in the same position.
The small amount of personal information published about her says she collects glass on the beach, her maiden name is Rector, she owns two horses and a $50,000 Hermes saddle and her mother is part American Indian. Mrs. Klein, who will turn 36 on Nov. 2, decided to assemble "Pools" three years ago, after discovering there were no books to refer to when she and Mr. Klein were considering a pool for their home in East Hampton.
Today, she is revisiting two of the pools that are in the book. The first is at the West Side Y.M.C.A., on West 63d Street, the second at the home of a friend in Greenwich, Conn.
"The pool at the Y. is quite beautiful, though I don't think I would swim in it," she says. "Uhm," she adds uncertainly, "you don't have to say I wouldn't. I just don't swim in public places. Since I was a child I only swam at someone's house." She sighs. "It's not about swimming, anyway. It's about design."
She tries again: "Actually, my most favorite pool in New York, which I would die to swim in, is at the New York Athletic Club, with that chic 1920's great style. Women have just been allowed there, but they wouldn't let us photograph it. They're so uptight."
Alighting from the limo -- and truly, she alights -- Mrs. Klein heads into the lobby of the Y.M.C.A., which reeks of chlorine. The harried receptionist, sporting smeared makeup and three inches of roots, looks up. "Are you interested in joining?" she asks while a handsome young man in roller skates, who knows exactly who Mrs. Klein is, laughs out loud.
She remains calm, striding up the stairs toward the office of the marketing director, who shows the way to the adult pool, decorated with tiles that were a gift from the King of Spain in 1930. Then on to the children's pool, which is even more dazzling, in an elaborate scheme of blue, yellow and white. "Can you imagine children walking in here?" Mrs. Klein asks. "All this blue." Her eyes open unnaturally wide, as if trying to feel the color.
The marketing director, buoyed by the interest, points out the original stained glass in the windows. "Oh, yes?" Mrs. Klein says, already through the door. "Very festive.""
Back in the limo, Greenwich bound, Mrs. Klein says: "When I started, it was strictly a beautiful book on pools. But my vision was broadened by old archival photos from the 1920's and 30's and I thought how fabulous to mix them in with contemporary pool pictures."
She leafs through the book, past her five-page introduction and the foreword by Esther Williams, caressing each spectacular photograph with a hypnotic circular motion. "They're replacing chlorine now in pools," she says, "using an ozone process where water recycles through copper coils and cleanses itself and filters back. I don't really know how it works, but a lot of people in L.A. are doing it."
Mrs. Klein says she contacted between 300 and 400 photographers for the book. "Then I added fashion, which is my background, and it sort of all fell into place," she continues. "I did the book as if I were creating a collection of clothing, where you buy fabric, put it into different silhouettes, make 100 outfits, send the girls down the runway to take a look and edit out what's not that interesting. This book started with 3,000 photos, which I edited to the best 200 in a sequence that flowed from beginning to end."
But $100 in a recession, for pictures of pools, no matter how beautiful? Even Madonna's new coffee table book, "Sex," is only $49.95. "I want people to buy 'Pools' because they need help," Mrs. Klein says. "It is for architects, for the woman who lives in the country who wants to know about color, shape, materials. When I thought about a pool, my architect said there were no books, even though everyone always asks for one. Everyone needs one."
"I also wanted to do what I could for AIDS, so I'm donating all my profits," she says. "I wanted this book to have a lot of style. I wanted it to be expensive, printed on beautiful paper. And Knopf came through for me. I had no complaints. I'm proud of this book." Her tone is plaintive. "It's not a $39.95 coffee-table book," she adds. "It's better printed. It has a lot of color, and black and white. I wasn't interested in doing a book that was $39."
The car has arrived at the gate of the Greenwich home of Vince and Kristen Camuto. Mrs. Klein rides horses with Mrs. Camuto. The house resembles a European chateau and Mrs. Klein says that the pool, which is cut into rock, forming a partial cave set off by columns, was inspired by a villa in Florence. Mrs. Camuto comes onto the terrace, briefly, in her riding garb with her three-year-old towheaded son. It's like falling into a page of Town and Country.
Mrs. Klein takes off her jacket and lies on an evergreen chaise longue near the pool. She is very at home here. You might guess that anyone sitting in direct sunlight wearing a cashmere sweater would sweat. Mrs. Klein does not.
Two uniformed maids appear with trays of tea, turkey sandwiches and huge raspberry-filled cookies. Mrs. Klein picks the turkey off the bread with her fingertips and eats it, then pinches crumbs off her cookie.
Now that the book presentation is over, she is supremely relaxed. She's good at girl talk, loose and confident. There's something compelling and finally attractive about someone so genuinely sheltered, because it feeds the universal longing for a happy ending. Remote, yet possible.
Her clothes alone are every woman's fantasy. "I have amazing clothes," she agrees. "I have an amazing closet. It's a bedroom, actually. Though sometimes I wish I was married to a plumber so I would have beautiful sinks and tubs. I've always been interested in clothes. I always loved to get dressed, to put colors together." Given how competitive the fashion world is, does she wear only Calvin Klein? "Well, I have some antique clothes," she says. "But I don't wear other designers."
"I am Calvin's muse," she continues. "He designs everything for me. I happen to be very American, look very American. That helps, to fit right into his sense of design and style. I love him. I love everything he does. He's just the best guy in the world. I never felt threatened by his success and fame. I've only learned from it. It's made me independent, stronger. So, I'm happy I can wear his clothes and look as beautiful in them as I do. I'm flattered by that, really."
Mrs. Klein keeps an office at Calvin Klein, though she no longer works there full time. "I did this book because I felt that it was time for me to do something on my own and step away," she says. "We're together 24 hours a day, living and working, and we do it well. But it is important to be passionate about other things that are your own. The book became my passion."
Has she ever considered the possibility that the book might not be well received, that it might be reviewed poorly, or not at all, or that it just might not sell?
"I don't think that way," she says. "I love this book and believe in it. I hope other people feel that way, and if not, O.K. I had the courage to do this. I can't have fears. I'm not a writer, I'm a visual person. I'm not about words. I just never worried this book wasn't going to work."
Has she ever had disappointment in her life? Sitting here now, contentedly licking cookie crumbs from her fingers, the prospect seems absurd.
She thinks. "When I don't win in the horse show," she says. "I like to win, but if the animal is not having a good day, or I'm off, it's hard to make it work. It's a very hard sport. It's about appearance and performance, so you have to be as beautiful and perfect as possible. I love the way the horse and the people look all dressed up. I forget about everything else in my life, the tensions of New York."
Mrs. Klein says she wakes up at 5:30 A.M. five days a week, meditates, then skims the papers. She runs to her gym and works out with her personal trainer. Then she runs home. Depending on how crowded her work schedule is, she either goes to the office or rides her horses, Gratis and Navajo, in northern Westchester. Mr. Klein often works until 8 P.M., she says, and in the evenings they either attend black-tie benefits, eat out, or order in sushi.
As for children, Mrs. Klein says: "I don't wake up thinking about them. I like my job, riding horses and traveling with Calvin. I don't want to give that up. I'll be 36 soon, so I'll have to take my chances. There's nothing wrong with adopting, either." She is already a stepmother to Marci Klein, Mr. Klein's 26-year-old daughter, who is a talent coordinator for "Saturday Night Live."
Though she does not yet have another idea for a book, Mrs. Klein says she would like to do another soon. As for her own reading, she says she likes anything by Dominick Dunne, loved Josephine Hart's "Damage" and is drawn to biographies.
"I like reading about people with interesting lives," she says. "Like Princess Di. I loved that book, the one with the white cover where she's wearing the white dress. I felt so sorry for her. The poor thing is completely miserable. I mean, as long as it was all true. I hate people's speculation."

HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES;
A Rocky Off Season Lies Ahead for the A's

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MARTINEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
Their season ended a week ago, but it was not the kind of exit that the Oakland Athletics expected, not for a team that was as close as it gets to a dynasty in baseball these days. They were hooted in Toronto, beaten back by the Blue Jays and ushered out of a return to the World Series with a resounding shove.
Now, they are likely to be dismantled by the bottom line. 
 It is still too soon to know what the winter will bring, but the directive sent by the A's ownership to Sandy Alderson, the general manager, is unmistakable: reduce a $42 million payroll by as much as $12 million.
Because the A's will have as many as 15 possible free agents on the market once the season ends, they do not view the end of the World Series with much anticipation. And if the off season becomes another feeding frenzy for big names and bigger salaries, the Oakland Coliseum could become a wasteland next season.
The A's stand to lose such longtime notables as Dave Stewart, Mark McGwire and Terry Steinbach. Jose Canseco was traded in August. Carney Lansford announced his retirement after the team lost to the Blue Jays in the American League Championship Series. Others, such as Ruben Sierra, Mike Moore and Harold Baines, might also leave.
 
Back to Mediocre?
 Without them, the A's could drift back to a mediocrity they haven't known since before Tony La Russa became manager. In the last five seasons, they have won four division titles, three pennants and one World Series. They haven't drawn fewer than two million fans since 1987.
"We've lost significant amounts of money the last few years," Alderson said from Toronto. "Just look at the way our payroll has gone up, from $20 million two years ago to $39 million last year. This year, it will be in the $42 million range. Your payroll can't keep going up while, at the same time, your attendance is going down."
The A's have been so determined to keep salaries in check that they did not negotiate with anyone during the season except relief pitcher Dennis Eckersley, who signed a two-year extension for $7.8 million, far less than he would have attracted elsewhere. With the others, the A's chose to wait, gambling that the offers from other teams will not be as high as in previous winters.
 
Boils Down to Economics
 "It will all be dictated by economics," said Walt Jocketty, the team's director of baseball administration, "but I think some of them will be back. We're not going to strip the team down completely."
Alderson said that he, Jocketty and La Russa have not yet identified their top priorities, preferring to see what kinds of proposals other teams will place on the negotiating table. But the A's, who aren't expected to give more than three-year contracts, will clearly not be the first to make offers to anyone.
"How can I achieve our primary goal of getting the payroll down by jumping in right away?" Alderson asked. "What am I going to be pre-emptive with? If what we're reading is right about what certain players might earn, it might be difficult to bring them back."
The task is not a simple one for Alderson, who is regarded as one of the game's most astute executives. But as outfielder Dave Henderson said after the A's season concluded: "I figure we're going to see how good Sandy really is. Now he's got a chance to prove it. Our season is over. Sandy's is just beginning."
When he sorts out the mess, Alderson is very likely to pursue Steinbach, McGwire and Sierra, who came in the Canseco deal, in earnest. Those three, however, could cost as much as $14 million for one year. Stewart has expressed a desire to return, but the team may not offer him more than a one-season deal.
Lansford could be enticed to put off his retirement for one more summer if the offer is right. The A's can keep pitcher Mike Moore by offering arbitration, although he could win more from an arbitrator than he could on the free-agent market.
 
Cards Anyone?
 "There are so many variables," Alderson said. "This is a card game. We can't dictate what's going to happen."
In one way, though, the A's may have played some cards correctly. With the expansion draft scheduled next month, they will be able to keep some of the organization's younger players from being exposed. Free agents cannot be protected.
But youth is not necessarily the direction the A's will go if they lose on free agency this winter.
Alderson said that he may attempt to sign other free agents who would cost less than his own. "I wouldn't say there's an overabundance of talent ready to play in the major leagues," he said of his team's prospects, "but it doesn't mean we can't find other players out there."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Democrats: Courting the Younger Generation

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
The Democratic National Committee on Tuesday began a $1 million advertising campaign aimed at younger voters. The 30-second spots, one feature a young man and the other a young woman, are appearing on the networks, geared to shows with younger audiences like "Beverly Hills 90210" and "Roseanne."
 
ON THE SCREEN White letters on black background: "A reality check. Jonathan."
Various images of young man named Jonathan, talking to camera, in the kitchen, looking through the newspaper classifieds, of his mother in the kitchen as he talks about living at home, snapshots of Jonathan with friends at graduation.
These words appear on screen: "The Democratic Plan: create new jobs, invest in people, develop new technologies."
Ends with these words on screen: "The Democratic Party. A plan that works for a change." 

PRODUCER Frank Greer/Mandy Grunwald
 
TELEVISION SCRIPT Jonathan: "Since I graduated I've done telemarketing, I was a bicycle messenger . . .
"I hope in the future to get a job in my field and from there start my own life, but there are no jobs. I feel trapped, having to live at home. The Republicans really do not know what the average American is going through.
"The Democratic plan is the plan that makes the most sense. I really believe that the Democrats would bring a lot of hope and enthusiasm to this country."
 
ACCURACY Nothing inherently inaccurate.
 
SCORECARD This so-called "generic" ad is paid for by the Democratic Party so it cannot directly mention Mr. Clinton or Mr. Bush. But it clearly repeated Mr. Clinton's central message: that he is the candidate of change. It seeks to lend authenticity to the message by using a young man who says he has been a direct casualty of the nation's economic woes. This is all part of a Democratic effort to win first-time voters and get them to the polls.

HEADLINE: D'Amato Serves as a Magnet for Funds

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH

 BODY:
It was an obscure provision buried deep in the arcane language of a 1,000-page trade bill, but Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was on the case. A handful of sugar refiners, including one with a plant in Brooklyn, stood to gain $365 million in tariff rebates and Mr. D'Amato was all for it.
With his help, the provision squeaked through the Senate in the summer of 1987. That fall, five years before his next race, Mr. D'Amato received $8,500 in campaign contributions from the sugar refiners. 
 It is from such incidents that Mr. D'Amato, who has cultivated an image as a zealous guardian of constituents' interests, has also gained a reputation as one of the Senate's most aggressive and prolific fund-raisers.
 
Several Inquiries
 Over the last decade, he has collected more than $21 million, much of it from people or businesses with matters pending before one of the Senate committees on which he has served. His practices have gained such notoriety that they have led to several well-publicized investigations and have damaged his popularity.
But as Mr. D'Amato, a Republican, seeks a third term, his continued ability to amass a huge political fund has enabled him to run a fiercely competitive campaign against Attorney General Robert Abrams, a Democrat who is one of the state's all-time vote-getters. And Mr. D'Amato's fund has made it possible for Mr. D'Amato to wage a bold and expensive television campaign suggesting that Mr. Abrams has improperly accepted campaign contributions from people with business pending before his office. Mr. D'Amato has himself faced such criticism throughout his career.
With more than $9.4 million collected since his last election, Mr. D'Amato will vastly outspend Mr. Abrams, who has raised $5.4 million but was forced to spend much of it in the bitterly contested Democratic primary. Last Friday Mr. Abrams had $545,000 on hand, while Mr. D'Amato had about $2 million.
 
Television Ad Campaign
 Mr. D'Amato plans to spend every dollar of that money and thousands more expected from two fund-raising events next week, said Kieran Mahoney, his campaign manager. Nearly all the money will be used to pay for the television ad campaign, he said.
Some of the commercials echo the criticisms of a state commission that faulted Mr. Abrams three years ago for accepting donations from lawyers and real-estate investors who had business before his office. While Mr. Abrams was not accused of doing favors in return for contributions, the panel described such solicitation as "implicitly coercive." The commission focused only on state officials, so it did not review Mr. D'Amato's fund-raising.
Mr. Mahoney acknowledged that the D'Amato campaign has no general policy barring donations from people who are seeking help or legislation from the Senator. In fact, a review of Mr. D'Amato's campaign records shows a strong pattern of donations from businesses and people for whom Mr. D'Amato can provide critical assistance, whether on matters of parochial interest or broad public policy.
 
'Insultingly Preposterous'
 "The Senator fights hard for New York, and a lot of New Yorkers appreciate what he does," Mr. Mahoney said. He rejected as "insultingly preposterous" any suggestion that there is a relationship between campaign contributions and Mr. D'Amato's official actions. "We've helped hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, some of whom we have never met," Mr. Mahoney said.
Over the years, the financial industry has provided the most money to Mr. D'Amato's campaigns, the records show. He has been a member of the Senate Banking Committee, where he has been a strong advocate for measures backed by the securities industry.
In 1985, when he was chairman of the securities subcommittee, Mr. D'Amato excluded from legislation he introduced a proposal that would have limited the purchase of junk bonds by federally regulated savings and loans. That same year, Drexel Burnham Lambert, then the top marketer of the high-risk securities, held a fund-raising reception for Mr. D'Amato at Chasen's restaurant in Beverly Hills. Drexel, now defunct, had opposed the junk-bond proposal.
Since his last election, Mr. D'Amato has accepted more than $300,000 from individuals who work for brokerages and investment banks, the records show.
A study by Public Citizen, a government watchdog group founded by Ralph Nader, showed that Mr. D'Amato has accepted $627,402 since he went to the Senate in 1981 from political action committees organized by securities and banking groups.
 
One of 8 Senators
 Mr. D'Amato was one of eight members of Congress made a target for defeat yesterday by Public Citizen, which asserted that Mr. D'Amato is improperly influenced by special-interest money. Mr. D'Amato "too often represents the lobbyists who pay for his campaigns, not the voters who sent him to Washington," said Craig McDonald, a spokesman for the group.
Mr. Mahoney, the D'Amato campaign manager, defended the Senator's championing of the securities firms, calling their health vital to the economy of New York because they provide thousands of jobs.
The Senator's relationship with Wall Street became a subject of an investigation by the Senate's Select Committee on Ethics after a complaint was filed by Mark Green, the New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner, whom Mr. D'Amato defeated in the 1986 Senate election.
In a report released last year, the committee found that Mr. D'Amato violated neither Federal laws nor Senate rules in his handling of the junk bond legislation after he accepted the donations from Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1985. In regard to most of the 15 other allegations made by Mr. Green, the committee found "no credible evidence" that Mr. D'Amato had acted improperly.
But the committee did criticize him for "conducting the business of his office in an improper and inappropriate manner" by allowing his brother Armand to use it for lobbying activities. Armand D'Amato was indicted for mail fraud this year, accused of accepting $200,000 in unreported payments to lobby his brother on behalf of the Sperry Corporation and its successor, Unysis. He pleaded not guilty, and the Senator has said he was unaware of his brother's activities.
On one fund-raising issue involved whether Mr. D'Amato had helped win roughly $60 million in Federal housing authorizations for Eduardo Lopez Ballori, a developer in Puerto Rico who was indicted on a technical Federal charge involving $30,000 in illegal contributions to the Senator's campaign. At a trial last June, which ended in a hung jury, Mr. Lopez Ballori contended that he was unaware of regulations restricting his contributions.
The Senator, who said he was unaware of the improper contributions, donated the money to charity.
Mr. Lopez Ballori is to be retried shortly in San Juan.
The matter is one of several involving Mr. D'Amato, some of his contributors and fund-raisers, and the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, whose New York regional office was run for much of the 1980's by one of his proteges and contributors, Joseph Monticiollo.
 
Sugar in Brooklyn
 Employees of the office have testified before a Congressional committee or told reporters that Mr. Monticiollo and others in the H.U.D. office seemed to be pressing for favorable treatment for housing grants that would benefit such D'Amato supporters as a Great Neck, L.I., construction company called Jobco. Owners and employees of the company have contributed more than $5,000 to Mr. D'Amato and have held fund-raisers for him as well.
Mr. D'Amato has denied exerting pressure on behalf of contributors. Jobco officials have denied benefiting as well, citing H.U.D. work received before Mr. D'Amato's election.
In the 1987 debate over the proposal to benefit the sugar companies, Mr. D'Amato said the key issue was jobs for New York. He warned that the Domino Sugar refinery near the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn would be shut down -- and 800 jobs would be lost -- if the provision was not enacted. Domino stood to gain $135 million in rebates of sugar import tariff, more than any other company.
Senator John H. Chafee, a Republican from Rhode Island, complained that the tax break was a "government handout of the most outrageous kind," but Mr. D'Amato, with assistance from the other New York Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat, pushed the measure through the Senate.
Months later, the provision died in a conference committee because of opposition from the White House. Domino never got the rebate, but the Brooklyn plant remains open. No jobs were lost.
Mr. D'Amato has continued to champion the sugar industry, which has given him $12,800 more in campaign contributions since 1988.
 
Reviving the Specter of Mussolini

The most dramatic television commercial of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's campaign came in two versions last week: tough and tougher.
Ten days ago, the Republican Senator's campaign began running advertisements attacking his Democratic opponent, State Attorney General Robert Abrams, for calling him "a fascist." The ad shown to the press, and broadcast initially, used a narrator speaking over pictures of news clippings about Mr. Abrams's remark.
But the campaign acknowledged yesterday that, without notice, it had also used another, visually harsher version of the same script, over silent sepia-toned footage of Benito Mussolini exhorting a crowd. The Senator's spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, said the first ad was made so quickly that the D'Amato team could not get the archival film it wanted, switched the commercials within 48 hours and simply forgot to alert reporters.
But a tape provided by the D'Amato camp shows the same production date stamped on both versions.
Ms. Mucha defended both yesterday, saying, "The only thing the ad was trying to say was where the word fascist originated from." Neither ad is on the air any longer; they have been replaced by a new ad whose tagline is: "Al D'Amato. Always fighting for us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato (John Sotomayor/The New York Times) (pg. A1)

HEADLINE: If Clinton Wants a Democratic Foreign Policy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Few would quarrel with "The Clinton Doctrine" by A. M. Rosenthal (column, Oct. 6), which welcomes Gov. Bill Clinton's commitment to a more democratic foreign policy. More troubling is the unholy mix of sanctimony and cynicism with which Mr. Rosenthal -- and Governor Clinton -- reduce an important principle to a self-serving slogan.
Stung by past charges that they were dovish on defense, Democrats are looking for a way to criticize President Bush from the right. So they accuse him of coddling Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Saddam Hussein. 
 In fact, Mr. Bush continued Ronald Reagan's policy, which they too now advocate. A little history will make clear what that is. Up to Vietnam, the United States response to third world revolutions had been largely defensive: to support regimes with our money, arms and sometimes our troops. After that debacle -- and other unfavorable developments across the third world -- we decided it would be cheaper and more effective to support counterrevolutions.
Leftist third world governments made their share of mistakes. But they also faced armed rebels that we collected in an assortment of beleaguered democrats, ardent nationalists, ethnic separatists, former Communists, religious fundamentalists and former colonialist collaborators. We sponsored wars in Afghanistan, Angola, Nicaragua, to name a few.
Presidents Reagan and Bush are hardly guilty of having propped up Mr. Gorbachev. Our massive arms buildup did much to push the Soviet Union into terminal economic crisis. When our European allies wanted to meet Soviet reform with economic aid, we blocked this. Meanwhile, through Radio Free Europe, Radio Liberty, the National Endowment for Democracy, the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations and no doubt the Central Intelligence Agency, we supported the Soviet Union's breakup. Mr. Bush's facade of caution allowed him to strike lopsided arms agreements with a declining government.
The Reagan-Bush policy deserves credit for victory and the chaos it has brought. Mr. Rosenthal supports both Russian and Baltic nationalism. He seems not to notice that they are in conflict, with the Baltics disenfranchising Russians, and the Russians threatening the Baltics. Eastern and Western Europe are now the breeding ground of ethnic strife and a growing fascist movement.
The Clinton doctrine would intensify this crusade with Radio Free Asia and Radio Free China. It isn't clear how India or China can break up peacefully or what will happen to the mosaic of minorities across that continent and the world. In greater tolerance lies the beginning of wisdom. Meanwhile we show little regard for democratic movements that challenge our financial interests -- for example, in Mexico and Brazil.
If Mr. Clinton really wants a democratic foreign policy, it will have to be more than a self-serving crusade. He will have to open American policy to true reform of the United Nations Security Council, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank so that these reflect a diversity of interests and needs, rather than a projection of United States power.
He will have to address the twin problems of the environment and development, not only for the world's rich but also for its poor. Only when we demonstrate our commitment to freedom from hunger, disease and despair will our campaign for democracy be a reality that is worthy of the name.
 
DAVID KEPPEL
Essex, Conn., Oct. 7, 1992

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Can Aid Mexico, but Not Us

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Free Trade but With Time Bombs" (editorial, Oct. 6) discusses how some of Bill Clinton's proposed modifications of the North American Free Trade Agreement may scuttle it. You say the agreement "would simultaneously propel Mexico's pro-market reforms forward and raise living standards for U.S. consumers." I think most Americans understand the benefits the agreement would bring Mexico. But it is hard to see how it would benefit us.
Cheap Mexican labor and lower manufacturing costs make it sensible for American manufacturers to move plants to Mexico. But will the Americans who thus lose their jobs be able to buy the cheaper articles produced in Mexico or even articles produced in the United States? Lower-priced Mexican-manufactured goods don't help the unemployed. 
 It would take a long time for masses of Mexicans to become sufficiently affluent to buy more United States-manufactured goods. A dozen countries have already penetrated our markets; why couldn't they do the same in Mexico and Canada? Finally, affluent Mexicans will most likely buy Mexican goods, which their good times will let them produce themselves.
 
EDWARD PEIZER
Pinehurst, N.C., Oct. 6, 1992

HEADLINE: Jobs Bond Proposal Will Assist New York

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Others have been telling us how they will improve our economy and quality of life, but New Yorkers can do it themselves with a yes vote Nov. 3 for Proposal 1, the jobs bond.
Proposal 1 will create jobs and lay the foundation for economic growth -- 24,000 immediate jobs, it is estimated, as infrastructure improvement projects proposed by local governments are undertaken under fast track procedures. Many projects could begin by the spring construction season. This work will also stimulate private development and expansion, resulting in 80,000 to 100,000 permanent private-sector jobs, adding about $10 billion to our economy. 
 At an annual cost of about $65 million, Proposal 1 will generate more than $120 million in new revenues annually for the state and localities, easing the strain on the state's budget and helping local governments meet community needs. These revenues will be used to revitalize urban areas and waterfronts, improve water quality and clean up polluted industrial sites.
 
WILLIAM H. ALLEN
New York, Oct. 8, 1992
 
The writer is senior vice president of Parsons Brinckerhoff, engineers.

HEADLINE: A Congressional Race Turns Into a Grudge Match

 BODY:
There may be no Congressional race anywhere this year that presents sharper political choices than the contest between Nita M. Lowey, a liberal incumbent Democratic Representative, and Joseph J. DioGuardi, a conservative Republican who represented the same district from 1985-88. After redistricting, the new 18th Congressional District that they both want to serve includes much of southern Westchester and a sliver of the Bronx and Queens.
The two last faced each other in 1988, when Mrs. Lowey unseated Mr. DioGuardi. That year, Mr. DioGuardi, who had defeated the liberal stalwart Bella S. Abzug in 1986, called Mrs. Lowey "Bella without a hat." Mrs. Lowey said Mr. DioGuardi was "just Dan Quayle without the good looks." The 1992 race took off from there. 
 The following are excerpts from interviews with both candidates this week by William Glaberson, a reporter for The New York Times.
 
Nita M. Lowey
 Q. Describe your opponent.
A. A far-right, radical, former failed member of Congress. Part of the Reagan-Bush failed policies.
Q. And you, he says, are among the 25 most liberal members of Congress.
A. If it means full funding of Head Start, if it means gun control, if it means criticizing China because of their atrocious human rights abuses, I'm proud of that progressive record.
Q. In 1988 you beat Mr. DioGuardi and he's here again. Some call it a grudge match. Is it?
A. It certainly is. People have rejected him. People don't want to go back to the past.
Q. Is abortion a critical issue in this race?
A. It is a defining issue because he is of the far right, most extreme position. I don't believe government should have a role in that very personal decision. I respect the rights of women to make their own choice.
Q. What is the single most important thing that needs to be done to get the economy moving again?
A.The most important thing we can do is invest in rebuilding our infrastructure. This will create jobs which will trigger economic activity in other areas. At the same time we have to continue to make tough choices to cut wasteful expenditures as I have. You have to cut and invest.
Q. Mr. DioGuardi says that in 1988 you pledged you wouldn't raise taxes. He says you voted to raise taxes at least nine, maybe 16 times. Is that your version of "Read my lips"?
A. First of all, I have never made foolish pledges of any kind because I'm dealing with reality. And we have important problems in this country that we need to address. And what we need is fairness, tax fairness, Mr. DioGuardi's record shows that he voted to raise 10 times, so again he's just talking.
Q. You're against the death penalty, but you voted for a Federal bill that includes the death penalty.
A. I voted for the crime bill, which is one of the toughest crime bills ever to come out and that did include the death penalty. I voted for it because I think it's so important that we take a strong position on getting crime off our streets.
Q. You voted against support of the Gulf war. Was that a mistake?
A. At the time I voted against the Gulf war I took the advice of seven former Secretaries of Defense. After the decison was made I supported the President, I supported the troops and I feel sad that the President didn't complete the job and remove Saddam Hussein from power. Hindsight is very easy. But at the time it was a very difficult decision and it was a vote of conscience.
Q. There is a mood in the country against negative campaigning, but this race has been marked by attacks by each side against the other. Are you proud of the way the race has been run?
A. I have presented my positive accomplishments on the economy and education and health care and crime and I'm proud of that. Mr. DioGuardi spews forth venom and rage and only wants to focus on the negative and, therefore, toward the end of the campaign I may have to refute the lies that he is giving the public.
 
Joseph J. DioGuardi
 Q. How would you describe the choices facing people in this district?
A. Joe DioGuardi is a certified public accountant, the only one ever elected in 215 years, a fiscal conservative who wants to get government off your backs and out of your pockets. Nita Lowey is a 100 percent certified public liberal.
Q. She says she is for the middle class. What is your view of what her record shows?
A. You have to see the way she comports herself. Number one, I believe she represents herself. She's a person who's got a big ego, a big pocketbook, who decided it was time to become a Congresswoman.
Q. What do you think is the major action that needs to be taken to spur the economy?
A. The Joe DioGuardi business-oriented, three-point plan: Number one: Reduce the capital gains tax to 10 percent. Next point: Not even think of raising taxes. Third: Control spending by a balanced budget amendment and a line-item veto.
Q. But Mrs. Lowey says you voted to raise taxes 10 times. Did you and would you vote to raise taxes again?
A. I would never even think of raising taxes. It's possible someone may have slipped in something. I doubt it.
Q. Do you think Mrs. Lowey made a mistake when she voted against support of the Gulf war?
A. It was a slap in the face of Israel. My record on Israel is unblemished.
Q. Mrs. Lowey says her first day of campaigning was marred by people tied to your campaign following her around and shouting on bullhorns. Her supporters call these "the DioGuardi goon squads." Are you proud of the way you have run the campaign?
A. Absolutely. But she grossly exaggerated what happened. No one put a bullhorn anywhere near her. Listen, when people want to express their First Amendment rights -- she's so proud to say that it's important to express your First Amendment rights she says you can burn the flag; she never spoke out when the Act Up group came into the Cathedral in front of the Cardinal and threw condoms on the floor along with the host. What's wrong with 30 people, constituents, joined with two of my people to show them where the district is, expressing their First Amendment rights?
Q. She said you spew forth venom and rage and that that you have presented lies to the public.
A. What is a negative campaign? Is perpetuating a lie a negative campaign or is telling the truth? I am telling the truth.
Q. You have the Right to Life line, as well as the Republican and Conservative ones. Do you think it's constructive to have the endorsement of a one-issue party?
A. While I don't believe one issue should determine a campaign, if you have constituents that feel so strongly about an issue -- as many do about this issue on both sides in this district-- then I think you want to send the signal. I believe that the word 'choice' has no place when you're talking about two lives in being. Would you use the word 'choice' for 'ethnic cleansing'?
Q. You support President Bush.
A. We can trust George Bush.

HEADLINE: LAW FAILS TO STEM ABUSE OF MIGRANTS, U.S. PANEL REPORTS

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The law Congress enacted six years ago to combat illegal immigration has done nothing to stop exploitation of migrant farm workers, one of its principal objectives, a Government-appointed, bipartisan commission has found.
The panel, charged with assessing the law's impact on agriculture, confirms earlier reports that illegal immigration continues largely unchecked. The commission attributes the problem to lax enforcement, widespread fraud and the tenacity of people, mostly Mexicans, in fleeing severe unemployment at home for jobs in the United States.
 
Little Incentive to Improve
 Congress was both tough and benign in adopting the Immigration Reform and Control Act. To stop illegal immigration, the law established sanctions against employers who hire unauthorized workers, and it granted amnesty to three million workers who could show they had worked at least 90 days in agriculture in the United States in the year ending May 1, 1986. But inadvertently, the law also gave birth to a bustling market in counterfeit documents that has undermined the objectives of the law. 
 The resulting tide of new illegal immigrants who possess phony documents and who accept substandard working conditions leaves employers with little incentive to improve those conditions. Unless a document is obviously bogus, it is evidence enough to protect an employer from the law's sanctions, ranging from a $100 fine for sloppy bookkeeping to six months in prison. Indeed, if an employer is overly cautious and demands additional proof from a worker who turns out to be legal, the employer risks being charged with discrimination.
 
Less and Less Effective
 The law's failings are most apparent in agriculture, the focus of the commission's scrutiny. The migrant and seasonal farm labor force is the easiest place for illegal immigrants to find work, and agriculture, especially labor-intensive fruit and vegetable farming, is the industry most dependent on them.
The commission's study, the most comprehensive look at the impact of the immigration law, will be submitted to Congress early next year.
The final draft of the study says that with fraud increasing the law is becoming less and less effective. Beefing up enforcement and making changes in the law can help slow the immigration.
The study proposes development of a "fraud-proof work authorization document for all persons legally authorized to work in the United States," some-
thing that civil libertarians persuaded Congress to leave out of the law on the ground that it smacked of an identity card.
To control illegal immigration, the commission urges Congress to sweep away prerogatives that exempt many farmers from providing their workers with overtime pay, housing with toilets, unemployment insurance, workers' compensation for injuries on the job and the right to form unions. Farms with less than 10 employees, the majority of all farms, also do not have to comply with Federal health and safety laws. Farmers have thus become dependent on people who will accept those conditions, primarily Central Americans.
If the exemptions were phased out, the commission says, legal workers who shun most farm jobs today would vie for the jobs and crowd out illegal immigrants.
 
Created as Concession
 Congress created the panel, the Commission on Agricultural Workers, to review the impact of the law as a concession to farming interests who feared that the immigrants granted amnesty would flock to better-paying jobs off the farm and leave them with no one to harvest crops. After five years of research, the commission has completed its work and will meet Nov. 6 for the final review of its findings.
The chairman, Henry J. Voss, who is a peach grower in California and the director of the state's Department of Food and Agriculture, said he expected little more than fine-tuning because he and the 10 other commissioners worked through their differences during the drafting process. "Our findings around the country were generally the same," Mr. Voss said. "There is a continuous stream of illegal immigrants entering the agricultural work force."
The draft, a copy of which was obtained from people close to the commission, says the law has produced none of the major benefits that lawmakers expected, especially improvements in agricultural wages and working conditions. Nor did it bring about the shortage of workers feared by fruit and vegetable growers. "Rather than stabilizing," says the draft, "the national farm labor supply is registering a pronounced surplus."
The commission's proposals will probably face wide opposition from farmers' organizations, and it is surprising in a majority of the 11 members, like Mr. Voss, are current or former farmers or leaders of farm organizations who could have something to lose from expanding Federal regulations to farm labor.
"We will be violently interested in that," said Elizabeth Whitley, assistant director for national affairs at the American Farm Bureau.
The commission found that bigger problems await the nation without vast changes in agricultural policy. Mr. Voss said illegal immigration, in creating hundreds of thousands of jobless or underemployed workers, many with families, affects all taxpayers, including farmers. "The social problems are an issue that have to be addressed," he said.
Without changes in the law, the report warns that "farm worker households of the 1990's will likely experience increasing levels of poverty and economic stress" and that "if present trends continue, by the turn of the century, a very substantial portion of the overall U.S. farm labor force is likely to again be unauthorized."
No one really knows how many illegal immigrants are working in the country. The commission estimates that 2.5 million laborers, most of them immigrants, work on the nation's farms. Under the amnesty program, three million people were granted residency permits, and uncounted others who never sought or received amnesty continue to work in the fields. How many more have come into the country illegally since then, or where they have gone to work, is incalculable.
One gauge of the law's failings is the number of apprehensions of people trying to cross the 2,000-mile Mexican-American border. Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said apprehensions of illegal immigrants plunged to 853,000 in 1989 from 1.6 million in the 1986 fiscal year, just before the law was enacted. But he said they had been rising since then, to an estimated 1.2 million in the 1992 fiscal year. The number of border agents has changed little in that time, he said.
Congress established the amnesty program largely to placate agricultural employers who feared losing their pool of immigrant labor. It also established a program to permit farmers to recruit more foreign workers if the newly legalized workers fled farms to better jobs. The farm labor pool is bigger than ever, however, and no farmer has had to resort to the recruiting program, the report says.
The commission says few workers granted amnesty have left agriculture because of a lack of skills, language difficulties and the recession in the United States. And the workers are no better off. "Since the mid-1980's," it says, "hired farm workers' living and working conditions have generally not improved."
With increases in the Federal minimum wage to the current $4.25 from $3.35 an hour, when the law was enacted, the average farm worker's wage reached $5.57 an hour last year. But after taking account of inflation, it declined 2 percent from 1986 to 1991.
A consequence of the surplus of labor is that immigrants, legal and illegal, get less work than they want. "In most areas," the report says, "an increasing number of newly arriving, unauthorized workers compete for available jobs, reducing the number of hours available to and contributing to lower annual earnings for all workers."
Said Daniel Stein, executive director of the Federation for American Immigration Reform, which wants to limit all immigration to the rate of growth of the American population, or to about 300,000 people a year. "Illegal immigration has destroyed the incentive to provide decent wages, housing and working conditions."
At the root of the failure of the law is the fraudulent-document industry, people who make birth certificates, resident alien cards, Social Security cards, driver's licenses and other documents to show employers that the immigrants are authorized to work in the United States.
"Supplying fraudulent work-authorizing documents has now become a thriving business," the commission's draft says.
Senator Alan K. Simpson, the Wyoming Republican who was one of the law's principal authors, said he had been skeptical about whether the law could work because of the concessions it made to farmers, like the amnesty program and the decision not to require a fraud-proof driver's license or other identification document because they would threaten workers' privacy.
Mr. Simpson said he had not seen the commission's draft report. But he said: "Employer sanctions really don't function correctly unless you do something about fraudulent documents."
President Reagan appointed six commission members members, including Mr. Voss. The Speaker of the House appointed three, and the President pro tem of the Senate appointed three. In addition to Mr. Voss the commissioners are Richard B. Abell, an Assistant Attorney General in the Reagan Administration; Lloyd W. Aubry Jr., director of the California Department of Industrial Relations; Michael V. Durando, president of the California Grape and Fruit League; Ben M. Gramling 2d, a South Carolina peach grower; Delores Huerta, co-founder and first vice president of the United Farm Workers.
Also, Roger M. Mahony, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles; Phillip L. Martin, agricultural economist at the University of California at Davis; Russell Pitzer, a West Virginia fruit grower; George Sorn, executive vice president of the Florida Fruit and Vegetable Association, and Russell L. Williams, president of Agricultural Producers of California. A 12th member, Othal E. Brand, the Republican Mayor of McAllen, Tex., resigned.
