HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: House Race;
Colorado's Test for the Religious Right

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARVADA, Colo., Oct. 20

 BODY:
The political power of the religious right, demonstrated this summer in its control of the Republican Party platform, will be tested soon in an otherwise obscure Congressional race here.
Without help, Bryan Day, an inexperienced and underfinanced Republican challenger, would hardly stand a chance against Representative David E. Skaggs, a three-term Democrat, even though Mr. Skaggs had 57 overdrafts at the House bank. 
 Mr. Skaggs, known in the House as a hard worker on matters like supporting abortion rights and opposing the space station, also has a record of involvement in issues important locally, like the Rocky Flats nuclear plant and a new airport in Denver. He expects to spend $500,000 on his campaign, while Mr. Day estimates his spending will reach only $150,000.
 
Little for Congress to Do
 But Mr. Day, a 34-year-old Baptist minister here, whose campaign emphasizes reducing the deficit, Constitutional amendments requiring a balanced budget, allowing a line item veto and limiting Congressional terms, can count on help because of the abortion issue he rarely brings up.
He said in an interview that he will vote "pro life" when he can, but contends that Congress will have little to do on the subject since he expects the Supreme Court to reverse Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court that legalized a woman's right to abortion, and leave the issue up to the states.
He hardly has to mention the issue. The Rev. Pat Robertson's group, the Christian Coalition, plans to mail out thousands of voter's guides showing Mr. Day as preferable to Mr. Skaggs, whom the organization has labeled "a foe of the family." More copies will be distributed through local churches.
Possibly more important will be the efforts of at least one group from Colorado's burgeoning list of "family values" organizations, Citizens for Responsible Government, an ally of the Christian Coalition but with more freedom because it does not enjoy tax-exempt status. "We'll be doing a flyer distribution at the churches" two days before Election Day, said Leslie Hanks, the group's executive director. The flyer will show a 10-week-old fetus and urge support for Mr. Day.
Since the Houston convention, many Republicans have worried about being tied too closely to the politics of Pat Robertson and other evangelical crusaders for family values. But here in Colorado, the embrace is welcomed.
 
Praise for Religious Right
 "As far as I am concerned, they can say what they want to about the religious right," said Bruce Benson, the state's Republican chairman. "The religious right works harder than anybody in the world. They will turn out."
Mr. Day can also count on from $30,000 to $50,000 from the National Republican Congressional Committee, enabling him to broadcast his commercials on the major television stations as well as the less-expensive cable channels, where they now appear. Mr. Skaggs has already invested heavily in local television commercials.
Mr. Skaggs raised the issue of Mr. Day's backers late last month at a news conference on the steps of the State Capitol. He accused Mr. Robertson and Mr. Day of wanting to "impose their own religious views on everybody else." Mr. Skaggs cited documents prepared by Robertson aides to their followers to conduct "stealth" campaigns that cloak extremist views on issues like abortion behind mainstream concerns like the deficit, and said that was the kind of campaign Mr. Day was running.
Mr. Day says no one recruited him to run, but that he just decided it was time that someone took on the liberal incumbent. Moreover, Mr. Day, the pastor of the very informal Foothills Community Church here, accuses Mr. Skaggs of "attacking my religion." He said that with the news conference at the State Capitol, Mr. Skaggs "has taken the first step down the road that Hitler took."
 
Talking About Fiscal Messes
 In calmer moments, the Third District's candidates talk about the economy. Mr. Day says he wants to do something about the "financial mess we're in," noting that Constitutional amendments on the balanced budget and the line-item veto are essential because "Congress has proved to the American people it cannot reduce the deficit."
The 49-year-old Mr. Skaggs described his approach as "fundamentally the Clinton message," emphasizing education, private investment and rebuilding the nation's roads and bridges.His television ads portray him as a friend of tax cuts for the middle class. The Marine veteran talks about his votes, including his opposition to a Constitutional amendment prohibiting flag-burning, proposed by President Bush and defeated in the House.
In the end, what may prove decisive for him is the chief issue that motivated organizations to oppose him: abortion. He insists that the district strongly favors abortion rights, and this week he broadcast two television ads that say "women should be given freedom of choice," while Mr. Day "wants to outlaw abortions even in cases of rape and incest."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Democrats File Complaint
 WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Democratic Party filed a complaint today, accusing a group founded by the religious broadcaster Pat Robertson of engaging in illegal political activity.
The complaint to the Federal Election Commission said the Christian Coalition was raising money as a tax-exempt group but spending it on pro-Republican activities.
The coalition insisted it does not need to register, because it does not endorse parties or candidates but merely educates its members.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues -- Education;
Rivals Agree on Need for National School Standards but Differ on U.S. Role

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
In a campaign in which education continues to get lost someplace between the economy and character, the real question is not so much how candidates differ on the issues but how much education will matter in their Presidencies.
Broad philosophical differences do divide the candidates and shape their education policies. But it is striking just how much President Bush, Gov. Bill Clinton and Ross Perot agree about what ails American schools and how to fix them. 
 All three candidates endorse the idea, untried in American education, of formal national curriculum standards outlining what American students should be expected to know. All want some national testing system to check whether students know these things and how well their schools are teaching them.
They all say they would pay more for preschool programs like Head Start. They all believe that hiring and keeping better-qualified teachers means opening teaching to people without standard teaching degrees and paying more money to better teachers or those being lured from higher-salaried fields like science or mathematics. All three candidates want to give more power to principals and teachers and less to central bureaucracies. President Bush and Governor Clinton have both proposed linking high school and work through an apprenticeship program for students not planning to go to college.
 
Philosophy
How Big a Role For Washington?
 Yet important differences remain among the candidates. "Clinton is more of a believer in proactive government than Bush, who believes in privatism and market forces," said Michael D. Usdan, president of the Institute for Educational Leadership, a Washington-based group. "Clinton is much more supportive of investing in preventive strategies."
As befits a Republican, President Bush minimizes the role that the Federal Government can play in transforming American schools and turns instead to the free market. His education strategy relies not on money or Federal programs but primarily on an appeal to local communities, parents and businesses. These "consumers" of education must force changes that insiders like teachers and bureaucrats have stymied, the President's advisers argue.
This conviction that only competition will improve schools is the reason the President is pushing so hard for vouchers that would allow parents to take the tax money they otherwise would have paid for public schools and spend it on private or parochial school tuition instead. There is little evidence so far that such private school choice would improve schools, because only one small-scale experiment is under way, in Milwaukee.
As befits a Democrat, Governor Clinton sees a much larger education role for the Federal Government, with Washington providing more money, programs and leadership. His wife, Hillary, has worked extensively with children's advocacy organizations, and both Clintons place much more emphasis on the links between education and poverty, prenatal care, children's health and preschool programs. Governor Clinton argues that alienating the very education insiders who would implement changes would doom real reform.
And he dismisses the free-market model, saying that using vouchers would amount to using public money for private schools. He and other critics fear that vouchers would skim off the best students with the savviest parents for private schools, leaving the public schools with handicapped, disruptive or neglected students.
 
The Eclectic Perot
 Mr. Perot is, as usual, eclectic, guardedly endorsing at least a pilot version of a voucher plan beloved to conservatives but also promising to give even more money to preschools than Governor Clinton.
Educators have traditionally judged politicians by how much money they give to schools. All three candidates say money alone will not solve problems.
But of the three, Governor Clinton has pledged to spend the most money on education -- $63 billion in new money over the next four years, primarily for a new college loan program, full financing of Head Start and an apprenticeship program that would link high school students to jobs.
Although Mr. Perot has provided sketchy figures, his plan calls for $12 billion in new spending over the next four years. Most of the money would pay for a vastly expanded Head Start program.
Mr. Bush has repeatedly said that more money will not fix schools, and his education strategy does not offer much -- $690 million last year and $768 million this year. But education spending increased by 22 percent after inflation during his term. Head Start received the largest increases in its 25-year history, in part because Congress in most cases appropriated even more money than the President had asked for.
 
Proposals
Loans for College Draw Attention
 Of all the proposals, the one that has most caught the public imagination has been Governor Clinton's college loan plan. He would offer loans to students regardless of their income and let them repay them either as a percentage of their income or through national service. But details have been scarce, and the plan is more restricted than Mr. Clinton's brief descriptions suggest.
Many middle-class families earn too much to qualify for government-subsidized loans, but still cannot afford tuition. Although a new bill Congress passed this summer expanded size and availability of loans for middle-class families, Mr. Clinton's plan goes further. Loans would be collected by the Internal Revenue Service, cutting back on defaults. Because students could pay back loans as a percentage of their income, they would be freer to choose lower-paying jobs and might be less likely to default. Or students could choose national service jobs like teaching or policing, with small stipends paid by the Government.
Mr. Clinton estimates this plan would cost about $8 billion a year. Although he does not say so on the campaign trail, his policy advisers say he would limit the number of national service jobs available to keep costs down. But tuition experts say the costs might well be far higher.
Mr. Bush has also proposed expanding college loans, but White House estimates suggest his plan would increase loans by only about 2 percent a year.
The array of proposals leaves some important issues unaddressed. None of the candidates has proposed any measures to combat the huge gaps in education spending between rich and poor school districts. No one has discussed school desegregation, traditionally a responsibility of the Federal Government. No one has raised the question of why good programs seem to exist in individual schools but seldom spread throughout entire school systems.
 
Achievements
What the Rivals Can Point To
 More than offering any one proposal, however, each candidate needs to convince voters that he will actually do something to make schools better.
As with domestic policy over all, President Bush has been on the defensive about his record in education. Second only to the quips about "read my lips: no new taxes" come those twitting him about his 1988 promise to be "the education President."
Yet Mr. Bush claims education as his proudest domestic accomplishment. Even his critics praise several moves: an "education summit" in 1989 in which he and the nation's governors established six national goals for education; the appointment as Education Secretary of Lamar Alexander, a former Governor of Tennessee active in the drive to improve schools; several planks of an education strategy announced in April 1991.
Many educators endorsed Mr. Bush's call for national curriculum standards, national tests, parental responsibility and local community action to change schools. And while many educators dismissed the idea of creating entirely different "New American Schools," many now say a competition to design some has produced valuable ideas.
So far, Mr. Bush's plan has produced few tangible results. His defenders say that the most important accomplishment -- the creation of 1,700 communities across the country that have pledged to change their local schools and are supposed to be working on plans to do so -- is taking place outside Washington, invisible to pundits and education lobbyists.
But even those who endorse the President's conservative agenda say he has not done enough to push his plans through Congress or take his case to the public.
Of the three candidates, Governor Clinton has the deepest and most sustained involvement in education, both in Arkansas, where he has worked to improve schools, and on a national level, where he led the National Governors' Association's education efforts in the late 1980's.
Governor Clinton helped to bring about many sweeping changes in Arkansas's schools, including expanding preschool for poor children, raising academic standards, lowering dropout rates, requiring competency testing for teachers and encouraging greater college attendance. Arkansas now spends more of its budget on education than all but two other states. But like many other education policies undertaken in the 1980's, including Mr. Perot's drive as head of a state select committee to improve Texas's schools, Governor Clinton's policies have wrought modest, not dramatic, improvements in student achievement.
President Bush's surrogates charge that Governor Clinton, who has been endorsed by the two leading teachers' unions, is so beholden to education insiders that he would not make the necessary radical changes. Mr. Clinton's defenders point out that his endorsement of competency testing for teachers in Arkansas infuriated teachers' unions.
For Mr. Perot, education is one of the few areas where he can actually point to a record. With a skillful mix of money, lobbying and sound bites, he led a drive that in 1984 resulted in one of the most sweeping education laws in Texas history, paid for by its first state tax increase in 13 years.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "CANDIDATES ON THE ISSUES: Prescription For Education"
 
THE RECORDS
President Bush has won praise for his appointment of Lamar Alexander as Secretary of Education and several parts of his education strategy, including calls for parental responsibility and local community action. But he can point to few tangible results that have actually improved schools. Critics say he has not spent enough money for education and has failed to push his plans hard enough.
Gov. Bill Clinton pushed through sweeping changes in Arkansas's schools, including spending more money, expanding preschool, raising academic standards and slowing dropout rates. Despite these improvements, student results have showed only modest gains, and Arkansas's schools still lag behind those of many other states.
Ross Perot led a tough fight to improve schools and redistribute education spending in Texas, enacting measures similar to Mr. Clinton's, but Texas schools also show only incremental progress.
 
THE PROPOSALS
The three candidates agree on many proposals, including national curriculum standards, national tests and giving teachers more freedom. Mr. Clinton sees a stronger role for the Federal Government and emphasizes the links between education, preschool and women's and children's health. Mr. Bush says schools would improve through competition and endorses vouchers allowing parents to spend public money on private schools.
 
THE SCORECARD
Mr. Clinton has the most hands-on knowledge about education. But none of the candidates' programs have produced enormous leaps in student performance to date. Much of the argument remains theoretical -- whether a stronger Federal role, more money, or competition are the keys to improving education.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Turbulent Session Ends Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices ended marginally lower yesterday in a turbulent session influenced by stronger-than-expected economic statistics and some questionable trades in the Chicago futures market.
"It's been a volatile day, what with the data and the ruckus in Chicago," said Steve Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond ended down 7/32 point, or $2.19 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, was 7.61 percent, up from 7.60 percent late Wednesday.
Bonds fell early in the day after the Labor Department reported that the number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits fell to 368,000 in early October, the lowest level in more than two years. The decline of 15,000 claims in the week that ended on Oct. 10 was the third straight drop, and some experts believe the unemployment rate should decline if claims remain below 400,000.
 
Surprise to Market
 The report surprised the credit markets, which expected an increase of 15,000 in applications for unemployment insurance. Higher unemployment increases the chances the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates to stimulate the economy, a move that increases bond prices.
The market was also whipsawed by what traders called possibly improper transactions in the Chicago futures pits and an unusual intervention in the market by the Chicago Board of Trade to correct them.
Traders and analysts said someone who might not have had proper trading credentials made a series of large trades in Treasury bond futures that sent the market sharply lower. The transactions caused bond prices to plunge about a point.
Traders said the Board of Trade intervened, helping bond prices retrace their losses in the early afternoon.
Bond prices resumed falling late in the day, after the Government reported a much larger-than-expected growth in money supply, signaling that the economy might be more robust than bond traders believed.
Traders and analysts said the market was facing two big problems right now. One is a fear that Bill Clinton will be elected President and stimulate the economy through higher spending, which the market considers inflationary.
The other is the prospect of oversupply. The Treasury is auctioning 2-year and 5-year securities next week. It is expected to issue about $37 billion of 3-year, 10-year and 30-year securities next month.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term maturities fell between 3/32 and 1/8 point and intermediate maturities fell between 5/32 and 1/4 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point equals a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all Treasury issues outstanding with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.83 to 1254.69.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 2.98 percent as the discount rose 2 basis points, to 2.93 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 3.26 percent as the discount rose 3 basis points, to 3.17 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 3.48 percent as the discount rose 4 basis points, to 3.35 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, rose to 3 percent, up from 215/16 percent late Wednesday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 9415/16 , down 7/32 point. The average yield to maturity was 6.58 percent, up from 6.56 percent late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Dow Chemical Net Plunges

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: MIDLAND, Mich., Oct. 22

 BODY:
The Dow Chemical Company said today that third-quarter net income plunged 35 percent because of higher interest expenses and taxes and a sluggish economy.
Net income dropped to $145 million, or 53 cents a share, from $223 million, or 82 cents, a year earlier. Earnings were eroded by a $46 million rise in interest expenses and currency-exchange charges. Sales rose 6 percent, to $4.8 billion from $4.5 billion. 
 Analysts pointed to prices depressed by a sluggish economy and a worldwide overcapacity of ethylene, which is used to make everything from antifreeze to plastics.
"This combination of a sluggish recovery in the U.S. economy, a severe slowdown in Europe and weak industry fundamentals globally have denied us the pricing flexibility to restore profit margins in basic chemicals and plastics," Enrique C. Falla, executive vice president, said.
Dow shares rose 50 cents today, closing at $54.75.
Operating income, or earnings before interest, taxes and extraordinary gains or losses, rose 9 percent, to $446 million from $410 million.
Third-quarter pharmaceutical sales increased 17 percent, while chemicals rose 5 percent, led by chlorine-based products.
Plastics sales edged up 4 percent, consumer specialty chemical sales gained 10 percent and consumer product sales rose 1 percent. Sales of agricultural products were flat, the company said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
3 Oil Companies Post Mixed Results

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
Three oil companies reported mixed quarterly results yesterday.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said earnings declined 64.3 percent and Ashland Oil Inc. posted a $103 million loss. But the Amerada Hess Corporation said it earned $8.7 million, in contrast to a loss of $7.5 million in the 1991 quarter. 
 The companies in many ways are atypical of the oil industry, which analysts generally expect to report higher earnings for the third quarter. On Wednesday, Texaco Inc., citing costs related to Hurricane Andrew, said its profit slipped 5.9 percent, while Amoco's income rose 61 percent.
Occidental is dominated by its chemicals unit, which suffered from weak demand. Ashland Oil and Amerada Hess are large refiners in the East, where prices and demand have been weak, but Amerada improved because of higher profits in oil-and-gas production.
Paul Mlotok, an oil industry analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said rising prices for natural gas and crude oil during the quarter hurt profit margins in chemicals and refining because both fuels are used as feedstocks in chemical and petroleum refining. "That was an industrywide problem," he said.
Following are details from the companies' earnings reports:
Occidental
 
 
 Net third-quarter income was $61 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with $171 million, or 56 cents a share, in the 1991 quarter. Sales were flat, at $2.3 billion.
Excluding special items, income for the Los Angeles-based company declined 55.3 percent.
"Chemical earnings continue to be adversely affected by worldwide economic conditions," said Ray R. Irani, chairman and chief executive.
Earnings for the chemicals unit fell to $31 million, from $79 million in the year-earlier period before a restructuring charge of $260 million and an $80 million charge for costs to meet environmental standards. Sales for the unit, at $1.08 billion, amounted to 47 percent of the company's total sales.
Occidental's natural-gas pipeline unit posted profits of $97 million, up from $56 million. The gain included the reduction of a legal reserve amounting to $55 million before taxes. Profit in oil-and-gas operations rose to $81 million, from $57 million, excluding a special charge a year earlier.
Occidental's share price fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $16.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Ashland Oil
 
 
 The fiscal fourth-quarter loss of $103 million was in contrast to a profit of $63 million, or $1.07 a share, in the quarter last year. Sales rose 3.7 percent, to $2.8 billion from $2.7 billion.
The loss for Ashland Oil, one of the nation's largest independent refiners, was mainly related to the adoption of a change in accounting for the cost ofretiree health-care benefits. Ashland restated its results for the four quarters of its 1992 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, to reflect equal amounts of the special $291 million charge.
For the year, the company lost $336 million, in contrast to a profit of $145 million, or $2.66 a share, in the 1991 fiscal year. Revenues rose to $10.2 billion, from $9.9 billion.
"Fiscal 1992 was a difficult year," said John R. Hall, chairman and chief executive. "We believe a refining industry shakeout is inevitable."
Ashland Oil's share price fell 50 cents, to $25.50.
Amerada Hess
 
 
 Net income was $8.7 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with a loss of $7.5 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 6.8 percent, to $1.42 billion from $1.33 billion.
Profits from exploration and production carried the New York-based company in the quarter. The unit earned $32.2 million, compared with $20.8 million a year earlier. Refining and marketing lost $7.8 million, or more than double the loss of $3.8 million in the period last year.
Capital spending declined to $400 million in the quarter, from $481.5 million in the period a year earlier.
Amerada Hess's share price was unchanged, at $50.25.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: If I Were Defense Secretary . . .;
An Essay Contest On the Peace Dividend

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Peace contractors might never earn as much as military contractors, but a group of economists hopes to spread the rewards a bit more evenly. Economists Allied for Arms Reduction, an international group based in New York, is pledging $25,000 for the best essay on how to convert from a military economy to a peacetime economy.
The organization hopes to prompt more thought about how Pentagon cutbacks can actually further economic growth, countering those who marshal economic arguments against a leaner military. Considering the context, the prize money may not seem much of a motivator. That $25,000 might not buy more than a few wrenches or toilet seats. 
 Still, the economists are hoping that the word processor proves mightier than the Washington lobbyist. To publicize the awards at a Washington news conference today, they plan to deploy Oscar Arias Sanchez, the former President of Costa Rica; John Kenneth Galbraith, a Harvard professor emeritus, and Robert Solow, a Nobel-prize-winning economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Prof. Galbraith said he hoped to change what he said was the conventional wisdom the news media report about military spending. "It's well recognized that Government expenditures for the poor, for the South Bronx, are a heavy burden," he said, in characterizing these media reports. "When you get to the military, it ceases to be a burden."
In fact, he said, a dollar spent on civilian production creates more jobs than a dollar spent on the military.
Second prize will be $5,000, with 10 runners-up receiving $1,000 each. The deadline is March 1.
Those wanting to enter can write to Essay Contest, ECAAR, 70 West 40th Street, Fourth Floor, New York, N.Y. 10018.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Drop For 3d Time

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell to 368,000 in early October, the lowest level in more than two years, the Government reported today.
The Labor Department said the decline of 15,000 during the week that ended on Oct. 10 was the third straight drop. Many analysts had predicted a 15,000 increase in applications for unemployment insurance. 
 The previous low was 367,000 during the week ended Aug. 11, 1990.
Some analysts believe the unemployment rate should decline if claims remain below 400,000. The rate was 7.5 percent in September.
 
Enthusiastic Response
 A report by economists at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York called the decline "a potential sign that the labor markets may finally be improving."
"Even though there is a very loose relationship between these data and the monthly employment statistics, the data are clearly pointing in the direction of improvement," the report said.
Secretary of Labor Lynn Martin said the report "indicates a much improved labor market."
After rising to 424,000 during the week ended Sept. 19, claims fell to 399,000 the following week and to 383,000 a week later.
But the Labor Department cautioned that recent claims numbers were being held down by some claimants using a special emergency unemployment program that is not counted in the weekly release.
 
4-Week Average
 Because of the volatility of the weekly claims, many analysts prefer to track a four-week moving average that smooths out the erratic changes and is considered a more reliable indicator of the labor situation.
The average was 393,500 during the period ended Oct. 10, down from 405,000 a week earlier and the lowest since 390,500 during the period that ended on Sept. 5.
Despite the overall decline, 44 states and territories registered increases in claims, while 9 posted declines. The national figures are adjusted for seasonal variations, but the individual state figures are not.
States reporting the largest increases in new claims were Pennsylvania, with 3,439; New Jersey, with 2,286; New York, with 2,271; Texas, with 2,250, and Washington, with 2,074.
States recording the largest decreases in claims were California, with 3,584; Kentucky, with 2,943; North Carolina, with 2,508, and Hawaii, with 1,290.

HEADLINE: Profits Posted At Caterpillar

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 23

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. reported today that it earned $23 million in the third quarter, breaking a series of six losing quarters.
The manufacturer of tractors and other heavy construction equipment cited improved sales and higher prices for the turnaround. 
 The profit of 23 cents a share was in contrast to a loss of $37 million in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 14 percent, to $2.68 billion from $2.36 billion.
"It's an improved quarter but we aren't celebrating," a spokesman said. "Certainly, $23 million is not much to write home about."
The spokesman said the quarter included sales deferred from earlier in the year as customers waited out a 163-day strike by the United Auto Workers union. He added that the company expected the fourth quarter to be "marginally profitable."
The company said its 1993 outlook depends on the strength of the economic recovery in North America and the timing of the recovery in Europe. During the six unprofitable quarters, Caterpillar's losses totaled $589 million.
Caterpillar's shares gained 62.5 cents today on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $53.50.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls as Early Bounce From Jobless Report Fizzles

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against most leading currencies after receiving a short-lived bounce on news of a drop in the number of new claims for jobless benefits.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $343.10 an ounce, down $1 from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $1.35 an ounce, to a late bid price of $342.40. 
 The dollar moved in a very narrow range with little news to push it significantly in either direction, said Curtis Perkins, a currency trader at Chemical Bank in New York.
The currency rose after the release of a Labor Department report saying the number of new claims for jobless benefits shrank in early October for the third straight week, retreating to the lowest level in more than two years. But since the statistic is considered a volatile one, economists were wary about whether the report showed any real improvement in the job market.
 
Awaiting Election
 "The jobless numbers did not have much of an effect besides a little movment to the upside from the knee-jerk explanations of what the figures mean," Mr. Perkins said. "As we waited for more information, it faded from our thoughts and the dollar went down."
Traders and investors are also waiting for the outcome of the Presidential election before making any bold moves in the currency markets, Mr. Perkins said.
In New York, the dollar settled at 120.73 Japanese yen, down from 122.60 late Wednesday. Earlier in London, the dollar fell to 120.55 yen. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 122.36 yen from 122.38 yen at Wednesday's close.
At the close in New York, the pound fetched $1.6260, up from $1.6067 late Wednesday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6230 from $1.6140 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5080 German marks, down from 1.5195; 1.3460 Swiss francs, down from 1.3575; 5.1170 French francs, down from 5.1575; 1,325.50 Italian lire, down from 1,335.00; and 1.24175 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2398.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday: 1.5080 German marks, up from 1.5075; 1.3475 Swiss francs, down from 1.3480; 5.1150 French francs, down from 5.1186; 1.6965 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6975; 1,323.50 Italian lire, down from 1,329.75; 1.2423 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2378.

HEADLINE: Dun Net Rose 11% in Quarter

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's third-quarter profit rose 11 percent, led by double-digit revenue growth in its financial and marketing information divisions.
The company, which produces the Nielsen television audience ratings and Moody's debt ratings, said Wednesday that it earned $150 million, or 84 cents a share, compared with $135.3 million, or 76 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue for the quarter rose 8.1 percent, to $1.19 billion from $1.1 billion. 
 Operating earnings rose 4 percent, reflecting the impact of weak economic conditions on its directory information services business.
Operating revenue fell 12 percent in that division, while it rose 34 percent in the financial information services unit that includes Moody's and 12 percent in marketing information services, which includes Nielsen.
Dun & Bradstreet shares fell 25 cents, to $57.75, in New York Stock Exchange composite trading Wednesday, and they were unchanged yesterday.

HEADLINE: Review/Concert;
A Scaled-Back Visit From the Old World

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
Expectations were high in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. The La Scala Orchestra and Chorus was in town for the first time since 1976. This visit, meant to commemorate Columbus's exploratory voyage, was to have been part of a full-scale national tour by the Milanese opera company, including four fully staged opera productions here in New York. It was meant to be an offering for the New World from the Old, by an institution at the center of the Italian operatic tradition.
But economic problems and changes in the Italian Government (which picked up the tab for the tour), threw the plans into disarray. The proposed tour of a half-dozen cities shrank to one, and the stagings were jettisoned. What was left when the checks cleared were two performances of Verdi's Requiem (the second will be tonight at Carnegie Hall), conducted by the company's music director, Riccardo Muti. Though Mr. Muti has been heard quite often here in recent years, he left his post as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra last season; this was the first time he was heard in New York leading the La Scala company. 
 There were aspects of this performance that repaid expectations. The 256 musicians onstage had a warm affection for this extraordinary composition. The Verdi Requiem, an operatic portrait of the soul facing the terrors of imminent death, has an unambiguous sincerity; its lyricism is not a matter of display or artifice. And the players treated the work with fervent dedication. There was a sort of golden hue to the tone of the orchestra and chorus coming from the familiarity of long acquaintance. On occasion, as when Mr. Muti pulled out the stops for Verdian triple fortes, the effect could be thrilling. There was no strain; the volume seemed to derive from a natural expression of passion.
This was achieved despite the fact that in exposed sections the orchestra's playing was not up to the best quality of international ensembles, and the chorus did not always articulate the Latin as crisply as it might have.
As for Mr. Muti, he tended to come to life primarily when the music was dynamically explosive. The Tuba Mirum was exuberantly loud; the offstage trumpets were in the third balcony and spread "wondrous sound" (as the text has it) through the hall. Other moments tended to get lost; the pianissimo passages had little sense of portent. The hints of mystery that began the piece never returned. The music was generally static, almost immovable. It was as if the conductor wanted a monumental performance rather than a touching one.
There were also times when the almost elemental quality of the music was taken for granted. Any interpretation of Verdi's Requiem must make dramatic sense of sudden shifts from fortissimo to pianissimo in a single bar, of blocks of a cappella singing alternating with outbursts of orchestral energy, of fury and fear shifting to melodic compassion. I didn't hear that on Wednesday: Mr. Muti tended to move from moment to moment, as if each could care for itself.
The performance might have also been helped by more compelling soloists. Among the Old World soloists, the soprano Maria Dragoni has an attractive instrument, but it was undercut at times by her swoops into phrases and her attempts to give lines emotional power by making them throb. The mezzo, Luciana D'Intino was less demonstrative, but lacked sufficient personality to give her solos urgency. The New World soloists, too, were less than satisfying. The tenor Richard Leech phrased well and produced his B flats with ease, but his emphasis was more on projection than introspection. Even the usually commanding Samuel Ramey tended toward the stentorian.
Wednesday's concert was greeted with audience acclaim, but at least for this listener, the strong relationship between the company and its native repertory was evident only on the surface. It suggested that another tour might be more satisfactory: a pilgrimage to hear La Scala at La Scala.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
I Shall Not Return, the Giants' Moore Declares

BYLINE: By JENNIFER FREY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 22

 BODY:
This should not come as a surprise. Another Giant is unhappy. Another Giant has harsh words about the coaching staff. And this Giant -- right guard Eric Moore -- has decided that he wants out.
Today, Moore, a five-year veteran lineman, told reporters that he will not be wearing a Giants uniform next season. He doesn't care if he has another year remaining on his contract. He's not coming back. 
 "No matter what, at the end of the season, I'm leaving," Moore said. "I will not return to the Giants. I will not."
"In my eyes, I feel that Wellington Mara and the Maras and George Young and Harry Hulmes -- I think they've been very fair to me," Moore added later, speaking of part of the Giant ownership and of upper-level management. "I just feel that after you drop below that level, I've always been kicked in the rear end around here and I'm just tired of it. I feel like it's time to go somewhere else."
The 27-year-old Moore, who signed a two-year contract worth $1.45 million on Sept. 7, said he informed both Coach Ray Handley and General Manager George Young of his unhappiness last summer and had requested a trade before the deadline passed on Oct. 13.
If the Giants do not trade him after this season, Moore will be forced to sit out the final year of his Giants' contract -- unpaid -- before he can look elsewhere for a job. Young indicated today that his respect for Moore as a player would lead him to try to trade Moore after the season, but the possibility of being unemployed next season didn't seem to upset Moore that much.
"When you're employed, if you're not happy with your employer, basically, you want to find another job," Moore said. "That's just the situation I find myself in. I have to find another job. If I have to sit for a year and then my contract expires, so be it, and I'll just look for employment after that."
Moore's announcement came one day after the Giants released veteran defensive back Everson Walls, who had often expressed unhappiness with his situation this season, and a few weeks following Lawrence Taylor's decision to call this season his final one.
Moore said that he had been miserable for his entire five years with the Giants, and that he did not want to be "in this atmosphere" any longer.
"Not everybody's going to be happy with his role," Handley said in response to Moore's statements. "I can't do anything about that."
Handley said today that he still planned to start Moore this Sunday and that Moore "had better be" as effective as he would have been had he not made the decision to leave. Moore promised that he would play to the best of his ability for the remainder of the year.
"I think he's been like a lot of the other linemen," Handley said. "He hasn't been as consistent as I'd like him to be. He's one of that group."
Moore took a great deal of grief from both reporters and the Giants organization for his failure to enter the game during a goal-line play against the Raiders three weeks ago, forcing the Giants to call a timeout in what eventually turned into a partially botched drive. The Giants kicked a field goal instead of getting a touchdown and went on to lose the game by 3 points.
Last Sunday, in Los Angeles, Moore was seen having a heated argument with offensive line coach Fred Hoaglin on the sideline after he was pulled from the game in the fourth quarter for missing a block on his man on a play.
"I don't like talking negative about my teammates because I think we have a good situation around here," Moore said. "But I just gave up one big play, a big hit on the quarterback, and I felt I shouldn't have been pulled from the game being that he had probably four or five big hits on him that day."
"But that's not what made me mad at Fred Hoaglin," Moore continued. "It was his sarcasm, that he kept saying things after the decision was made to pull me out of the game."
Hoaglin refused to comment on his discussion with Moore.
 
EXTRA POINTS
 The players hustled out of practice Thursday to avoid traffic tie-ups caused by the arrival of PRESIDENT BUSH, via helicopter, in the Meadowlands parking lot late in the afternoon. . . . The former Giants coach BILL PARCELLS made his first visit to Giants Stadium as a television commentator Thursday, meeting with Coach RAY HANDLEY after practice regarding NBC's coverage of this Sunday's Giants-Seahawks game. Handley, who also spoke with Parcells in the morning, has this to say of the man he succeeded as coach: "Bill and I are good friends now. We have been friends for a long time. We are friends now, and we'll be good friends long after this is over."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Who Said What and What They Said

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Familiar Quotations
A Collection of Passages, Phrases and Proverbs Traced to Their Sources in Ancient and Modern Literature
16th Edition
By John Bartlett
Justin Kaplan, general editor. 1,405 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $40.
 
The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations
Fourth Edition
Edited by Angela Partington. 1,061 pages.
Oxford University Press. $35.
 
The New York Public Library Book of 20th-Century American Quotations
Edited by Stephen Donadio, Joan Smith, Susan Mesner and Rebecca Davison. 622 pages. Stonesong Press/Warner Books.
$24.95.
 It's too soon to guess which one-liners will become part of our national memory after the 1992 Presidential campaign. Meantime, the newly revised 16th edition of Bartlett's Familiar Quotations is filled with enough political wisdom to please even the most professional speech writer and spin meister. Justin Kaplan, the biographer of Walt Whitman and Mark Twain, has performed a service for students of language and literature by bringing Bartlett's up to date for almost the rest of the 20th century.
As general editor, he has shaken up good old Bartlett's (the first edition came out in 1855) and let its "self-evident propositions, ceremonial boilerplate, gassy platitudes and fortune-cookie sentiments" fall out. While retaining material essential to our culture -- Shakespeare leads with 1,960 quotations and the Bible follows with 1,591 -- he has added hundreds of items from the movies, books, theater, television (which turned out to be a slim source of originality), public affairs and politics. 
 Take politics and politicians. Former President Ronald Reagan -- who was caught delivering a fake Lincoln quotation at this year's Republican convention -- helped to make famous such movie lines as "Win one for the Gipper" (spoken by Mr. Reagan as George Gipp in the 1940 film "Knute Rockne -- All American," written by Robert Buckner), "Go ahead, make my day" (spoken by Clint Eastwood, written by Joseph C. Stinson for the 1983 film, "Sudden Impact") and "evil empire" (written by George Lucas for his 1977 screenplay of "Star Wars," not to describe the Soviet Union). These are more memorable than a puzzling sentence of Mr. Reagan's own: "It's difficult to believe that people are starving in this country because food isn't available."
President Bush makes Bartlett's with "Voodoo economics," "I want a kinder, gentler nation" and one he would probably like to forget: "Read my lips -- no new taxes." Neither Bill Clinton nor Ross Perot is in Bartlett's. There's a bright, if less lasting, quote by Barbara Bush at Wellesley College: "Somewhere out in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps, and preside over the White House as the President's spouse. I wish him well!"
Since the last edition 12 years ago, Mr. Kaplan has found fresh literary voices, who make the new Bartlett's a reference book that's actually readable. These are among the 340 authors included for the first time:
Toni Morrison: "At no point in my life have I ever felt as though I were an American."
Annie Dillard: "I had been my whole life a bell, and never knew it until at that moment I was lifted and struck."
August Wilson: "As long as the colored man look to white folks to put the crown on what he say . . . as long as he looks to white folks for approval . . . then he ain't never gonna find out who he is and what he's about."
Russell Baker: "The only thing I was fit for was to be a writer, and this notion rested solely on my suspicion that I would never be fit for real work, and that writing didn't require any."
Susan Sontag: "Illness is the night-side of life, a more onerous citizenship. Everyone who is born holds dual citizenship, in the kingdom of the well and in the kingdom of the sick."
Unless you need to go to the original source for context, it's helpful to look up something in Bartlett's because writings and sayings are often misquoted, misattributed and mistranslated. Consider the phrase "You could look it up." Don't bet your last sou or subway token that Casey Stengel said it first; he only popularized it. Thanks to the new Bartlett's, you can look it up and find that "You Could Look It Up" was the title of a 1941 story by James Thurber.
Two newly issued quotation books, which include modern as well as traditional sources, also deserve consideration because of their special qualities.
Although originating in England, the Oxford Dictionary of Quotations doesn't overlook American authors. Even some Americans not in Bartlett's are included here; for example, the playwright Robert Anderson: "All you're supposed to do is every once in a while give the boys a little tea and sympathy."
What makes this book unusual is its tilt toward British and foreign literature, as well as its insightful feminist quotations. Jane Austen, previously represented by her witticisms, is revealed as a greater chronicler of women in society: "Men have had every advantage of us in telling their own story. Education has been theirs in so much higher a degree; the pen has been in their hands."
As its title indicates, the New York Public Library Book of 20th-Century American Quotations is limited but lively. Its arrangement into 40 major topics makes it a challenge to track down a phrase, but it's useful if you're pursuing a subject by category.
The Public Library book is right up to the moment; it includes several pages of quotes on the gulf war alone. For example, here is Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf: "Once we had taken out his eyes, we did what could best be described as the Hail Mary play in football."
Inevitably, some quotations are repeated in all three books; or, as Yogi Berra said, "It's deja vu all over again."

HEADLINE: Critic's Choice;
From Clubs To Town Hall For a Gala

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
The economically fragile world of cabaret has always needed all the help it can get. And in the Mabel Mercer Foundation, an organization devoted to nurturing and showcasing cabaret talent, it has found an invaluable supporter. For the last three years, the foundation, established by Donald F. Smith, a cabaret promoter and friend of Mabel Mercer, has sponsored an annual fall convention that brings together performers and club owners from around the country. The focus of the convention is a series of low-priced gala concerts at Town Hall whose goal is to attract a young urban audience.
This year's events began at Town Hall on Wednesday with a tribute to Sylvia Syms, and continued yesterday evening with a songwriters' showcase. This evening's concert is a tribute to Mae Barnes, a cabaret legend who will give a rare performance. Miss Barnes, who is now 85 years old, became a fixture in the New York nightclub scene in the late 1930's, and during the 50's appeared regularly at the Bon Soir in Greenwich Village. She is known for her robust voice, her mischievous patter and her signature song, "I Ain't Gonna Be No Topsy," a playful affirmation of black pride that was ahead of its time. 
 Along with Miss Barnes, some of the performers scheduled to appear are Ann Hampton Callaway, Susannah McCorkle, Larry Woodard, Billy Stritch, the Wise Guys, Elisabeth Welch, Barbara Lea, and Blossom Dearie. Anne Francine is the show's host.
Tomorrow evening, another remarkably vital and engaging cabaret legend, Hildegarde, will preside over a gala concert that will feature more than 20 rising younger cabaret acts. The lineup includes Phillip Officer, Nora York, Sara Zahn, Baby Jane Dexter, the Manhattan Rhythm Kings, and Bill Wright, among others.
Show time for both performances is at 6 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, and all tickets are $10. Information: (212) 840-2824 or (212) 980-3026.

HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES;
Baseball as Politics: Chasing Wild Pitches

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
In the boonies this week, eating breakfast on drugstore countertops, I kept making errors while fielding that second cuppa question: "Who you think's gonna win?"
I'd start to say, "It's all pitching," and stop as eyes rolled up and down the counter. Someone would clear a throat and say, "For president." 
 I'd mutter something about momentum and poke my nose into the home fries. What's wrong with the fools on the stools? To understand America, you first have to understand baseball. No wonder more people watched the debates than the so-called World Series (still really the North American Hardball Championship for Men). When will Americans realize that everything they love about politics is also available in baseball, without the risk of war or depression?
Baseball has "talking points," too. For example:
MEDIA INFLUENCE Don't you think Deion Sanders would have torn the Blue Jays apart if he hadn't been hampered and diverted by a biased media rooting for Toronto? Sanders threw cold water on Tim McCarver to express justified rage at those pencil-necked geeks who live in glass boxes and dare to interpret the bold and the beautiful who actually compete in the arena. (The fact that McCarver's baseball-playing credentials are still better than Deion's is irrelevant, maybe.)
FAT-CAT INTERESTS The so-called World Series is being played with "The Ball With No Name" because the statesman Fay Vincent was dumped by those avaricious, greedy, fat-cat, kill-the-golden-goose owners who couldn't stand him playing a romanticized version of Kenesaw Mountain Landis (a racist, second-rate jurist, by the way). This was an old role for Fay, who was a $47,500 Securities and Exchange Commission functionary in 1978 when the fat-cat owners of Columbia Pictures, bruised by scandal, made him the $250,000-plus president as "a healer, a Judge Landis." Four years later, when Coca-Cola bought the studio, Fay became a fat cat, too.
THE ECONOMY Because avaricious, greedy, fat-cat, kill-the-golden goose players are making too much money, the game is in serious trouble. Typical is the current situation in which American jobs and American workers were exported to enrich a foreign country. This is so difficult to explain that I probably couldn't do it even if I understood it. But suffice to say, the balance of trade has to do with three Canadian workers, Mark Messier, Adam Graves and Tie Domi, whose efforts for an American company could turn everything around if they only increased productivity in the critical final quarter.
INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS Why were members of the American armed forces carrying the flag of another country, first on American soil, then, in apology for carrying it upside down, on foreign soil? (Could that well-known internationalist Ted Turner, the Goodwill Gamer himself, have asked his Braves to tank the Series to boost the self-esteem of our closest ally? Is it relevant that his team got to the so-called World Series on the base hit of a Dominican on a work visa who is earning $148,000 a year, baseball's equivalent of a minimum wage?)
THE NATIVE QUESTION The Tomahawk Chop, insult and embarrassment, is still with us; the fact that such sensitive political operators as Turner, Jane Fonda (who may have found God, or at least prayer, at the Series) and former President Jimmy Carter have done so little to placate the anti-Choppers leads us to ask the spin-pitchers why. They are of two minds; some sneer that Turner et al., have written the Indians off, figuring there are too few of them to matter, while others opine that keeping the chop wound raw will have impact on Monday's Canadian referendum. A yes/ oui vote on Canada's proposed redefinition will have positive implications for its long oppressed native populations.
THE CHARACTER QUESTION Now that David Winfield is an elder statesman and David Cone is a free-agent-to-be, it has become somehow declasse to remember that each left New York under a cloud. Winfield was involved with two of the most interesting characters on the sports scene, the Olympic statesman George Steinbrenner and the former heavyweight champion's former mother-in-law, Ruth Roper. In both cases, there were charges and countercharges, lawyers and settlements. Cone was a seminal figure in the Mets' apparently successful attempt to chill the media's interest in their lust for life. Cone was also named in a suit from which we can infer that he should have been exiled to the Montreal Expos.
AVOIDING THE ISSUE If President Bush hadn't characterized a Clinton presidency as equivalent to "sending some Little League guy to coach the Braves," we might never have known how important mere games can be.

HEADLINE: In 'Signal of Hope,' Sarajevo Utilities Are Restored;
Yugoslav in Appeal

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The Yugoslav Prime Minister reiterated his call for an end to the United Nations trade embargo against his country today, saying it weakened him in his political struggle against the forces of reactionary Serbian nationalism.
The Prime Minister, Milan Panic, also warned that continuing the blockade would cost the West a lot of money because it would be obliged to begin an expensive new humanitarian relief operation to help his people this winter as supplies run low. 
 But Mr. Panic's appeal, made in an interview aboard his plane while flying back from talks in Geneva, came a day after the United States and the 12 European Community countries said sanctions must remain so long as Slobodan Milosevic, the President of the Serbian Republic and Mr. Panic's archrival, refused to denounce violence by Serbs in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The statement said the trade embargo would remain until all human rights abuses in Bosnia and Herzegovina ceased, naming the Bosnian Serbs as "the principal offenders."
 
A Mixed Blessing
 For Mr. Panic, who describes himself as a man of peace opposed to "ethnic cleansing," such Western attacks on his main political rival are a distinctly mixed blessing.
He said elections scheduled here for Dec. 13 were "crucial to strengthening the forces of democracy and peace" and could lead to Mr. Milosevic's downfall. But with the sanctions, the Prime Minister contended, his efforts to promote peace and racial justice in the Balkans had yielded only "insults and suffering" for his country and its people and this played into Mr. Milosevic's hands.
The difficulty with Mr. Panic's stand is that he has not been able to stop the "ethnic cleansing" carried out by Bosnian Serbs supplied by the Yugoslav Army.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
State Aid for Keeping Businesses

 BODY:
In the Letters column today, Vincent Tese, New York State's Director of Economic Development, points with justifiable pride to the state's contributions toward keeping critical businesses in New York City. State officials have participated in the delicate negotiations with companies that are considering leaving the city. And they have offered substantial financial incentives to complement those granted by the city. 
 In the recent successful effort to retain Morgan Stanley's corporate headquarters, for example, the state provided almost a quarter of the $40 million package of public incentives. In earlier successful retentions, the state's contribution ranged as high as $71 million. State and city negotiators deserve applause for their judicious use of incentives to maintain New York as a world financial services center.

HEADLINE: How New York State Helps Keep Business in New York City

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"How to Keep Business in New York," your Oct. 21 editorial about Morgan Stanley's decision to retain 4,100 jobs in New York City, fails to note New York State's critical role in maintaining the city's status as a world capital of financial services. 
 While justifiably applauding New York City's job retention efforts, you inadvertently help to perpetuate the myth that New York City and New York State act alone on matters of economic survival. In fact, the partnership between the city and the state has never been stronger.
You omit telling readers of the essential involvement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and other state officials, who brought to bear both the personal commitment and the financial resources to make the Morgan Stanley retention coup possible. This personal and financial support also contributed to each of the other financial services success stories you cite.
Here's what you left out: In addition to our personal involvement, New York State provided a $9.1 million tax reduction to keep Morgan Stanley in New York City. The state provided $48.7 million in low-cost energy savings and $16.7 million in tax relief to keep 5,000 Prudential Securities jobs here for the next 20 years.
New York State also committed more than $27 million to prevent more than 8,000 commodities exchange jobs from moving to New Jersey. And although you don't mention it, some $71 million in state tax and energy assistance helped secure 4,500 Chase Financial Services jobs here as well.
The state's business retention efforts are part of a comprehensive, intelligent economic development plan. Our office maintains continuous contact with business and civic leaders throughout the city and state. We repeatedly and judiciously extend technical and financial assistance to businesses, both large and small, throughout New York City: from Wall Street to Far Rockaway, from Brooklyn Heights to the South Bronx.
We coordinate our efforts with local governments and offer joint assistance where appropriate. While this city continues to face tough competitive challenges, the record shows that New York State has helped save tens of thousands of financial services jobs here. Our investment earns a handsome return, in employment, in tax revenues, in ancillary business growth and in reduced public assistance costs.
Under Governor Cuomo's leadership, New York State has forged a solid partnership with the city and made a profound commitment to the economic future of all New Yorkers. Readers deserve to know how we are living up to this commitment through our investments.
 
VINCENT TESE
Director of Economic Development
New York, Oct. 21, 1992

HEADLINE: Among the Earth Baby Set, Disposable Diapers Are Back

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
The war over how to cover American baby bottoms has ended in a rout.
Exhausted by their failure to convince parents that the nation's landfills have turned into reeking mountains of disposable diapers, many of the most zealous environmentalists have simply stopped trying. 
 The signs of surrender are everywhere. Three years ago 22 states considered taxing or banning disposables. None have succeeded. In 1990, New York nearly passed a law requiring hospitals to distribute pamphlets about cotton diapers to all new parents. This year a similar effort died in a day. Even the Environmental Protection Agency seems to have run up the (reusable) white flag. In its major new guide to reducing waste, the word diaper never even appears.
 
Environmentalists' Quandary
 "You know Freud was right about us," said Allen Hershkowitz, a solid waste expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council, and a man who has long been plagued by his own ambivalence over the diaper debate. "Civilization has its costs."
Clearly one of those costs is disposable diapers. There has never been a more potent symbol of the national conflict between convenience and conservation. More than 17 billion disposable diapers were sold in the United States last year, and every child who uses them goes through about 4,500 during infancy. Cotton diapers, by comparison, which have swaddled babies at least since Alexander ruled Macedonia, can be used hundreds of times -- then recycled.
For years environmentalists fumed about the waste caused by disposables -- arguing that each diaper tossed onto the rubbish heap furnished fresh evidence that Americans would rather plunder nature than spend the effort necessary to preserve it.
"Let's deal with the big-ticket items before we ask millions of mothers to torture themselves," said William Rathje, an archeologist and director of the Garbage Project at the University of Arizona. "There are so many ways we are wasteful in this country that are not at the absolute core of modern American behavior. Let's start there. After all, convenience is something we should consider."
At first, the debate seemed one of stark contrasts: disposable diapers waste trees, often include plastics that can't be broken down, and account for a numbing amount of unnecessary garbage each year. Cloth diapers, on the other hand, which now account for less than 15 percent of the American market, seemed environmentally benign.
But closer scrutiny suggests the facts are less one-sided. Many of the trees used for disposables are planted just for that purpose. Excavations of representative landfills -- including Fresh Kills on Staten Island, the world's largest dump -- have revealed that discarded diapers take up from 0.5 to 1.8 percent of landfill space. Compared with old newspapers (which can account for as much as 40 percent of space at landfills), construction debris or food waste, diapers are about as big a problem as used sheets and towels.
Reusable diapers have their problems, too. They can require large amounts of water and detergent to clean. Diaper-service delivery trucks burn gas-wasting energy and cause pollution. In some Western states, like California and Washington, where droughts have presented major problems in recent years and landfill space is relatively easy to find, disposable diapers not only seem to many people more convenient but better for the environment as well.
"This is not a simple issue," said a senior E.P.A. official who insisted on anonymity due to the "sensitive nature" of the debate. "There are environmental consequences, health considerations, and issues of life style that all matter. And the right answer is not always the same for everyone. But it certainly is not something one should resolve based on ideology alone."
 
Freedom at a Cost
 It takes only a few brief conversations with harried parents to appreciate the overwhelming freedom that disposable diapers can offer. Even the most aggressively "green" parents seem to have ways to rationalize their use of such an obvious symbol of the throwaway society. Stricken by fear, guilt and conscience, some have even been caught hiding their Pampers when friends come to visit.
"I hate to admit what a chicken I was," writes a confessional Patricia Poore, editor of the quintessentially environmentally correct publication, Garbage magazine. Ms. Poore came out of the closet as a user of disposables in the current issue.
"I let myself be bullied by image," she wrote, explaining her initial view that cloth diapers were the only permissible route for someone in her position. "How else to explain that the disposables bought for travel days were locked in the glove compartment or hidden in my luggage?"
Yet, eventually, convenience had its way with her, as it has with millions of other parents. Disposable diapers are easy to find, easy to use and easy to get rid of. They almost always cost more -- about 25 cents each compared with as little as 7 cents each for cloth diapers washed at home -- but the washing takes time that many people are not willing to spend.
 
The Diapers of Tomorrow
 Of course there are some die-hard devotees of cotton. Services that provide cotton diapers have scrambled to make their product competitive. Cotton diapers have come a long way since the days when their rigid edges and flat pins brought tears to the eyes of mothers and babies alike.
"In the next year you are going to see a revolution in the diaper industry," said Anne Beaudry, an environmental consultant who frequently works for the National Association of Diaper Services. "You'll see the soft inner lining, the outer plastics, the snap closures and plenty of Velcro. The only thing that will be different is that you can you use them again."
Ms. Beaudry concedes that disposable diaper fans have overwhelmed the cloth contingent, and that legislation to limit the use of disposables has become a waste of time. But she and others say that millions of dollars worth of advertising from companies like Procter & Gamble -- which dominates the industry with Pampers and Luvs -- has had far more to do with the shift than any fair discussion of environmental priorities.
They also contend that ignoring the waste caused by disposable diapers because it represents "only" 1 percent of municipal refuse is foolish and shortsighted.
 
A Big 1 Percent
 "Because there is no overwhelming conclusion to draw from most of the studies that have been done on this issue, people think they can ignore it," said Richard Dennison, a senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, which, like most similar organizations, takes no official position on whether disposable diapers are acceptable baby wear. "One percent of billions of tons is worth worrying about. And if we don't think about how to address that one percent, which one percent will we address? "
Mr. Dennison argues that nobody can make proper assessments of waste by looking only at what fills garbage dumps -- or in what quantity. "These are renewable resources that are used once. And we can do better than that, even with disposable diapers."
Many advocates for cotton diapers now say the only way to limit disposables is to begin charging more for all garbage. Led by Seattle, many cities are now doing just that -- the more a family tosses out each week the bigger the bill they must pay for sanitation. If garbage costs increased sharply -- and many economists argue they should -- people might begin to take another look at the issue.
Until that happens, however, the diaper wars appear to be over.
"It's funny," said Judy Enck, a senior environmental associate at the New York Public Interest Research Group, who is an opponent of cloth diapers and proud of it. "I've seen backlashes before, but I never saw one this powerful."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 24, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the environmental battle against disposable diapers misstated the position of Judy Enck, a senior environmental associate at the New York Public Interest Research Group. She and the organization strongly support the use of cotton diapers.
