HEADLINE: Sticking With One of Their Men;
Clinton-D'Amato Is the Ticket for Many Reagan Democrats

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Here in Erie County, many Reagan Democrats are finally drifting back to their party in this Presidential election. But a hardier species, which also came to life in 1980, survives: the D'Amato Democrat.
A striking number of Democrats who plan to vote for Bill Clinton on Nov. 3, after supporting Ronald Reagan and George Bush, say they will switch over to the G.O.P. column to vote for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. 
 The reasons vary -- some people say they simply believe in Mr. D'Amato's self-characterization as the "Senator Pothole" who has gotten things done, while others say they like the idea of backing a Republican to keep an eye on what they assume will be a Democratic White House. And one man here laughingly -- but favorably -- likened Mr. D'Amato's bombastic tenure to "getting to watch your crazy uncle go to the Senate."
Many of the voters say they blame President Bush for the state of the economy. But there appears to be less inclination to fault Senator D'Amato personally, even though he has generally supported Republican policies for 12 years now.
 
Not Inspiring Trust
 And many say they are D'Amato Democrats by default -- less from any continuing ardor for the Senator than from distaste for his opponent, Attorney General Robert Abrams.
Mr. Abrams has had to contend throughout this campaign with a cease less wave of commercials from the D'Amato camp, seeking to transform him from a mild-mannered public servant into a vicious mudslinger who is "hopelessly liberal."
"Don't ask me what it is, I just don't trust Abrams anymore," said Betty A. Sienkiewicz of Buffalo, "and if anybody should like him, it's me -- my maiden name is Abrams." (She is no relation.)
Frank Mulderig, a laborer for the city Buildings Department, said of Mr. Abrams, "He's the kind of a guy who, if you told him he had $200 to spend on a problem, he'd figure out a way to spend $250."
Said Jack Giardina, owner of the Basilica Diner in Lackawanna, "When it comes to holding the line on spending, you just need a more conservative guy than Abrams."
None of these comments, of course, can be taken as any indication that Mr. D'Amato will win the election. In a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans by nearly three to two, and where Mr. Clinton could attract a huge Democratic turnout, Mr. Abrams could probably prevail in this election even if a substantial number of conservative Democrats defect to Mr. D'Amato.
 
Still a Chance
 Certainly there are plenty of Reagan Democrats here who say that their re-found allegiance to the Democratic Party will include a vote for Mr. Abrams. And Mr. Abrams could win back many more conservative Democrats in the coming days: Vastly outfinanced by Mr. D'Amato, he is just beginning to unleash the advertising blitz his aides have promised for the final days of the campaign.
But interviews with more than 80 registered voters and recent polls indicate that with less than two weeks until Election Day, Mr. D'Amato is running a far more competitive race against Mr. Abrams here than President Bush is against Mr. Clinton. They also suggest that one important part of Mr. D'Amato's strategy -- holding on to many of the conservative Democrats who helped him squeak into the Senate in 1980 and win comfortably in 1986 -- could well be successful. His opposition to higher taxes and higher spending and support for the death penalty -- all classic Reagan Democrat issues -- have figured prominently in his ad campaign.
There is probably no better place to find the D'Amato Democrats than in largely blue-collar Erie County, which consists of Buffalo and its outlying suburbs and factory towns. Many voters here combine a virtually genetic registration in the Democratic Party with conservative values that have led many in recent years to vote for Republicans anyway.
In Mr. D'Amato's case, the numbers here are clear enough. There are 269,737 registered Democrats in Erie County and 165,190 Republicans, a margin that has persisted through the decade, and yet Mr. D'Amato handily won the county in elections in 1980 and 1986.
Mr. D'Amato got 168,641 votes in 1986 to 116,357 for the Democratic nominee, Mark Green. In 1980, he beat Elizabeth Holtzman 207,292 to 144,207.
 
Issues, Not Insults
 One remarkable undercurrent of this election season, in which Mr. Clinton may have successfully fended off queries about extramarital relations and his draft status by challenging voters to "stick to the real issues," like the economy, is that candidates like Mr. D'Amato may succeed in doing the same thing with questions that would seem to go to the heart of the public trust.
The Senator has been the subject of numerous investigations into allegations that he improperly intervened on behalf of his financial supporters, and a Senate Ethics Committee report said he improperly allowed his brother, who has since been indicted, to use his office for lobbying activities. But in a series of pre-emptive strikes, Mr. D'Amato has attacked Mr. Abrams's ethics in a series of television advertisements that seem to have helped the Senator by fueling the disgust of many voters with "mudslinging."
Many people here reacted with hostility when asked whether they were concerned about Mr. D'Amato's ethics.
"I just don't want to hear about any of the dirt, O.K.?" said Larry Kucharski, a 42-year-old warehouse worker in Buffalo's East Side and a Democrat who said he would vote for Mr. D'Amato again because he thought there was less chance he would vote to raise taxes. "Whatever happened in the past doesn't bother me. The only thing I want to know in this election is, what are you going to do for me?"
Some people, in fact, specifically said they were impressed with Mr. D'Amato's counterattacks. "The guy's had a lot of negative publicity, and he stood up to the negativity," said Mark Ruffato, a 31-year-old driver for the Pepsi-Cola company in Buffalo.
Mr. D'Amato also seems to have been spared much of the blame for a sluggish economy.
"When you're President, if things go wrong, you can't really say, 'Well, someone else did it,' " said Bonnie Boechel, a 26-year-old waitress in Lackawanna, N.Y. "But D'Amato, I think he's been trying to do something all these years, and it's not like you can totally blame him for the mess."
Mr. Mulderig, after beginning a lengthy tirade about what the Reagan and Bush Administrations had done to ruin the economy, was asked why he planned to vote again for Mr. D'Amato, a Republican in Washington during all that time. "You got me there," he said with a laugh. "I really don't know what to say."
 
'A Loudmouth'
 Still, many Democrats remain undecided, and even if they find Mr. D'Amato vaguely amusing, they are beginning to question just what he has accomplished.
"I don't know about this image D'Amato portrays," said Larry Brady, a 43-year-old construction worker at a site on Chippewa Street in Buffalo's downtown. "He's a bit of a loudmouth, he's always shooting his mouth off, but I'd like it more if I felt he was making more sense." Mr. Brady said he is leaning toward Mr. Abrams.
But even as they harbor doubts about Mr. D'Amato, the voters are also clearly wondering about Mr. Abrams. Two weeks ago, his frustration with Mr. D'Amato's attacks finally got the better of him, and he referred to the Senator as a "fascist" at a campaign rally. While few people here said they believed Mr. D'Amato's suggestions that it was an anti-Italian slur, several people said the incident made them wonder whether Mr. Abrams was too intemperate to be a good Senator.
"These guys are supposed to know what they're doing," said Alan Riley, a sports-card dealer, who had spread his wares at a table in the cavernous 110-year-old Broadway Market in Buffalo. "If you're a politician, you should give an awful lot of thought to what you're saying, particularly when you're going to slanderize your opponent."
Carol Wagner, a bakery saleswoman and Democrat who said she will vote for Mr. D'Amato, said the incident confirmed an impression of hers that Mr. Abrams was not ready for "the big leagues" in Washington.
"If you're going to speak in front of people, you should know what you're going to say," she said.
 
Many Still Undecided
 To be sure, many voters remain undecided, and some threaten to skip over the Senate race altogether when they get into the voting booth, although past elections suggest that most voters in the end will choose sides in both races. Still, with Mr. Abrams having begun his campaign for the Democratic nomination by arguing that he was the best candidate to take on Mr. D'Amato over ethics issues, the general mood of disillusionment cannot be encouraging.
"I don't agree with all the mudslinging," said Ron Lewandowski, a produce dealer at the Broadway Market. "It's like a cancer, spreading, spreading, but at this point, I'm not even interested in knowing which candidate started it."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Environmental Policy;
BUSH TO ANNOUNCE ENVIRONMENT PLAN

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The White House is planning to announce a series of environmental regulations next week to focus attention on President Bush's environmental program just before the election, Administration officials and critics of the Administration said today.
Although the announcements appear to be aimed in part at fending off assertions that the White House has undermined clean-air laws, some of the rules may lead to additional criticism of the Administration's environmental record. 
 Indeed, the political strategy appears aimed in part at highlighting the Administration's differences with the Clinton campaign, appealing to industries that favor the Bush environmental program and the efforts of the White House Council on Competitiveness, led by Vice President Dan Quayle, to soften the impact of clean-air regulations on industry.
To some extent, the way the regulations are received depends on whether they include provisions that have been pushed by White House officials over the objections of the Environmental Protection Agency.
 
Signs of Softening
 Conflicts between the agency and White House offices over environmental issues have long held up important environmental regulations. Last month, the White House showed signs of softening some of its positions, when the White House chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, ordered changes in a rule that would have allowed manufacturers to dispose of hazardous wastes in town dumps.
At the time, Bush Administration officials said the change was made out of concern that the Bush campaign had become vulnerable to Democratic criticism on the environment.
But in the past week, President Bush has been harshly critical of the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, Senator Al Gore, calling him "Mr. Ozone" for his views on how to cut air pollution.
The Sierra Club, which has been critical of the Administration's record, said it had learned of five announcements, one scheduled for each day beginning Monday. Environmental groups were issued invitations on Thursday to briefings on some of the announcements.
"This last minute flurry of activity will not obscure the fact that the Bush Administration has failed to issue dozens of needed regulations required under the Clean Air Act of 1990," said Blake Early, a Sierra Club official.
 
Political Purposes
 A White House official said that while some of the regulations had been moving through the normal review process for months, announcing them right before the election also served political purposes.
Some of the rules required by the Clean Air Act are being published well behind schedule, and others may have been weakened, but the Sierra Club said that one of the new rules, dealing with air pollution from coke ovens in the steel industry, is "strong enough that the environmental community will support it."
But environmentalists might end up objecting to parts of the regulations on acid rain pollution. These regulations, which were to be published last May but have been held up by a White House review, establish an "allowance" system letting coal-fired power plants buy and sell pollution rights.
The Administration won considerable praise for establishing this market-based approach to pollution control under the Clean Air Act.
But the Sierra Club said the Office of Management and Budget was trying to allow municipal waste incinerators to qualify for conservation allowances that were intended to promote conservation and the use of renewable energy.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Jump

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Average interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages shot up to 8.23 percent this week, the highest level in nearly four months, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today.
The rate, up from 8.06 percent a week earlier, was the highest since such mortgages averaged 8.29 percent in the week that ended on July 2. It was the sharpest weekly increase since mid-January. 
 Before rising five times in the last six weeks, mortgage rates had fallen consistently, from 9.03 percent in mid-March to a 19-year low of 7.84 percent in mid-September.
On one-year, adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.13 percent, up from 5.05 percent last week and the highest since the week that ended on Sept. 11. Adjustable rates hit a low of 4.97 percent two weeks ago.
David Lereah, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said he expected rates to edge down again after the Nov. 3 Presidential election.

HEADLINE: Tension of Waiting at The Daily News

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
A Daily News delivery driver, working on a loading dock this week, chalked across a blackboard: "Welcome to the NEW N.Y. Daily News!" It was an upbeat slogan, but with the newspaper's destiny in the hands of a bankruptcy judge, anxieties continued to weigh on the tabloid's employees.
"We've been in a constant state of crisis for three years," Juan Gonzalez, a Daily News columnist said on Friday. "We're so thoroughly demoralized that we're just working on automatic pilot." 
 Judge Tina L. Brozman of Federal Bankruptcy Court is expected to rule next week on Mortimer B. Zuckerman's $36.3 million bid to buy the newspaper.
Capping two years of extraordinary stress, including one of the nation's worst newspaper strikes, mass firings and months of bankruptcy reorganization, the court delays have only stoked the pressure-cooker atmosphere for News employees.
 
'This Is Our Last Shot'
 "This is like standing on a Times Square platform and it's 110 degrees and no train is coming and the temperature is rising," said Barbara Ross, a political reporter.
In a third-floor lunchroom at the paper's Brooklyn printing plant, a dozen ink-stained pressmen discussed their prospects.
"This is our last shot," said John Welch, a pressman with 41 years at The Daily News. "If this sale doesn't go through, we'll all be out the window, on the unemployment line."
But another pressman, Pete Kershaw, 55, interrupted: "But this guy Zuckerman, I really think he can be a savior for The News. I really think he can turn things around here."
 
Living on Hope
 Down one flight of stairs, a dozen delivery drivers were sipping coffee on a sorting dock.
"We're Daily News truckers -- survivors," said Jimmy Larkin, a 27-year veteran with The News's delivery fleet. "We've survived three years of ravages, strikes and uncertainty. We're alive. We live on hope."
What did he think of Mr. Zuckerman?
"If he's willing to treat us fairly, we'll put out a paper for him," Mr. Larkin said. "If he's willing to recognize our contribution, we'll recognize his contribution."
For his part, Mr. Zuckerman found himself sitting through a second day of bankruptcy proceedings on Friday as lawyers slogged through arguments in the Old Customs House in the Battery.
The New York Typographical Union Local 6 representing the printers, though acknowledging that new technology has nearly eliminated the need for their labor, wants the News and Mr. Zuckerman to honor the 18-year old contract.
Lawyers for the News estimated it costs $61,000 a year in wages and benefits for each printer, some $10 million a year, while an initial investment of about $2 million in automated machinery would eliminate the need for a composing room entirely. Mr. Zuckerman has offered to retain 80 printers and reduce their numbers to 15 workers by 1996 when he hopes to complete a new color printing plant for the paper.
The union has held out for severence pay of $50,000 for each printer let go, a proposal rejected by the prospective buyer.
Judge Brozman, apparently hopeful the two sides may negotiate a settlement on their own over the weekend, said she would issue a ruling on Monday before moving on to the larger issue of accepting Mr. Zuckerman's bid for the ailing tabloid.
 
Seeing Positive Side
 If many News employees viewed the future guardedly, some, like Tina Honnigringer, an advertising manager who works at the paper's headquarters at 220 East 42d Street in Manhattan, bubbled with optimism.
"This can only be positive. I'm very excited," she said. "Mr. Zuckerman will not only bring a new infusion of money, but he's got great ideas to improve the editorial product and increase circulation. And he's a New Yorker -- that's a great plus."
Cheryl Coleman, a secretary who spoke as she passed the vast globe that revolves in the Art Deco lobby of The News's headquarters, said of Mr. Zuckerman: "He wants to fire and rehire. He wants to save money. That commitment to efficiency is what the company needs to survive."
Ronald Hoff, 57, a sales representative who works at News offices in Garden City, L.I., the site of a printing plant that has not been used since the paper's 1990-1991 strike, said a purchase by Mr. Zuckerman would be a big relief. "We'll be able to get on with our lives, and get this paper back to where it should be."
 
Fear for Some Employees
 Most of the 10 unions at the News came to terms with Mr. Zuckerman in the fall, but two have opposed the purchase: the Newspaper Guild and the New York Typographical Union. Members of those two unions appeared most fearful about their prospects if Mr. Zuckerman takes charge.
Charles Dunn, a 45-year-old sales representative, said he was worried that Mr. Zuckerman would target Newspaper Guild members who participated in the 1990-1991 strike. "Those who crossed the line, the scabs, they'll keep their jobs," Mr. Dunn said. "And guys like me who walked the lines will get fired."

HEADLINE: Maputo Journal;
In the Midst of War, Art Is Thriving

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAPUTO, Mozambique

 BODY:
At a crowded, stylish art opening here guests could have been forgiven for thinking they were at a SoHo gallery in Manhattan in the go-go years. Patrons circulated around bold canvases and sophisticated sculptures in a split-level loft.
A video of painters at work played in one corner. And the hottest artist in town, a mysterious woman from the provinces known simply as Renata, wearing 1950's pink sunglasses and a blue pants suit trimmed with safety pins, showed off her ceramics to adoring clients. 
 The event at the Brazilian Center was just one of several art happenings in this art-crazed city. Days earlier, a sculptor and critic, Eugenio Lemas, unveiled his 12-foot Calder-like outdoor iron sculpture whose spherical pieces, three years in the making, appeared to float on the grass.
For a change of tempo, there was an exhibition of photographs of Makonde sculpture, the tribal art whose spirit animates much of Mozambique's modern art.
 
'In the Avant-Garde'
 "I am not being chauvinistic, but Mozambique is in the avant-garde -- certainly in the southern African zone and probably elsewhere in Africa," said Malangatana Valente Ngwenya, a 56-year-old painter who is regarded as the father and nurturer of the vibrant contemporary art scene here.
"I know when I go to Tanzania, you don't find the boiling point that you do among the young artists of Mozambique," he said. "I passed by a cultural center yesterday where there will be a show of young artists. These young artists can pull you, can make you think twice about how to start a new painting."
Theories abound about why in a country where a 16-year-old war has ruined the economy and killed a million people there is so much new art and such a fraternity of artists who meet and talk and exchange ideas.
"Every day, I have hundreds of people asking if they can use the center to show their art," Luiza Helena Bennett, the director of the Brazilian Center, said. "It's incredible, very impressive."
The show that opened the other night juxtaposes fresh works of Mr. Ngwenya with those of younger painters as well as pieces from overseas.
Mr. Ngwenya -- known as Malangatana in art circles here and in Portugal, where his works are prized -- said there were probably two explanations, internal and external, for the abundance of art. He remembers growing up in a village in southern Mozambique where there was plenty of creativity.
"Aside from making useful things like gourds, people carved things for witch doctors, and there were very strong, impulsive dances," he said. "And there was poetry."
Just as important as this innate imagination, Mr. Ngwenya argues, was the exterior influence of Portuguese colonialism and what he calls its double-edged character.
"The colonial situation helped stimulate art," he said as he showed a visitor around his rambling house, where he is in the midst of building a cultural archive for Mozambican painting, sculpture and anthropological treasures. "Until 1975 when the Portuguese left, you didn't find any black doctors, or architects, or any blacks with academic credentials. This racism helped a lot to make people express themselves."
The repression was so pervasive, Mr. Ngwenya said, that after 9 P.M. Mozambicans were not allowed to walk on the street in Maputo. If they did, they faced a long prison sentence or being sent to the Portuguese island colony of Sao Tome.
 
Both 'Sweet and Sour'
 "But also there was a kind of non-racism, because there were some restaurants where blacks and whites could go," he said. "You could be drinking with a Portuguese but at the same time you could be swept off the streets. The relationship was sweet and sour."
Taken under the wing of a Portuguese modernist architect, Mr. Ngwenya had access to paints and canvas. With these he created works in the 1960's and 70's, often in brilliant oranges and reds, suggesting the torment the Mozambicans suffered under the Portuguese.
After independence, he supported the new Government but tried, he said, to send signals through his art that as the country slid into economic chaos and war, all was not well. "I'm a social painter, but not in a pamphleteering way," he said.
The new wave of young Mozambican artists show little concern with post-independence traumas, or even the civil war, but rather concentrate on modern renditions of traditional spiritual life. The works of 24-year-old Idasse, whose pieces in charcoal on paper were shown alongside Mr. Ngwenya's in Europe last year, evoke African mythologies of birds, animals, women.
 
Traditional Stories Used
 At the School of Visual Arts, one of the teachers, Ulisses Gomez Oviedo, said his students' works often hark back to traditional stories passed down from generation to generation.
"Ask them to describe their art, and they will tell stories of witch doctors, of old customs," Mr. Oviedo said. "They listen from the family, the grandfather. The art is very strong."
Alongside the flourishing production of art, a support system insures that word of what is new gets around.
A critic's circle writes in the Sunday newspaper, and the one television station often shows documentaries on artists. A video to appear on television of the opening at the Brazilian Center shows Renata stretched out on the floor dancing rhythmic movements to the thump of music and the excitement of the first-night crowd, emphasizing perhaps the multi-media dimensions of new Mozambican art.

HEADLINE: A Caprice That Chevy Couldn't Sell

SERIES: Closing Willow Run: At G.M., a Design Gone Wrong -- Fifth article of a series

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YPSILANTI, Mich., Oct. 23

 BODY:
Kathy Graham, who oversees market research for new designs at the General Motors Corporation, still recalls the excitement of that day, back in 1989. "I was told, 'Run out to the front of the building! It's coming!' "
After two years behind locked doors, the 1991 Chevrolet Caprice Classic LTZ sedan, with its curvy lines and voluptuous rear end, was ready for a test drive. The consensus of Ms. Graham and her co-workers was that Charles M. Jordan, G.M.'s design chief, had a winner. 
 "We all went, 'Wow!"' Ms. Graham said.
Several months later, the six-passenger, rear-wheel-drive Caprice made its debut before the 4,000 people who would be building it at the Willow Run plant in Ypsilanti, 30 miles southwest of Detroit. Everybody said, 'Wow, what an ugly car!' " said Jerry Krampitz, who knows something about cars, having built them at Willow Run for 32 years. "It looked like an upside-down bathtub. I thought, 'I hope something like this sells."
Bob Hall, who had a new baby, a new house and little seniority in a company where seniority is everything, said he had a sense of impending doom. "People looked at that car and said, 'Guess we're next. There go our jobs.' "
This time, the workers, not the marketing experts and the designers, were right. The Caprice, mocked by Automobile magazine as "the knock-kneed Baby Huey," by others as Shamu the Whale, has been shunned by buyers. G.M. redesigned it for 1993 -- "in record speed," Mr. Jordan says -- but it was too late for Willow Run.
The failure of the Caprice, America's hottest-selling car in the late 1960's, was only the latest in a series of miscalculations that will ultimately cost Mr. Hall, Mr. Krampitz and their co-workers their jobs here. Sometime next year, the plant will close, one of 21 that G.M. will abandon as customers turn away from its showrooms.
"Were it just the Caprice that had bombed, it would be one thing," said Harley Shaiken, an auto expert at the University of California in San Diego. "But it happened as G.M.'s market share went down a very steep downhill slide. It was the equivalent of skiing down the Matterhorn."
Now, as rumors swirl about the future of G.M.'s chairman, and with some directors apparently pressing to quicken the pace of change at the nation's largest manufacturing company, the story of the Caprice illustrates one of G.M.'s biggest problems: Its stubborn -- some say arrogant -- insistence on doing things its own way long after the market has passed it by.
For G.M., once renowned for its management and its ability to lead the automotive world, the Caprice's failure also underscores the brutal competitiveness of the auto industry today. "A car is always a crapshoot," said Frank Joyce, a spokesman for the United Automobile Workers union. "But the Caprice was a dud in an environment in which it's increasingly difficult to be a success."
 
 
Failures Are More Costly
 No longer can G.M. conceive a car and dictate its success. No longer can it produce disasters like the Corvair or the Vega and still manage to forge ahead to greater profits. Now failures like the Caprice, or the Pontiac Fiero of the mid-1980's, can mean plant closings, the loss of thousands of jobs, the end of executive careers.
"The customer closed the factory," Maryann Keller, an analyst with Furman, Selz Inc. in New York, said, referring to Willow Run. "Why did the customer close the factory? Because they bought somebody else's car. Somebody else had something they wanted to buy, and G.M. didn't offer it. That's why plants close. They reflect corporate mistakes."
The man behind the Caprice, Chuck Jordan, occupies a corner suite at the General Motors Technical Center outside of Detroit, with an Art Deco-style teak sofa and oversized globe that dates to the 1950's, when the legendary Harley Earl was in charge of design. On his desk is a model of a big-finned 1959 Cadillac, which Mr. Jordan designed. In the 1950's, when G.M. owned the market, designing cars was much simpler.
"There was one Cadillac, one Chevy, one Pontiac, one Buick," he said. "Ford always copied us. We never paid attention to Chrysler. There were no Japanese. The Europeans weren't over here."
Now, after 43 years with G.M., Mr. Jordan's last day of work will be this Friday. With the way things are changing, he said, "I couldn't have timed my retirement better."
 
 
A Bold, but 'Wrong,' Design
 Mr. Jordan is part of the old G.M., analysts say, a culture that began changing last spring, when the G.M. board stepped in. "The car guys made the decisions," Ms. Keller said. "It just wasn't tradition to pay very much attention to outsiders, to the voice of the consumer as they now call it. When competition was minimal, they were probably going to be right. When competition increased, it became harder and harder for these guys to recognize that they were no longer dictating taste."
The Caprice, understandably, is not Mr. Jordan's favorite topic. "This was not a frivolous design," he said. "We thought we had a pretty graceful total car."
Some analysts admire the risks Mr. Jordan took. "It's a very bold car," said Leon Mandel, the publisher of Auto Week Magazine. "It's a very courageous car. It just happens to be wrong."
 
 
When Chevy Set the Pace
 For three decades, from the 1950's through the 1970's, Chevrolet's full-size models, from the fabled Bel Air, with its clean lines, to the Impala, with its distinctive sets of triple tailights, to the Caprice, ruled the open road. The cars, like G.M., seemed as invincible as America. And Chevrolet sold that image for decades, beginning on television in 1956 with "The Dinah Shore Chevy Show" with its "See the U.S.A. in Your Chevrolet," theme song, on up to today's "Heartbeat of America" advertising jingle.
Mr. Hall, the auto worker, who is 36, spent much of his childhood in the back of his father's Caprice. "The Caprice was more than just a car," he said. "My dad was from the hills of Kentucky. He grew up in the Depression. When he bought something, it had to be good. It had to last. That was the Caprice."
 
 
A Shrinking Part of the Market
 The end began during the gasoline shortages of the 1970's. G.M. and the other auto makers began introducing smaller, more fuel-efficient cars. Chuck Jordan helped shrink the Caprice in 1977.
By 1980, the company considered scrapping the Caprice by the end of the decade. But cars have special-interest groups, and the Caprice had Chevrolet dealers, owners of rental fleets and taxi companies, and police forces, who liked the way the car handled at high speeds.
And, in 1985, Robert D. Burger, then the general manager of Chevrolet, decided to take a chance on the Caprice. "There were a number of owners, in their late 50's and 60's, who wanted another Caprice, one more time," Mr. Burger, who has since retired, said in a telephone interview from his home in northern Michigan. "In spite of the fact that the market was shrinking, we decided we would take one last swing and reskin it and see how long it would go."
With G.M. still racking up record profits, it looked like a modest gamble. Chevrolet would continue to make the car with its old rear-wheel-drive configuration and large engines. It was still mostly opening plants, not closing them. Full-size, six-passenger cars still accounted for 15 percent of the market -- a market the Japanese had not yet invaded.
Reskinning the Caprice meant restyling the exterior. Customers who were shown prototypes expressed doubts about the heavy-looking rear end. "We waited, and thought, 'They will come to like it,' " Ms. Graham said.
Mr. Jordan, who owns a red Ferrari Testarossa, wants to talk about the cars now being developed at the Tech Center. "We're living in 1996 here," he said.
But it is very much 1992 in Ypsilanti. And the workers at Willow Run seem obsessed with the winter of 1989, when everything began to go wrong.
First, G.M.'s Chevrolet-Pontiac-Canada Group took over management of the plant. "C.P.C. had a reputation for closing plants," Mr. Hall said.
The old Caprice was being built in Arlington, Tex., and Lakewood, Ga. In late 1989, as Willow Run was being retooled to trade the popular Pontiac Bonneville for the Caprice, G.M. closed the Lakewood plant. The market was shrinking and fewer plants were needed, the company said.
 
 
A Party and an Award
 In January, 1990, Chevrolet-Pontiac-Canada threw a party at Willow Run. "All the bigwigs were there," Mr. Hall said. "They had hot dogs, popcorn, music. They told us, 'This car is going to be the flagship of our fleet sales, and you are going to be the main plant.' "
Ugly or not, the Caprice was Willow Run's car. The workers got on board. "You still have pride in your work," Mr. Hall said. "After a while, we said, 'Who knows? It could take off.' "
The restyled Caprice hit the market in 1990. The timing could not have been worse. By fall, gasoline prices were skyrocketing after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The economy was worsening. The Ford Taurus, which had made its debut several years earlier, was wildly successful. (Many analysts say Chevrolet had tried -- and failed -- to mimic the Taurus's jelly-bean shape with the Caprice.)
Bob Harlow, president of the U.A.W. local at Willow Run, bought the first car for sale that rolled off the line. It was $20,500 retail -- $16,000 with the worker's G.M. discount. "I wanted to promote sales," Mr. Harlow said.
The roomy car turned out to be perfect for his three small children. "I love my Caprice," Mr. Harlow said sincerely.
The parking lot at Willow run is filled with Chevy vans and pickups. Even if they did like it, the Caprice was too expensive for a lot of workers, especially since the lack of demand meant the end of overtime work.
In 1991, Motor Trend magazine named the Caprice its car of the year, an award that many people in the industry say is meaningless. "The Caprice certainly wasn't the marketplace's car of the year," Mr. Mandel said.
Doug Arter, an assembler, said he found it paradoxical that the workers received Car-of-the-Year T-shirts on the day they got layoff notices. The plant began a series of temporary shutdowns. Under terms of the contract, laid-off workers receive nearly their full incomes, plus benefits.
Pat Morrissey, a spokesman for General Motors, says the design of the 1991 Caprice did not prompt the closing of Willow Run. "There is simply not enough market interest in the full-size, rear-wheel-drive vehicles to justify building these vehicles at two plants," he said. He cited statistics: from 1982 to 1992, full-size, six-passenger cars dropped from 15 percent of the market to 8 percent.
Instead of being built at two plants, as it is now, the Caprice will be produced at only one, in Arlington, Tex.
 
 
Changes Weren't Anticipated
 Some analysts say General Motors should have seen the change coming. "Don't they understand that these trends don't happen in a nanosecond?" Ms. Keller said. "If the market for this car is declining, then why didn't they have something else to put in the factory? Take your pick: Either the car was ugly, or the customers were disappearing. In either case, they are to blame for not acting upon that information."
At Willow Run, even as they wait anxiously for transfers to other plants, the workers are building the 1993 Caprice. G.M. has slimmed down the 1991 version and recarved the rear-wheel openings to make the new model look less bottom-heavy.
Mr. Krampitz, the longtime auto worker, says he will probably be forced to retire and, at age 51, he is prepared to go to work cutting lawns. Mr. Hall and his wife, Jessie, who have two small children, are in turmoil. Should they pick up and follow the Caprice to Arlington, where there will be jobs for 400 Willow Run workers? Who knows how long Arlington will stay open?
"The new car looks a lot better," Mr. Hall said. "Too bad it's too late for us."

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

Voting Your Religion
Not surprisingly, Americans put the economy ahead of all other issues in determining how they will vote this year for President. But in a new national poll sponsored by the VISN interfaith television network, 10 percent of respondents said the determining factor would be religion. 
 A telephone survey of 718 registered voters conducted early this month found that 74 percent said a candidate's economic plan would determine how they would vote. But among those who attended church more than once a week, the number who put economics first fell to 50 percent, as against 26 percent who cited religious issues.
The poll, conducted by Blum & Weprin Inc. of Manhattan from Oct. 8 to 10, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
The poll also found that despite the efforts of the Republicans to paint themselves as the party of God in this election, the Democrats were well ahead among churchgoing Christians.
Consistent with other polls, the new survey found Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas to be well ahead of President Bush, even among voters who said they attended church five or more times in the last month (46 percent to 34 percent). Ross Perot, the independent candidate, garnered 4 percent of these churchgoers.
The two major candidates ran neck and neck among voters who believe "everything in the Bible word for word," with Mr. Clinton favored by 37 percent and President Bush by 36 percent.
Micheline Blum, president of the polling company, said the results demonstrated that the issue of religion, "which has been a focal point of Republican politics for the last 12 years, is not helping this year in the way that the Bush campaign hoped it would."
 
Saints and Sinners
 This week, Operation Rescue, the militant anti-abortion group, sent more than 90,000 letters to Christian clergy members across the country with this message: "Pastor, warn your flock: To vote for Bill Clinton is to sin against God."
The letter, signed by Randall A. Terry, the founder and leader of the group, was not exactly a ringing endorsement of President Bush. "The alternative may not appear very good," it conceded, "but even a status quo administration would not rob us of the gains we've made in the last decade." It concluded: "Christian, vote your conscience, not your pocketbook -- both will be better off."
Max Parker, deputy press secretary for the Clinton campaign, said the letter was "an outrage" that twisted the Governor's beliefs and postions. "This is a prime example of a group that wants to continue to divide Americans over an emotional issue," he said. "By this point in the campaign, people realize that to conquer our greatest problems, we need to work together instead of buying into these divisive tactics."
 
Interfaith Miracles
 It had an "only in New York" quality: Jewish, Christian and Muslim clergy members gathered Thursday morning in a Roman Catholic Church to eat bagels and talk about Islam. A banner overhead said "Expect Miracles."
The words were the motto of the sponsoring group, a Partnership of Faith in New York City, which hopes to heal divisions in the city through better understanding between religions.
Imam Talib 'Abdur-Rashid used a common biblical metaphor to give an introductory talk about Islam, saying his religion was the latest "patch in Joseph's multicolored coat of faith." To demonstrate that Islam is not something foreign or fanatical, but familiar and neighborly, he led a discussion with four New Yorkers who lead Islamic lives in the city.
When the floor was opened to the visiting clergy, there were some sparks over the morality of the death sentence declared by the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on Salman Rushdie for writing "The Satanic Verses." The assembled Muslims supported the decree, but Rabbi Marshall Meyer of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Manhattan called it "violent and fundamentalist."
Imam Talib, the leader of the Mosque of Islamic Brotherhood in Harlem, broke the tension when he said that Muslims were also upset by the film "The Last Temptation of Christ," by the singer Sinead O'Connor's ripping up a picture of Pope John Paul II and by the desecration of Jewish houses of worship and cemeteries.
"We have strong feelings about these things, and you are going to see us come out of our cocoon and talk about them," he said.
 
An Ideal Rabbi
 Rabbi Haskell Lookstein of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in Manhattan has won the Finkle Award, given each year to the rabbi who "exemplifies the highest ideals of the rabbinate, serves a congregation in exemplary fashion and reaches out to the broader community." The award, presented Thursday by the New York Board of Rabbis, includes a $10,000 prize.
The spiritual leader of Cambodian Buddhism, Preah Maha Ghosananda, has been awarded the $4,000 Professor Thorolf Rafto Prize for Human Rights for his work in promoting peace and reconciliation in his country. The prize is awarded by the Thorolf Rafto Foundation for Human Rights of Bergen, Norway.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Lists Public Works Bond Act Would Finance

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
For almost a year, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been touting his $800 million jobs bond act as a way to help pull New York State out of its deep recession by creating tens of thousands of jobs. But not until yesterday did his office release a list of the projects it said would be financed by the bond act, which is to be put before the state's voters on Election Day.
The release of the list, the subject of painstaking negotiations between the Governor, the Democratic-controlled Assembly and the Republican-led State Senate over the last few weeks, was clearly timed to help bolster the Governor's case for the bond act, Proposal 1 on the Nov. 3 ballot. And in this year of scarce resources, it provides the state's lawmakers something to dangle before their constituents as the election approaches. 
 Governor Cuomo said that the bond act would generate almost 35,000 construction jobs. Beyond that, the Governor's office has estimated that the public works projects built through the act would entice an estimated 122,000 permanent private-sector jobs and retain another estimated 42,000 existing jobs.
"These projects all share a common purpose: to create immediate jobs and to lay the foundation for sustained economic growth," he said. "They can provide the spark needed to begin the revitalization of communities across New York."
 
Money for Infrastructure
 The list includes 390 separate projects to improve infrastructure like roads and sewage hookups across the state, with an eye toward using those projects to attract business to New York.
The list includes nearly $300 million for New York City, like rebuilding piers at the South Street Seaport and Battery Park at a cost of $12 million; building a 600-space parking garage in Jamaica, Queens, for $6.4 million, and refurbishing the Staten Island Ferry Terminal for $6.3 million.
Under the list, which is in the form of a memorandum of understanding signed between Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature, Nassau County would receive $42 million, Suffolk would receive $43 million and Westchester, $28.5 million.
For Nassau County, the projects include $8.6 million to modify and expand a wastewater treatment center in Glen Cove, and $4 million to refurbish parking, lights and sidewalks in the village of Farmingdale. For Suffolk, the projects include $2.5 million to expand the Port Jefferson wastewater treatment plant and $3.5 million to revamp the infrastructure at the Brookhaven Industrial Park.
In each case, the county or municipality would be required to put up part of the cost of the project, so that the state would only pay a portion.
Conservative groups, which have been urging voters to reject the bond act as a fiscally irresponsible move that will saddle the state with more debt, questioned the timing of releasing the list yesterday and said that the voters should have been informed earlier of what they were being asked to vote for.
 
Questions of Timing
 "There's no reason that this document should be coming out just 10 days before the election," said Paul P. Jesep, a spokesman for Change-NY, a conservative group that supports less government spending. "New Yorkers have a right to examine this very clearly and carefully, and it should have been released a long time ago."
But Mardi Massaroni, a spokeswoman for the Jobs Bond Act Information Office, said the list took so long to compile because the state received many more applications than it had expected.
For the last week, officials have been working nearly around the clock to cull the final list from 1,000 proposed projects that would have required a total of $2.5 billion in assistance, she said.
Mitch Pally, vice president for legislative and economic affairs for the Long Island Association, a business and civic group, said that he welcomed the final list for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, even though the projects included were relatively modest.
"It's not like building Yankee Stadium, but when you add it all together it adds thousands of construction jobs and creates thousands more permanent ones," he said.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales in U.S. Jumped in Mid-October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and trucks jumped 27.1 percent in mid-October, compared with a particularly weak period a year earlier, auto makers reported today.
Sales of new North American-built cars rose 15.4 percent in the Oct. 11-20 period, while new-truck sales jumped 48.8 percent. Vehicles built in the United States, Canada and Mexico are considered domestic. 
 Cars sold at a projected annual rate of 6.4 million, the Commerce Department reported today, a vast improvement from the 5.8 million projected rate in the first 10 days of the month. Sales of light trucks were running at a projected annual rate of more than five million in the first 20 days of October.
Dealers also said auto sales were improving, and some expected even more sales after the Presidential election on Nov. 3.
"Sales have actually been pretty darn good," said Ray Spacagna, general manager of Mike Luna Chevrolet-Oldsmobile-Geo in Belen, N.M. But, he said, people coming into the dealership have been "a little bit worried about the economy and who's going to be President."
The reports follow the Chrysler Corporation's announcement on Tuesday that it earned $202 million in the third quarter. But the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company are expected to report combined losses of more than $1 billion next week.
Among the Big Three American auto makers, Ford reported the biggest gains: a 27 percent increase in car sales and a 52.4 percent gain in truck sales.
G.M. reported a 9.6 percent increase in car sales and a 40.5 percent gain in truck sales.
Chrysler's combined car and truck sales were up 15.4 percent, according to estimates by Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication. Chrysler does not report 10-day sales.
 
 
A Continuing Improvement
 Gerry Paul, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York, said he was encouraged by the sales increases. "But it's probably not as strong as you'd expect," he said. "It's a continuing improvement, but it's also moving slowly."
Among Japanese auto makers with North American plants, the Nissan Motor Company reported its sales of American-made cars more than doubled in mid-October, while truck sales were up 67.9 percent. The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation reported a 57.6 percent gain in new-car sales. And the Mazda Motor Corporation reported a 53.4 rise in car sales, but a 50.2 percent drop in truck sales.
Wide percentage swings occur in sales of American-made Japanese cars because they have a small part of the overall market.
Also today, Chevrolet's general manager, Jim Perkins, announced that Chevrolet-Geo dealers had already ordered more than half of the 1993 production of the redesigned Geo Prizm, only about a month into the new model year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Exxon Profits Up 1.8% and Mobil Advances 13.2%

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The Exxon Corporation's earnings rose slightly, by 1.8 percent, in the third quarter while the Mobil Corporation's profits rose by 13.2 percent.
Both companies, the nation's two largest in oil, said they had benefited from higher natural gas and crude oil prices in the United States, and continued to generate the bulk of their profits abroad. Operations in gasoline and other petroleum products in the United States remained weak because of the economy and thin profit margins in the Midwest and East. 
 Excluding special items, Exxon's operating income rose by 6 percent in the quarter and Mobil's rose 11 percent. Both companies said they had modestly pared spending for plant expansions, drilling programs and other operations, which reduced costs and aided profits in the quarter.
Mobil said it had expanded its existing programs to cut costs and improve productivity. Allen E. Murray, chairman and chief executive, said its plan to trim 2,000 jobs by year-end was "proceeding on a wider front and at a faster pace."
 
Texaco Reports Gain
 Those cutbacks and the auctions of reserves and other properties, he said, "will result in higher productivity and significantly greater savings than originally estimated."
Texaco this week reported a 17 percent gain in operating income, and Amoco a gain of 16 percent, and analysts said they expected the major oil companies to report gains of 15 to 20 percent on average.
Chevron and ARCO, companies with large refining operations on the West Coast and significant producers of domestic natural gas, are expected to post substantially larger gains for the quarter when they report earnings on Monday.
Mobil's domestic refining unit had its third consecutive quarterly loss, while Exxon's refining profit in the United States fell 68 percent.
Gasoline demand in the United States "is still well below normal levels," said George F. Friesen, senior oil analyst for the Deutsche Bank Capital Group in New York.
Following are details from the Exxon and Mobil earnings reports:
 
Exxon
 Net income was $1.14 billion, or 90 cents a share, compared with $1.12 billion, or 88 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Revenue for the nation's biggest oil company, based in Irving, Tex., rose 11.3 percent, to $30.6 billion, from $27.5 billion.
The Exxon profit was modestly below analysts' estimates, in part because of the steep decline in refining profits in the United States, to $31 million, from $98 million. The oil giant's foreign refining profits, however, were up sharply, to $459 million, from $312 million.
Profits from drilling operations in the United States also rose drastically, to $272 million, from $142 million.Exxon's chemical unit reported higher profits, to $87 million, from $55 million.
Exxon's share price was unchanged yesterday, at $62, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Mobil
 Net income rose to $413 million, or $1 per share, from $365 million, or 87 cents per share. Revenues for the company, based in Fairfax, Va., increased 8 percent, to $16.2 billion, from $15.0 billion.
Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company, posted its third straight quarterly loss in United States refining, a loss of $19 million. Higher natural gas and crude prices contributed to a profit surge in domestic drilling operations, to $146 million, from $39 million a year ago.
Natural gas prices for the quarter rose to an estimated average of $1.90 per 1,000 cubic feet in the United States, from $1.39 in the period a year ago. In foreign operations, natural gas prices rose to $2.92, from $2.78. Crude oil prices rose to an estimated average of $17.32 per barrel in the United States, from $16.31 a year ago. Foreign crude sales average an estimated $20.16 per barrel, compared with $19.32 a year ago.
Damage costs from Hurricane Andrew amounted to $13 million. Other one-time costs included $68 million in programs to trim employees and operations and a $50 million writeoff from an asset sale. Most of the costs were offset by a $106 million profit on asset sales.
Mr. Murray said that Mobil had raised $600 million this year from selling reserves and other assets and that more sales were expected this quarter. He added that the company had spent $154 million this year for early-retirement and other cost-reduction programs.
Mobil's share price gained 25 cents, to $63.375, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
West Point-Pepperell Buyer Steps Down as Its Chairman

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
William F. Farley resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of West Point-Pepperell Inc., a company he bought in 1988 for $1.5 billion in a highly leveraged hostile takeover, which ultimately led West Point to seek bankruptcy protection.
Mr. Farley, who is 50 years old, also resigned as chairman and chief executive of Valley Fashions Inc., the parent of West Point-Pepperell. 
 Holcombe T. Green Jr., an independent director named to the board of Valley Fashions when it emerged from bankruptcy protection last month, will succeed Mr. Farley as chairman and interim chief executive. Mr. Green, who is 53, is a principal of Green Capital Investors, an Atlanta investment partnership.
 
 
A Bitter Struggle
 Valley Fashions is the name taken by the West Point Acquisition Corporation when it emerged from bankruptcy. Mr. Farley created West Point Acquisition in 1989 to buy West Point-Pepperell, whose bed and bath linens are sold under brand names that include Martex, Utica, Lady Pepperell, Tastemaker and Vellux.
After a bitter struggle with Joseph Lanier Jr., West Point's chairman and the great-grandson of LaFayette Lanier, the company's founder, Mr. Farley acquired 95.3 percent of West Point's shares, financing most of the purchase with bank debt and $700 million of high-yield junk bonds. Mr. Farley's stake was limited to about $200 million in cash and West Point stock, analysts said.
Mr. Farley planned to sell West Point assets and purchase the remaining 4.7 percent of the shares he did not already own. Those plans were never realized, however, as the economic slowdown and the huge debt Mr. Farley placed on West Point dragged the company down.
By March 1990, West Point was in default on interest payments. It later filed for Chapter 11 protection.
 
 
Focus on Fruit of the Loom
 Mr. Farley, who engineered a successful leveraged buyout of Fruit of the Loom Inc. earlier in the 1980's, said in a news release that he intended to concentrate on that company. "At this time, with West Point's problems largely behind it, I feel that it is appropriate that I focus my attention on Fruit of the Loom," he said.
Burton Malkiel, a professor of economics at Princeton University, said the West Point takeover was a case study in what could go wrong in leveraged buyouts in the 1980's.
"To the extent that you leverage a perfectly fine company like West Point to the hilt, what might be a minor perturbation in sales for an unleveraged company can become a disaster for one that is heavily leveraged," he said.
Requests for an interview with Mr. Farley were denied.
Along with his resignation, Mr. Farley and his associates agreed to sell their remaining stock and warrants in Valley Fashions back to the company. Pamela L. Webber, a spokeswoman for Farley Industries, would not comment on the size or value of Mr. Farley's holdings.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the price of West Point-Pepperell's shares rose 25 cents each, to $40.25. The company has 1.1 million common shares outstanding.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 6.76 on Economic Signs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices managed a small gain yesterday during a drifting session in which investors apparently were somewhat encouraged by talk of possible strengthening in the economy.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 6.76 points, to 3,207.64, finishing the week with a net gain of 33.23 points. 
 Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by about 9 to 8 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume totaled 199.1 million shares, compared with 216.4 million Thursday.
 
 
Unemployment Claims
 Analysts said hopes had stirred in recent days that the pace of the economy might be picking up, at least a little. The latest data on initial claims for state employment insurance, for instance, showed that a recent downward trend was continuing.
But evidence of a stronger economy has also served to push up interest rates. Prices of long-term government bonds fell more than $2.50 for each $1,000 in face value yesterday.
Brokers said a good many investors were also sitting back to await the Presidential election, having already assigned a high probability to a victory by Gov. Bill Clinton.
"With a Clinton victory seemingly discounted by the market, the future trend in equity prices will be more influenced by the extent of economic recovery," John Shaughnessy of Advest Inc. said.
General Motors rose 5/8, to 33 1/2, in active trading amid reports that G.M. directors may be preparing to oust Robert C. Stempel as chairman.
Goodyear Tire and Rubber gained 1 7/8, to 67 5/8. Third-quarter profits came to $1.44 a share, up from $1.01 a share in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Exxon, which posted third-quarter earnings of 90 cents a share against 88 cents a share in the like period last year, was unchanged at 62.
Other gainers among the blue chips included American Telephone and Telegraph, up 1 1/8, at 43 1/8; Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up 1 7/8 at 103 1/8, and Walt Disney, up 1 3/4, at 38 1/2.
R. P. Scherer lost 1 1/8, to 31, after a secondary offering of 3.5 million shares was priced at that level.
Nacco Industries climbed 5 5/8, to 43 7/8, as the company posted sharply higher third-quarter profits.
 
 
Salomon Slides
 Salomon Inc. dropped 3/4, to 33, after a 4 1/4-point slide on Thursday, when the company reported that its third-quarter earnings fell to $6 million from $85 million in the corresponding period last year.
Archive, one of the most active issues in Nasdaq over-the-counter trading, jumped 3 3/4, to 10 1/2, while Conner Peripherals rose 1/4, to 18 3/4, on the Big Board. Late Thursday, Conner agreed to acquire Archive for $11.25 a share in cash.
Sun Microsystems, another Nasdaq stock, climbed 3 3/8, to 32. The company reported sharply lower quarterly earnings late Thursday, but analysts described a bright outlook for future quarters.
The Nasdaq composite index edged up 0.18 point to 597.30. At the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index dropped 0.27 point to 374.24.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Amid Rumors Of Bundesbank Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against most leading currencies amid a bullish market swept up in rumors about interest rates.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $343.60 an ounce, up 50 cents from late Thursday. Republic National Bank said gold had risen 80 cents, to $343.20. 
 "I think we are seeing the beginnings of a bull trend" in the dollar," said Robert Ryan, a senior trader at the Bank of New York.
Traders concentrated on rumors of potential interest rate cuts by the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, and the reality of rising interest rates in the United States, Mr. Ryan said. These factors made a rising dollar inevitable, he said.
In New York, the dollar settled at 121.60 Japanese yen, up from 120.725 yen late Thursday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 121.20 yen, down 1.16 yen from Thursday's close. But it was quoted later in London at 121.90 yen.
 
Pound Falls in London
 At the close in New York, the pound fetched $1.6225, down from $1.6260 late Thursday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6165 from $1.6230 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.5275 German marks, up from 1.5080; 1.3630 Swiss francs, up from 1.3460; 5.1800 French francs, up from 5.1170; 1,340.5 Italian lire, up from 1,325.50, and 1.24675 Canadian dollars, up from 1.24175.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5305 German marks, up from 1.5080; 1.3635 Swiss francs, up from 1.3475; 5.1855 French francs, up from 5.1150; 1.7208 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6965; 1,338.75 Italian lire, up from 1,323.50, and 1.2470 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2423.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $342.65 an ounce from $343.15 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $342.60 an ounce from $342.50 bid late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 89 cents an ounce to close at $343.36.
Silver fell worldwide. On the Comex in New York, silver settled at $3.769 an ounce, down from $3.781. In London, silver fell to a late bid of $3.78 from $3.79late Thursday.

HEADLINE: Franks Gets a Lift From an Opponent

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DANBURY, Conn.

 BODY:
Even supporters of Representative Gary Franks, the first black Republican elected to Congress since the 1930's, describe his first term as inauspicious. But the 39-year-old former alderman from Waterbury is now considered the front-runner in his re-election bid -- helped, oddly enough, by his most vitriolic opponent's decision to stay in the race.
Mr. Franks, who won his nomination through something of a fluke in a six-way race, is benefiting from Connecticut's three-party politics. A Connecticut Party, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s independent vehicle, has provided a home for State Representative Lynn Taborsak, a 49-year-old plumber from Danbury and the unexpected loser in a bitter Democratic primary fight. 
 Ms. Taborsak and the Democratic nominee, James Lawlor, a Waterbury Probate Court judge, now seem to be splitting the large anti-Franks vote in this diverse district, which stretches northwest from the bucolic northeastern suburbs of New York City through the conservative, working-class Naugatuk Valley to the old brass-making city of Waterbury.
 
Intense Rivalries
 Rivalries within the Fifth District are intense, suspicions mutual and pervasive. It is said that when the Naugatuck Valley wins a Federal grant, Waterburians view the money as foreign aid. The district was a Democratic bastion but became the most solidly Republican district in the state in the last three Presidential elections.
The candidates' geographies, personalities and backgrounds work to Mr. Franks's advantage. Ms. Taborsak undercuts Mr. Lawlor in the southwestern towns around Danbury, where he is viewed as something of a carpetbagger. Both are white Democrats. Mr. Franks splits the pro-choice vote with Ms. Taborsak and the Waterbury vote with Mr. Lawlor.
Earlier, the race's central issue had appeared to be Mr. Franks, and what his opponents called his continuing string of blunders. For instance, when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney testified before the Armed Services Committee on the Administration's plans to cancel the Seawolf submarine, a project important to the state's struggling economy, Mr. Franks had no questions for him. The Representative was in the restroom.
"Gary Franks is a slug," said Ms. Taborsak. "He's in over his head. His report card shows a big, fat F. He doesn't deserve re-election."
But geography is working against his challengers. The southwestern segment of the district, whose lines were essentially unchanged by this year's redistricting, tunes in to New York City; the northeastern portion catches New Haven and Hartford. That makes it impossibly dear to buy name recognition and gives Mr. Franks, who enjoys districtwide familiarity, a giant advantage.
 
Money in the Bank
 Mr. Franks raised a campaign fund of $577,000, one of the state's largest, and still has $200,000 in the bank to orchestrate a last-week crescendo. Mr. Lawlor reported having $2,821.54 in the bank at the end of September and debts of $15,000. Ms. Taborsak's campaign said it had $57,000.
"It's a microcosm of the difficulty in unseating an incumbent, even in a year of discontent," said Frederick Hartwig, an important Lawlor consultant as vice president of Garin Hart Strategic Research Group. "You can't give enough speeches or ring enough doorbells. The only way to win is through the mass media. That's just flat-out expensive. If Jim Lawlor spends as much as Gary Franks, I think we'd win. Can we spend less and win? I'm not sure."
Ms. Taborsak's liberalism and environmentalism gives her a solid base, but it alienates swing and conservative voters. And Mr. Lawlor's opposition to abortion has led some of Ms. Taborsak's supporters to make Mr. Franks their second choice. A Lawlor poll of 401 likely voters taken three weeks ago showed him trailing Mr. Franks by 16 points, 41 percent to 25 percent. Ms. Taborsak had 17 percent in the survey, which had a margin of error of 4 percentage points.
Mr. Lawlor insists he is catching up. But at times he appears to lack the fire of an underdog on the move. When Donna McLean, a nurse's aide, greeted him with a friendly "Remember me?" at the dedication of a new housing complex, Mr. Lawlor stared blankly at her. "Not really," he finally said. He then excused himself to prepare for his one-minute speech. In a subsequent interview, Mrs. McLean, once a Lawlor supporter, said she now was undecided.
"People want change," said Mrs. McLean, a co-captain of the housing complex's block watch. "They're sick and tired of what's going on. People don't care who's there. But if you're there, do the job. Just do it."
In many ways, the election seems a replay of the Republican primary that rocketed Mr. Franks into the national limelight. He was one of six candidates seeking the seat vacated by John G. Rowland, when he ran unsuccessfully for governor. He finished last on the first round of balloting at the district convention. But when several opponents pushed votes his way in a frantic but miscalibrated effort to deny the nomination to more hated rivals, he emerged on the ninth ballot as the consensus second choice. In one of the most celebrated campaigns of the 1990 election, he defeated the former Democratic Representative Toby Moffett, who was attempting a political comeback.
 
Courtship of the Media
 As the first black Republican to win a voting seat in the House of Representatives since Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal lured blacks away from the party of Abraham Lincoln, Mr. Franks was catapulted into the national limelight. He was eagerly courted by the Administration and the national media as a spokesman for black conservatives. Handsome and soft spoken, he was an instant hit on television and was flatteringly profiled in major newspapers.
The attention came in part because he focused on national issues.
But at home he was earning a reputation for unreliability. He missed scheduled meetings and Connecticut residents called him "Phantom Franks," as he had been dubbed by Mr. Moffett. Leonard D'Amico, a Beacon Falls selectman and a Republican since he moved to his wife's hometown 30 years ago, said he repeatedly called and wrote Mr. Franks's office over a controversy about a planned regional post office.
"We'd set a time and date for a visit and he'd cancel," said Mr. D'Amico, who added he got better service from Democrats. "When we looked to him for help, support and service all we got was lip service. He just wasn't there."
Asked whom he was supporting for Congress this time, Mr. D'Amico declined to say.
Mr. Franks has acknowledged problems with his early performance, but blamed staff members he dismissed shortly before Christmas. But the way he conducted the dismissals -- summoning the police to supervise senior staff members clearing out their desks -- brought further criticism.
Then came a spate of embarrassing disclosures over his personal finances. He was sued for falling behind on his mortgage payments and credit-card payments. A former campaign official also sued claiming he was owed back pay. And in February, it was divulged that the brother of former Waterbury Mayor, Joseph Santopietro, who helped engineer Mr. Franks's primary victory before being indicted, was on his payroll.
Mr. Franks dismisses the criticism as the venting of political enemies and disgruntled former staffers. He says liberal Democrats, especially fellow blacks, are trying to discredit him because they fear that his philosophy and success will draw minority voters back to the Republican Party.
"If you're delivering fish every Friday, the last thing you want is to teach people how to fish -- because then you're out of business," he said. "We have a great story to tell. We're the most pro-business, pro-jobs Congressman in Connecticut. But the media only puts bad things in the paper."
